prefixDef.p: URIs using the eats prefix are references to EATS entities.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.
Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.

div.p: When work on a collection such as this one extends over so long a period of time (begun in 2004), writing acknowledgments becomes not only an extensive series of 'thank you's' for assistance given, but an archaeological dig of sorts. A generation of splendid archivists and librarians that was once there has largely retired from the scene, giving way to a new one; some archives have been given new names, affiliations and institutional expectations (even new shelf marks for many materials); and this book is being published in a form unimaginable for it when work began in 2004. Yet amongst the comings and goings of time's children, the miracle that is REED continues to thrive.

My acknowledgments must rightly begin with the two towering figures in REED's pantheon. The first is REED's legendary Founder (and now Senior Consultant), Professor Emerita Alexandra F. Johnson, who (with REED's Board) accepted me into the REED orbit as a fledgling editor in 1980, and kept a careful guiding eye during my first lengthy on-site research trip that same year. Without her there would be no REED, of course, and for me personally there would have been no career doing the work that I love.

The second is Professor Sally-Beth Maclean, Director of Research and General Editor of the REED Project, who, in 1982 became the face of REED (and many times thereafter its saviour) when Sandy took on her heavy responsibilities as Principal of Victoria College, University of Toronto, before returning to REED. On a personal note, Sally-Beth has been the guiding presence that helped bring my own three REED collections through to completion.

REED has always been characterized by its collaborative spirit and team approach to scholarship. So, thanks, and admiration, must first go to the REED editorial team for its very considerable contributions to the production of this collection: to Sally-Beth MacLean and Professor John Craig (Simon Fraser University), Chair of the REED Executive Board, for their essential advice in the shaping of the Introduction; to Tanya Hagen, Managing Editor, and Chief Editor of EMLoT (Early Modern London Theatres) for her oversight and team guidance; to Patrick Gregory, Associate Editor, Latinist, Palaeographer, Glossarian, and possessor of what could only be described as a gift for unknotting editorial and linguistic perplexities; to Illya Nokhrin, Research Associate, Lead Digital Indexer; and to Peter Greenfield (University of Puget Sound), member of the REED Executive Board, English Palaeographer for the volume, and fellow REED editor, for his selfless contributions during production. No less essential and substantive have been the contributions of four talented research assistants on the editorial team: Alexandra Atiya (Centre for Medieval Studies), Bibliographer, Latin Glossarian, and Latin Checker; Morgan Moore (Centre for Medieval Studies), Content Checker; Andrew Wiebe (Faculty of Information), Mapping and Locations Indexer; and Laina Southgate (Department of English), Assistant Indexer.

Other REED associates who deserve special thanks for their skills and contributions include Stephanie Hovland, Stuart Palmer, Matthew Payne, Alan H. Nelson, and Peter Greenfield, who variously conducted invaluable on-site checking of manuscripts and documents at The National Archives, the British Library, Oxford University, Cambridge Univerity, Norfolk Record Office, and Suffolk Record Offices at Bury St Edmunds and Ipswich. Without that crucial work, often done with deadlines looming, timely publication of the collection to REED standards would not have been possible.

Looking further afield, when I sought help in gathering names of staff to acknowledge at the three branches of the Suffolk Record Office, the senior archivist to whom I spoke declined to single them out, saying that they worked as a team and preferred to be acknowledged in that way. I can thus only offer my thanks and admiration to the great many unnamed archivists who assisted me at Suffolk Record Office Ipswich, Bury St Edmunds, and Lowestoft. But I can more properly acknowledge other persons, in Suffolk and beyond, who generously facilitated and contributed to the work on this volume. The late David Dymond, Vice-President of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History, President of Suffolk Record Society, and Vice-President of the British Association for Local History was rightly described by Mark Bailey of the Institute as ‘Suffolk’s greatest historian.’ He had a special interest in REED and enthusiastically responded to my every question, especially those having to do with the Suffolk glebe. Sue Andrews, Honorary Archivist at Hadleigh Archives and a respected local historian, made documents accessible and identified a document containing performance content that would not otherwise have made its way into the collection. Anthony Breen, Bury historian, shared useful information concerning Abbey tenements in Bury which the Sacrist had rented to secular entertainers in the town. Local historian David Lindley, of Beccles and District Museum (now retired), generously shared his considerable collection (some 23 pages) of carefully researched materials concerning the Beccles game place, which he had mined from the Rix Collection (now archived at SRO Ipswich). Catherine Howard-Dobson, Lead Curator for Aldeburgh Museum, and a Town Councillor of Aldeburgh, most generously shared her knowledge of early performance in that town. My thanks as well to Paul R. Dryburgh, Medieval Records Specialist, Advice & Records Knowledge Department of the National Archives, and Richard W. Barber, founder of The Boydell Press and a noted medieval historian, for their assistance with records of Edward the Black Prince, and the early tournament tradition in Suffolk. Finally, Northamptonshire Record Office supplied a copy and document description of a letter containing references to Christmas games written by John Chamberlain to Sir Ralph Winwood on 13 January 1609, for which I am most appreciative.

I gratefully acknowledge permissions to publish transcriptions of extracts from among their holdings that were given by numerous archives and libraries, including: the National Archives, Kew; The British Library, London; The Bodleian Library, Oxford; Cambridge University Library; Suffolk Record Office (SRO) Lowestoft; SRO Bury St. Edmunds; SRO Ipswich; Northamptonshire Record Office; University of Chicago Library, Special Collections Research Center, notably (for their splendid assistance), Julia Gardner (Head of Reader Services at the Center) and Christine Colburn for facilitating the obtaining of photographs; and, finally, The Society of Antiquaries, London, for providing access to study household account books of the Duke of Norfolk.

Finally (but incalculably significantly in their impact on the collection), I received support in the form of grants, fellowships and awards from a number of sources that enabled me to do on-site research, and to have the time and several settings in which to make the results of that research ready for publication). For all that support, I am endebted beyond measure. This patronage (to use a REED term) includes: a fellowship from the National Endowment for the Humanities; a travel grant from the American Philosophical Society; a Friends of the UW-Madison Libraries Grant-in-Aid; two UW-System fellowships, plus an additional Honorary Fellowship at the Institute for Research in the Humanities, UW-Madison; two sabbaticals from University of Wisconsin-Stevens Point (UWSP); seven research grants from UWSP; a number of recognitions from UWSP that enabled on-site research to continue; and finally, the consistent support for multi-year research by the UWSP Chair of English, the successive Deans of the UWSP College of Letters and Science, and the numerous colleagues who comprised the UWSP Personnel Development Committee. Words cannot suffice. . . .

I must always thank my teacher, mentor and true friend, the late John Wasson, Washington State University professor, and pioneering REED editor for his uniquely generous introduction to the magical world of documentary research.
Lastly (but firstly), with love, to my wife and fellow explorer Bobbie.

The county of Suffolk lies sixty miles north of London. Together with Norfolk it forms the heart of East Anglia, a region that, culturally and geographically, also includes Essex and parts of Cambridgeshire. Anciently described as 'a maritime county,' Suffolk borders the North Sea to the east. To the north, the rivers Little Ouse and the Waveney form the border between Suffolk and Norfolk; to the west, The Devil's Ditch (an ancient seven and a half mile ditch and rampart) form the border with Cambridgeshire; and to the south, the River Stour separates Suffolk from Essex.Gordon Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk (Lancaster, 2001), 1–2; David Dymond and Peter Northeast, A History of Suffolk (Chichester, 1995), 31. On its surface, Suffolk is deceptively modest and simple. As Suffolk historian Mark Bailey puts it, to the eye of a visitor, it 'might appear to be a pleasant, but undistinguished, backwater.'Mark Bailey, Medieval Suffolk (Woodbridge, 2007), 1. Even its gentle topography lacks severe extremes. Yet Suffolk has made contributions of central, national, and lasting importance at every point in English history. Even its performance traditions and its sophisticated culture are of a magnitude out of proportion to Suffolk's by-way location and its unassuming ways. The facts of Suffolk's history offer useful insights into the reasons for the richness of that performative heritage.

One key to situating Suffolk's unique cultural heritage within its immediate surroundings is to notice the interdependent relationship among Suffolk's soil regions, rivers, and transportation systems, and their contribution to the essential mobility that is a characteristic feature of early Suffolk. The first of these three topographical features, Suffolk's landscape, is composed of four regions, viewed west to east. In the far northwest lie the Fens and the Breckland, sandy soils once suitable mainly for sheep-raising and rabbit warrens. The centre two-thirds of the county, High Suffolk and Woodlands, generally the highest land in the county, is composed of boulder-clay, and occupied with agricultural production amidst substantial villages and isolated churches. The northern part of High Suffolk is flat and interfluvial (meaning that it is an area between adjacent streams that flow in the same direction, in this case, toward the east and the sea). Once dominated by hedgerows and small farms, High Suffolk now has many large, unbroken, fields. In the way that they preserve 'two millenia or more of planning and replanning, expansion and contraction, and piecemeal alteration,' the fields and minor routeways of High Suffolk are, in the words of landscape historian, Tom Williamson, 'a rich historical document' of the greatest value. In the southern part of High Suffolk, known as the Woodlands, the land is more compact and dissected by streams. The central region was particularly known for its production of butter and cheese. At Suffolk's eastern edge, stretching the entire length of the county is the coastal Sandlings, composed of alluvial soils and suitable mainly for sheep and corn.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 2–3; John Wymer, 'Surface Geology,' in David Dymond and Edward Martin (eds), An Historical Atlas of Suffolk, 3rd ed (Ipswich, 1999), 18; Edward Martin, 'Soil Regions,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 20–21; Tom Williamson, 'Ancient Landscapes,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 48–49. Suffolk's considerable dramatic records come from communities located in all four of these geographical regions.

The retreating glacial age that created Suffolk's 'gently undulating countryside' also created the county's signature river valleys. As John Wymer explains, melt-waters from the receding glaciers drained east and southeast creating the wide and shallow valleys associated with the Rivers Waveney, Deben, Gipping, and Stour. Suffolk has four other, lesser, rivers as well: Lark, Little Ouse, Blyth, and Alde, plus innumerable smaller waterways. All but two of those eight major rivers flow west to east, providing 'ready-made highways.' They and other of Suffolk's waterways had quays, jetties, rudimentary cranes, bridges, and ferries built and operated along them. Rivers and creeks emptied into the North Sea at one or another of Suffolk's seven larger ports (Aldeburgh, Dunwich, Ipswich, Lowestoft, Orford, Southwold, and Woodbridge). Using them, early Suffolk engaged in massive coastal shipping (from Newcastle to London), major commerce with the midlands, and considerable traffic with Iceland, and continental Europe. This sophisticated system of water-transport, complementing its roadways, made Suffolk 'one of the most commercialized areas in medieval England.'Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 1, 163–5, 168–9; John Wymer, 'The Shaping of Suffolk,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 14; Alistair Robertson, 'Rivers and Navigations,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 130; and Robert Malster, 'Navigation, Ports and Trade,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 132–3.

The third of these interdependent elements—Suffolk's major and minor or local road systems—offers further potential insights into the county's performance traditions. Early maps indicate one major north-south road as going from London to Chelmsford, Essex. At that point this main road diverged into two roads that both made their way through Suffolk. The first of them (a coastal branch) went from Chelmsford to Colchester (Essex) to Ipswich, Aldeburgh, and Dunwich, branching at Dunwich either to Yarmouth in Norfolk or to Norwich. The second branch went from Chelmsford, Essex, to Sudbury and Bury St Edmunds, to Thetford, Norfolk. At Thetford, this branch diverged, with one road continuing to Norwich, the other going to King's Lynn. One major east-west road travelled through early Suffolk, going from Ipswich to Bury, Newmarket and Cambridge. In four spots along this east-west road (at Creeting St Mary, Elmswell, Bury St Edmunds, and Newmarket) branches travelled south-north into Norfolk.

Based on the number of payments to players in the Suffolk records and elsewhere, these main roads from London to Suffolk, and from Suffolk into the midlands, constituted part of the most heavily travelled circuit for professional performers in the kingdom. Interestingly, the many payments to itinerant professionals in Suffolk occur only in communities on or very near these few major roads. The payments themselves occur only in the accounts of towns, religious foundations, and private households. While Suffolk's churchwardens' and religious guild accounts record exceptionally robust amateur local playing traditions in parishes, none of those parish and guild accounts (with one exception) contain payments to professional troupes (nationally). The reasons for the apparent separateness of the two traditions may partly lie in the robust nature of Suffolk's powerful market towns, parishes, and religious guilds as patrons and producers of local religious drama (see discussions below under towns, parishes, and guilds). Perhaps it is just a matter of professionals sticking to their own pre-planned circuits for their own reasons.

In addition to its main roadways, early Suffolk had a vast capillary system of local roads. The density of its population and the magnitude of its agricultural and industrial needs, together with a host of other social factors, made that network of local routes necessary. As Mark Bailey has observed, various kinds of evidence serve to confirm the presence and importance of these local roads. Among those sources are: the considerable expenditures for bridges in financial records; the many charitable bequests for the upkeep of roads in wills; the regulation of specific local roads by courts; the ubiquitous presence of two-wheeled carts used on roads to carry grain, wines, herring, and other goods and produce; the movement of livestock; the manorial renting of horses and carts to conduct business in ways involving travel; the great number of cart horses recorded; and manorial records.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 166–8 and nn 18–21.

One form of evidence that has not been considered in the study of local roads is the local playing circuits that are characteristic of Suffolk. Records show that each of Suffolk's topographical regions had local playing circuits in which various forms of inter-parish support involving travel existed among a great number of parishes. Communities travelled to announce their plays; people from other parishes travelled to attend those plays; communities loaned theatrical gear, costumes, and scripts to other communities; neighbouring communities exchanged customary traditions. Some communities cooperated in the production of a shared play. Boxford's churchwardens' accounts give the names of twenty-eight communities who in one year contributed support for Boxford's play. A map of the required roads in that instance would look as interlaced as a spider's web. The intricate number of possible reasons why small communities cooperated in their production of local religious drama is yet to be fully resolved, but the evidence clearly shows that interparish cooperation involved mobility and that the mobility would have required many more local roads than are shown on contemporary maps.

Because of Suffolk's navigable rivers, many roads, and negotiable regions, its early borders were not barriers so much as doors, in a manner of speaking, opening the way to and from London, the midlands, the eastern coast of England, Iceland and the countries of the continent, most notably the low countries.

Those three features, among others, have always attracted a large population to Suffolk. Using archaeological, financial, and manorial documents, David Dymond and Peter Northeast estimate Suffolk's population as being 72,000 in 1066. The two most informed and recent estimates by professional medieval historians independently estimate the population c 1340 as being around 225,000.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 42–3; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 291, and B.M.S. Campbell and Lorraine Barry, ‘The Population Geography of Great Britain c.1290,’ in C. Briggs, P.M. Kitson, and S.J. Thompson, (eds), Population, Welfare and Economic Change in Britain 1290-1834 (Woodbridge, 2014), p 57. By 1327 Suffolk was 'one of the most densely populated, intensively farmed and economically advanced counties of England,' with an ever-growing population. However, in the mid-fourteenth century the Black Death is estimated to have killed between half and two-thirds of Suffolk's population. Three hundred years later the population had not yet returned to pre-plague numbers.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 42–3; Hilary Todd and David Dymond, 'Population Densities, 1327 and 1524,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 80. Citing the research of John Patten, Gordon Blackwood estimates Suffolk's population as being 90,000 in 1520, 108,000 in 1603, and 125,000 in 1670. He lists seventeen Suffolk towns having at least 1,000 inhabitants at some point between 1524 and 1670. All but two doubled their population between 1524 and 1670, with the number of urban dwellers in Suffolk rising from fifteen to twenty-seven percent during those years.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 4–6, 265–6 nn 21–34. All but one of those seventeen towns (Halesworth) left dramatic records, but all the seventy-six other Suffolk communities that left dramatic records had populations much smaller than those seventeen towns. There appears to be no necessary correlation between size of population and amount of dramatic activity. Ipswich, for example, had a population roughly comparable to that of Bury St Edmunds during much of the sixteenth century, yet it has left a greater volume of dramatic records. Walsham-le-Willows had a population comparable to a number of its neighbouring villages, yet it had a dedicated outdoor playing space where plays were certainly staged, while those other communities apparently did not. In relation to the presence of performance in early Suffolk, other factors seem more significant than size of population.

The years between 1360 and 1530 brought great prosperity to Suffolk, mainly from four principal sources: the cloth trade, agriculture, fishing, and the proceeds from continental warfare.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 55. During this period, 'the cloth industry reached a major peak of prosperity, and especially so in the main broadcloth area of South Suffolk,' centred in the hundreds of Babergh and Cosford. With it came huge wealth, plentiful employment in the cloth trade, a new class of capitalists, and a surge in local pride and patronage that led to the building or refurbishment or re-building of magnificent parish churches and 'fine timber-framed houses,' both in the cloth-making regions, along the Suffolk coast, and in the central dairying regions.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 51–2, 53. The prosperous years coincide with references to locally-sponsored performance and ceremony, and fund raising in religious guild and parish records. Documents show considerable ownership of local religious responsibility by the craftsmen and craftswomen, capitalists, and merchants in Suffolk's ever-more-prosperous towns on the eve of the Reformation.

Much of this relative peace, prosperity, and unanimity was swept away in the tumult of the sixteenth century. Four principal and interrelated kinds of stresses repeatedly bludgeoned the county during that century and the first half of the next. The economic stresses are easy enough to summarize. Most catastrophic was the decline of the cloth trade caused by the collapsing demand for Suffolk dyed cloth in Europe, together with the clothiers' wide-spread failure to adjust to changing fashions; together with the increasing control of Suffolk’s coastal and overseas trade by London merchants, especially from the mid-fifteenth century. Other economic factors included the imposition of export restrictions, funding needs for the war with Spain, and the rise of venture capitalists (such as the Merchant Adventurers), who competed for investment monies. Further, a rising urban population with its attendant need for food caused a boom in agriculture; but while food costs rose, wages declined. Decreasing demand for fish damaged the fishing trades; encroachment by the sea and silting damaged ports and harbours; and piracy increased. These economic hardships brought with them an explosive atmosphere of civil unrest, seen most notably in the outbreaks of 1549 and 1569.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 65–8.

div.head: Religious History
div.p: The county of Suffolk became part of the southern province of the archbishop of Canterbury in the seventh century. From 1094 through 1836 all of Suffolk (excepting the three episcopal peculiars of Moulton, Hadleigh, and Monk's Eleigh) was part of the diocese of Norwich. From 1125 on, under the bishop of that diocese, Suffolk had two archdeaconries (the archdeaconry of Sudbury for West Suffolk, and the archdeaconry of Suffolk for East Suffolk). Those two archdeaconries bore administrative and disciplinary responsibility for the county's twenty-three rural deaneries (similar to the hundreds in their boundaries and names), whose rural deans in turn oversaw the clergy, the churches, and the other properties of 501 parishes (many dating, in origin and dimensions, from the late Anglo-Saxon period). The great East Anglian historian Norman Scarfe has shown that 418 of Suffolk's many parish churches were already founded by 1086, and he has identified at least thirty-two certain or likely minsters (central churches with teams of priests serving several parishes) from that early period, in patterns violently disrupted (especially in northeast Suffolk) by the Danish invasions. Significantly, according to Scarfe, 'the distribution of [[these early]] minsters seems to be related to the principal rivers, with strings [[of minsters]] lining the Waveney, Gipping and Stour valleys,' and to their connection 'with important royal or ecclesiastical manors.' The great new personal and civic wealth that came to Suffolk via commerce in the late medieval period led directly to the reconstruction of many of these parish churches. Cumulatively, they became one of the architectural glories of the county.Joanna Martin, 'Ecclesiastical Jurisdictions,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 24–5; and Norman Scarfe, 'Domesday Churches, in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 52–3.

Suffolk's many religious foundations (its abbey, colleges, friaries, nunneries, priories, and small cells) formed another major presence in the spiritual, economic, and cultural life of the county. At the time of the dissolution, Suffolk had forty functioning religious foundations (down from the sixty-plus listed by Knowles and the seventy-four listed by Cox). They represented nine religious orders, plus the Knights Templars, the Knights Hospitalers, and the Premonstratensian Canons. Collectively, these foundations possessed some 200 manors. The greater number of these religious foundations lay in East Suffolk. Far fewer of them lay in West Suffolk, a fact apparently reflecting the dominant presence there of the abbey of Bury St Edmunds, one of the largest, wealthiest, and most revered abbeys and sites of pilgrimage in England. Peter Northeast, 'Religious Houses,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlasp 70–1; David Knowles and R.N. Hancock, Medieval Religious Houses: England and Wales (London, 1971); and J.C. Cox, 'Religious Houses,' VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, pp 53–156, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 5 February 2025].

Religious foundations in Suffolk ranged in size from fifty to eighty monks at Bury St Edmunds, to two monks constituting the entire membership in each of several tiny foundations. The greatest number of houses were the Augustinians, the numerous hospitals, and the secular colleges, although in general friaries attracted a greater number of inhabitants than did monasteries and nunneries. Religious houses held authority over many of Suffolk's parishes. Although they were major landlords in the county, religious houses often rented their manorial properties and lands to others, thereby enriching glebes and properties in many of Suffolk parishes, although the religious houses reserved to themselves much of the wealth deriving from those properties. Peter Northeast, 'Religious Houses,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 70–1. Many of these religious manorial lands included parcels that became (or already were) the camping closes or outdoor recreational sites that became a distinguishing feature of the Suffolk landscape (see, for example, the game place at Beccles).

div.head: Guilds
div.p: Religious guilds were a vital feature in pre-Reformation Suffolk's social, administrative, and religious history. The existence of some 500 religious guilds based on local parish churches has been confirmed in the county, and the presence of numerous others can be inferred from wills, accounts, tax rolls, and other forms of evidence. The guilds, however, were not evenly distributed throughout the county. Northeast has shown that while the majority of parishes in both the west and northeast parts of Suffolk had one or more religious guilds, most parishes in southeast Suffolk were served by three very large, 'centrally-placed,' guilds (at Framlingham, Kelsale, and Woodbridge), and a very few others, a situation perhaps influenced by the powerful manorial presence of the Duke of Norfolk.Northeast, 'Parish Gilds,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 74.

An exponential rise in the number of religious guilds in Suffolk occurred in the aftermath of the Black Death of 1348–9. Guilds provided the 'communal response' to the religious and social needs that had been lost in the near obliteration of families and parishes. At the same time the rise of religious guilds reflected the growing affluence and economic power of the laity, most visible in the number of surviving guildhalls that remain one of Suffolk's architectural glories. The roles and contributions of the religious guilds are a matter of some complexity. In addition to religious and social services, in some places guilds became what Northeast calls 'civic guilds,' functioning as governing bodies. In the fourteenth century Ipswich renamed its gild merchant as the guild of Corpus Christi; in Bury the gild merchant became the Candlemas guild. Northeast, 'Parish Gilds,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 74; and Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 250, 140-141. The magnitude of the contributions of these religious guilds to local drama, custom, and ceremony in pre-Reformation Suffolk cannot be overstated. Together with parishes, they were the chief patrons of vernacular religious drama, custom, and ceremony.

Craft guilds, on the other hand, are rare in early Suffolk, and it is not clear whether those existing thought of themselves as guilds in the same way that we do. No craft guilds existed in rural areas, but they do appear in Bury and Ipswich. Bury had three known craft entities (the Weavers, Bakers, and Cordwainers). The Bakers' guild dated from the late twelfth century. The regulations of the Weavers (the only craft regulations to survive for Bury) don't use the word guild (the regulations refer to groups of craftsmen repeatedly as 'the Ocupiers of the seyd Crafte'). The Weavers bore responsibility for an Ascension pageant, one of several in the annual procession; however an entity other than the Weavers (likely the Candlemas guild) had authority over the procession. That is, the craft guild subordinated itself to the principal religious guild in matters of performance. The same principle applied in Ipswich (see the discussion of its Corpus Christi celebration below).

div.head: Public Administration
div.p: The system of public administration had very ancient roots in Suffolk. From at least the late Anglo-Saxon period forward, the basis of public administration in Suffolk was the hundred, an area thought either to represent 'a hundred hides or family holdings' or 'even older land units.' The hundreds were 'the basis of all public administration in medieval England, judicial, fiscal and military,' superseded only by the county court. Edward Martin, 'Hundreds and Liberties,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 26–7. Much of the information here provided concerning public administration in Suffolk is informed by Martin. In 1086 the county had twenty-five hundreds of various size; however, the number changed several times in subsequent centuries. A hundred bailiff presided over the hundred (or moot) courts. Originally nearly all-powerful, during the course of the medieval period the hundred courts gradually lost a good part of their authority to the rise of royal justice, the quarter sessions courts, municipal courts, and a sheriff from 1576 on.

Several other kinds of administrative entities existed alongside or superimposed across the authority of the hundreds. They included: the boroughs of Ipswich, Bury, and Sudbury (which were separate hundreds); the liberties of St Ethelreda Abbey at Ely and St Edmund Abbey at Bury (areas within which the crown had effectively privatized the functions and profits of the hundreds within the liberties of the two abbeys, answerable not to the sheriff or borough but to the lord); the north and south capitals of the geldable (a taxable unit under royal jurisdiction), at Beccles and Ipswich respectively; and several feudal liberties, including the honours (areas in which the lord had certain additional rights based on the number of manors which he held in Suffolk and elsewhere) of Clare, Eye, and Haughley, the manors of the duke of Norfolk, and the southern seat of the bishop of Norwich at Elmham. In the historical period covered by this edition, Suffolk returned sixteen members to parliaments: two knights of the shire, and two members each from its seven parliamentry boroughs: Dunwich and Ipswich (from 1298), Orford (regularly from 1529), Sudbury (from 1558), Aldeburgh and Eye (from 1571), and Bury St Edmunds (from 1621). Martin, ‘Hundreds and Liberties,’ in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 26-27; Gwyn Thomas, 'Parliamentary Constituencies,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 30–1.

div.head: Education
div.p: Writing in 1907, A.F. Leach offered several acute observations about education in early Suffolk. The unusually high proliferation of medieval grammar schools in Suffolk appears to reflect the county's early wealth, widespread commercial activity, and density of population. Many of those early schools, as Leach notes, far predate foundations by Edward VI and Elizabeth I. Even many of the schools founded in 1548 were actually re-foundings of much earlier schools. Most notably, at odds with the common view that early education sprang from the monasteries, early schools in Suffolk are 'found in connexion [sic] with the secular clergy, not the monks.' Even at the first known school in Bury, though he was appointed by the abbot, the master was a clerk, not a monk, and the school's students were not novices. That is, this earliest of Bury's schools was the public school of the town.VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, pp 301–2, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025]. Having a school, it appears, became a sought-after part of emerging civic identity for towns, a pattern also appearing to reflect the perpetual tension between religious authority and secular expression so characteristic of early Suffolk, and particularly strong in Bury.

Leach identifies fifty-six schools: fourteen of them grammar schools established before the reign Edward VI, another sixteen petty schools founded during the later sixteenth and seventeenth centuries, and twenty-six of them elementary schools (six established before 1642; twenty of them after). The grammar school at Dunwich was the oldest school of its kind in England. Other grammar schools established well before 1548 included those at Beccles, Boxford, Bury, Clare, Eye, Hadleigh, Ipswich, Long Melford, Lowestoft, Stoke-by-Clare, Stowmarket and Sudbury. Elizabethan schools included those at Botesdale, Bungay, Palgrave, and Woodbridge. Jacobean and Caroline grammar schools included those at Aldeburgh, Brandon, Debenham, Framlingham, Gislingham, Lavenham, Little Thurlow, Mendlesham, Needham Market, and Stonham Aspall.VCH: Suffolk, pp 301–56, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025].

On the other hand, visitation records show that many of Suffolk's religious houses had to be directed by authorities to provide grammar school and singing masters for their novices at a time when towns were purposefully creating them. The lack of drive within religious houses to maintain their schools is puzzling. J.C. Cox identifies eight functioning, lapsed or inferable song-schools at: the colleges of Clare, Mettingham, Stoke-by-Clare, Sudbury and Wingfield; at Woolsey's ill-fated Cardinal's College at Ipswich; and at Bury Abbey, and Butley Priory. He also describes eight monastic grammar schools (some of them combined with song-schools) at the abbey of Bury St Edmunds, Hoxne Priory, Butley Priory (the latter of which had boarding scholars and one scholar sent to university); at Ipswich Priory of St Peter and Paul; at Cardinal's College in Ipswich; and at Mettingham College. Hoxne Priory appears to be nearly unique among Suffolk's religious foundations in that it 'kept a school [specifically] for the children of the parish, as opposed to novices.'VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, p 301, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025]; VCH: Suffolk, pp 76–8, 97–8, 102, 110, 130–1, 139, 142, 144–6, and 150–1, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025].

div.head: Religion and Society
div.p: Before the Reformation, the people of Suffolk shared a common theology. But pre-Reformation Christianity in Suffolk also reflected the social, political, and economic stresses afflicting Suffolk during the medieval period. Endless power struggles in the county (among towns, religious foundations, the Crown, knights and other lords, and the Papacy) together with catastrophic natural events, helped make protest, resistance, and periodic upheaval in matters of society and religion a distinctive and permanent feature of the Suffolk character. Three seismically important factors in particular brought fundamental change to society and religion in Suffolk, and turned the county into ripe ground for the sixteenth-century Reformation.

Most devastating among them was the Black Death, which first struck the country in 1348. When it descended on Suffolk in 1349, the Black Death killed nearly half of the population. While the effects of the Black Death were unimaginably dire, historians Dymond and Northeast offer a corrective to the widely held view that the abandonment of buildings, the decline in rural population, and the leaving of lands untilled that occurred during the fourteenth century were mainly caused by the Black Death. In fact, after 1349 many heirs re-claimed the homes of family members who had fallen victim to the outbreak. Nor, they say, is it correct to refer to the many isolated churches in Suffolk as 'plague churches' of 1349 when, in fact, the Black Death merely advanced a process that was already occuring. Rather, it was later recurring outbreaks of the plague in the late fourteenth and fifteenth centuries that left 'vacant buildings and shrunken villages.' Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 47–51. More significantly, the Black Death left two-thirds of the county's parish priests dead. The loss of so many priests in 1349 crippled the ability of many parishes to conduct their traditional pastoral duties. In the vacuum, much care-giving work fell to the religious guilds in towns and villages. The men and women of those guilds (both sexes equally enfranchised by guild statutes), assumed many pastoral responsibilities (other than religious services), assisting the depleted clergy in providing traditional services such as chistenings, marriages and funerals. Practical piety moved increasingly into the hands of the laity via its guilds, whose powerful influence continued unabated until the abolition of the guilds under Edward VI. For important studies on the increase in ‘religious consumption’ by the laity and the lower orders during this period, see Judith Middleton Stewart, Inward Piety, Outward Splendour: Death and Remembrance in the Deanery of Dunwich, Suffolk, 1370-1547 (Cambridge, 2001); and Joanne Sear, ‘Benefitting the Soul: Religious Consumption in the Late Middle Ages,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History, 45.3 (2023), 439–59. This guild-driven popular religion in post-Black Death Suffolk also served to water the seeds of a growing discontent directed at all-powerful ecclesiastical authority. Many of the religious plays sponsored by parishes (for example, the Brome Abraham and Isaac), not only spoke to the oceans of grief engulfing parishioners in Suffolk manors, towns and villages, many also contained implicit critiques of higher authority, both religious and secular.

Two subsequent movements—one economic and political, one theological—further illustrate the fraught relationship between religion and society in medieval Suffolk. The county-wide insurrection in 1381 known as the Peasants' Revolt ushered in a decade of rebellion that plunged Suffolk into 'a state of reformist ferment.' John Rigard, ‘The Uprising of 1381,’ in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 90–1; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 184–93; Joe Chick, ‘The 1381 Rising in Bury St Edmunds: the Role of Leaders and the Community in Shaping the Rebellion,’ Pons Aelius, 13 (2016), pp 35–47, and ‘Leaders and Rebels: John Wrawe’s role in the Suffolk rising of 1381,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History, 44.2 (2018), pp 214–34. As Ridgard describes it, rebels had purposely chosen the eight days that began the rebellion (12–18 June 1381) to coincide with the feast of Corpus Christi, a time when people characteristically assembled for plays and ceremonies and processions. In fact, in Bury the rebellion included a theatrically conceived crowning of a king of Suffolk from among the rebels, and a conversation between the decapitated heads of the chief justice of England and the prior of the abbey at Bury, as well as other dramatic acts of public spectacle. The insurrection spread throughout the county, and the identified rebels numbered at least 2,000 (including seventy women). The rebels' main objective was to seize legal, fiscal and manorial records (especially those of religious houses), since they included the names of villeins, and to destroy them in public burnings. The rebels' chief targets were establishment lawyers, tax collectors, and church leaders, whereas the rebel leaders themselves included 'lowly paid clergy.' The revolt was far from an isolated event. It followed centuries of periodically violent outbursts of grievance by nearly every segment of a Suffolk population long existing at the economic mercy of the ruling classes, as occurred at Bury St Edmunds. It would be followed by successive rebellions in the county. The rebellion of 1381 also reflected the rising importance of market towns that were effectively functioning as boroughs in all but name and charter, and a growing number of freemen farmers and husbandmen who built large agricultural holdings and leased many manorial demesnes in the century after the Black Death.

The Lollard movement of the late fourteenth and early fifteenth century found equally fertile ground in Suffolk. The name Lollardy attached itself to a religious movement arising from the reformist prescriptions of Oxford theologian John Wycliffe (d. 1384), and his followers, originally known as Wycliffites. To a surprising degree, Wycliffe's teachings mirrored those that would later recur as foundational in the Reformation. Among their precepts were opposition to: the transubstantiation, confession, baptism, iconography, veneration of saints, oaths, fasting, prayers for the dead, pilgrimages, and ecclesiastical celibacy. That is, they were 'antisacramental and antisacerdotal.' Maureen Jurkowski, 'Lollardy and Social Status,' Speculum 82.1 (January 2007), 123. Maureen Jurkowski has shown that the majority of East Anglia's Lollards lived in east Suffolk and Norfolk in an area radiating nothward and southward from the Waveney Valley in or near thirty-eight small market towns and villages, plus several towns associated with the cloth market in central and south Suffolk. While adherents in East Anglia included artisans and tradesmen, most recorded Lollards, according to Jurkowski, were prosperous farmers and rural husbandmen who lived in small communities that were 'largely self-governing' and 'ruled largely by village elites and manorial officials.' East Anglian Lollardy 'was a faith that suited the aspirations of village elites and a nascent class of prosperous yeomen.'Jurkowski, 'Lollardy and Social Status,' pp 123–4, 150–4. Edwin Welch sees a strong connection between nonconformity and the 'early form of industrialization' prevalent in East Anglia that gave Lollardy a particularly strong appeal there. As he observes, many of the politically-driven rebel leaders in 1381 shared surnames with the theologically-driven leaders of the Lollard movement. Edwin Welch, 'Some Suffolk Lollards,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and Natural History 29, pt 2 (1962), 154.

Lollardy, as a movement, was short-lived. It was declared a heresy in 1382 and, although the movement opposed the Peasants' Revolt, Lollards were persecuted as traitors. The rebellion of Sir John Oldcastle in 1414 caused Lollardy to become connected to treason, and the movement, as a force, was gone by 1431.Welch, 'Suffolk Lollards,' p 154. However, its influence lingered into the sixteenth century in Suffolk. As Diarmaid MacCulloch observes, '[p]opular Protestantism could draw on the Lollard tradition preserved in the sixteenth century, particularly in such communities as Stoke by Nayland and Mendlesham.'Diarmaid MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors: Politics and Religion in an English County 1500–1600 (Oxford, 1986), 317. Lollards had a strong sense of community; they established schools and they used itinerant preachers—all features that would be central to the propagation of the Protestant faith in the sixteenth century. Just as in the sixteenth century, fairs, markets, and the Feast of Corpus Christi provided moments when people gathered in great numbers, an opportunity seized upon by both nonconformist dramatists and organizers, and which were greatly feared by the authorities.

Much of the period between the 1360s and 1530 saw great economic growth and accompanying wealth in Suffolk. Although the period from 1370 to 1520 saw major shifts within Suffolk’s agriculture from arable to livestock, and in its economy from agriculture to manufacturing and retail, which made the fortunes of some and increased wealth per head for the vast majority, the slump in the textile industry in the early sixteenth century brought severe economic decline to the county and great hardship to its population. Those economic difficulties were as nothing compared to the century of religious upheaval caused by the Reformation that was to come. As Christopher Haigh and Patrick Collinson have pointed out, the so-called Reformation was actually four successive state-imposed reformations (Henrician, Edwardian, Marian, and Elizabethan) and a 'parallel evangelical Reformation' which, together with many other forces, set church, state, and people at various ends with each other in events that played out uniquely in every county, town, and hamlet of the land. Christopher Haigh, English Reformations: Religion, Politics, and Society under the Tudors (Oxford, 1993), p 14; Patrick Collinson, The Birthpangs of Protestant England (London, 1988). As Alec Ryrie has shrewdly observed, describing the Reformation 'is governed by what you think is important and what is trivial, by whether there are heroes or villains you want to celebrate or condemn, and by the legacies and lessons which you think matter.' Alec Ryrie, The English Reformation: A Very Brief History (London, 2020), p xiv. In Suffolk, the mosaic of reformation was as complex as the social traditions, the structures of local power and governance, and the economic stresses that drove each community (see the section on towns and villages below). That complexity has been richly documented by John Craig, Diarmaid McCulloch, Patrick Collinson, and others. See Craig, Reformation, Politics and Polemics: The Growth of Protestantism in East Anglian Market Towns, 1500–1610, St Andrews Studies in Reformation History (London, 2001); MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors; Haigh, English Reformations; and Collinson, Birthpangs.

The extent to which the Reformation of Henry VIII was essentially religious or political is a matter of perpetual debate among historians. Ryrie has compellingly made the case that 'the organizing principle, the doctrine' of Henry's religion was the royal supremacy rather than theology, his political objectives creating 'theological incoherence.'Ryrie, 'Divine Kingship and Royal Theology in Henry VIII's Reformation,' Reformation 7.1 (2002), 54, 77. Successive royal decrees concerning religion, while seeming reformist, certainly also had the effect of asserting the monarch's power while diminishing that of the Pontiff in Rome. In 1534 the Act of Supremacy acknowledged Henry as head of the Church of England; abolished 'Peter's Pence' (annual payments that each parish had been required to make to Rome); and reduced the number of church holidays from ninety to thirty.

In 1536 in Suffolk, Henry closed the lesser abbey at Sibton, and the nunneries at Bungay and Campsey, and between 1537 and 1540 he closed the remaining twenty-eight larger houses in Suffolk. The effect cannot be overstated. As Page observes, ‘[p]robably no other county felt the change more keenly from a social and economic standpoint than was the case with Suffolk.’ The dissolution left 273 monks, canons, and nuns without a home or a mission. The county immediately lost many of its priest-schoolmasters; alms giving stopped at the entrances to religious houses, and tithing in 150 parishes passed from monastic lords to civilian lords collectively more interested in collecting money than in parcelling it out to the needy. The dissolution ‘involved the largest confiscation and redistribution of land and property since the Norman Conquest.'VCH: Suffolk, vol 2 (London, 1907), 28; and Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 82–8. Initially most of the monastic booty went (by sale, grant, exchange, or some combination thereof) to the county’s two great magnates (Charles Brandon and Thomas Howard, the dukes of Suffolk and Norfolk respectively), and eventually to five groups of individuals who became the county’s new ruling elite. They included five noblemen, the non-monastic Church, two local lawyers, a few important merchants, numerous royal officials, and three high-ranking officials who worked for Brandon or Howard. Half of the beneficiaries were Suffolk gentry, and they included both Catholics and Protestants.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 83–9, 310–317; and MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, pp 53–83. The foundational change in Suffolk brought by the dissolution was permanent.

Concerning religious practice nationwide, royal injunctions forbade placing candles before images, along with other 'superstitious' practices; ordered the destruction of images; forbade visible veneration of Thomas à Becket; ordered that every church have an English Bible; and with a royal decree on 22 July 1541, abolished the ceremony of the boy bishop. Because the boy bishop symbolically replaced the actual ruler with the ruled, Henry saw it as ‘"unlawful superstition", a dangerous inversion of the God-given social order and thus perhaps a form of indirect treason.’Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 60–1; and Ryrie, 'Divine Kingship,' p 71. Since most mimetic customs used similar inversions (Robin Hood, Christmas Lords, May Ladies, etc) the decree implicitly represented a serious potential threat to the survival of traditional customs in general. In December 1545, near the end of Henry’s reign and spurred by his requests, parliament passed an act that 'empowered the King, if he wished, to dissolve any chantries, colleges, hospitals or guilds' and seize their endowments; however, he did not actually exercise that power.Peter Marshall, Heretics and Believers: A History of the English Reformation(New Haven, CT, 2017), 294. See also Alan Kreider, English Chantries: The Road to Dissolution (Cambridge, MA, 1979), pp 165–85. The Chantries Act of his successor, Edward VI, would carry out the actual dissolutions and seizures of goods presaged by his father.

Dramatic as were the changes by Henry, traditional parish life and customs in Suffolk, as elsewhere, appear largely to have remained constant. For more on the effects of Henry VIII’s Chantries Act, see Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 60–1. At the same time, religious conflict between Suffolk's evangelicals and conservatives erupted in the 1530s, most dramatically in Hadleigh and Ipswich, but in other towns and parts of the countryside as well. While most clergy remained conservative, evangelical preachers from Cambridge and merchants and other travellers returning from the Low Countries brought protestant fervour to Suffolk. The diversity of views within the great households of Suffolk was no less inflammable. During these years, the first wave of the county's martyrs occurred in the religious tinder box that Suffolk had become during Henry's reign. For meticulous descriptions of the Henrician Reformation in Suffolk, see MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, particularly part 2; Craig, Reformation, notably Chapter 6 on Hadleigh; Haigh, English Reformations; and Collinson, Birthpangs.

Following the death of Henry VIII in 1547, the short reign of Edward VI (1547–53) brought sudden, massive, and foundational religious change to England. In what Ryrie describes as ‘an internal coup,' justification by faith only became (as Marshall says) ‘the centre of the teaching mission of the English Church,' replacing the doctrine that souls could also be redeemed by penitential suffering, good works, intercession and participation in ritualized communal worship. Marshall, Heretics, pp 307–8. Much of the description that follows is indebted to Marshall, pp 302–27. In condemning those traditional practices as 'papistical superstitions,’ it abandoned the related concepts of Purgatory, Confession, and the Eucharist.

The new government undertook its reformist campaign with lightning speed, the autumn of 1547 bringing what Peter Marshall calls 'a festival of destruction' in churches. Specifically, in 1547 royal injunctions reaffirmed the Henrican proscription of shrines and processions. Injunctions also ordered: change of the liturgy; replacement of the old Latin service with an English service; the replacement of wall paintings with texts from scripture; the destruction of objects retained from pilgrimages; the use of an English book of common prayer (except in college chapels and grammar schools, which might still use Latin); the removal of candles and incense before images; and the destruction in churches of statues, including roods. One of their first actions, the Chantries Act of 6 December 1547, was nothing less than 'a second dissolution' in its financial and cultural impact. Marshall, Heretics, p 310; Ryrie, English Reformation, pp 24–25. Of grave significance to parish life, it abolished all chantries and parish religious guilds or confraternities, which had provided sponsorship and infrastructure for the production of fund-raising religious drama and games as a form of lay religious practice.

The imposed changes continued unabated. In 1548 the regime abolished the use of ashes, palms, and candles on, respectively, Ash Wednesday, Palm Sunday and the Feast of the Purification of the Virgin. It banned the use of holy bread and holy water, as well as the ceremony of creeping to the cross on Good Friday, and it suppressed the ringing of knells. Further, it imposed a 'blanket ban on church imagery,' made confession optional, and authorized the sale of chantry lands. In short, its actions caused a 'huge local disruption' to the 'financial and devotional life' of parishes, replacing lay piety with spiritual rhetoric fed by an extraordinary proliferation of evangelical presses. In 1549 it changed the language of the liturgy into an English book of common prayer, while abolishing the feast of Corpus Christi and many other important feasts.

As had always happened in Suffolk, the shape and intensity of responses to religious change in the county reflected the complicated character of the county. As MacCulloch puts it, the Suffolk character combined 'conventional commitment to Catholic piety’ (most strikingly seen in the grand churches of its cloth towns) with 'a tendency towards independence of mind and an interest in dissident ideas' (reflecting the wealth and mobility of labour in the cloth towns).MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, p 176. Surviving parish and civic records show that on the eve of the Reformation, Suffolk parishes were thriving Catholic communities, immersed in the pietistic and festive rituals, ceremonies and entertainments associated with traditional communal town and village life, activities seen as good and godly service.

Sophisticated fund-raising drama and games, in particular, flourished. Yet beginning in the early 1530s Reformation ideologies took root in Suffolk parishes with extraordinary speed. The reasons defy facile generalizations, but as MacCulloch fairly says: 'What would matter in the East Anglian parishes would be the combination of the new ideas from Germany with the existing obscure undercurrents of dissent in the parishes.' He cites several possible factors: encounters of Suffolk's merchants with Lutheranism in their continental dealings; a continuity between the resistance mentality of Lollardism (as it survived in Suffolk) and the congruent ideas of Protestantism; and the rapid spread of new ideas facilitated by the travels of the new Protestant preachers. Diarmaid MacCulloch, 'The Impact of the Reformation on Suffolk Parish Life,' The Suffolk Review 15 (Autumn 1990), 4–6. One might also note the persistent resentment against rents and other taxes levied by the Church, and the independent-mindedness of town bodies that had become essentially self-governing in the face of absentee landlords.

The revolutionary change thus begun effected 'a mammoth effort of realignment of parish life which dwarfed the hesitant beginnings of change' by the earlier monarchs.MacCulloch, 'Impact,' p 11. It shifted the centre of communal religious life from the parish church to a preaching clergy and sometimes interminable sermons. MacCulloch, 'Impact,' pp 14–16. The movement swept away most fund-raising customs, rituals and drama. Above all, this evangelizing reformation enforced the creation of new ways of being—religiously, socially, and politically—everywhere in the kingdom, changing the very definition of community.

While the massive religious and social changes imposed by reformists fractured communal harmony in many parishes (as evidence from court records most vividly testifies), Christopher Marsh has shown that while the Reformation brought community-destroying conflict, the period experienced a different process in many parishes as well. He describes a complex, as yet imperfectly understood, evolution in which the great number of parishioners forged the social and spiritual continuities that they would hope for were they to live in a peaceful community. They did so by adhering to authority, by finding sufficiently acceptable continuities between the liturgy of the traditional religion and that of the newly imposed one, and by maintaining at least transactional harmony through neighbourliness and charity. The success with which a given community might bridge the seemingly insurmountable contradictions of the age, as Marsh shows, was largely determined by unique societal factors within each individual parish, and by their skillfull application of the new religious dicta. Christopher Marsh, Popular Religion in Sixteen–Century England (New York, 1998), especially 197–219.

Predictably, this massive assault on traditional religious culture brought waves of bloody protest throughout the kingdom. The Western Rebellion, begun in Cornwall in 1547, expanded to Devon in 1548. Protests ignited across the kingdom in the summer of 1549 with rioting, looting, assaults on landlords, encampments, and petitions to the Crown.Ryrie, English Reformation, pp 26–7; Anthony Fletcher and Diarmaid MacCulloch, Tudor Rebellions, 6th ed (London, 2016), 44–50. Kett's Rebellion—by far the worst of the violence, and the most threatening to the established order—occurred in Norfolk in that summer, eventually embroiling thousands on both sides. Andy Wood, The 1549 Rebellions and the Making of Early Modern England (Cambridge, 2007), 55–69. Kett's Rebellion began at a play about St Thomas à Becket in Wymondham, spread to Yarmouth and other Norfolk towns, and centred finally at a huge rebel encampment on the outskirts of Norwich where many hundreds would die. It spread as well into Suffolk towns, most notably Bury St Edmunds and Ipswich. While the cause of rebellion in the Western counties was strongly theological, Kett’s Rebellion was principally fuelled by anger at rapacious economic policies imposed by both by the Crown and wealthy local landlords. Fletcher and MacCulloch, Tudor Rebellions, pp 68–75.

When the Edwardian whirlwind ended with Edward's illness and death in 1553, his Catholic sister, Mary, moved to reinstate (as official policy) much of the cultural and religious traditionalism that Edward's regime had sought to destroy. However, her five-year reign brought not a sudden and simple obverse Catholic image of Edward's seven-year Protestant rule, but a fraught chain of events. She needed first to secure her throne, which she did at the beginning of her reign with great daring and with what turned out to be massive support from leaders in the eastern parts of Suffolk.Marshall, Heretics, pp 358–9. While Suffolk had become a solidly Protestant county by the mid-sixteenth century, the Catholic families of Suffolk were primarily responsible for Mary's ability to evade capture, seize power, and secure the throne. MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, pp 79–80.

Although her throne was securely established, she faced complexity in matters of religious practice that could have led to civil war at the very beginning of her reign. In August 1553 she moved quickly to restore traditional Catholic liturgy, ritual, and music (and followed it herself), yet she also allowed the funeral of Edward VI to be performed by bishop Gardiner in Westminster Cathedral, on 8 August, using the 1552 Prayer Book (although she subsequently also ordered Gardiner to celebrate a requiem for Edward, together with a general public claim that the new state had accepted Catholic orthodoxy as an act of conscience not the imposition of Catholicism on the nation). It was, as Marshall puts it, 'England's first declaration of formal religious toleration, albeit an explicitly temporary [and tactical] one.’Marshall, Heretics, p 363. It mainly served to sow confusion and political hesitancy on both sides. Beneath this stable-appearing surface stirred thorny issues. What precisely would be the future relationship between the Papacy and the English church and state? Would the wealthy gentry be required to return monastic lands and wealth? Would the new queen undertake a dynastic marriage? Marshall, Heretics, pp 365–8.

These controversies culminated in January–February 1553/4, when Mary faced the most dangerous rebellion of her reign, saving her throne by the sheer bravura of her response.Marshall, Heretics, pp 368–73. Her victory brought the two responses that have come to define her five-year reign: the full-throated implementation of Catholic orthodoxy and practice; and, in its wake, the imposition of bloody justice. The new orthodoxy restored processions, ceremonies, holy days, fasts, tithing; and the defrocking of married priests (all seen most impactfully at the parish level). The hardening of views deepened on both sides.Marshall, Heretics, pp 372–9.

The new justice reflected a return to the defining of conscience-driven resistance as heresy so as to require burning at the stake, of individuals and groups, in ever-growing numbers as a form of religio-political theatre. Mary restored a statute, de Haeretico Comburendo (the burning of heretics), originally passed by Parliament on 10 March 1400/1 but repealed by Henry VIII, and again repealed by Elizabeth I following the reign of Mary. The Marian enforcement began with the execution of some 100 rebel leaders between February and April 1554. During the next three years her regime burned several hundred 'heretics,' great and obscure, often in mass burnings, the latter of which seems to have been the preferred way.Marshall, Heretics, pp 372–416.

When Elizabeth I ascended the throne on 17 November 1558, a moderate Protestantism once again became the state-sanctioned religion of England. But the country itself was riven by dangerous theological, political, and social conflicts among reformist Protestants and Catholics alike. It was undoubtedly the Catholics who would pose the greatest existential threat during the first three decades of Elizabeth’s reign. Managing those chasmic divisions and accelerating existential threats would become the never-ending masterwork of the queen and her councillors during her half-century of rule.Ryrie, English Reformation, p 59.

Her problem was the irreconcilable gap between the ideologues on both sides and her own principal objective, which was to have ‘quiet and orderliness’ in her kingdom. Her means to that end was the twin acts of supremacy and uniformity passed by parliament in 1559. It prescribed uniformity (via the Book of Common Prayer) and Royal Supremacy, while seeking to couple them with a leniency and tolerance toward Catholics that seems to have been part of her nature.Marshall, Heretics, pp 419–27. To that end, she reestablished her father’s ‘moderate middle way’ or ‘via media’ as her own operating principle, coupling it with a steely unwillingness to waver from a position once she had taken it.Ryrie, English Reformation, p 68.

The queen’s approach had the opposite effect to the one she intended. Her complex approach caused both sides to conclude that she was a ‘Nicodemite Queen’ (one who hides his or her true religious feelings behind dissembling), a suspicion causing great fear and anxiety among her allies and the protestant reformists, and undue hopes among Catholics who were encouraged by her liking for dignified and formal ceremonialism, her love of choral music, her acceptance of a controlled episcopacy; her rejection of marriage by clergy; and her retention of a crucifix in her private chapel.As Ryrie points out, in spite of Protestant fears, Elizabeth supported the Calvinist doctrine of predestination and the use of a common book of prayer, and over the course of her reign universities steadily developed protestant ministers; towns endowed ‘lectureships’ for preachers; reformists produced a flood of robust rhetoric via ‘cheap pamphlets and ballads’; the English Church introduced the Geneva bible; and the queen’s preference for law and structure advanced long–sought protestant uniformity; see Ryrie, English Reformation, pp 58–65, 72; Marshall, Heretics, pp 448–9.

The relentless efforts of ideologues on both sides forced the queen and her ministers to move inexorably from moderate policies to violent and repressive ones. Elizabeth’s continuous purging of Catholic rites and core beliefs brought Catholics together as an aggrieved, threatened community, and galvanized European Catholicism. In their trajectory, the actions and counter-actions of Crown and Catholics between 1565 and 1588 took on a tragic inevitability culminating in two incalculably significant events: the Crown’s execution of Mary, Queen of Scots, on 8 February 1586/7 (an action resulting from the perception that Catholic plotting had dangerously merged with the ambitions of the Scottish queen); and the English defeat in August 1588 of the invading Spanish Armada.Marshall, Heretics, pp 419–75. Marshall’s exhaustive survey of reactions by the Crown to resistance to conformity between 1559 and 1588 shows the uninterrupted intensification of the violence on both sides, notably: the purging of Catholics from official positions and the publishing of new articles of faith and the rejecting of transubstantiation and purgatory in 1563; the formalizing of the recusancy law in the early 1560’s; the Catholic rising in 1569 that brought violent and bloody retribution from Elizabeth; the papal declaration of Elizabeth as a heretic in 1570 followed by schemes to assassinate her; the execution of priests between 1571–3; and the beheading of Mary, Queen of Scots in 1587; see pp 457, 467, 491, 493–5, 498, 560.

The English saw their maritime victory as the victory of their religion. While the Catholic question would continue to bedevil (so to speak) England, erupting most spectacularly in the attempt to blow up King James and the English parliament in 1605, there was no question after 1588 that England was a Protestant nation.Marshall, Heretics, pp 575–77. The battles to come between 1588 and the English Civil War in 1642 were between parliamentarian and royalist sympathizers. The English were now free to get really nasty with each other.

Elizabethan Suffolk remained its contradictory, nationally significant, self during her reign. While still one of the most Protestant-minded counties in England, Suffolk’s powerful conservative elements, which had put Mary on the throne and remained loyal to her memory, also represented a potent political force in the county. But being weary of conflict and ‘religious extremism,’ as Diarmaid MacCulloch puts it, the county’s elite from both camps initially adopted a ‘state of cautious compromise,’ gracefully accepting the new queen.MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, pp 181–2. Open conflict would return with a vengence throughout the 1560s and 1570s.

In his close study of Mildenhall's churchwardens' accounts, for example, John Craig reveals a complex interplay between the town's 'reasonable observance to the Protestant order of the day’ and 'concerns reflective more of local initiatives than of deference to authority,’ specifically to 'a growth of puritanism' and 'a world of nonconformity and dissent' in the parish. The accounts reflect the conflict between two factions—conservatives and non-conformists—in the people and the clergy of the parish by the community’s swift embrace of Protestantism. Communal harmony withered away as the very idea of what constituted a community changed utterly. Figures such as Thomas Bilney, the brilliant and inflammatory preacher and Cambridge don, turned the county into a rhetorical arena, as did the minister and playwright, John Bale. For example, the large religious morality plays which were one of the fifteenth-century cultural jewels of Suffolk, and which dramatized the journey of the self toward redemption, gave way to political moralities that satirically and parodically dramatized 'seditious' themes about the powerful. The age of ideologies put down some of its earliest and deepest English roots in Suffolk.Craig, Reformation, pp 53–8. Other rich sources of evidence can also be brought to bear more fully in the study of the popular response to Protestantism, most notably the charges and witness testimonies in the rich deposition books of the ecclesiastical courts and the order books of the quarter sessions courts, not to mention the statutes of local confraternities or religious guilds (until 1547); see James Stokes (ed), Somerset, REED (Toronto, 1996), and Lincolnshire, REED (Toronto, 2009).

In the latter years of the 1570s the Crown was carefully watching Suffolk move toward crisis. As Patrick Collinson has said: ‘This was a region whose very soul was at stake, as progressive, Protestantizing, elements competed for the upper hand with conservative, Catholic, or crypto-Catholic forces.’Patrick Collinson, ‘Pulling the Strings: Religion and Politics in the Progress of 1578,’ The Progresses, Pageants, and Entertainments of Queen Elizabeth I, Jayne Elizabeth Archer et al (eds) (Oxford, 2007), 126. Two signature events defined the dangerous complexity of the time in Suffolk. The first was the lengthy progress made through the heart and length of Suffolk and Norfolk by the queen in July and August 1578. Collinson has compellingly shown, in meticulous detail, that nothing whatsoever about this progress was random. Rather, its use of statecraft, selection of lodgings, spectacles, pageantry and performances, Protestant knightings and recusant shamings and finings were all meant, through a display of royal power, as a powerful rebuke to Catholic elements in both counties, so as to ensure peace in both the diocese of Norwich and greater East Anglia.For a detailed analysis of the progress from this perspective, see Collinson, ‘Pulling the Strings,’ pp 122–41; MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, pp 195–197.

The second event, an upheaval between 1578 and 1585 that has come to be known as the 'Bury "stirs",' served as a check on radical protestantism. At the heart of the crisis was a constitutional dispute (grown ever more fraught following the dissolution of the abbey): who, in the absence of a local corporation, was to dominate governance in Bury? At that historical moment, three groups—religious conservatives (Catholics), conformist Protestant moderates, and radical reformist puritans—were competing for power. Bury had become the center of puritanism in West Suffolk and puritans were taking ever more control of the county’s judicial system. Their chief jurisdictional opponent in Bury was the bishop of Norwich (also representing the interests of the Crown), but they also faced serious local challenges from both conformist Protestants and Catholic interests. The political situation in late sixteenth-century Bury was almost impossibly complex. In the absence of a corporation or a powerful religious guild, administrative power in Bury lay with the town feoffees and the governors of Bury School, mainly representing conformist interests, although conservatives and moderates found it necessary to form an alliance against the puritans. Conflict during the stirs unfolded as a series of legal and judicial battles used largely as a means to punish and discipline opponents. Executions and demonizations of opponents resulted. Both the tenor and the factionalism in Bury reflect the larger currents in the county but were especially explosive there.For essential analyses of the Bury stirs and their context, see Craig, Reformation, pp 72–114; MacCulloch, Suffolk and the Tudors, pp 192–219.

During the rule of the two early Stuarts (1603 to 1642), Suffolk, like all of England, was firmly Protestant. However, the conflicts that had threatened Suffolk during the reign of Elizabeth (Catholics versus Protestants, and the Church of England versus Puritans) continued and, together with new difficulties, brought an irreconcilable hardening to matters of religion and politics.

The thriving Elizabethan economy in Suffolk declined under the Stuarts. The once-robust cloth trade collapsed in the face of falling European demand, domestic export restrictions, and failure to respond to changing fashions abroad in the cloth trade. Fishing suffered from a post-Reformation decrease in demand for fish, foreign competition, and sea erosion in port towns. While agriculture boomed for food producers, workers suffered in poverty. While local grammar schools proliferated (former household clergy often serving as schoolmasters), the focus of education shifted from preparation for holy orders to preparation for law school. While literacy grew greatly among the gentry, yeomen, and tradesmen, most other folks remained illiterate—a situation contributing to the rise of a new ruling class. As a major maritime county, Suffolk became increasingly involved in the fraught issues of the day (war with Spain, foreign trade, emigration, colonization, and voyages of discovery). That is to say, the Suffolk of the early Stuarts was ‘precarious and turbulent,’ but never more so than in matters of religion and control of local order.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 67–73. While identifiable Catholic recusants declined sharply in number during the early seventeenth century, they remained a social force in the county, mainly because of who they were. As Blackwood says, ‘Roman Catholic Recusancy was essentially seignorial’ under Elizabeth and the Stuarts, the greatest number of identifiable recusants being gentry, as well as some yeomen. The Howards, dukes of Norfolk; Sir Thomas Cornwallis of Brome, and the Jernegans of Somerlyton, among others, had been nationally important under Elizabeth. By 1641 a mere thirty-four identifiably recusant gentry families, all diminished by the Crown, remained in Suffolk. Recusants were mainly to be found, according to Joy Rowe, ‘in High Suffolk and the Liberty of St Edmund’ and ‘ along the valley of the River Waveney,’ but Blackwood notes that they were ‘practically non-existent in the Breckland, in Risbridge Hundred, in Ipswich and especially in the Sandlings.’Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 117–119; Joy Rowe in England’s Long Reformation, pp 169–70 and 178, quoted in Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 119; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 120.

The struggle over order and control in early Stuart Suffolk was now between the Anglicans (Church of England) and the Puritans. Both were firmly protestant. As Patrick Collinson says, ‘the differences between Puritans and Anglicans were differences of degree, of theological temperature ... rather than of fundamental principle.’Patrick Collinson, The Elizabethan Puritan Movement (London, 1967), 26–7, as quoted in Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 122. Both factions believed in the fundamental tenets of protestant theology. The Puritans, however, passionately rejected the ceremonial and episcopal hierarchies retained by the Anglican church, which elements the Puritans judged to be residual Catholicism.

Several factors strongly favored the Puritans in the struggle. First, East Anglia was a strongly Puritan region and, as MacCulloch says, Suffolk was ‘the heart of East Anglian Puritanism, where so many of the leading gentry were enthusiastic for radical reformation.’Diarmaid MacCulloch, ‘Catholic and Puritan in Elizabethan Suffolk,’ Archive for Reformation History 72 (1981), p 283, quoted in Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 122. Second, Puritans expressed a deeper commitment to their objections, perceiving Catholic vestiges as undermining Protestantism itself. Third, and most decisive, the gentry and the clergy of Puritan Suffolk struck an alliance, which has come to be known as ‘magistracy and ministry,’ that consolidated their power in governing the county. The Puritan clergy were generally learned, sincerely religious, and skilled in public speaking, and they were utterly opposed to ceremonial, to major prescriptions in the Prayer Book, and to the episcopal hierarchy. Jacobean Puritanism expressed minimal objections to the Crown, since it seemed so strongly Calvinist and supported the importance of preaching.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 123–6.

Most importantly, ‘the character of Puritanism changed’ in that it took ‘an inward turn,’ becoming especially concerned about ‘household religion, sabbatarianism, and an emphasis on discipline, preaching and strict morality, especially the latter.’ Clergy were supported in their disciplinary efforts by the gentry, who appointed clergy, practiced household religion, were pietistic, held strong anti-episcopal feeling, and saw a decline of morality in the county. A kind of stifling probity took over and Puritan magistrates earnestly focused on matters of personal behaviour (the zealous punishing of minds, hearts, and bodies, in the name of good order).Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 126–7, 132.
