While the Puritan magistracy and ministry worked relentlessly to complete the Reformation (as they saw it needed doing), their opponents, in the person of the Anglican bishops, were equally zealous in carrying out the opposing policies and religious positions of the Crown and the High Church. The bishops of Norwich countermanded Puritan actions, strengthened ceremonials, and did so in ways that severely alienated parishioners in the battle for hearts and minds. While the four bishops of the period (Francis White, Richard Corbett, Matthew Wren, and Richard Montague) served to strengthen the Puritan mindset against the episcopacy, none had more negative impact than Matthew Wren. In summary, he was unpleasant; was hated; held Armenian (anti-predestination) views; tactlessly espoused royal authority; imposed strict liturgical and doctrinal uniformity and conformity among clergy; was very ceremonial, anti-sabbatarian, and anti-preaching; was pro-catechizing; and suppressed lecturers. And he ordered the moving of the communion table further away from the congregation.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 129–32. However, the greatest difficulty facing Anglicans was the monarch himself, Charles I, who tried to finance his wars with excessive taxation, and dissolved his parliaments (the first time in 1626), imposing a personal rule that almost everyone found problematic.

div.head: Towns and Villages
div.p: Eight Suffolk communities have left large, or otherwise substantial, bodies of dramatic records.

div.head: ALDEBURGH
div.p: It can initially seem inexplicable that a charming but modest and remote little town on the Suffolk coast (as it now is) should have attracted repeated visits by royal troupes, plus eleven other nationally prominent acting companies, between 1567 and 1635. The answer, then and now, lies largely with the sea.

Aldeburgh (in Plomesgate Hundred) rests very literally beside the sea between Orford and Dunwich on the River Alde, which was once navigable to Snape Bridge. Aldeburgh's fishermen used batella (small five-man draggable boats) to navigate the Alde and other rivers and creeks into Aldeburgh, and for off shore fishing for coastal species. Originally the site of a small Roman port, Aldeburgh became, in the early modern period, 'an important port centred on a haven.' It had a significant shipbuilding industry and a substantial sprat (a small sardine-like fish) and line-fishing industry.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 16; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 156, 164. It received a borough charter in 1529, and from 1571 was one of seven Suffolk parliamentary boroughs, sending two members to parliament. The borough (reduced to a municipal corporation since 1832) was ‘governed by two bailiffs, ten capital burgesses, and twenty-four inferior burgesses.’ Its timber-framed Moot Hall, where those officials met, was built between 1520 and 1540.Wendy Goult, A Survey of Suffolk Parish History: East Suffolk A–H (Ipswich, 1990), np; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 36–7; Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 16–17. The town was granted a market in 1547 and a second one in 1568. Land for a grammar school was incorporated in 1638. Its grammar school predated 1581, and in the seventeenth century the school recorded itself as having a 'school dame.' Its population, according to Blackwood, was 700 in 1524, and 1,300 in 1603. Its occupants included many sailors, mariners and maritime craftsmen.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 16; Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 24. Its parish church of Sts Peter and Paul (where players also performed), was built with wealth from its fishing and overseas trade in the fifteenth century. Aldeburgh, in short, was a significant borough during the sixteenth century, and easily accessible on coastal roads between Ipswich and Yarmouth. But it has proved to be extraordinarily vulnerable to the sea. As Birch has observed, in the sixteenth century it had five substantial streets running parallel to the sea. Today it has two. Its Moot Hall, which once stood in the Market Square at the centre of town now stands at the edge of the beach. Nor can the town move inland, given its geography.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 55; Birch, Ancient Sites, p 16.

Aldeburgh's social structure is no less idiosyncratic and corporate. There is no record that the town had religious guilds. Its Elizabethan and Jacobean civic accounts (which include parish business) give great emphasis to the responsibilities of burgesses and their wives in worship, ceremonies, and processions.Arthur T. Winn, Records of the Borough of Aldeburgh: the Church (Hertford, 1926), 7–10. As Dickens says, Aldeburgh had 'a Protestant presence between 1520 and 1558,' perhaps initially intensified because of its strong trading contacts with the continent.A.G. Dickens, quoted in Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 101. Later, during the Civil War, Aldeburgh was 'clearly Parliamentarian in sympathy,' even raising a company of foot soldiers in their cause.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 150.

div.head: BECCLES
div.p: Beccles is situated on a rise overlooking the River Waveney in Wangford Hundred in northeast Suffolk, nearly equidistant between the towns of Bungay and Lowestoft. It is one of the oldest towns in Suffolk, and in earlier centuries was 'the most substantial [town] between Ipswich and Norwich.'Nesta Evans, 'The Holy Ghost Gild and the Beccles Town Land Feoffees in the Sixteenth and Seventeenth Centuries,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and Natural History 37, pt 1 (1989), pp 31–43. Along with Ipswich, it was one of two capitals of an Anglo-Saxon division in Suffolk called the Geldable (a place empowered to levy royal geld or taxes). Domesday Book confirms that it already had burgesses at the time of the Conquest. Beccles was one of eleven Suffolk towns that had a market and 'urban status,' and one of only six of those towns that had burgesses, though it never became a parliamentary borough. By virtue of its location at the farthest navigable point of the Waveney River, and because it was positioned on what was once ‘the main route from London to Yarmouth,’ it was always commercially significant. Its market dates from the Anglo-Saxon period. As early as the tenth century its thriving riverine port 'provided 60,000 herring a year' for the abbey of Bury St Edmunds. In 1302 its market had eighty-two stalls, and partly because of its strategic position in the borderland between Suffolk and Norfolk, the market survived the general economic decline of the fifteenth century.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 32; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 116, 168–9, 266; Evans, 'Holy Ghost Gild'; Keith Wade and David Dymond, 'Smaller Medieval Towns,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 162; and Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 35–36. During the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries it continued to be important to the Waveney Valley in the marketing of agricultural produce, and in the linen industry, which was 'mainly concentrated in the Valleys of the Waveney and the Little Ouse.'Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 21; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 34.

Though important, Beccles was never large. In 1327 it ranked second among Suffolk towns, having 167 taxpayers. It had between 1,000 and 2,500 residents in the fourteenth century, 1,200 in 1525, 1,100 in 1603, 1,750 in the 1670’s, and 2,000 by the end of the seventeenth century.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 5; and Evans 'Holy Ghost Gild,' p 41.

The abbey of Bury St Edmunds, which had acquired Beccles in the mid-tenth century, remained its landlord until 1536. At the time of the Conquest, the abbots took most customary rights due from Beccles market, and were given a charter to hold a fair in 1205, which charter was renewed in 1259.Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 35–36. As a ‘mesne’ or seignorial borough, Beccles developed a network of seven medieval religious guilds (Holy Ghost, St Michael, Ascension, Holy Trinity, Holy Name of Jesus and St Nicholas, Corpus Christi, and Halfpenny, the first six of which were housed in the guildhall). Those guilds effectively provided local governance.Nesta Evans, Beccles Rediscovered (Beccles, 1984), 65; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 141. Burgesses rented the rich grazing lands of the town fen from the abbot of Bury and before the Reformation assigned administration of those lands (including the game place) to the most important of its guilds, the Holy Ghost guild, which had been founded in the fifteenth century.Evans, Beccles Rediscovered, 57–9, 65; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 141. The Holy Ghost guild protected the manorial lands from seizure by the Crown by creating the Lands Feoffment Trust, with the help of merchant William Rede. Although responsibility for the manorial lands had thereby devolved to the Trust after the dissolution, the town had to contend with Rede for ownership of the manorial lands until 1590. In 1584 a limited charter created the Corporation of Beccles, giving it the power to regulate the manorial lands of the fen. While the Corporation had no comparable formal power over the town, it essentially shaped the ways in which the town increasingly governed itself. The often overlapping membership of the Corporation (its portreeves) and the Lands Feoffment Trust (its thirteen feoffees) constituted a local ruling oligarchy.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 86; Evans, 'Holy Ghost Gild,' pp 31–4.

Medieval and early modern Beccles had a contentious religious history that reflects the presence of competing social, cultural, and economic forces in the area. Beccles’ manorial landlords, the abbots of Bury St Edmunds, of course exerted great influence over the town (as described above). The parish church of St Michael in Beccles was built between 1350 and 1400. In addition to its seven religious guilds, pre-Reformation Beccles had a Hermitage Chapel dedicated to Mary, a leper’s hospital dedicated to St Mary Magdalene and St Anthony, and a medieval chapel dedicated to St Peter that was important to the fishermen of Beccles.Goult, A Survey of Suffolk Parish History: East Suffolk A–H (Ipswich, 1990), np; Birch, Ancient Sites, p 35. Pre-Reformation Beccles certainly lived under a strong traditional religious presence. But at the same time most of Suffolk’s Lollards 'lived in or near the Waveney valley,' and Beccles and Bungay 'were considered the chief centres' of Lollard activity in the region. The presence of stone fonts depicting the sacraments in fourteen churches 'near former centres of East Anglian Lollardy' (including Bungay near Beccles) reflects the Orthodox church reacting to Lollard attacks on the sacraments, and three Lollards were burnt at the stake in Suffolk in the early sixteenth century (one from Bungay in 1511; one each from Eye and Earl Stonham between 1512 and 1515). During the Marian persecutions in 1556, three Protestants were burned at the stake in Beccles. Such evidence indicates a volatile combination of traditional Catholicism, Lollardy, and eventually Tudor Protestantism in Beccles.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 69–70. The politics of land ownership in Beccles with the aforesaid William Rede were no less contentious. For several decades following the dissolution, the town waged legal battles with Rede for control of the manorial lands (including the game place). The town finally won the contest in 1584 when a charter awarded the lands to the Corporation of Beccles Common. However, lordship of the Manor remained with the Redes and later with Sir Thomas Gresham (1519-79), founder of the Royal Exchange.Evans, Beccles Rediscovered, pp 5–7.

div.head: BOXFORD
div.p: Boxford is a small village situated partly in Babergh and partly in Cosford Hundreds, five miles south-west of Hadleigh, on the River Box, a small tributary of the River Stour in southwest Suffolk. Boxford's significance in Suffolk's economic and dramatic history is out of proportion to its modest size as a parish.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 45; Peter Northeast (ed), Boxford Churchwardens' Accounts 1530–1561, Suffolk Record Society 23 (Woodbridge, 1982), xii.

From the late thirteenth century forward, Babergh and Cosford Hundreds were the centre of the broadcloth industry in Suffolk, which brought great wealth to the communities, most notably, to Babergh Hundred, which was the second most densely populated area of the county.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 52; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 14-16. For the most comprehensive scholarly study of textiles in Suffolk, see Nicholas R. Amor, Suffolk in the Middle Ages: the Triumph of the Suffolk Clothier (Bungay, 2016). According to Bailey, the growth of clothmaking intensified after the Black Death, particularly in 'rapidly industrializing villages,' including Boxford, in the Stour valley. In the 1460's Boxford ranked twelfth among cloth-making centres in Suffolk, becoming increasingly 'dominated by shearmen and weavers' in particular. By 1522, according to Dymond and Northeast, Boxford had the largest number of cloth workers in Babergh Hundred.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 272–4; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 52. Of its 101 taxpayers in 1522, fifty-five worked in the cloth trades. Though wealthy, Boxford never grew into a large community and had only an unofficial, not a licensed, market.Northeast, Boxford Churchwardens' Accounts, p xii; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 46. Its population was eighteen in 1086, thirteen taxpayers in 1327, and 101 taxpayers in 1522. Its church was dedicated to the Blessed Virgin Mary and the parish had a parson. Pre-Reformation Boxford had three religious guilds (St Peter, Holy Trinity, and St John), but as was typical of many cloth-making towns, it developed strong protestant tendencies and became a centre of puritanism, although it was able quickly to restore Catholic furnishings and worship during the brief reign of Mary. Wendy Goult, A Survey of Suffolk Parish History: West Suffolk (Ipswich, 1990) np; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 91, 94–5, 99. It had a grammar school by 1596, with two free scholars each from Boxford, Edwardstone, Groton, and Assington, plus an additional twelve paying scholars.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 45; Goult, West Suffolk, np.

div.head: BUNGAY
div.p: The ancient borough of Bungay in north-east Suffolk lies on the River Waveney in Wangford Hundred, and the deanery of South Elmham, close by the Waveney towns of Mettingham and Beccles. Nearly encircled by the River Waveney at a navigable point, Bungay has always been a strategically significant place. Roger Bigod, one of William the Conquerer’s barons, built a massive Norman Castle there in the twelfth century, as Birch puts it, ‘in a superbly defensive position above the Waveney, at a point where the river forms a great horseshoe bend.’Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 60–1; Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np. Bungay is also an ancient site, on a Roman road, with evidences of Roman, pre-Christian Anglo-Saxon, and Danish occupation.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 55; Birch, Ancient Sites, p 61. By 1158 it had a mint and before 1228 it had become a borough and vill, indicating its contemporary military importance to the Crown.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 60; M.W. Beresford and H.P.R. Finberg, English Medieval Boroughs: A Hand-List (Totowa, NJ, 1973), 165. Medieval Bungay had two parish churches (St Mary and Holy Trinity) plus a thirteenth-century church of St Thomas, a hospital of St John, three chapels and a nunnery, a fair, which existed before 1199 because in that year, ‘Hugh Bigot gained permission to extend the privileges of his fair,’ and two markets, and by 1565 a grammar school. Though substantial and important, Bungay, like other of Suffolk’s market towns, was never large. Its population has been estimated as 230 in 1086, 650 in 1524/5, 1,050 in 1603, and 1,200 in the 1670’s.Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 5. By the fourteenth century Bungay had become an important link in the river-shipping of grain on the Ouse and Waveney River system. It also received cattle driven by land for sale in the town and benefitted from the development of the dairying industry on the clays of north Suffolk. Some woollen and linen textile manufacturing developed here in the century or so after the Black Death. Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 169, 272. During the seventeenth century the linen and sail cloth industry had concentrated in the Ouse and Waveney river valleys, bringing Bungay relief from earlier severe poverty that had been caused by waning of trade in the wake of continental wars. In spite of the powerful seignorial and spiritual presence of the abbey of Bury St Edmunds, religious protest appears always to have been part of the character of Bungay. Most of Suffolk’s Lollards 'lived in or near the Waveney valley,' and Beccles and Bungay 'were considered the chief centres' of Lollard activity in the region, and the area periodically experienced vehement and violent religious outbursts in opposition to sacramentalism.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 21, 69–70. Two Lollard school teachers from Bungay were executed in 1428. At the same time, strong traditionalist elements quickly reasserted themselves during the reign of Mary. Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 58; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 95.

div.head: BURY ST EDMUNDS
div.p: It would be impossible to overestimate the importance of both the abbey and the borough of Bury St Edmunds in Suffolk history, or the extent to which there was perpetual conflict between the two. Town and abbey were ever locked in an historical embrace, as it were, that was seldom friendly and which the town found intolerably stifling.

Historically, the town and the abbey developed simultaneously. It was the eleventh century that gave Bury its name, its medieval identity, and the beginnings of its vast importance. In 1020 King Cnut founded a Benedictine monastery on the site, and in 1038 Beodericeworth became a fortified town named Byrig, although it increasingly came to be called by variations including the words St Edmund and Bury.Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 67–8; Statham (ed), Accounts of the Feoffees of the Town Lands of Bury St Edmunds, 1569–1622, Suffolk Record Society 46 (Woodbridge, 2003), p xviii. A huge area known as the Liberty of St Edmund (comprising the large hundreds of Babergh, Blackbourn, Cosford, Lackford, Thedwestre, Thingoe, and Risbridge) formed the dowry of Cnut's wife Emma. Her son, Edward the Confessor (1042–66), granted the entire liberty to the abbey at Bury, making the abbot the wealthiest, most powerful landlord in the county. The Liberty of St Edmund eventually became West Suffolk, whose boundary with East Suffolk was 'the most potent line of demarcation within Suffolk.'Statham, Accounts of the Feoffees, p xviii; McCullough, quoted in Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 33.

In founding the town, King Cnut granted privileges associated with boroughs, including burgesses, a coroner, a great or county court, courts leet, and a major market. In doing so, the town of Bury became the capital of the Liberty of St Edmund, and the eventual capital of West Suffolk. Subsequent charters by Edward the Confessor, Stephen, and Henry I confirmed, and notably expanded, the original privileges granted abbey and town by Cnut. Following the invasion of 1066, eleventh-century Bury thrived under the Normans. However, while Cnut had granted the town the practical right (and financial responsibility) to carry out the duties of a borough, he had given the authority of a landlord over those rights to the abbey, an ownership reaffirmed by subsequent kings, making the town a mesne borough. The town might appoint a bailiff or other officers, but it must seek the approval of the abbot, the cellarer, or the sacrist for its choices. Further, the town must pay rents and taxes levied by the abbey. The town would remain a non-parliamentary, non-chartered borough until the early seventeenth century, an arrangement that guaranteed the four centuries of conflict between abbey and town that would follow.These details are gleaned from: Statham, Accounts of the Feoffees, p xviii; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 34, 39–41; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 33, 36; Beresford and Finberg, English Medieval Boroughs, pp 165–6; and Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 67–71.

During the twelfth century abbey and town experienced major growth and continuing conflict. Henry I confirmed the liberties granted by Cnut and Edward the Confessor. A mid-century charter by King Stephen exempted the borough from all taxation except that levied by the abbey. The town had a guild merchant, which gave rising influence to the alderman of that guild, although the guild itself was not allowed to develop into an incorporated body.The definitive study of civic history in Bury St Edmunds remains Mary D. Lobel, The Borough of Bury St Edmunds: a Study in the Government and Development of a Monastic Town (Oxford, 1935). See also Beresford and Finberg, English Medieval Boroughs, pp 165–6; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 138–9; Statham, Accounts of the Feoffees, p xviii. Bury had become the legal, economic, and administrative centre of East Suffolk. As Bailey acutely observes, the town exercised more rights than it officially had.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 138–9. Yet the growth in importance and power of the town was dwarfed by that of the abbey, whose temporal power came from two factors. In Bailey's words: 'The landed estates of the abbey of Bury St Edmunds dominated west Suffolk, and its additional judicial rights associated with the Liberty of St Edmund enabled the abbey to protect its interests effectively and to control the local political landscape with an iron grip.'Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 34. And as the keeper of the shrine of St Edmund, the abbey was a centre of incalcuable spiritual attraction for kings and pilgrims alike. Both the abbey and the town experienced financial difficulties during the twelfth century. The century ended with the abbot intensifying his efforts to control the town and its money, while the town devised schemes to grow its corporate power and fiscal independence, setting the periodically explosive pattern of the next two centuries. See Antonia Gransden, A History of the Abbey of Bury St Edmunds, 1182–1301, 2 vols (Woodbridge, 2007 (vol 1), 2015 (vol 2), passim.

The thirteenth century brought sustained development to town and abbey. During the first sixteen years of the century, ending with the signing of the Magna Carta and the death of King John, the town of Bury continued to grow as an important centre of textile manufacturing and trade. King John signed a charter reaffirming the abbot's absolute monopoly over markets in all of the vast Liberty of St Edmund, a monopoly that the abbot ruthlessly affirmed when necessary. However, prosperity also brought endless conflicts involving money and power that entangled abbey, town, king, papacy, and barons in constantly shifting demands and alliances. Bury's impressive and ever-growing resources also became it greatest vulnerability. A controversy between the abbot and the Crown concerning the right to select the next abbot (should the right belong to the king or to the abbey?) also caused serious conflict between factions within the Abbey. The burgesses of the town, as might be expected, sided with the king. Further, between 1212 and 1214 the king assessed 4,000 marks from the abbey in taxes, and in response the abbey taxed the town for that money. No party was endearing itself to any of the others in this permanently simmering pot of trouble.Gransden, History of the Abbey, vols 1–2, passim.

The long reign of Henry III (1216–72) brought no easing of conflicts.R.S. Gottfried, Bury St Edmunds and the Urban Crisis (Princeton, NJ, 1982), 94–106. The town's textile industry continued to produce fabric prized throughout the kingdom. The former guild merchant (now called the Candlemas guild) expanded its guildhall. The town also had a cordwainers' guild. In 1264, with the town still chafing under the abbey's control, major riots broke out challenging the abbot's charter of 1194 (which had given primacy to the abbot's court over the borough court). Further, the young burgesses, demanding that the Candlemas Guild be recognized as a corporation guild, formed the guild of youth. They elected an alderman, set up a court, and restricted the power of the monks in town affairs, also attacking the abbey gates and assaulting monks. In the end, their efforts came to nothing when the Crown forced them to abandon their guild. Although the abbot was now by far the largest landlord in Suffolk, its status ensured by Crown and papacy alike, it literally fought all encroachments upon its temporal and spiritual power, notably by the mendicant orders who sought to establish themselves in the town and succeeded even though the town and secular clergy consistently sided with the mendicants. In the 1260's Henry III faced a major insurrection by the barons, who assaulted Norwich. When the abbey at Bury harboured the rebels and their loot, incurring the king's wrath, blame somehow fell from the abbey onto the alderman and burgesses, who were prosecuted, costing the town its recently acquired rights. To further his point, in 1272 the king held a parliament at Bury to punish the rebels involved in the Norwich assault, executing thirty-five of them.

The essential point concerning the thirteenth century is that the town’s economic importance and wealth marched ahead of the abbey. In the eleventh and twelfth centuries, the town had existed to serve the abbey, but in the thirteenth century the development and growth of the town as an important centre of commerce and manufacture in its own right, and the consequent wealth and influence of the leading merchants, created tension between town and abbey: for freedom on the one hand, and for continued iron control on the other.

For the town, the only thing worse than having one resident landlord was having two, both of them inclined to make rapacious demands. During his 35-year reign (1272–1307) Edward I visited Bury fifteen times (often with Queen Eleanor) and kept a permanent residence in the abbey. He significantly augmented the abbey's powers and wealth, appointing the sacrist as judge of the assizes, granting the abbey the view of weights and measures, awarding a fair to the abbot in 1272, and generally siding with the abbey in its disputes with the town. However, he also taxed the abbey mercilessly, mainly to finance his wars with France and Wales (in 1277, 1282, 1292, and 1294). Exacerbating the town's ever-growing resentments, the abbey several times passed those royal taxes along to it. In 1291, for example, the abbey levied a tax on the town to offset the 1,000 marks that it had been forced to pay the Crown. In 1295 the king levied a heavy war tax directly onto the town. In 1297 the king confiscated all the goods of the abbot and the town. In short, during the last thirty years of the thirteenth century, the town achieved minor concessions but little of substance in seeking its rights as a borough.

During the fourteenth century, protests by the town against the abbey periodically and violently escalated. An uprising in 1305 achieved little. In 1327, seizing upon distractions provided by efforts to depose Edward II, 'the townsmen attacked and burnt many of the monastic buildings,' stealing records, muniments, gold, silver, vessels, vestments, plus other evidences of abbey control.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 47; Norman Scarfe, Suffolk in the Middle Ages (Woodbridge, 1986), 68. The rebellious burgesses and townsmen were eventually defeated (with many subsequent executions of burgesses), their revolt having had little permanent effect on the abbey's control of the town. During the Peasants Revolt of 1381, rebels again attacked the abbey muniment rooms, stealing documents and precious objects and summarily beheading the prior, the keeper of the abbey's court rolls, and a third man. This time however, their punishment was merely a fine of 2,000 marks and the ordered return of everything that they had stolen.Gottfried, Bury St Edmunds, pp 231–5 ; Chick, ‘The 1381 Rising in Bury St Edmunds: the Role of Leaders and the Community in Shaping the Rebellion,’ pp 35-47; and his ‘Leaders and Rebels: John Wrawe’s role in the Suffolk rising of 1381,’ pp 214–34; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 47; and Scarfe, Suffolk in the Middle Ages, pp 68–9 and n 56.

In spite of upheavals (and the Black Death that struck mid-century, killing nearly half of the monks in the abbey), both the town and the abbey continued to grow in wealth and influence during the fourteenth century. The town is estimated to have had between 5,000 and 7,000 persons in the early fourteen century, its population notable for the large number of specialist craftsmen in the industrial processes of the textile trades. Through the Abbey's power, which suppressed all competing markets within eight miles of the town, Bury had become one of the two 'most dominant' towns in the county.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 128–9; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 46. It had at least eighteen religious guilds, including the powerful Candlemas guild (the former guild merchant), and a handful trade and craft guilds, including the weavers (which supported the Corpus Christi pageant and procession), the linen drapers, and the shoemakers. The town used its religious and craft guilds to create structures providing religious, communal, and commercial authority that was at least nominally independent of the Abbey.Amor, From Wool to Cloth, pp 137-41; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 138–41. Yet, the town remained a mesne borough, seemingly forever doomed to be economically and civically subject to the abbey.

For its part, the abbey remained 'comfortably the county's most powerful and dominant landlord,' far greater than Suffolk 's three other major landlords—the earls of Norfolk, Suffolk, and Clare. The influence of its presence was incalculable. As described by Dymond and Northeast, the abbey remained 'the centre of a major pilgimage, it entertained kings and queens, housed parliaments, [and] built up a famous manuscript library with over 2,000 volumes,' and may have hosted a meeting leading 'to the granting of Magna Carta.' It exerted ultimate authority over every aspect of the town of Bury's life—its courts, markets, rents, guilds, and bailiffs, thereby perpetuating a 'notoriously fractious' relationship.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 16, 34, 137; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 39. In spite of its huge income, the abbey continually felt financial pressures, which did not ease in the post plague era when land values fell yet wages and costs rose. In this pre-Reformation world, the dramatic records of the town and the abbey indicate a bifurcated local culture unlike any that appears in other of Suffolk's dramatic records: apparently, neither town or abbey contributed much at all to the performance or customary culture of the other.

Between the mid-fifteenth and the early sixteenth centuries, the profound social, economic, and religious turmoil affecting Bury mirrored those affecting society as a whole. Cade's Rebellion in 1450 drew major support from textile workers in Bury, as it did from other of Suffolk's textile manufacturing towns.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 192. At the same time, Bury's (and greater Suffolk's) agricultural and industrial/commercial economy thrived between 1450 and 1530. The cloth industry 'reached a major peak of prosperity, and especially so in the main broadcloth area of south Suffolk—roughly a triangle with points at Clare, Bury St Edmunds and East Bergholt.' During these eighty years, Bury's cloth-production ranked third, after Hadleigh and Lavenham, among Suffolk towns (although it would lose its primacy in the early seventeenth century because of its failure to respond to changing fashions).Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 51–2, 67. Trade and craft guilds formed the heart and core of Bury's civic life throughout the entire Middle Ages, but never more so than during this late medieval period. As summarized by Bailey, Bury used trade, craft, and even religious guilds to organize commercial activity that was free from abbey control. The weavers and linen drapers regulated textiles; the bakers and shoemakers exerted similar control in their respective areas of interest. The weavers produced the Corpus Christi pageant and procession. Most powerful was the Candlemas guild (the former guild merchant), based in St James Church: 'By the end of the fifteenth century the gild merchant had acquired sufficient legal standing to allow burgesses to act as a communal body.' In this use of its guilds as its central instruments of governance (lacking, as they did, a formal government) Bailey finds Bury to be unique (save for Beccles) among Suffolk towns.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 140–41. Conversely however, while the abbey remained 'the fifth wealthiest Benedictine house in England,' it experienced a sharp decline of income during its final eight decades of existence. As described by Bailey, its financial difficulties included major decreases in charitable donations, in income from spiritualities, in bequests by wealthy clothiers and others, and in its inability to increase the number or value of its estates.Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 76; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 257.

The sixteenth century was, of course, catastrophic for the abbey, culminating in its dissolution on 4 November 1539 and the simultaneous abolishing of the rights and powers of the Liberty of St Edmund. The many payments to royal and other important troupes in the abbey records in the quarter century before the dissolution testify to the ever-increasing intensity of the Crown's gaze, and the reclaiming of power to itself from the church and the nobility.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 60.The Crown, together with the barons, proved no less demanding and controlling a landlord than had the abbey. Bury would remain a seignorial, non-chartered borough until the early seventeenth century.

Although it lacked the legal right to run its own affairs free of the abbot’s control, the town developed a series of structural entities that enabled its leading citizens to operate with greater independence from the abbey. The process had begun in the mid-fifteenth century when local benefactor John (also known as Jankyn) Smith provided funding for what might be called administrative charities used to protect the town's hard-earned customs. The process continued to evolve with a charter in 1470 between the abbot and alderman confirming the customs identified in Smith's will, as well as a body of greater and lesser burgesses. Two years later, in 1472, new statutes gave the Candlemas guild (composed of both men and women) the right to administer these customs after the death of the early benefactors, thereby providing the town with protections against future abbots. The town also established other quasi-administrative customs as well. Even though the Candlemas guild was officially abolished mid-century (as were other chantries and guilds), it continued to operate as a crypto-governing body throughout the early seventeenth century, electing an alderman, managing the guildhall (which the town now owned), and financially supporting a clerk, porter, chaplain, sexton, cook, and preacher. A book of orders codified the rules and processes guiding the town's governance. As described by Statham, the town appears to have developed a tripartite structure (comprised of the Company, the Common Conference, and the Feoffees of the town lands) that provided it with a practical way to govern the community, including the management of building projects and care of the poor.

The town finally achieved its long-sought goal when it received three corporation charters from the Crown in the early seventeenth century. A charter on 3 April 1606 described them as a new corporation with an alderman, twelve capital burgesses, twenty-four burgesses of the common council, four justices of the peace, a recorder, a town clerk, and two sergents at mace, while still withholding several important privileges. A second charter, given on 1 July 1608 in the wake of a fire that had devastated the town, provided for rebuilding and restoration by awarding the remaining financial powers sought by the town—control of ‘tithes, fairs, markets, and glebe lands.’ A third charter, in July 1614, gave the town control of quarter sessions and leet courts, a coroner, the right to four maces, churches with their advowsons (the right to select clergy), and above all in its importance, the right to send two members to parliament. The town had arrived.Statham, Accounts of the Feoffees, pp xviii–li.

div.head: DUNWICH
div.p: For centuries, the ill-fated town of Dunwich, in Blything Hundred, on the east coast of Suffolk fought against the relentless onslaught of the North Sea. However, by 1740 what had been described as a city in 803 AD (rather optimistically), a borough with 120 burgesses in 1066, a chartered borough with a merchant guild in 1200, and a place with a large, ancient port and major fishing industry, had been reduced to a small hamlet, its many substantial buildings lying beneath the encroaching waves. In spite of the ceaseless erosion, in the age of Shakespeare Dunwich was still a thriving, if struggling, borough and a minor, but lucrative, port. Important professional acting companies, including Shakespeare’s own troupe, still found reason to perform there.

Dunwich's unparalleled reversal is of such an epic scale that the town has been called 'the English Atlantis.' It was always an important place. Founded on the site of an earlier Roman settlement in c 632 by St Felix, who made the town his seat, Dunwich grew into the ancient capital of East Anglia. Its college and seminary, founded by Felix, was the 'oldest school in English history.' Before the Conquest, it was 'the principal fishing port in Suffolk,' with a deep-water harbour. Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 25; Birch, Ancient Sites, p, 108; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 24, 30; Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np.

Dunwich rivaled Ipswich in its early importance. The town's defining development occurred during the eleventh and twelfth centuries under the Normans, who recognized its strategic importance. Its population in 1086 was 628 recorded people. In 1173 it had been heavily fortified with a ditch and massive rampart, and as a royal demesne and mint under Henry II, the town and port flourished.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 36; Birch, Ancient Sites, p, 109. It received its first charter as a free borough from King John in 1199, with considerable civic autonomy as a royal borough, and by the late twelfth century it had a daily market and numerous religious institutions. The ‘road into town from the south eroded away by sea [in] 1609,’ and an east-west road ran from Dunwich to Bury St Edmunds.Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np.

At its peak in the thirteenth and early fourteenth centuries, Dunwich was an impressive place. It had at least seven churches (plus four lost churches), six rectories, a Saxon monastery, a Benedictine cell to Eye Priory, a preceptory of the Knights Templar, two convents—of the Black Friars and the Grey Friars, two hospitals, many almshouses, and four or more manors. It maintained eleven ships of war, sixteen fair ships, twenty barks and other vessels, and it engaged in North Sea and Icelandic trade. In 1334 it had fifty-four shops and four bakeries.Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np. In the thirteenth and early fourteenth centuries Dunwich was still one of Suffolk's largest towns with a population estimated to have been between 1,000 and 2,500 persons, but it had 'suffered badly from a silting harbour and catastrophic marine inundations,' losing a documented six parishes, 600 buildings, and its harbour mouth during a period of frequent and extreme storm activity between the 1290s and the 1340s.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 128. From the mid-fourteenth through the fifteenth centuries, a litany of factors, notably its relentless battering by the sea, and the wake of the Black Death, accelerated Dunwich's continuing decline. The borough’s revenue base shrank, its 'fishing fleet slumped, the income from its market stalls fell by two thirds, and the borough faced recurrent financial crises,' as its population shrank and it faced fierce competition for trade along the east coast from Southwold, Walberswick and Aldeburgh.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 134, 264–5, 277, 281–2.

Sixteenth-century Dunwich was increasingly a ghostly shadow of its earlier self. Except for similarly sea-challenged Aldeburgh, Dunwich was the only Suffolk town with a shrinking population, going from 1,150 residents in 1524/5 to 850 in 1603 to 300 in the 1670's. From the 1570's to the 1590's, the number of vessels held by its port were reduced by decade from fourteen vessels to ten to seven, and ‘by the end of the sixteenth century,’ the port was ‘completely blocked.’Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 5; Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 68. Yet Dunwich retained its status as a royal borough.

div.head: IPSWICH
div.p: Ipswich is the county city of Suffolk, and (it is today claimed) 'the first known town in Britain since the Roman period.' Its geographically strategic position on the River Gipping—which becomes the Orwell at 'the spot where it becomes tidal' lies 'some twelve miles from the open sea with direct access to mainland Europe'—determined that Ipswich must become a major port. Indeed, Anglo-Saxon Ipswich is thought to be 'the largest known early trading community in north-west Europe.' As Dymond and Northeast note, by the late sixth century the port was engaging in trade with the Low Countries and the Rhineland. Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 33–4; Wade, quoted in Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 34. Close as it is by the royal town of Rendlesham, and by Sutton Hoo, early Anglo-Saxon Ipswich had craftsmen skilled in metal-working, weaving, fishing, and pottery making, and it had a royal mint by 925. However, the strength of its geographical position was also the town's greatest vulnerability. In 885 the fleet of King Alfred won a decisive victory at Ipswich against the Danes, but invading Viking fleets then won three successive victories—by Olaf (with 93 ships) in 991, Thurkell the Tall in 1010, and Cnut in 1016. In 1069 an army led by Norman barons defeated a final Viking invasion, led by Sweyn of Denmark.Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 214–216. As a result of those many invasions, the Normans found the previously flourishing borough of Ipswich in a despoiled, impoverished, state. However, under Norman control and driven by the eventual revival of its shipbuilding, trade and commerce, Ipswich began what would become 450 years of sometimes interrupted, but never permanently broken, growth and revival.

During the late twelfth and thirteenth centuries the essential features of what would become the permanent civic identity of Ipswich developed. In 1200 it received a foundational corporation charter from King John, which, as described by Geoffrey Martin, gave it, in perpetuity, these much coveted rights as a royal borough: freedom of tolls throughout all of the king's lands; perpetual hold of the borough; a guild merchant or hanse; a protective trade association; exemption from the billeting of royal officers; protection from impleading outside the borough; permanent possession of its own free customs and the choice of its own magistrates; two bailiffs and four coroners; and overseeing of the processes of justice. The town promptly elected twelve chief portmen (as governors), two beadles or sergeants; devised a common seal; and appointed an alderman and four associates of the guild merchant.Geoffrey Martin, 'The Governance of Ipswich: I. From its Origins to c. 1550,' Ipswich Borough Archives 1255–1835, a Catalogue, David Allen (comp), Suffolk Record Society 43 (Woodbridge, 2000), xix–xx; see also Charles Gross, The Gild Merchant: a Contribution to British Municipal History, vol 2 (1890; rpt Oxford, 1964), 114–32. The townsmen immediately set about to write two rolls that would become the earliest known borough records—the one being the laws and customs of the town (which they called Domesday), the other being the rules or ordinances of the merchant guild (notably recording the guild's control of admissions to the borough). As Geoffrey Martin astutely observes, the burgesses could not have won the royal ratification of their liberties without a civic organization already in place that was substantially the same as that decreed under licence in 1200. That is, the institutions and customs of the town had been operating long before the charter of 1200. A surviving roll of 1255–6 shows that the principal court of the borough (the portmanmote) was already established well before that time. A charter from Henry III in 1256 further expanded the rights and independence of the town. As of 1298 Ipswich had also become a parliamentary borough.Martin, 'Governance,' pp xix–xxii; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 36.

The guild merchant is central in Ipswich history because of its early role in both local governance and the production of town-sponsored drama and ceremony. As John Wodderspoon explains it, early on Norman Ipswich developed a customary trade association now remembered as 'the old Hanse' to manage its foreign commerce. In effect, the Hanse acted as a guild-merchant-without-charter. When the town received its corporation charter from King John in 1199 (with the granting of a guild merchant, aldermen, and common council), the town took immediate steps to turn those new liberties into fact, absorbing the old Hanse into a new guild merchant. Especially early on, the new guild merchant acted as 'an informal town government,' its leading officers serving as a 'a de facto town council.'John Wodderspoon, Memorials of the Ancient Town of Ipswich in the County of Suffolk (Ipswich and London, 1850), 157–8; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 139. For the next 125 years the guild merchant would function, although with decreasing centrality, as part of civic governance, notably in its power to admit burgesses and collect monies. However, in 1325, impelled by the new feast of Corpus Christi (instituted by Rome in 1264), and the urgings of the local clergy, the town changed the name of the guild merchant to the Corpus Christi guild. The guild's new constitution transformed it into the town's principal socio-religious guild, or confraternity, with responsibility for the town's three-day Corpus Christi celebration, including its new Corpus Christi procession, pageants, plays, ceremonies, and dinner or feast. The guild's mission, in short, was to unify the town in spiritual terms that emphasized the imminence of Christ and the actualizing of his life in the streets of Ipswich, and to instill a sense of universal spiritual community in the hearts of the laity.Wodderspoon, Memorials, pp 155–7, 161–80; Martin, 'Governance,' p xxv. The guild achieved its goals by overseeing the awe-inspiring spectacle of the procession and shows (intended to inspire the faithful and subdue the faithless, as it were). Multiple entries in the town's books between 1444 and 1546 record the activities of the guild, from the appointment of the guild's schoolmaster to the Corpus Christi celebration to the managing of the guild's monies and properties. From the 1550s forward the records simply refer to the body as 'The Guild.' Later civic accounts tend to refer to the annual feast and elections as 'The Guild.' By 1627 the guild had reverted even further back, once again styling itself 'The Guild Merchant.'

The Corpus Christi guild operated at the direction of the Great Court of all the freemen (also called the General Court), which was the city's 'administrative authority' (paralleling the city's chief 'judicial authority,’ the portmanmote). The Great Court made ordinances concerning 'all aspects of town government,' including the election of the bailiffs, coroners, treasurer, chamberlains, and other officials. The Great Court itself acted on recommendations made by the Assembly, a body comprising the bailiffs, twelve portmen, and the twenty-four members of the common council. Among its manifold duties, the Great Court also supervised the annual election of the officers of the Corpus Christi guild, including the guild's alderman, its four wardens, and the wardens of specific pageants. The Great Court also appointed certain freemen of the city to guard the pageants.

When electing the alderman of the Corpus Christi guild, the Great Court also approved his two associates. The four wardens of the guild, who worked at the direction of the alderman, were elected from among the commonality of burgesses, and usually never served twice. Until 1545 the guild wardens numbered four; thereafter they usually numbered two. The alderman and wardens handled the guild's business (organizing the election of officers; managing finances; and organizing the annual dinner, known as the feast).

Ipswich was always 'a community of merchants and sailors and a town noted for its independent spirit and corporate pride in its privileges.' During the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries Ipswich further secured and extended those privileges through confirmations in a succession of royal charters (five in the fourteenth century, one each in 1446 and 1463). It had 'the best harbour and most accessible estuary' in Suffolk, and most of Suffolk's exported and imported goods made their way through Ipswich, notably 'wine, ale, herrings, hides, linen and canvas cloth, wool, millstones and salt.' It was a major commercial distribution centre, and had a daily market of its own. By 1334, Ipswich had become one of three Suffolk towns ranked 'among the … wealthiest [towns] in England.'Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 43; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 128–130, 150. The town continued to grow, surpassing Bury as the most populous town in the county, its population estimated as between 5,000 and 7,000 people in the fourteenth century. In the wake of successive outbreaks of plague, it became a magnet for persons migrating in from the devastated countryside, even though the plague struck in Ipswich too. Ipswich was also 'the centre of the county's administration and system of justice.' According to Dymond, Ipswich and Bury were the only two towns in the county strongly associated with craft or trade guilds (although an incident in Bungay in 1514 involving its pageants suggests a craft guild presence in that town as well).Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 129–30, 161, 150; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 60. Guilds of that kind were particularly numerous in Ipswich. In 1400 forty-one crafts in six companies took part in the Ipswich Corpus Christi procession.

In the mid-fifteenth century a great economic depression brought on in large part by foreign wars left Ipswich (and many other towns) impoverished; its all-important common quay was in 'partial decay.' As Bailey says, this catastrophe caused 'harsh competition in a contracting market' between Ipswich and Bury. However, within twenty years Ipswich had recovered and surpassed its earlier strengths. As described by Nicholas Amor, by 1470 the economy was recovering and its administrative system had mushroomed. In addition to the bailiffs, portmen, chamberlains and council of twenty-four it now included: ‘two escheators, six justices of the peace, four clavigers, a clerk of the peace, a common clerk, two additional sergeants, a master and six sub-porters [,] … and four wardens of the Corpus Christi guild.' 'Residents served as assessors and collectors,’ and (as summarized by Amor) as jurors valuers, chief pledges, tithingmen and affeerors, overseers of markets, and wine drawers. While Ipswich still had to contend with three magnates in the county (the dukes of Suffolk and Norfolk, and the earl of Oxford), the town had become 'the head port of a jurisdiction that stretched from Orford Haven to Brightingsea and included the harbours of Colchester (via its outport of Hythe), Harwich and Maldon.'Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 265; Nicholas R. Amor, Late Medieval Ipswich: Trade and Industry (Woodbridge, 2011), 18–19.

The Reformation immediately took firm hold in Ipswich, eventually transforming the town. By 1530 Ipswich had a 'strong Protestant presence,' likely (in Blackwood's view) 'because of the port's trading contacts with the Low Countries.' In 1556 Marian supporters identified ninety-eight residents (among them five clergy) as Protestant, and '[u]nder Elizabeth I Ipswich would become the capital of Protestantism, indeed of Puritanism, in Suffolk.'Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 101. During the brief Catholic interlude of the Marian reign, three Protestant martyrs were burned at the stake.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 221.

The tumult of the times changed every other aspect of Ipswich life as well. By 1524 a thriving Ipswich had become 'the sixth wealthiest provincial town in England.' However, the town's fortunes drastically reversed between the 1520's and 1560. Wars damaged trade and the cloth markets, leading to over-production in the wake of receding markets. Those markets, agrarian change, and the redistribution of wealth caused by the dissolution of the monasteries led to industrial unemployment, severe poverty, and what Geoffrey Martin calls 'structural destitution.'Birch, Ancient Sites, p 215; Martin, 'Governance,' p xxviii. The town responded to this crisis with many positive steps. Using its charitable foundations and taxing strategies in the 1570's, the town began its efforts to recover, purchasing defunct properties and developing ‘an infirmary, almshouse, house of correction,’ and a hospital to address the suffering of its citizens and the new realities of life in Ipswich.Martin, 'Governance,' pp xxviii, xxx. It enriched the charter of the grammar school. Through its efforts, its markets and trade began to recover.

However, this new environment brought structural and cultural changes to governance in Ipswich. Driven by necessity and the sense of social obligation felt by the 'godly Puritan elite' that controlled the town, borough government greatly expanded it numbers and its powers to meet the physical needs of the community. In this reformist environment the justice system also felt an increasing need to order 'the religious and moral lives of the inhabitants,' doing so with severe policing and punishments including public shaming, carting, and the pillory.Martin, 'Governance,' pp xxix–xxxii. Other than these spectacles, public performance increasingly included only civic ceremonies, music by the town waits, and visits by royal troupes (who could not be shunned). Most strikingly, in this environment the independent spirit and universal enfranchisement that had characterized governance in Ipswich increasingly gave way to 'government by oligarchy,' conducted by a 'self-perpetuating elite' made up of wealthy merchants, lawyers, gentry, wine traders, and cloth producers.Martin, 'Governance,' p xxix; Amor, Late Medieval Ipswich, p 17. It was a new age in this sea-faring town.

div.head: SUDBURY
div.p: Sudbury, in Babergh Hundred and Sudbury Deanery in southwest Suffolk, is one of Suffolk's oldest towns and a very ancient urban site. It is strategically located on the route north from Essex to Bury St Edmunds and at a crossing point of the River Stour, latterly navigable by barges to Sudbury. It was a Saxon royal town and a minster, had a royal mint from the tenth through the twelfth centuries, and was already a borough at the time of the Conquest.Birch, Ancient Sites, p 367; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 2. In 1086 Domesday described it as having ‘sixty-three burgesses dwelling by the hall and fifty-five others dwelling on the demesne,’ and well before 1274 it had a mayor and a ruling council (aldermen, burgesses, sergeants, bailiff, and so on).Beresford and Finberg, English Medieval Boroughs, p 167; and W.W. Hodson, 'The Old Moot Hall at Sudbury,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 7 (1888/9), 257.

Between the thirteenth and sixteenth centuries the key to Sudbury's success was its canny adaptability, both in cloth-making and politics. As skillfully outlined by Mark Bailey, by 1200 Sudbury was one of England's significant cloth-making towns, mainly in 'higher quality cloths for a wealthy clientele' and by 1300 it was one of Suffolk's three main textile manufacturing centres.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 158, 275, 269. Its expertise enabled it to prosper during the tumult of the mid-fourteenth century, responding rapidly to the growing demand for textiles among the lower orders of society: Sudbury weaving peaked between the 1350s and 1370's. A number of scholars make similar observations concerning Sudbury's flourishing economy from the fourteenth through the early sixteenth centuries.See Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 367–9; Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 52, 67; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 282; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 5. In spite of Sudbury's major role in the Peasants' Revolt of 1381, Sudbury cloth-manufacturing continued to flourish in the face of a more general economic downturn between the 1390s and 1420s During the fifteenth century, Sudbury was one of the most productive cloth-making towns in Suffolk, ranking seventh among Suffolk towns in cloth manufacture. Unlike other important cloth-making towns which failed to respond to changing times in the sixteenth century, Sudbury shifted to lighter, more colourful fabrics, and did well. In 1524 it ranked seventh among Suffolk towns in taxable wealth and was the fifth most populous town in the county with 1,200 inhabitants.

div.head: WALSHAM LE WILLOWS
div.p: Medieval Walsham was not a town or borough, but a large, populous village in Blackbourn Hundred, West Suffolk, with a flourishing cultural and religious life more characteristic of towns than of villages. It lies a roughly equidistant ten miles (moving clockwise) from Diss in Norfolk, Stowmarket, Bury, and Thetford. It is five miles from Ixworth, and Walsham's main west-to-east street is part of the Ixworth to Finningham Road. The village has other roads to numerous villages. That is to say, it was (and is) well situated to engage in the agricultural commerce and inter-parish enterprise that was, and remains, its principal enterprise. At the same time, it had a diverse and skilled employment base that included yeomen, husbandmen, cloth workers, shearmen, tanners, and the like. Walsham's Church of St Mary is centrally located at the intersection of its main street and Church Way. The pre-Reformation village had four religious guilds: Blessed Virgin Mary, St Trinity (1446), St John Baptist (1446), and St Catherine (1521), and a guildhall. Its population was listed as sixty-one residents in 1086, ninety taxpayers in 1283, twenty-two taxpayers in 1327, sixty-seven taxpayers in 1524, 4-600 persons in 1577, and 3-400 adults in 1603.Ray Lock, ‘The Black Death in Walsham-le-Willows,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology and History (1992), 317; Wendy Goult, West Suffolk, np; Claude Morley, ‘A Check–List of the Sacred Buildings of Suffolk, to which are Added Gilds,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 19 (1925–6), 207.

Lock describes Walsham as lying within 'an area of dense and wealthy population.' On the eve of the Black Death in 1349, the population of Walsham was greater than at any time before or since, but between March and June of 1349 the pandemic killed half the parish’s population. Walsham’s population would never again exceed its pre-plague numbers. The short-term effects of the Black Death were dire, with poverty among survivors and many tenements and messuages abandoned, but the manorial and religious institutions remained intact and economic and social life soon adapted and recovered.

Walsham Manor passed to a succession of landlords through the centuries, absorbing sub-manors as time passed. During the years which saw the generation of records related to the Walsham game place, the lords of Walsham Manor were George Talbot, seventh earl of Shrewsbury (lord from 1497), Charles Brandon, duke of Suffolk (from 1533), and Sir Nicholas Bacon (from 1581).

Walsham earned a place in this collection because of one cluster of records, all having to do with its famous game place. Of Walsham, one wonders if there is something detectable in its records that might explain why, among more than 500 Suffolk parishes, it would have one of Suffolk's three confirmed, purpose-built, medieval outdoor playing places (plus one of the innumerable other outdoor recreational sites dotting the countryside)? If so, that something is hard to pinpoint with certainty.

Lock describes Walsham as an 'unremarkable’ place in that it had no great religious house, no noble family, no industrial development, and no cataclysmic political events. The lords of its three manors appear to have exercised no absolute hegemonic control over the village. Those qualities may offer some clues as to why Walsham might have had a site used only for plays. Though nominally a village, Walsham acted like a town, governed by its laity and religious guilds. In 1496 and 1497 the owner of the land that included Walsham's camping close and playing site gave that land to the church of Walsham to be used, for its benefit, by the guild of the Blessed Virgin Mary and by the other guilds of the parish.In 1505–6 Thetford Priory paid 16d 'in regard to Walsham game et Gyslyngham,' likely when the two parishes came to Thetford to announce a play and seek support. The wording of the entry is less than clear, but it appears to be saying that the play was to be produced at Walsham, and that Gislingham was co–producing or otherwise assisting with it. The famous Rickinghall Fragment (see abbey of Bury St Edmunds records text for 1369–70) is a snippet of dialogue in Norman French and English from a history play surviving on a fragment of manorial court roll. So we can know that at least three of the villages edging Allwood Green had drama and that two of them certainly collaborated with each other in that enterprise. The five parishes also shared common grazing provided by Allwood Green, another indication of their ties and understandings. All five also had medieval guildhalls. The only other indications of Walsham's early entertainments—the surrender of a rood of land at the Maypole in 1318 and a ploughale in 1392—further indicate festive customary entertainments by the laity in Walsham (Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 131, 158, 320–21; Lock, Court Rolls, pp 68, 34-5, 179. Lock defines ploughale as 'boonwork at ploughtime when ale and food were provided by the lord' (p 213).

Fourteen other villages and towns have left small, but significant, evidences of their local dramatic, customary, and musical traditions. They include Bardwell, Cratfield, Creeting St Mary, Dennington, Hadleigh, Huntingfield, Long Melford, Metfield, Mildenhall, Newmarket, Rickinghall, Stoke by Nayland, Sudbury, and Walberswick. They are briefly described in the headnotes to their Records.

div.head: Families
div.p: Three magnates dominated the redistribution of landholding in Norman Suffolk—William Malet, Roger Bigod and Richard FitzGilbert (along with some seventy lesser Norman lords) chosen by William I to ensure the subjection of a key strategic county with strong Anglo-Scandinavian sympathies. Roger Bigod or Bigot (d. 1107) controlled the towns of Bungay and, Ipswich, the strategic settlements of Framlingham and Walton, together with 117 other lordships. His second son, Hugh, became the first earl of Norfolk (first creation), a line which ended in 1306. Richard de Clare (FitzGilbert, chief justice and trusted advisor and relative of William the Conqueror) held the Honour of Clare and ninety-five lordships in Suffolk. The house would end in 1314 with the death in battle of the childless Gilbert de Clare. William Malet (d. 1071), a companion of William the Conqueror who fought at the Battle of Hastings, held the Honour of Eye (the largest lordship in East Anglia) and the extraordinary number of 221 lordships in Suffolk. A successor, William Malet (d. 1121), would forfeit his English lands two generations later and be banished between 1106 and 1113, re-establishing himself in Normandy. Together, the forces of these three magnates would defeat the final invasion of a Scandinavian force near Ipswich in 1069.Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 35–6.

During the post-Norman Middle Ages, the period when Suffolk's earliest dramatic records begin, four great magnates exercised near absolute control of the county (except for several peculiars belonging mainly to the Crown or the Church): the successive abbots of Bury St Edmunds; the earls (later dukes) of Norfolk; the earls (later dukes) of Suffolk; and the earls of Clare. Their power derived from their vast land holdings, their judicial powers, their lineage, and the royal favour they enjoyed. The abbot of Bury St Edmunds, by far the most powerful of the four medieval magnates, held the Liberty of Bury St Edmunds, which encompassed all the hundreds in the western half of Suffolk, making the abbot the king’s judicial representative and the dominant landholder in half the county. His large household, including numerous sub-households managed by his officers, was comparable to any aristocrat, employing many servants and largely supplied by, the abbot's manors in the vicinity of Bury itself. The abbey’s shrine of St Edmund made the abbey a major place of pilgrimage for kings and simple people alike.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 16–18.

The earl of Norfolk, as Mark Bailey puts it, held 'the most important lay estate' in the county, with manors (including Bungay and Framlingham) strategically placed along the rivers of east Suffolk. Before the Conquest, two English-born Bretons had held the title, earl of Norfolk, but the first major dynasty to hold the lordship was five descendants of Roger Bigod, ending with the fifth earl, Roger Bigod who died childless in 1306 and had disinherited his brother, thus ending the creation. The second creation began with its first duke, Thomas de Mowbray, and ended with the death of the fourth duke, John de Mowbray, in 1476. The third creation began with, John Howard, who as son of Sir Robert Howard and Margaret, daughter of Thomas Mowbray, of Stoke by Nayland inherited the Mowbray lands and titles. This creation continues under the Howards to this day. Both the Mowbray and Howard creations have yielded dramatic records for this collection, as have records related to the earls (later dukes) of Suffolk, who held manors in east and north-east Suffolk. The earls of Suffolk (first creation) were members of the de la Pole family, from William de la Pole (d. 1450), fourth earl and first duke of Suffolk through Edmund de la Pole (d. 1513), the third duke, who was beheaded by Henry VIII in 1513. The first duke of the second creation was Charles Brandon (d. 1545). The title became extinct with the death of Brandon's younger son, Charles in 1551. The third creation had but one duke, Henry Grey, father of Lady Jane Grey, executed in 1554 during the reign of Mary.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 17; John Martin Robinson, The Dukes of Norfolk, rev ed (Oxford, 1995), 1–9.

The earl of Clare held seven Suffolk manors at Domesday, including three large manors at or near the borough of Clare itself. A Norman family that took its name from that place held the vast Honour of Clare, spread across England and Wales. Otherwise, the landholdings of the great English aristocratic families in the county were limited. The earl of Oxford of Castle Hedingham, Essex, held three Suffolk manors, including Lavenham; the prior and convent of Ely held four manors and a handful of privatized hundreds as the Liberty of St Ethelreda in East Suffolk; and the bishopric of Ely held eight Suffolk manors. Several women were comparable aristocratic landlords in Suffolk, among them Elizabeth de Burgh who inherited the Clare estate, Alice de Bryne of Acton, and Katherine de Norwich, of Mettingham and Norwich.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 16–18. Performance records survive for four of these great landlords (the abbots of Bury, the Howards, Charles Brandon, and Alice de Bryne).

The medieval aristocracy in Suffolk stood atop a society largely controlled by lesser lay landlords that, as superbly analyzed by Mark Bailey, was sophisticated and complex in ways unique to East Anglia in general and Suffolk in particular. The description that follows draws substantially on Bailey's work.See especially Medieval Suffolk, pp 10–35. All of Suffolk's landlords—whether aristocrats, gentry, minor lay landlords, rectors and landlords of smaller monasteries, or prominent local freemen—shared common goals: to own land as the principal source of status; to accrue wealth by exploiting that land either directly or by leasing to a third party; and to rise in rank by marriage or some other means, within the hierarchical strictures of the times. Yet for all our focus on the aristocrats holding land within the county, whether lay (dukes, marquesses, earls, viscounts, and barons) or ecclesiastical, (bishops, abbeys and priories), the archetypal lord in Suffolk was a low status gentry lords of modest means holding at most two or three small manors, most of whom came to be known as gentlemen in later centuries, plus rectors and smaller monastic landlords. On the lowest rung were prominent local freemen, with perhaps a hundred acres of land aspiring to the status of lesser gentry. The Suffolk landscape is littered with timber-framed hall houses, and the remains of small moats, which lesser landlords built not for defense but to assert their higher social status from the peasantry around them in stylish imitation of the greater households.

The modest social status of local lordship, and the small size of manors, is unusual by national standards, and may offer insights into the development of local drama in Suffolk because of the insights it affords into Suffolk local culture. As Bailey points out, much of England had a 'strong manorial structure' (that is, a strong single lordship, high proportion of villein tenants, and coterminality with a village or parish bearing the manor's name). Suffolk, however, had a 'weak manorial structure' (that is, many small manors dominated by free tenures, landlords of lower rank, communities divided among many minor lordships, strong 'social and economic individualism,' and, because of all that, 'higher levels of economic development'). Though nominally seignorial, many Suffolk communities derived their unity and communal structures not from a lord but from their parochial identity, their confraternities, their inter-community bonds; and their shared commercial interests and trading systems.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 27; Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 392–3. However, save for their chance appearances in parish and civic records, land transactions and the occasional will, most of these minor lay landlords are unknowable in any detail before the Reformation.

The Reformation brought the greatest sudden elevation of families since the Norman Conquest, and the extinction of the holdings of Suffolk's wealthiest land-holding magnate, the abbot of Bury St Edmunds. As Blackwood succinctly describes it, Henry VIII granted or sold 146 manors, formerly held by the church, to sixty-two people, a group that included: Anne of Cleves (Henry’s fourth wife); five members of the nobility (the dukes of Suffolk and Norfolk, the earls of Essex and Oxford, and Lord Darcy of Chiche); two diocesan entities (deans and chapters of Ely and Norwich); two Suffolk lawyers (Sir Humphrey Wingfield and Henry Payne); five merchants (William Rede, Sir Thomas Gresham, Adam Winthrop, Paul Withipoll, and most notably Thomas Kitson); eight royal officials (including Sir Nicholas Bacon, far and away the most significant of the eight); three officials who worked for the dukes of Suffolk and Norfolk; and thirty-one additional members of the gentry, mainly from Suffolk (most notably Thomas Bacon, Sir William Drury).Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 83–9. With the Reformation, for the first time in history Suffolk families would be distinguished from each other on the basis of theological difference. See headnotes to records of individual families for discussion of both their biographies and their residences.

Records (both documentary and literary), together with the numerous play texts that survive, show that medieval and early modern Suffolk had an extraordinarily rich fabric of playing traditions. Many of those traditions flourished concurrently within the county’s complex social, religious, and political environment.

This collection contains a wealth of evidence from a great variety of sources, but readers experienced with REED editions will notice that it lacks two classes of documents typically found there. Because Suffolk was part of the diocese of Norwich, under the authority of the bishop of Norwich, most of the voluminous court records generated by the diocese, in which those of Norfolk and Suffolk are intermingled, are kept at the Norfolk Record Office in Norwich. For that reason, work on the Suffolk ecclesiastical court records is being deferred until concentrated work on the Norfolk records commences following completion of the Suffolk collection. In due course, Suffolk records emerging from the work on Norfolk will be integrated into the Suffolk edition, an easy task with a digital publication.

The evolution of the Suffolk quarter sessions courts too involves complexities which account for their untypically thin contribution of material for a REED edition. Suffolk quarter sessions were organized into four divisions, which each met once a year in Beccles, Bury St Edmunds, Ipswich and Woodbridge. Today, most early records of their sessions are housed at Suffolk Archives in Ipswich. As was a typical impulse in Suffolk, municipal corporations ‘sought to obtain their own Sessions of the Peace to exclude the county authorities.' Borough courts took on much of the traditional business of sessions themselves. Further, the evolving courts often found themselves handling both criminal and administrative matters, reducing detail in entries of potential interest.David Allen, Ipswich Borough Archives 1255–1835 (Woodbridge, 2000), 43, 91–2.

The earliest surviving written references to drama in early Suffolk occur in book lists and catalogues to the library at the abbey of Bury St Edmunds. In the eleventh century the library had two copies of Prudentius’ Psychomachia. By the second quarter of the twelfth century Abbot Anselm had brought an emphasis on the Feast of the Immaculate Conception and ‘the stories of the Virgin’s miracles.’ By the mid-twelfth century the abbey library had a volume containing the complete works of Plautus and Terence. And by the mid- to late-thirteenth century, the library had a copy of Seneca’s Tragedies. The presence of these books provides no evidence that any of these plays was performed at the Abbey during that period, but it does confirm a local awareness of matters theatrical from a very early time.R.M. Thomson, ‘The Library of Bury St. Edmunds Abbey in the Eleventh and Twelfth Centuries,’ Speculum 47.4 (October 1972), 623, 631, 633, 620.

The records of actual events having performative content in Suffolk begin with tournaments. The earliest tournaments in Suffolk, those in the late twelfth and early thirteenth centuries, were, as typically of the period, warlike melees—very destructive in that they ‘ranged over such a wide area of countryside,’ and, therefore, do not appear to have been mimetic in the sense used in this book. The earliest such tournament in Suffolk occurred at a site between Bury and Thetford in 1194. Its aftermath, but not the melee itself, included a rowdy bout of singing and dancing by the knights at Bury.Juliet V. Barker, The Tournament in England 1100–1400 (Woodbridge, 1986), 10, 51, 12. By the fourteenth century, tournaments—now called ‘hastiludi’—had evolved from pure melees into forms of entertainment with metaphorical elements of mock warfare. In Richard Barber’s words, the ‘hastiludi’ had become ‘knightly prowess as visual entertainment, even theatre.’ ‘Hastiludi’ characteristically included mimetic processions, feasting, elaborate costumes and masks, scenery, trumpets and other musical instruments, though Suffolk documents do not confirm those elements in Suffolk ‘hastiludi.’ Notably, great numbers of costumed women of rank took part, as attested by royal accounts from the period. Expenses of Edward the Black Prince related to a tournament at Bury St Edmunds in 1348 certainly contained rewards to minstrels, and lavish spending on garments for noble women who took part in the event, but say nothing more descriptive about the proceedings.Richard Barber, Edward III and the Triumph of England: The Battle of Crécy and the Company of the Garter (London, 2013), 70–1, 76–7, 82–3, 73, 75, 74. East Anglian tournaments (both licensed by the king and unlicensed) include these: in 1194 (Richard I) at a site between Bury and Thetford, followed by singing and dancing at Bury; in 1310 (Edward II) at Sudbury (planned, but prohibited); in 1328 (Edward III) at Thetford, Norfolk, 25 September, near border with Suffolk; in 1331 (24 May–4 June) and in 1334 (February), both at Newmarket; in 1341 (20 February) and 1350 (6 December), both at Norwich; in 1344, at Bungay, between 15 November–30 December; and in 1348 at Bury St. Edmunds, circa February. See Barber, Appendix 4, pp 520–524 for dates and locations of all of Edward III’s tournaments. Other ‘hastiludi’ of this kind are recorded in Suffolk in the reign of Edward II at Bungay, Newmarket, and Sudbury, and early in the reign of Edward III at Bury.TNA: C66/133, mb 18 (Bungay and Newmarket); C 66/131, mb 9 and C 66/138, mbs 4–5 (Newmarket); C 66/133, mb 18 (Sudbury); and E 101/391/15 (Bury).

div.head: Local Drama and Civic Ceremony
div.p: The jewel of performance in early Suffolk is its multifarious traditions of locally produced religious and civic drama and mimetic customs. Together, they present a picture of a complex culture steeped in performance. But scribal usage, particularly laconic references to ‘game,’ 'play,’ ‘interlude,’ and ‘ale’ in the records sometimes make it difficult to know exactly to what kind of performance a scribe is referring. In some instances the records make perfectly clear that game meant play, as is the case with Bungay’s two parishes. In Holy Trinity parish, for example, the ‘game’ in parish records referred to the play (that is, the interlude) staged within the context of an elaborate church ale. The Holy Trinity game had an ‘Interlude & game Booke’ (see the Bungay records), from which the wardens paid for writing out parts in 1557–8. The Holy Trinity game also had costumes. In 1565–6 wardens borrowed apparel for playing from the earl of Surrey in Norwich.
