His house, to which they would have returned the apparel, was the duke of Norfolk’s palace, situated on the south side of the River Wensum not far from the Market Place. They paid elsewhere for the staining of certain clothing for the interlude. Following the game in 1567–8 they returned apparel to Wymondham, Norfolk (a town that had a game place, and an inventory that included 'a list of "apparel for the game players"'; thus in Wymondham too, game meant play).John Wasson and Peter Galloway (eds), Records of Plays and Players in Norfolk and Suffolk 1330–1642, Malone Society 11 (Oxford, 1980/1), 120. In 1576–7 Holy Trinity sold ‘the game players gownes & coat{es}’ from old copes; elsewhere the same account refers to 'the game players app{ar}ell.' In 1590–1 the parish sold players’ coats, apparently no longer used in community drama. The Holy Trinity game also used props. In 1557–8, a parishioner rode to Yarmouth for game gear and in 1567–8 the wardens purchased nine planks for the cloud. Holy Trinity also used a scaffold stage for its game. In 1565–6 the wardens paid for a scaffold 'for the Interlude in the churchyarde' and took a collection 'at the churche ale & game on Trinyte sondaie.' In 1566–7 they twice purchased nails for the scaffold and also paid for making and watching the scaffold. In 1567–8 they paid for disassembling the scaffold.

The interchangeable use of game, interlude, and play, as part of a church ale by Holy Trinity, Bungay, confirms that the three terms were one and the same to the scribe and the wardens for whom he was writing. A payment 'to Kelsaye the vyce for his pastyme before the plaie and after the playe both daies' and another payment for the dying of wigsfor the interlude players (both payments in 1565–6) strongly suggest that the play or game was a two-day production and was very likely a morality play. In the records that we have, it was always produced within the context of a church ale and the parish provided a dinner for the players.Lowestoft: Suffolk Record Office 116/E1/1, p 18; Lowestoft: Suffolk Record Office 115/E1/1, pp 34–5.

St Mary, Bungay, the town’s other parish, also had a game, which they mounted on Corpus Christi Day in 1542–3. The game must have been a scaffold play because the producers copied out parts from the game book in 1525–6, purchased nails for the stage in 1545–6 and 1573, and paid to strengthen the stage in 1546–7. Characters appear to have worn costumes in that the churchwardens paid for the sewing of six albs. In 1545–6 St Mary parish appears to have staged its play in the churchyard. St Mary also mounted a procession on the Friday following Corpus Christi Day. A case recorded in the court of Star Chamber indicates that the procession had at least five pageants (Heaven, the World, Paradise, Bethlehem, and Hell) that were ‘Caryed abowt the seyd Town’ on that day. The records establish no links between the play and the procession except to confirm that the Corpus Christi celebration in Bungay was a two-day event.

Walsham le Willows provides a further example of the certain interchangeability of the terms ‘game’ and ‘play.’ Late fifteenth and sixteenth century Walsham had an outdoor playing space which they called the game place, and described it as ‘made of purpose for the use of stage playes.’

A much larger number of records contain references to games or plays, but never to both in the same record, and almost never with sufficient detail to determine the precise nature of the event being recorded.

We know that three of these communities had a game only because they travelled to advertise it, as recorded by the place they visited to announce their production. Thetford Priory, bordering Suffolk in Norfolk, paid 'Walsham game et Gyslyngham' 16d in 1505–6. Both parishes lie but a few miles from Thetford. The entry appears to indicate that the two Suffolk communities were advertising their co-sponsored game. Walsham records, as mentioned above, confirm that the parish used its game place for stage plays (see below), so one might assume that game in the Thetford entry means play. In the same year (1505–6) Thetford Priory also paid Bardwell, Suffolk, for announcing its game.Register of Thetford Priory, Part 1, Cambridge, CUL: Add. MSS 6969, f 72.

The remaining references to games occur as opaque entries in parish records. Bramfield received 4d when it ‘schewed’ its game at Walberswick in 1493–4 . The town of Metfield (approximately 5 miles from Bungay) collected the extremely large amount of 11 marks 4s for its game in 1510–11, and an indeterminate amount in 1513–14, the only two references to its game that survive. Metfield also contributed to Bungay’s game in 1510. Long Melford (near Bury) kept a game in 1555–6 and again in 1556–7 . Long Melford proclaimed its game as far away as Braintree, Essex, and Ipswich, an effort that they likely would not have exerted if the game was anything but a play. Further indicating that the Long Melford game at Whitsuntide was likely a play, the parish set up thirteen seats in the churchyard for some who attended. In 1538 the fragmentary accounts of the parish of Mickfield, a tiny parish three miles west of Debenham in the centre of the county recorded receipts from its game (without providing details as to what the game entailed). In spite of the miniscule size of the parish, the records give no indication that it was aided in producing its game by other parishes.

The one reference to a play, as opposed to a game, occurs when Thetford Priory paid Mildenhall (a few miles from Thetford) 12d for announcing its play in 1505–6.Cambridge University Library, Add MS 6969, f 70. In 1504–5 Mildenhall had staged a play of St Thomas in its hall yard, at which they collected £7 in contributions for the parish. One might reasonably assume that the Mildenhall play being advertised the following year at Thetford was the same parish play of St Thomas. In 1509–10 Mildenhall paid players 13d at its May ale and in 1528 many parishioners gave contributions toward what they identified as a play called a May game. In 1540 parishioners contributed 21s for what they described as a play or church ale. Based on these records, Mildenhall appears to have used game, play, and church ale interchangeably.

In the records cited above, the word 'game' never demonstrably refers to something less than a play, and it often co-exists synonymously with the words ‘play,’ ‘interlude,’ and ‘show,' but in other cases it may well have meant some mimetic custom other than a play or interlude. The term also several times occurs in connection with a church ale. Games appear only intermittently in the records of any place, and when that happens, they appear to be major fund-raising events that drew crowds and contributors from places far outside the host community.

div.head: Local Drama
div.p: The records provide evidence that at least thirty-six Suffolk communities had productions of their own. Additionally, the Suffolk records identify three communities from Essex, one from Cambridgeshire, and two from Norfolk that also had plays, and either received support from, or extended support to, Suffolk communities in the production of their plays. In some cases, the evidence for these plays appears in churchwardens' accounts as payments or collections concerning their play's production. The evidence might be as spare as a single payment for nails or boards to repair the stage (as at Aldeburgh or Walberswick ); or as page after page of contributions made, or offerings given in support of the play; as expenses of other kinds for an elaborate production and church ale (as at Bungay); or as contributions by a host of other parishes supporting a single parish that was mounting its play (as at Boxford). In numerous other places, the evidence might be a solitary gift to players who had come to advertise their play, as in the register of Thetford Priory and at Bardwell, Walsham, and Gislingham.Cambridge University Library, Add MS 6969, f 72.

In the distribution of those places that had plays, one can see five clusters of communities. The largest cluster, with fourteen communities in northeast Suffolk, encompassed northern areas and towns along or near the Waveney River between Thetford and the coast. One could reasonably extend that group to include nearby Yarmouth and Wymondham, in Norfolk, especially since both made contributions of various kinds to plays in several of those Suffolk towns and also had plays of their own. Moving south lay a second cluster, with four places, in north-central Suffolk, an area associated with the Rickenhall fragment (see below) and the Walsham-le-Willows game place. A third small cluster including Bury St Edmunds and Long Melford lay in west-central Suffolk, as did a fourth small cluster in central Suffolk. Finally a fifth cluster involving seven communities lay in south Suffolk, in an area near the border with Essex. This cluster is the second largest one in the county. Additionally, three Essex communities near the border with Suffolk whose plays are mentioned in Suffolk records, could be added to this fifth cluster. Viewing these clusters in horizontal terms, one can see three horizontal strata in the communities with recorded plays (a northern stratum with nineteen places; a central stratum with four places; and a southern stratum with nine places). Every region of the county had parish plays, but they are most abundant in the northern parts of the county. Finally, one can see clusters or micro-clusters of communities that lie within a given hundred (notably in places on or near the border with Norfolk). It is unclear whether that distribution suggests possible links between the plays and the very ancient adminstrative institutions (such as the hundreds) that were ‘the basis of all public administration in medieval England, judicial, fiscal, and military,’ second only to the county courts until ‘superceded by the establishment of Quarter Sessions in the later Middle Ages.’Martin, ‘Hundreds and Liberties,’ in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, p 26.

Rickinghall, a village situated near a tributary of the River Waveney in northwest Suffolk, has a place in this edition because of one very significant document—the famous Rickinghall Fragment, a one-piece fragment of a medieval play. The words from the play survive on a small piece of parchment attached to an account roll from the manor of the abbey of Bury St Edmunds dated 1369–70. The medieval landlord of Rickinghall Inferior (one half of a bifurcated village) was the abbot of Bury St Edmunds.Mel Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 319–21; Goult, West Suffolk, np; and Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 49, 55, 61, and 111. The play fragment itself appears to date from the early fourteenth century. It is written in Norman French and English, with a stage direction in Latin. The collection containing the fragment came to the British Library from Redgrave Hall. Since the Hall is only about two miles from Rickinghall, the fragment appears never to have migrated very far from its original home. Whether the play was staged at Rickinghall or Redgrave Hall, or somewhere else is unclear. Rickinghall is one of five parishes bordering the immense Allwood Green.One of the five bordering parishes (Walsham–le–Willows) had an outdoor playing space; two of them (Walsham and Gislingham) advertised their play together at Thetford Priory, near the Norfolk border with Suffolk.

div.head: Corpus Christi Drama and Its Aftermath
div.p: Records of Corpus Christi drama and related Corpus Christi activities survive for five Suffolk communities: Bungay, Bury, Eye, Ipswich, and Mildenhall, ranging from 1389 to 1547.

Bury St Edmunds has the earliest recorded Corpus Christi tradition in the county, one that comes down to us in three documents only. A certificate of 1389 for the guild of Corpus Christi, listing the duties of the brothers and sisters of the guild on Corpus Christi Day, includes the holding of a mass, the wearing of hooded livery, and the providing of 'maintenance' and 'support' for a Corpus Christi interlude. The certificate does not mention a procession or pageants; however, the words 'maintenance' and 'support' suggest at least the possibility of a permanent store of play-making properties of some kind. In 1477 the Regulations of the Guild of Woolen Weavers refers to a procession of pageants and a pageant of the Ascension of God in 1477. In 1558 a civic rental and inventory refers to ‘certain pageants’ that remain from the Corpus Christi guild. Based on these few documents (transcribed in the records), in Bury (as in Ipswich) the Corpus Christi play and the procession appear to have been separate and distinct events, although the Ascension pageant (as described in the record) sounds as if it had dramatic elements. However, it is hard to know whether the dramatic elements in pageants such as this one were dumb shows or enactments within the procession.Gail McMurray Gibson has proposed that The Croxton Play of the Sacrament was written for, and performed on, the feast of Corpus Christi in Bury St Edmunds (The Theatre of Devotion: East Anglian Drama and Society in the Late Middle Ages (Chicago, 1989), 34–8, 40). She cites local allusions in the manuscript; a town configuration that meets the staging requirements of the play (‘the open market square at Angel Hill, just in front of the parish church of St James,’ p 40), and the initials ‘R.C.’ written on the manuscript that she suggests refer to the Haughley vicar Robert Cooke, whose will bequeaths all his playbooks to his brother. She sees the play as a ‘careful, polemical answer to Lollard heresy ... affirming the miracle of the Real Presence’ a theme especially appropriate to Corpus Christi (p 35). Her close analysis of the text further serves to support her thesis (pp 36–7). She also proposes that the play was produced by the town’s Corpus Christi Guild, with allusions in it to the local Guild of The Holy Name of Jesus as well (pp 38-40). She freely acknowledges that, in the absence of documentary confirmation, ‘there is no way to know with certainty’ where the play originated (p 35).

The few records that survive concerning Corpus Christi activities in Bungay provide particularly suggestive detail. In 1514 five men of Bungay brought a case to the court of Star Chamber charging that the bailiff of the town, the duke of Norfolk’s officer, Richard Wharton, together with other rioters had broken and thrown down five Corpus Christi pageants (namely, the pageants of Heaven, of the World, of Paradise, of Bethlehem, and of Hell), 'whyche were euer wont tofore to be Caryed abowt the seyd Town vpon the seyd daye' [of Corpus Christi].' In his answer, Wharton acknowledged the deed; claimed that the pageants were 'very old & auncyent' and a source of great expense; that he had made peace with the victims; and that he would assist in building new pageants. The description of the pageants suggests the possibility of a cycle of sorts. Wharton's defense suggests that pageantry and the celebration of Corpus Christi itself were not under attack; rather it was the dilapidated state of the pageants that had given rise to the trouble.

The town of Eye (in north-central Suffolk) recorded a play on Corpus Christi Day in 1536. In 1540–1 the churchwardens’ accounts of the town of Mildenhall had two successive entries—one records a receipt of money from a gathering on Corpus Christi Day; the other records a receipt of money from a gathering for the play (also called a church ale). Proximity of the two entries aside, without further details it is impossible to determine whether the play and ale occurred on Corpus Christi Day.

By far the most details of a Corpus Christi tradition appear in the Ipswich court books and civic accounts. In that important port town, responsibility for civic celebration of Corpus Christi lay with the ancient guild of Corpus Christi, which was also the city's principal governing body.

The Corpus Christi guild (originally called the Ipswich merchant guild) operated at the direction of the Great Court of all the freemen (also called the General Court). Among its manifold duties, the Great Court also supervised the annual election of the officers of the Corpus Christi guild, including the wardens of specific pageants, and appointed certain freemen of the city to guard the pageants. The wardens of the Corpus Christi guild bore entire responsibility for the city's festive and ceremonial celebration of the feast of Corpus Christi and all matters related to it. The records indicate that with the common clerk, and under the supervision of the bailiffs, the wardens periodically appointed (and the Great Court so ordered) a craftsman with special skills to attend, administer, and guard every one of the accoutrements of the pageants; to do repair of the pageants; to oversee the making of stages for the players from within the town and without; and to supervise the hiring of costumes. In 1445, for example, the court admitted John Causton as a resident burgess and hired him to be that overseer for the seven years to follow. No doubt his four sons also benefited from that arrangement.

The Corpus Christi guild used several sources of revenue to finance its Corpus Christi activities. First, in 1443 and 1445, the Great Court granted it the profits from two pieces of land: 'the Marsh' with its houses, buildings, arable lands, meadows, grazing pastures, marshes, and appurtenances; and 'the Councillors' meadow. The Court also ordered that farmers of the properties should pay 40s annually to the guild, all the resulting monies from the properties to be used for the maintenance and repair of the pageants. Second, in 1446, the alderman of the Corpus Christi guild received a monopoly to sell or trade any large stone (mill, quarry, grinding, paving, and any others unnamed) within the city. Third, all burgesses, resident and non-resident alike, were annually assessed 16d toward the work of Corpus Christi. In 1482 the Court reminded everyone that any burgess not paying his assessment stood in pain of forfeiting his status as a burgess. Fourth, in 1503 the Court appointed two of the freemen to collect the usual 50s for the pageant on Corpus Christi Day (the wording makes it unclear as to whether it was that pageant or the collecting that occurred on Corpus Christi Day), and pass it along to the person in charge. Officials also appointed a number of other people with specific responsibilities (see for example, SRO Ipswich: C/2/10/3/5, pp 434 and 548; C/2/10/3/8, p 102; BL: Add MS 24435, ff 33 and 153-3v; and numerous others).

The guild had three principal duties related to the celebration of Corpus Christi: to host the Corpus Christi feast; to produce the Corpus Christi play; and to organize the Corpus Christi procession and pageants. The first mention of the dinner occurs in 1469. In 1515 the assembly book mentions a great store of utensils, dinnerware, and related supplies, all to be carefully guarded. References to the dinner disappear from the records between 1515 and 1589, though references to the annual meeting and elections regularly appear. Responsibility for the dinner, and disputes about payment for burgesses and their wives recur in the records, which may account for the dinners' disappearance. After 1589, the dinners reappear periodically through the mid-seventeenth century, though often by seemingly reluctant wardens under duress to do so.

While crafts contributed mightily to the Corpus Christi procession with their pageants, ultimate authority over the procession, and everything in it, lay with the Corpus Christi guild. The guild’s constitution for the Corpus Christi procession provides the sequence of occupations and pageants to be followed in the procession. Participants in 1325 included fourteen companies, three groups of friars (the Carmelites, Dominicans, and Franciscans), clerics, and civic officials. The companies represented forty-nine guilds, who presented nine pageants and a tabernacle. The pageants included those of five saints (George, John, Giles, Thomas, and Luke), the Blessed Virgin Mary, a dolphin, a bull, and a ship. Some time after the original of this constitution was copied in 1530, someone crossed out, in red ink, all the pageants except the dolphin and the ship, clearly a sixteenth-century effort to expunge Catholic elements.Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 139–41, 148, 250–1, 298–9; Northeast, 'Parish Gilds,' in Dymond and Martin, Historical Atlas, pp 74–5; and Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 64–6, 275 nn 32–42. Wodderspoon, Memorials, pp 155-80.

In 1400 'The Pageant' (as the procession is called in the record), included thirteen (not fourteen) companies and forty-eight (not forty-nine) guilds, plus the three groups of friars. The companies presented eight (not nine) pageants that included images, shrines related to patron saints, contrivances, a bull, and a ship. The Friars had a tabernacle. In 1437 the Customal called ‘The Little Domesday Book’ provides a smaller list that includes a mere fifteen of what it calls 'Pageants' comprising twelve guilds, three saints (George, Giles, and Thomas), a tabernacle, the usual three orders of friars, but also the Prioress of Trinity and Saint Peter, the bailiff, and the portman.

In 1493–6 the list includes thirteen companies and forty-three guilds, but only four named pageants, all of them pageants of saints (George, Giles, John, and Thomas). The procession includes gentlemen, but makes no mention of clerics, a tabernacle, the friars, or town officers. In 1495 a list of payments for Corpus Christi includes four saints and eleven guilds only, but payments by no one else. A final list, c 1500–8, the last one before the Reformation, has forty-eight guilds in fourteen companies, with eight pageants that include a dolphin, a ship, and six saints (Giles, George, John, Luke, Thomas, and the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary).

It is not possible to know if the pageants of the dolphin, the bull, the Assumption, or the various saints also included acting with speeches, but descriptions of the duties assigned to Causton and later to King certainly do not seem specific to the pageant of the ships only, and in 1493 Ipswich had elected a resident burgess for 'making and correcting the book of Corpus Christi.' At least one of the pageants, described in 1473 as 'the tabernacle of St Thomas the Martyr' does seem a likely candidate to have been a tableau vivant. It also seems likely that the pageants were large structures. An order in 1493 sets aside money, as the Council had done the previous year, 'for the maintenance of the pageant the same sum for the craftsmen.’

It is impossible to sort out the precise relationship between the Corpus Christi procession, with its pageants, and the Corpus Christi play, with its stages. The entire celebration is suffused with performance. Over the course of time, the terminology used in the records shifts. Early on the records rather formally distinguish between the procession and the play. But in 1503 the town's recorder refers to the whole procession as 'the pageant,' and sometimes as 'the pastime.' In 1531 the town laid aside the play forever, but in 1542 an order decreed that every householder was to follow the pageants of Corpus Christi.

The elements of the procession suggest a carefully organized, pious—yet spectacle-filled—event, confirmed by the reference in one record to a Corpus Christi Book. The procession included tableaux vivants but the description of the ship pageant as having speeches from within indicates elements of characterization and dialogue as well, and a pageant of considerable size, as did the pageant of the Dolphin. If the pageant of the Assumption resembled other Assumption pageants in the East Midlands, it likely included machinery and several visual levels.See Barbara D. Palmer, ‘Staging the Virgin’s Body: Spectacular Effects of Annunciation and Assumption,’ The Early Drama, Art, and Music Review 21.2 (Spring 1999), 63–80; and James Stokes, ‘Staging Wonders: Ritual and Space in the Drama and Ceremony of Lincoln Cathedral and its Environs,' Ritual and Space in the Middle Ages, Francis Andrews (ed), Harlaxton Medieval Studies 21 (Donington, 2011), 197–212. See especially pp 210–12, and n 31.

The Corpus Christi play appears to have been a separate event from the procession within the larger celebration of Corpus Christi: the play was a fixed-site production that used scaffold stages, whereas the pageants were processional.

Clearly, the Corpus Christi celebration in Ipswich had unbroken access to great show-producing skill during much of the fifteenth century. In 1445 the Council hired a man, John Causton, who 'will make provision and arrangements concerning the repair of the pageants and for the construction of the stages for the actors both from the town and outside.' Causton, the common clerk, and the bailiffs were to be responsible for 'incurring all and each of the expenses both for the repair of the pageants and for the hiring of the arrayment, clothing, and other necessaries which will be necessary for the said pageants.'Suffolk Archives, Ipswich, C/2/10/1/1, mb 1d.

As Philip Butterworth and Michael Spence show, Ipswich had the services of William Parnell, a master property player, during the second half of the fifteenth century.Philip Butterworth and Michael Spence, ‘William Parnell, Supplier of Staging and Ingenious Devices, and his Role in the Entry of Elizabeth Woodville into Norwich in 1469,’ Medieval English Theatre 40 (2018), 8, 13, 22, 26–7, 31, 33. Their article studies the entry of Queen Elizabeth Woodville into Norwich in 1469 by exploring in great detail the contributions to production of the plays and spectacles created for the entry by Parnell, a theatrical producer from Ipswich who had ‘undoubted’ theatrical skill, and ‘who regularly supplies ingenious devices for plays and stations’ in that town. In Norwich Parnell worked with William Bisshope, and a number of men whom Parnell had brought from Ipswich ‘to work with him.’ The authors describe in great detail the platform stages and dressings that Parnell and his crew built and ‘some kind of three-dimensional structured edifice surrounding the gate under which the Queen entered the city.’ He also supplied two giants and costumes for two (or more) patriarchs, three empresses, twelve apostles, and sixteen virgins.

Later (in 1474), the by-then famous Parnell together with his son, John, and William Baker (all from Ipswich), would build 'a wooden semi-automaton known as the "Iorge"' at the church of St Botolph in London.Butterworth and Spence, ‘ William Parnell,’ p 26. In 1479 he built something called a ‘dozzer’ for Ipswich and the court records there describe him as in charge of the Corpus Christi pageants, procession and all that pertained to them. Butterworth and Spence describe him as being the second earliest known property player in East Anglia (preceded only by John Causton, of Ipswich). By 1505 Parnell’s son, John, had followed in his father’s footsteps in Ipswich, as one who worked on the Corpus Christi play there. He is also recorded as making the pageants on Corpus Christi Day in Dunmow, Essex in 1527/8.Butterworth and Spence, ‘William Parnell,’ pp 32–3 and 33 n 57.

In 1493 the guild hired one John Regner to repair the book of Corpus Christi (among other Corpus Christi-related duties). Whether that book was an ordinal for the procession or a play text, the records do not say. Other than reference to the stages, assembly books offer no other detail concerning the Corpus Christi play in Ipswich. Whether or not to produce the play was apparently a problem for the city in the early sixteenth century. Although they almost always held the dinner through 1514, officials cancelled both the dinner and the play in 1515, 1517, 1519, and 1520, and cancelled only the play in 1522, 1529, and 1530. In 1531 the city ordered that the play be laid aside forever, whereas the pageants continued to flourish. The city gives no reason for abandoning the play but there was an explosive political environment of protest in Suffolk during those years. In Bungay, for example, in 1537, the duke of Suffolk spent considerable effort pursuing the maker of a play satirizing the king and fomenting sedition.

Following the suppression of the feast of Corpus Christi in 1548, the former Corpus Christi guild emerged as the merchant guild. From 1565 through 1634 the guild paid minstrels to perform at its annual feast, which they also called ‘the Guild.’ In Elizabethan and Jacobean Ipswich drama and ceremony gradually re-emerged as civic drama, processions, feasts and ceremonies. In 1563–4 the council paid the town players on 17 November, but whether the players were celebrating the Queen’s coronation, the entry does not say. At least some of the pageants in the town’s huge civic procession certainly had dramatic elements. In 1583 the council reimbursed John King who 'lately made [a] shewe of a certen pageant in forme of a Shippe with certen convenynt speches therin' for the feast of the merchant guild.' (See discussion of King below.). A pageant of the ship had first been mentioned in the city records more than sixty years earlier, in 1521, so that pageant had a life cycle spanning much of the sixteenth century. Between 1588 and 1600 the town mounted a celebration of Coronation Day and on another day in 1588–9, a triumph (to celebrate the defeat of the Spanish Armada). Celebrations of Coronation Day (also known as Queen’s Day) were mounted nine times, in 1582–3, 1584, 1587–8, 1588–9, 1590 , 1590–1, 1592 , 1594–5, and 1599–1600. Observance of Coronation Day lapsed during James I, but reappeared three times during Charles I, in 1632-3, 1634–5, and 1636. Coronation Day celebrations included pageants during the 1580’s, a show in 1594–5, and a stage (purpose unknown) in 1599–1600. Otherwise the records included payments for music, speeches, and drumming only.

div.head: Staging
div.p: The records indicate that scaffold staging was the dominant method of production for local parish plays in Suffolk. The records also include payments for pageants but their number is smaller. Sometimes however, scaffold staging and pageants occur in the same performance setting. The evidence for staging, however fragmentary and opaque, occurs in the records of eleven communities.

Ipswich is one of only three towns in Suffolk (the other two being Bungay and Bury St Edmunds) whose records mention both pageants and scaffold stages, and do so in both pre- and post-suppression incarnations. Ipswich is the only one of the three to record using pageants and scaffold stages in connection with a single event—the celebration of the feast of Corpus Christi.

In two instances, the Aldeburgh churchwardens made payments for what may be the building or assembling of scaffold stages. In 1571–2 they paid 6d 'for nayles to mak the stagis,' and in 1574–5 'for carieng of staging & Ropes for ye church.'In 1573–4, the Aldeburgh wardens paid 10s ' To ye earle of Lecesters menne when thei plaied in ye church ye xxti of Ivne,’ but whether the players used scaffold staging the records do not say. A single reference to staging occurs in the Boxford records, in 1547–8, when the wardens paid 6d ' to forbye for helpynge of the Wryghter of the churche to make hys stagynge' (Suffolk Archives EE 1/I/2/1). As discussed earlier, the town of Bungay used both pageants and scaffold staging, but they appear to have been used on different kinds of occasions—the pageants in Corpus Christi processions, the scaffold stages in plays at church ales in the churchyard.

As early as 1477 Bury St Edmunds was using pageants in processions. In that year, the regulations of the Woolen Weavers decreed that if a warden of that guild failed to carry out his duties toward the guild, half of his fine should ‘go to the sustentacion & mayntenance of the payent [pageant] of the Assencion of our lord god and of the yiftys of the holy gost as yt hath be customed of olde tyme owte of mynde yeerly to be had to the wurshepe of god amongge other payenttes in the procession in the ffeste of Corpus christi.' The tradition had apparently died away well before 1558 because in that year pageants were included in an inventory of defunct items. Whether it had been revived during the reign of Mary (after being suppressed in 1547), the records do not say. By this point local plays were being staged in houses or halls, usually by the schoolmaster and his students, and an occasional travelling company. The first and only reference to scaffolding occurs very late, in 1639, when the schoolmaster, Mr. Stevens, was to be reimbursed for ‘... all the charges that shalbe layd out & disbursed for the makynge of a stage at the Abby for a Com{m}odye for the entertaynem{en}t of the high sheriff of the County of Suffo{lk} that now is: & the seid stage to be kept & the serues to the vse of the Schoole...' So by the mid-sixteenth century only the schoolmaster and his school boys were apparently using scaffold staging in Bury.

Hadleigh certainly used scaffold staging during the sixteenth century. In 1547 the churchwardens paid ' ffor makyng ye stage yn the chorche & ffor nayls.' In 1597 the privy council, having heard of the town of Hadleigh's intention ‘...to make ce{r}taine Stage playes at this tyme of the Whitson holydaies next ensuinge; and thether to draw a Concourse of people out of the Country thereaboute{s} pretending heerein the benefit of the Towne...' issued an order prohibiting '...the Officers and all others in the Towne of Hadley not to goe forward w{i}th the sayd playes, and to Cause the Stage prepared for them to be plucked downe....'

Walberswick churchwardens’ accounts contain three payments for staging in the second half of the fifteenth century. In 1450 the wardens paid 'herdelys for the staging.' In 1496–7 they paid 'Iamys symson & Rychard howlet & Iohn sstanton for helpyng to make the stage for ther herys & bordyng.'The Walberswick records also make one reference to a piece of theatrically–informed 'machinery.' The will of John Almyngham from 1500–9 requests that there be made 'a Canope over the hygh auter well don wyth our lady and iiij aungelys & the holy gost goyng vp & down wyth a Chyme' (JIM PLEASE PROVIDE A SHELFMARK FOR THIS RECORD) Almyngham’s description suggests the possibility that this was a mechanism for enacting the Assumption and/or Coronation of the Blessed Virgin Mary, a kind of device common in celebrations of the Assumption that were ubiquitous in England. See for example, the enactment of the Assumption and Coronation of Mary (certainly on a much bigger scale) in Lincoln Cathedral on St Anne’s Day (Stokes, Lincolnshire, vol 1, pp 118–20, et passim). Peter Northeast describes several similar constructions in Suffolk churches ( ‘Suffolk Churches in the Later Middle Ages,’ East Anglia’s History: Studies in Honour of Norman Scarfe, Christopher Harper, Carole Rawcliffe, and Richard G. Wilson (eds) (Woodbridge, 2002), 100–1). This payment in 1496–7 occurred within a unique six-year period of recorded dramatic activity in which Walberswick received 20s from a church ale when their own game was held (1492–3); paid 3d in the same year when Wenhaston ‘schowyd’ its own game in Walberswick; paid 4d when Bramfield showed its game in Walberswick (1493–4); and collected 13s 4d from its own game (1494–5). This outburst of dramatic activity suggests that the staging was perhaps related to one or more of those events.

div.head: Local Playing Circuits and Patronage
div.p: The Suffolk records provide considerable evidence of inter-parish networking concerning their plays throughout Suffolk, south Norfolk, and north Essex (such circuits certainly did not stop at county borders). Records from twelve communities contain evidences of inter-parish playing circuits and support among eighty-two communities. Because the records are inevitably fragmentary, likely other instances of inter-parish cooperation in matters of custom, ceremony, and performance existed. Many of the places that had their own players were villages. To cite one example, Sir John Howard, of Tendring Hall in Stoke-by-Nayland, paid the players of the hamlet of Thorington Street; he also hosted amateur troupes from five towns in Essex (Billericay, Chelmsford Coggeshall, Colchester, and Esterford), and from the towns of Hadleigh and Lavenham. Stoke by Nayland also networked its own parish play. The Boxford churchwardens' accounts each year between 1529–30 and 1533–4 contain small payments for bread and drink given 'to Stoke play' (presumably gifts to men from Stoke by Nayland travelling to announce their play). Similarly, in 1535 Boxford recorded that Nayland (five miles south of Boxford, not the same place as Stoke by Nayland) had contributed 21s 8d to the Boxford play.London, BL: Add. MS 46349, f 102v (Stoke–by–Nayland); London, SA MS 76, f 84v (Thorington), f 105v (Coggeshall, Essex), f 106 (Hadleigh), f 107v (Esterford, Kelvedon, Essex); London, SA MS 77, f 31v Coggeshall, Essex), f 134v (Chelmsford, Essex), f 136 (Lavenham) and Suffolk Archives, Bury, FB 77/E2/2, pp 6, 8, 21, 30, and p 33 (Nayland, 5 miles south of Boxford); Cambridge, PCL: Framlingham L 2, p 41 (Billericay, Essex, Hadleigh and Lavenham).

Local troupes also occasionally travelled to perform well beyond local circuits. The players of Hadleigh, for example, performed at Canterbury on 10 September 1538, for which they were paid 20d by the city chamberlain. James M. Gibson (ed), Kent: Diocese of Canterbury, REED, vol 1 (London and Toronto, 2002), 149.

The evidence of local networking among villages and towns about which we can know something (however fragmentary) includes the parishes of Boxford, Bungay, Dennington, Long Melford, Metfield, Mildenhall, Stoke-by-Nayland, Walsham-le-Willows, Wattisfield and Walberswick, and the fifty-nine other communities mentioned in their records.

The density and ubiquity of the venues is extraordinary. Why individual networks developed in the ways they did defies easy answers. It appears to have been a matter of shared economic and historical interests, but perhaps also other local factors now less apparent to us. No one place (for example, Ipswich or Bury) was the single centre of dramatic activity in the county. Suffolk might more usefully be described as a series of micro-cultures, each with distinctive playing traditions within a common culture and bonds unique to each micro-culture. For example, as the county’s major city, Ipswich performance traditions included a civic Corpus Christi celebration with pageants and drama. Ipswich records have left no evidence of networking beyond the city. On the other hand, in the liberty of St Edmund, which encompassed all of west Suffolk, the management and farming of the vast manorial lands there devolved during the late medieval period from its manorial landlord, the abbot of Bury St Edmunds, to towns and villages. Glebe lands transferred by the abbot to the communities included camping closes, two of which (at Beccles and Walsham) included pieces of land identified in the records as game places, the one at Walsham certainly used for staging plays. Many communities, however small, had their own annual play, sometimes co-produced with their neighbors, and for which they travelled and advertised. Conversely, cloth-making communities in south Suffolk cooperated, sometimes in great number, to produce an occasional play for a community engaged in upgrading its church. And finally, the parts of east Suffolk controlled by the duke of Norfolk, notably the area north and south of the River Waveney, and from Stoke-by-Nayland to Framlingham, financed their own plays but provided considerable hospitality to visitors. They received production assistance from as far away as Norwich because of their connection there with their patron, the duke of Norfolk.

In the interests of accuracy, it seems important to stress that Suffolk’s playing circuits had nothing to do with county boundaries. Notably, those in north and south Suffolk extended well into Norfolk and Essex. The two identified sites in Norfolk (Yarmouth and Wymondham) both had strong local playing traditions, and Yarmouth had a game place, which scholars have determined was used for plays. Playing there must have shared theatrical conventions with towns in north Suffolk, because both Norfolk towns lent playing gear to Suffolk productions. The four towns in north Suffolk and south Norfolk were similarly important, but in different ways. Walsham was an agricultural hub; Beccles was the most important port town on the River Waveney. Yarmouth was the major North Sea Port in the area; and Wymondham was an important market and abbey town. Thetford, in Norfolk, welcomed local players from numerous other Suffolk communities who were announcing their own plays. Players from a number of Essex communities, including Coggeshall and Chelmsford, made their way into Suffolk, as did those from Suffolk go into Essex. The complex matter of local playing circuits in Suffolk deserves considerable further study.

div.head: Christmas
div.p: Boy bishops received rewards at the abbey of Bury St Edmunds in >each year for which we have records between 1417–18 and 1536–7. Customarily the boy bishop received 12d, although in three instances he received 4d. The clerks of St Nicholas received rewards at three venues. Sir John Howard gave the clerks of St Nicholas 8d at Stoke-by-Nayland in 1466 (Stoke had a chapel of St Nicholas, but whether related to the clerks is entirely unclear). Mettingham College gave the clerks 6d in 1399–1400 and 1403–4. At Boxford in 1466 John Cowper bequeathed a mitre and staff for the feast of St Nicholas to the parish church. In 1541–2 the Boxford church received 20d from Richard Clark for a red coat of St Nicholas. The boy bishops and their retinue differed from the clerks of St Nicholas only in that the St Nicholas clerks were somewhat older than the boy bishops and had advanced into minor orders. The activities of both boy bishops and St Nicholas clerks on St Nicholas Day (6 December) or the feast of the Holy Innocents (28 December) were characteristically ‘an opportunity for disguising and role reversal, involving parody by choirboys and students of their techers and masters.’Gibson, Kent, vol 1, pp lxxxvi–vii, and ccxi, nn 61–3. The Suffolk records give no glimpses into the nature of the ceremony as practiced there except that it was formal, mimetic, and included costumes and props for the boy who played the bishop.

Christmas entertainments turn up at ten locations (primarily private households and religious foundations—see the section on Households) in Suffolk records between the thirteenth century and 1573. Parish documents contain a paucity of references to Christmas entertainments. Most striking concerning Christmas entertainments is the great number of payments to amateur troupes with a named leader, and a troupe of between four and eight players, most of them in households and once in Ipswich. These troupes were often local, but they might come from places rather far afield (the players of Norwich or of Dunwich at Mettingham College, or the players of Coggeshall and Chelmsford, Essex, at Stoke-by-Nayland). A number of minstrels performed at Christmas too, most copiously at Mettingham College. Minstrels and players there are easily distinguishable in that entries for minstrels invariably just record the amount (item given to minstrels,’ for example), the presumption being that they were making music, whereas payments to players (whether ‘luzori,’ the parish clerk and his fellows, or another descriptor) usually also indicate that the payments were for playing (‘ludentes’ or a similar form). The third interesting feature of the records of Christmas performances is the number of sizable-looking productions (see the section on Households).

Lords of Misrule turn up at Mildenhall and Dennington; two professional troupes and a troupe of schoolboys at Ipswich in 1563–5; a St Nicholas night gathering at Mickfield in 1538; and an Epiphany ale at Brundish in 1541–2.

In Boxford the accounts list money collected on Plough Monday (which included a supper) and at the ‘hockpot’ (an ale held at Hocktide), apparently perceived as companionate activities.This is according to Northeast, Boxford Churchwardens' Accounts, p 99. Proceeds of the two (Plough Monday and hockpot) are characteristically either mentioned as discrete items within a single entry, or as separate entries immediately proximate to each other in the account. The impression is that Plough Monday and hockpot fund-raisings in Boxford were perceived as being events similar in nature, although more money by far was collected at the Boxford hockpot than on Plough Monday.Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk Archives, FB 77/E2/2, Boxford St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, pp 1, 11, 15, 20, 24, 27, 31–34, 39, 49, 51, 56, 58, 66, 71, 77–8, 81–2, 85–6.

div.head: Summer Games
div.p: In 1363, the village of Polstead recorded a play or ‘ludus’ called a summer game or ‘somergamen.’ Twenty later entries concerning May games occur in six Suffolk communities between 1478 and 1543. While fewer in number than those for other kinds of entertainments, the May game entries that survive indicate a robust tradition in connection with May Day. In 1508–9 the churchwardens at Mildenhall recorded income from four May ales. In 1509–10 they paid players and a taborer at their May Ale. In 1510–11 they recorded receipts from two May ales. In 1528 they recorded receipts from a play called a May game (‘pro ludo vocato Maygame’). And in 1543–4 they recorded receipts from a May Day gathering. Walberswick and nearby Blythburgh had interesting connections concerning May Games . Entries in the Walberswick churchwardens’ accounts describe a May drinking; a May, with a church ale (the wording seemingly describing two separate activities, the former sounding like a May game); a May ale; and a maidens’ gathering, undated but likely a May game activity, since the other Walberswick entries involving women and maidens are, for the most part, related to the May games. In most years between 1490 and 1499 Walberswick also made annual payments to the May of Blythburgh, its neighbour. Monk Sohum had a May ale and gathering in 1565. As they survive in the records, May games were a custom mainly in coastal Suffolk, plus Stoke-by-Nayland, which is in south-east Suffolk.

div.head: Robin Hood
div.p: At Chevington in 1380–1 a manorial court fined John Osbourne, called 'lytiljohan,' for brewing and selling what he had brewed . Christopher Dyer has observed that the reference to a brewer named John by his nickname, ‘Littlejohn,’ seems to confirm the currency of Robin Hood motifs in the popular culture of Suffolk before 1380. He also wonders whether its use near the date of the Peasants’ Revolt date might ‘express lower-class antagonisms towards those in authority,’ with locals connecting the rumoured ‘collusion between the monks of Bury and Sir John Cavendish’ at a time when the struggles between the abbey and the locals in surrounding towns were explosive and violent (see the section on Households).Christopher Dyer, ‘The Rising of 1381 in Suffolk: Its Origins and Participants,’ Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 36.4 (1988): p 281.

div.head: Non-Mimetic Traditions
div.p: Traditions involving processions and ritualized activities were diverse in fifteenth-century Suffolk. None of them was more curious than the Ceremony of the White Bull, in Bury St Edmunds, in which a wealthy woman, unable to conceive a child, went in a large procession preceded by a white bull, to the Abbey where a religious ceremony praying for her conception occurred. (See Appendix 2 concerning The Ceremony of the White Bull).

While it is clear that Plough Monday observances in Suffolk parishes might have ritualized elements, there is no evidence in the records that the observances had mimetic content. However, observance of Plough Monday was an important ritualistic part of parish life in Suffolk. Of the nineteen surviving churchwardens’ accounts from the county (some mere fragments), ten record Plough Monday traditions.

Several of the accounts offer suggestive glimpses as to what Plough Monday observances might include. In Brundish ‘diverse young folks’ (perhaps a guild) gathered and presented contributions on Plough Day, and the parish reimbursed those that ‘yeden with the plowe.’Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, FC 89/A2/1, Brundish St Andrew’s Churchwardens’ Accounts and Town Book, ff 2, 3, 4, 5v, 6v, 7v, 9v, 11v–12, 15v, 22v–3.

Bungay St Mary had two torch reeves, whose sole job was to collect and declare gatherings that they made on Plough Monday. Bungay Holy Trinity torch reeves presented gatherings made on Plough Day through the end of the sixteenth century, and in 1570–1 had payments for ‘a paier of gloves for the wyttche,’ likely ‘connected with the festivities of Plough Monday.’ Wasson and Galloway, Plays and Players, p 146. Charles Cox, in his revised edition of Joseph Strutt’s The Sports and Pastimes of the People of England (London, 1801; rev ed, Detroit, 1968), cites an article in Notes and Queries (ser 2, vol 9, p 381) which observes that in Huntingdonshire during the nineteenth century, Plough Monday mummers 'were termed "Plough-Witchers"' (p 274). Whether the person playing the witch was a man or a woman is unclear, but as the records show, the wives of the town made many gatherings, and routinely presented the money in purses. From the late fifteenth century through 1541–2, Dennington also had both a gathering on Plough Monday and a ‘Wycheys gatheryng.’Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, HD 1260/1, and FC 112/E1/1, Dennington St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, ff 1, 2–2v (HD 1260/1), and ff 1v, 4v (FC 112/E1/1).

Metfield had two plough reeves (also known as plough holders) who worked closely with the two churchwardens and the parish priest to collect, protect, and convey monies gathered from both its game and from Plough Monday.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Metfield St John Baptist Churchwardens’ Accounts, FC 91/E5/7, single sheet; FC 91/E5/8, single sheet; FC 91/A7/2 (2), single sheet; FC 91/A7/2 (3), single strip. Other parishes recording Plough Monday observances include Long Melford, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk Archives, FL 509/1/15, Black Book, ff, 36–6v, 46, 89v. Horham,Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, FC 85/E1/2, Horham St Mary Churchwardens’ Account, mb 1, dorse. Huntingfield,Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, FC 57/A1/1/1–17, Huntingfield St Mary Churchwardens’ Account, pp 7, 11, 14, 21, 24, 32, 47, 61. and Cratfield.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Cratfield St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, FC 62/E1/1, ff [3, 7v, 8–8v, 10, 11v]; FC 62/E1/3, ff 15v–16, 17v, 20v, 21, 22–22v; FC 62/A6/4, loose sheet; FC 62/A6/6, loose sheet; FC 62/A6/12, loose sheet dorse.

Every pre-Reformation Suffolk parish for which we have records produced church ales as their primary source of communal festivity and fund-raising. While most ales appear to have been typical, non-performative drinkings, in three instances they may have involved something more. At its ale in 1538–9, the parish of Dennington received 3s from ‘the Wycheys gathering,’ clearly characters of some kind being represented by someone.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Dennington St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, HD 1260/1, ff [1], et passim, FC 112/E1/1, ff [1v], et passim. See also Birch, Ancient Sites, p 104–5; Goult, East Suffolk A–H, np; and Joseph Strutt, Sports and Pastimes, pp 273-4. Mildenhall typically recorded four ales annually (one by the town, one each by the hamlets of Beck Row, Holywell Row, and West Row). The ales were intertwined with a rich performative tradition, as evidenced in its May ales (see the Mildenhall records).Mildenhall St Mary and St Andrew Churchwardens’ Accounts, Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk Archives, EL 110/5/3, ff 1v. (See also Bungay ales and plays discussed earlier.) Horham held a church ale on Whit Monday at which it gathered 20s 6d.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Horham St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, FC 5/E1/2, single sheet, dorse. The number of ales sponsored in a year also varied widely, as did the day of the week and the feast days on which they were held. Of all parishes, Boxford had the greatest number of church ales (typically six each year), which appear to have been produced by guilds (Boxford was a wealthy cloth-working town).Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk Archives, Bury St Edmunds St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, FB 77/E2/2, p 1, et passim. Cratfield too had between one and six ales annually, most often occurring at Whitsuntide (ten), Hallowmas (seven) Passion Sunday in Lent (four), and at the Great Harvest. Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Cratfield St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, FC 62/E1/1, ff [1], et passim; FC 62/E1/2, ff [1]; FC 62/A6/3, ff 15v, et passim. Other parishes recording ales (with no described performative features) are Brundish,Brundish St Andrew Churchwardens’ Accounts and Town Book, Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, FC 89/A2/1, ff 2, et passim. Bardwell,Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk Archives, Bardwell St Peter and St Paul Churchwardens’ Accounts, FL 522/11/20, pp 4, et passim, and FL 222/11/22, pp 16–17, et passim. and Mickfield.

When parishes had a church house or guildhall, they held their ales there. In Fressingfield, for example, so as to avoid any longer abusing the reverence of the parish church by using it for church ales, guilds, yeardays, and other drinkings, a group of parishioners purchased lands and properties which included what would become a Church House (later to become the new guildhall), where those happenings were thereafter to be held.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Deed of Feoffment to Churchwardens, FC 90/L3/8.

While records show a great deal of inter-parish support for plays, evidence of that same support is sparse for ales. Huntingfield is a striking exception. In 1535–6 seven other communities contributed to Huntingfield’s one ale. In 1536–7 six of the same seven communities again contributed. Five of the parishes lay within two to three miles of Huntingfield; the remaining two lay about five miles away.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives, Huntingfield St Mary Churchwardens’ Accounts, FC 57/A1/1/1–17, pp 1, et passim.

div.head: Wrestling and Other Sports
div.p: In the mid-thirteenth century a Christmas wrestling occurred at the abbey of Bury St Edmunds. From 1468 the Jesus and Mary guild in the parish of Creeting St Mary records a robust festive tradition that included minstrels, a taborer, singers, and processions with torches and banners. It also records an obscure event called a ‘sporting’ that garnered ‘sporting silver.’ The nature of the event—whether it was merely something athletic, or involved something else, the records simply do not say. While the Creeting Jesus and Mary guild accounts never use the word ‘ale,’ they do include a single payment to brewers.Accounts of the Jesus and Corpus Christi Guild, TNA: E 135/2/22, ff 40v.

div.head: School Performance
div.p: Children learned the arts of performance at every level of society, whether as part of formal education, as training in a craft, or as part of family life. Suffolk's secular grammar schools incorporated entertainments, ranging from plays to oratory, civic ceremony, and cockfights. At Bury school, for example, the master provided cocks on Shrove Tuesday.

School drama in Suffolk could be sophisticated. The statutes of Bury school order that the curriculum include 'the chaster plays of Plautus and Terrance.' Suffolk schoolmasters served as playwrights, producers, and directors of plays that their students performed. Students delivered orations and otherwise contributed at civic ceremonials, sometimes to demonstrate proficiencies warranting their advancement. In the cloth-making village of Boxford, for example, the ordinances of the school dictated that before they could be promoted to a higher form, students must perform a speech.Suffolk Archives, Bury St Edmunds, GD 503/1/4, sheets 1 and 2. At Bury in 1599–1600 the feoffees of the school paid the schoolmaster 40s for a comedy made by his students at one Mr Golding's.Likely Robert Golding, esquire, a feoffee in 1582–8 and again in 1606–11. He was a governor of the school from 1583. Statham says that there may have been two men of that name (Statham, Accounts of the Feoffees, p 355). In 1607 they paid one of the scholars for delivering an oration. In 1609 the scholars of the grammar school received 2s for verse performed on the King's Day, and another 2s 6d for the verses that they made for one Mr Mawes. And in 1639 the high schoolmaster, Mr Stevens, received the considerable sum of £6 13s 4d for his expenses in producing a comedy acted by his scholars in the Abbey for the High Sheriff. The feoffees then ordered that the stage built for the comedy should be kept for the use of the school.For orations and speeches by the boys and masters of Bury St Edmunds Grammar School, not included in this collection, see Suffolk Archives, Bury St Edmunds: E5/9/203.16 [item 4] (School Account and Rental); and E5/9/203.16 [item 6] (School Account and Rental). Hadleigh had a grammar or free school that was held in the guildhall for scholars who paid £10 per year to attend. The Hadleigh schoolmaster, William Hawkins, wrote a play called Apollo Shroving, which his students acted at a carnival on Shrove Tuesday, 6 February 1625/6 (venue unknown). The play had twenty-three characters (six of them female), acted by twenty students (two of them doubling, one playing three roles). The play was clearly intended for a mixed audience.W.A.B. Jones, Hadleigh Through the Ages (Ipswich, 1977), 57. Some of Hawkins’ Latin poems were recited for members of Cambridge University who had decamped to Hadleigh during the plague in 1630.William Hawkins, Corolla Varia (Cambridge, 1634). Secular grammar school masters and their scholars received rewards for performances in many other comunities as well. For example, at Ipswich the burgesses paid Mr Scott's lads for a play before New Year's Day in 1564–5; Mr Smyth for framing an oration on Coronation Day in 1583–4; and a youth appointed by Mr Easton for a speech for the townsmen of Colchester during their visit in 1624–5. This entire group of masters had matriculated at Cambridge University, and most of them were natives of Ipswich.John Scott, headmaster of Ipswich Grammar School, 1564 (or earlier)–1567; John Smith, master of Ipswich Grammar School, 1582–5; James Leman, usher of Ipswich Grammar School, 1595–1604; headmaster 1604–8; and Mr. Easton, Master of Ipswich Grammar School, 1616–30. At Long Melford the churchwardens paid to mend windows broken at the schoolmaster's play in 1579–80. At Boxford scholars made speeches before the wardens and governors of the school in 1632 as evidence supporting their promotion . (See the sections on Households and Waits and Other Musicians for sponsorship of child performers in contexts other than secular grammar schools.)

div.head: Religious Houses
div.p: Evidence of their great support of parish drama, custom, and music survive in the records of several religious houses. Most notable among them are the registers of Mettingham College, which record payments to performers of every kind, from professional troupes to parish players, from minstrels to boy bishops, from bearwards to jesters, from dancers to fools, over a 250-year period. Several small priories record payments to parish players and waits (Bungay Priory), a king and queen of the May and a harpist (Felixstowe Priory), and professional minstrels (Ipswich Priory). Strikingly, however, while the abbey at Bury St Edmunds paid many important professional troupes, as well as its own boy bishops, surviving account rolls from the abbey record not a single payment to parish players or customary performers. Performers in the abbey records actually cover a rather narrow spectrum (professionals and boys). It seems that the amount and range of support for local drama and custom was not necessarily a matter of interest for the bigger, wealthier Bury, while it was of great interest for several other houses large and small. Performances at the Abbey occurred every year on three occasions: the ceremony of the boy bishop on the Feast of St Nicholas (6 December); the commemoration of St Edmund's Day (20 November), and the feast of Christmas. Abbey officials paid minstrels for performing in the hall in 1401–2, and a minstrel at Christmas in 1417–18. They paid the boy bishop in 1417–18, 1422–3, and 1493–4. And they rewarded minstrels on the Feast of St Edmund in 1417–18, 1429–30, and 1486–7. Through the centuries all but one of their payments to entertainers occurred on one of eleven feast days: St Edmund (9 times); St Nicholas and Easter (4 each); Christmas and the Ascension (2 each); and St John Baptist, St Edward, All Saints, Purification, Lent, and St Mark (1 each).

Households, both secular and monastic, provided substantial patronage to performers, whether amateur or professional. Their patronage ranged from financial rewards and hospitality given to itinerant performers, to the supporting of players and musicians as members of their households, to the rewarding, sponsoring, and educating of children, who also performed. For detailed discussion of payments to professional entertainers by households both religious and private through the centuries, see the section on Professional Performers below.

div.head: Secular Households
div.p: The household accounts of Sir John Howard of Tendring Hall include payments to performers of nearly every kind. Amateurs paid included parish players from Hadleigh and Lavenham. Hadleigh players and 'ye olde man and ij children' performed at Tendring Hall during Christmas 1481 and four members of a Hadleigh troupe performed there on St Steven’s Day in 1526. The troupe may have contributed to Howard’s disguising at New Year’s 1526/7 since they were paid on a page containing many expenses related to the disguising. Howard hosted a second disguising in 1490–1.

Disguisings at Stoke-by-Nayland could be expensive and elaborate, including payments for costumes and gunpowder, in the Christmas season between 20 December and 2 January. Tendring Hall hosted numerous other Christmas entertainments as well. Amateurs of other kinds included St Nicholas clerks, the Children of the Chapel, a Robin Hood for whom Howard purchased eight shafts in 1483, and hocking by maidens on Hock Monday. He also paid amateur players from five towns in Essex (Billericay, Chelmsford, Coggeshall, Colchester, and Esterford). Howard’s payments to professionals were equally copious. He paid the Children of the Chapel in 1481; Gloucester’s troupe of four players in 1482; and the lord of Essex’s players in 1526. His payments to professionals also included other important troupes of players, as well as singers, musicians, bearwards, waits, jousters, tumblers, trumpeters, fools, and his own household performers.

Performers who may or may not have been professionals performed at numerous other private households. At Brome Hall three musicians performed before Sir Thomas Cornwallis in February 1560/1, as did two tumblers on 23 March. In 1572 one Adams of Bury played an interlude before Sir Thomas Kitson at Hengrave Hall near Bury at Christmas. When Elizabeth I made her progress through Suffolk in 1578, she was feted by Sir William Drury in his house at Hawstead near Bury; by Sir William Jermyn, of Rushbrooke; Sir Arthur Higham, of Barrow Hall six miles from Bury; and Sir William Cordell, Speaker of the House, at Melford Hall, in Long Melford near Bury.Suffolk Record Office, Ipswich: HA 411/5/3/3/3/1, ff [11v, 15] (Cornwallis); Cambridge, CUL: Hengrave MS 82 (3), f 14v (Kitson); Thomas Churchyard, A discovrse, STC: 5226 (Progress). Thomas Churchyard says that the events included not only dinners but gifts, triumphs, and devices. Sir Thomas Kitson, for example, produced a show representing fairies for the queen at Hengrave, where she stayed for three nights. In 1592 the Kitsons held dancing at Hengrave, where 'my L. Kytson ... [d]anced all this last night.’Letter of Philip Gawdy, London, British Library: Egerton MS. 2804, f 92. This item will appear in its entirety in the REED edition for Norfolk, research on which is now in progress. John Tasburgh, of the Tasburghs of Flixton Hall, paid a fiddler on Twelfth Night in 1597/8 and interlude players in May of 1598. In Bury scholars performed a play in 1599-1600 at the home of Robert Golding, governor of the school. At the home of Sir John Croft, in Little Saxham, women devised, produced, and acted a masque for James I in February 1619/20. The king also went shroving there in 1622.Suffolk Record Office, Ipswich: 741/ HA 12/B1/2/107, ff [19–19v];); Suffolk Record Office, Bury: E5/9/203.15 [item 3], mb 2 (Bury, Golding); TNA: SP 14/112, f 1, and SP 14/127, f 140 (Little Saxham).

The nobility and gentry provided considerable support to children, both in their education and in the development of their musical skills. Both the Howards and the Kitsons supported local song schools with numerous payments for clothing suitable for choristers, a song book and anthems, and other expenses related to performances.

Great lords might also undertake the patronage of individual talented children. In 1481 Sir John Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland paid diverse expenses related to the care of a singer known as Little Richard, including his initial boarding with a local priest before moving to Howard's residence, his costs into Sussex and other times going into London, and his wages. In 1482 Howard made a covenant with William Wastell of London, a harper, to teach the son of John Colet of Colchester, a harper, to harp and sing. The lad was then to be indentured into Howard's service and to retain the gown and the remains of the money earlier supplied by Howard. In 1543 the Kitsons of Hengrave Hall gave 11s to a Mistress Croft at the christening of the child of More, the blind harper.London, Society of Antiquaries, SA: MS 76, ff 90v, 97, 117, 145v, 146v, 151 (Little Richard); SA: MS 77, f 12 (Wastell); and CUL: Hengrave MS (82) 1 fol 107.

Some household musicians in Suffolk during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries were notable indeed. The distinguished composer and madrigalist John Wilbye (1574–1638) served for many years as musician and musical tutor to the Kitsons at Hengrave Hall. The admired composer Edward Johnson (1572–1601) served the Kitsons in that same capacity. The musicians' chamber at Hengrave was lavishly equipped with musical instruments, related equipment, and music books. Musician and composer George Kirbye (d. 1634) 'was employed as a domestic musician at Rushbrooke Hall near Bury St Edmunds, the seat of Sir Robert Jermyn.' Rushbrooke Hall was but a few miles from Hengrave and it is thought that Kirbye 'must have had personal contacts' with Wilbye. In 1605-6 the household accounts of the Adairs of Flixton Hall recorded rewards to the musicians 'Stubbs' and 'Connoway,' who appear to have been the family's household musicians, especially since they also repaired the family's musical instrument as required.The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, 2nd ed, Stanley Sadie and John Tyrell (eds) (New York, 2001), vol 13: 157 (Johnson), 617–18 (Kirbye); vol 27: 378–80 (Wilbye); Bury, SRO: IC 500/1/90/142, f [1] (Kirbye); Lowestoft, SRO: 741/HA 12/add 49, ff 7v–8 (Adair).

div.head: Monastic Households
div.p: Records show that several of Suffolk’s monastic households supported entertainers in ways comparable to those provided by the households of the nobility and gentry. Of monastic households, Mettingham College and the abbey of Bury St Edmunds provide the most copious evidence; they also present strikingly differing profiles.

Mettingham College seemingly welcomed every entertainer who approached their doors. Over a 250-year period, payments in the registers of the college range from professional troupes to parish players, from minstrels to boy bishops and clerks of St Nicholas, from bearwards to jesters, from dancers to fools, from schoolmasters’ troupes of boys to puppet acts (one of which included eight performers), to professional performers with great patrons. There is no evidence in the records that performers were following rigid annual itineraries (although the performers of a very few great patrons showed up more often); rather, most performers’ visits seem occasional. Visiting performers who visited came from nine different communities, including nearby Beccles and Bungay (players and dancers from Beccles visited once, as did a taborer and three dancers from Bungay). Mettingham registers include seventeen payments for Christmas entertainments, many of them involving plays by amateur troupes.

While Mettingham paid professionals and amateur alike, the accounts of the abbey at Bury St Edmunds (admittedly far fewer in number than Mettingham’s) include payments only to important professional troupes and the abbey’s own boy bishops. The accounts that survive give no evidence of cooperation between abbey and town in the production of performances. However, during the first half of the fourteenth century evidence of patronage of local professional musicians by the abbey does turn up in different kinds of records, including patent rolls (see the section on Household entertainments; for detailed discussion of the various kinds of professionals see the section below on Professional Performers; for professional music makers in particular, see the section on Waits and Other Musicians). From the abbey at Bury, the 'Gifts' section of an account for 1335–6 includes payments (all made on eight major feast days between All Saints 1335 and the Ascension of the Lord in 1336) to at least twenty-five minstrels (none of whose patrons are identified), plus a harpist, a taborer, and seven trumpets (all ten of whom had noble patrons). This extraordinary fragment also includes payments to a juggler, bearwards, royal heralds, messengers, and yeomen of the guard. In 1335–6 at least, the performative landscape at Bury was littered with entertainers of almost every kind in an atmosphere mingling royalty, nobility, ecclesiastics, local gentry, and performers. Several small priories record payments to parish players and waits (Bungay Priory), a king and queen of the May, a harpist (Felixstowe Priory), and professional minstrels (Ipswich Priory ).

div.head: Waits and Other Musicians
div.p: During the medieval and early modern periods, Suffolk was awash in music, whether by civic waits, minstrels, fiddlers, pipers, blind harpers, drummers, or other music makers variously identified by their skill with every instrument of the time. Local musicians and travelling professionals played in an array of complex social, ceremonial, and even judicial contexts.

In the Elizabethan period, one sees a detectable hierarchy evolving among musical performers. Waits emerge as entrepreneurs with a license to augment their income by travelling to performances elsewhere, even over the seas, as happened once in Ipswich. By virtue of their employment by the masters and burgesses, waits came to enjoy a near monopoly over musical performance in towns.

div.head: Town Waits
div.p: The records confirm that at least six Suffolk towns (Aldeburgh, Bungay, Bury, Dunwich, Ipswich, and Walberswick) sponsored waits. The earliest reference to a wait occurs in Bungay; the most detailed information occurs in Ipswich. For the other four towns, the few references to their waits provide but a fragmentary picture of the tradition in that town (see below). Many other communities and guilds retained one or more minstrels whose duties (performing at feasts, dinners, and ceremonies, leading processions, receiving a wage) mirrored those of waits. In Creeting St Mary, for example, in 1468 the Jesus and Corpus Christi guild listed two minstrels as members, and also recorded payments to them. In 1524–5 Thetford Priory in Norfolk paid 12d to the minstrel of Wangford.TNA: E 135/2/22, ff 1v, col 1, f 2, col 1, 24, 29, 30–61v; and Cambridge, University Library: Add. MSS 6969, f 173v. The ambiguous wording could indicate either that the minstrel held a position with Wangford, or simply that he happened to live there.

The records also indicate that Suffolk waits were similar in their organization and practices to those in other English counties. They functioned as companies controlled by a master. The towns hired the master who, in turn, hired and paid the members of his company. Generally, the company performed as a troupe within the customary life of the town, but individual members, most often the master, might sometimes perform, and be paid, alone. The company might also travel to perform elsewhere entrepreneurially, as permitted by the town. In addition to wages, towns paid the waits' expenses for livery and instruments. With the decline of travelling patronized companies during the late sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries, towns became a more stable patron for musicians than were lords; while individual waits might come and go, troupes of waits often enjoyed a long tenure, secure in the musical monopoly provided by their town. In Ipswich at least, waits also sometimes performed as, and with, actors in productions. In 1568–9, for example, they received 10s 'for playing the ffooles in the halle,' and in 1571–2 the town paid 6s 8d 'To will{i}am Martyne & his companye for a plaie at the Mote hall.'

div.head: ALDEBURGH
div.p: The first certain reference to the Aldeburgh waits occurs in 1573–4 (though a possible first reference occurs in 1567–8) and entries in the records continue thereafter through 1584–5. In 1583–4 a payment for their dinner confirms that the company of waits in Aldeburgh numbered four. Two of Aldeburgh's waits were certainly Peter Hunt and Thomas Brown. The third member of the company may have been John Brown, a minstrel whom the town paid in 1567 for fixing the clock and the dial and other work at the church. The fourth of the waits may have been John Bettes (later found among the Ipswich waits), who contributed to the care of a blind boy who would eventually become a wait. Numerous payments made to the Aldeburgh waits occur in connection with their care and training of that boy, Blind Harry, whom the waits developed as one of their own, and who grew to be a respected musician in the town. The waits’ involvement with Blind Harry spans more than twenty years in the records.

div.head: BUNGAY
div.p: In 1443 the prioress of Bungay Priory paid 4d to a minstrel who occupied the position of wait in Bungay, at a play staged before her. It is the earliest reference to a local wait in Suffolk and the only reference to a wait in Bungay.

div.head: BURY
div.p: The town of Bury had always chafed against the abbey’s control over its affairs. Support for a troupe of waits appears to reflect the town’s growing civic identity. The Bury waits first appear in 1537–8, one year before the dissolution of the abbey of Bury, when they received 12d for an appearance at Thetford Priory.Cambridge, CUL: Add. MSS 6969, f 273. At that point they disappear from the few civic records from Bury that survive, until the first half of the seventeenth century. In 1621 the feoffees of the Town Lands Trust paid for the waits' liveries (sum missing) and in 1622/3 they paid £3 7d for blue cloth for liveries and 54s 6d for silver cognizances for the waits. Among their other duties the waits performed at the feoffees’ feasts, dinners, elections, and investitures.

One of the Bury waits certainly appears to have been 'Iohn Grene the Musitian,' who performed at aldermanic feasts in 1619/20 and 1621/2. During this same half-century students from Bury School regularly performed plays, orations, and verses before the feoffees. In 1608 a list of charges for the scholars’ play included a payment of 10s to the aforesaid John Green (his usual fee) 'for his Musick at the Commodye.' The wills of two other resident musicians in Bury (William Allgate and Robert Hobart, who died respectively in 1642 and 1644) survive, but whether the two also served as waits the records do not say.Suffolk Archives, Bury: IC 500/1/99/68 (Allgate), and Suffolk Archives, Bury: IC 500/1/101/84 (Hobart).

div.head: DUNWICH
div.p: In spite of eventually fatal erosion and decline at the hands of the sea, Dunwich kept companies of waits through the early decades of the seventeenth century. In 1601 the assembly ordered that waits Thomas Copping, Robert Alyen and company should keep the watch with their instruments from Michaelmas through the Purification (29 September–2 February). In 1603 Copping and Alyen were also listed as two of the twenty-four burgesses of the town. An order in 1607–8 confirms that companies of waits in Dunwich traditionally had three or more musicians. The records also indicate that Dunwich experienced more turnover among its waits than was usual elsewhere. After Copping and Alyen, town books name different masters of the waits in 1607 and again in 1613–14. Thereafter the waits (like the town itself) faded away forever.

div.head: IPSWICH
div.p: Although a town of Ipswich’s importance likely sponsored waits in earlier centuries, civic accounts from medieval Ipswich do not survive. The borough made the first documented payment to its waits on 4 November 1538 when it granted an annual wage of 13s 4d to each member of a company of three waits.Nathaniell Bacon, The Annalls of Ipswche (1654), William H. Richardson (ed) (Ipswich, 1884), 212. Thereafter regular annual payments to waits begin to appear in 1565–6, the point at which surviving Elizabethan accounts in Ipswich commence. During the Elizabethan and Stuart years successive troupes of waits enjoyed stable long term employment with the town.

The first of those troupes served between 1561 and 1582, including the master wait William Martin and five other well-paid waits. Their most notable responsibility was to perform at the periodic civic meetings and feasts. In 1575–6 the chamberlain’s account records two separate payments to Martin, one for his salary as a wait, one for his salary as clerk of the market.

With the departure of Martin and his company in 1582, the city hired an interim group—Thomas Keele and his company of three other waits—who served for four years, from 1583 through 1586, when the city found its permanent replacement.

John Bettes and his company of four (later five) other waits served for the next twenty years (1587–1607), far longer than any previous recorded master wait in Ipswich. It seems likely that Bettes had earlier served as a wait in Aldeburgh. The duties of Bettes and his company mirrored those of his predecessors, with the further clarification that between October and May they should proceed nightly ‘from two of the Clock’ throughout the town with their music. Throughout all his years of service to the town, Bettes and his company received that same annual fixed amount of £4 and livery costs, plus the right to collect additional money from audiences. In 1588–9 Bettes partnered with the wait Raffe Owenden (Oldham), who would stay with the company as its co-master through 1597. On 2 November 1590 the council permitted the two to add a fifth musician to their company. On the same day that Bettes was first hired in 1587 the town elected John Cressey (alias Mynter) as drummer of the town, to receive 20s and livery costs each year. Thereafter Cressey performed together with the waits many times in civic ceremonials.
