Bettes’ company, like William Martin's before him, contributed to dramatic and ceremonial productions. All the evidence of the waits’ and drummers' possible involvement in staging relate to the celebration of the Queen's Coronation on 17 November, held annually between 1578 and 1600 (with a three-year lapse between 1579 and 1582), and to the celebrations on guild days. In September 1578 the council paid one John Kynge 6s 8d for charges related to the pageant he had made, and a further 40s for setting forth pageants both for the Guild Day and for the queen’s projected visit (which never actually occurred). In the following year (1578–9), Kynge again supplied a pageant for the Guild Day, receiving £2 4s 8d for his efforts. William Martin received 10s for his music on the Guild Day. So in that year the guild celebration included both pageantry and music.

John Kynge was a key figure in the Ipswich celebrations, and therefore in the performance life of the waits. The records identify him as both a schoolmaster and a scrivener, with skills in making pageants and shows. One of his shows, for the town’s guild merchant in 1583, was a ship pageant. Kynge produced a Coronation Day pageant and show one last time in 1583–4. In that same year the city paid a new schoolmaster, one Mr Smythe, for preparing an oration on the same Coronation Day. Martin's company of waits also disbanded or departed. The Coronation Day celebration then ceased for three years, during the temporary tenure of the new wait, Thomas Keele, and his company. The near simultaneous disappearance of Kynge and Martin's waits apparently made it impossible for the show on Coronation Day to continue in the hands of the new schoolmaster and master of the waits, Mr Smythe and Thomas Keele. However, the arrival of John Bettes and his company of waits in 1587–8 coincides with the return of the Coronation Day celebration. In the year of their hire Bettes’ troupe received 6s 8d for 'ther servis done one the Quens Daye.' Another person, one Grenelefe, also received 1s 8d 'for his paines taken the same day,' as did the drummer John Mynter.

The militarization of Coronation Day is apparent in the records: in 1588–9 the council paid for paper and thread to bind up gunpowder ot the event, and at similar civic spectacles in 1588–9, 1589, and 1590. Coronation Day still involved some kind of performance at the end of the sixteenth century because on 29 December 1599 the town paid one William Allderton for tressels that he used in setting up the stage on the Queen’s Day and paid for a show by Thomas Stevenson. Coronation Day celebrations disappear from the records between 1600 and 1632, returning mid-reign under Charles I, with payments to the musicians for playing on Coronation Day between 1632 and 1637.

In 1608 the town hired a new troupe of six waits, with the order that between Hallowmas and Lady Day they should progress through the town, making music with sackbuts, cornets, and a lute as the former musicians (John Bettes and his company) had done. An order in 1609 identifies Thomas Salter as the master of that company. In 1613, with a new master in Thomas Burrage, the company had five waits and a singing boy, hired with the understanding that they not ‘depa{r}t out of this towne w{i}th there musick w{i}thout the license of ye Bayliffes And shalbe redie at all tymes [w{i]th there musick w{i}thin the towne] to pleye vppon there Instrume{n}t{es}' as required by the bailiffs. That this order specifies that the troupe is not to travel to perform without a license from the bailiffs, indicates that they likely did sometimes travel to perform. Burrage, the longest serving master of the waits, first came into the records in 1609 and was master from 1613 through 1637, when waits stopped appearing in the records. He died in 1669.

In 1614–15, the city paid its drummer 'for one day at ye show' so the city was still sponsoring stagings of some kind at that date. In that same year, the city reduced the wages of the waits proportionally because one of their number, Simon Myndes, was discharged for unlawfully begetting two children with Alice Ward. However, he was reinstated a year later because in 1617–18, the city paid 15s 'to make Symonde Mynd{es} one of the Musitians A liuerye Coate.’

During the second half of the sixteenth century, payments to drummers increased, along with an increasing militarization of civic ceremonies. Drummers and their apprentices figured large in watches, musters, and training days at both Aldeburgh and Ipswich between 1575 and 1642, continuing to appear in the records long after payments to waits ceased.

div.head: WALBERSWICK
div.p: The records of Walberswick contain only four references to their wait, all from the late fifteenth century, but theirs is the second earliest recorded tradition of waits (after Bungay) in Suffolk. Three of the references are payments (in 1469–70, 1482, 1595–6) by churchwardens to ‘the wayte’ for work that they had hired him to do for the parish. In 1596–7 the wardens gave 2s to the wait as a reward, which sounds very much like payment for a performance. These few entries indicate that Walberswick retained at least one wait during the late fifteenth century, who worked for the parish as both an entertainer and a labourer.

div.head: Other Musicians
div.p: Hundreds of references to other musical performers (both local and professional) turn up in the Suffolk records through the centuries. Through the mid-sixteenth century, the records most often refer to music-makers as minstrels or by their particular skill (lutist, harper, fiddler, trumpeter, drummer, singer, and so on). Eventually ‘minstrel’ and other musical identifiers give way to 'musician,' the word that performers most often used in identifying themselves. By ‘professional,’ this collection means musicians who made their living as performers, and who had patrons who supported them in that endeavor. (For discussion of those musicians, see the sections on Professional Performers, Waits, and Household Entertainments.) Local or amateur musicians, on the other hand, were otherwise-employed (often very talented) people who occasionally worked as performers. Often the records do not provide their names. They had hosts (rather than patrons) who rewarded a particular performance without having an apparent permanent relationship with the musician as music-maker. This discussion focuses on this latter category of performer. Hosts or patrons for both kinds of musicians ranged from towns, religious houses, gentry, members of the royal family, parishes and guilds (both craft and religious), innkeepers, and justices, to other individuals and institutions. Sometimes it is difficult to determine, from the records, whether they are referring to professionals or locals.

The earliest recorded local musician in Suffolk, one Edric Vielator (fiddler), rented one acre of land in mid-thirteenth century Bures (near Stoke-by-Nayland). The earliest recorded performances, those by minstrels and other entertainers, occurred in late November and December 1296 and January 1296/7. During that two-month period Edward I chose to celebrate, in Ipswich, the nuptials and wedding of his daughter and youngest child, Elizabeth Plantagenet, to John I, count of Holland. Royal household accounts record payments on that occasion to at least forty performers, including a host of minstrels, the dancer Matilda Makejoy, six lyrists, three videlators, two harpers, two trumpeters, a fool, a taborer, and at least fourteen other performers. Whether some of these performers were local, the records do not say.

In the fourteenth century, professional musicians begin to proliferate in the records. The performative landscape of the abbey at Bury St Edmunds of that century included many professional minstrels in an atmosphere mingling royalty, nobility, ecclesiastics, local gentry, and performers. In 1335–6 an abbey account from Bury St Edmunds includes payments to at least twenty-five minstrels (none of whose patrons are identified), plus a harpist, a taborer, and seven trumpets (all ten of whom had noble patrons). In 1348 Edward of Woodstock, the Black Prince, awarded a war horse to a minstrel in connection with a hastiludium (joust or tournament) held near the town.

Payments to professional minstrels by religious foundations also began to emerge at Ipswich Priory and Mettingham College. Households, as it turns out, provide more evidence of local and amateur musicians than do any other kinds of documents in Suffolk. Most copious among households are the records of Mettingham College and the Howards of Stoke-by-Nayland. Particularly noteworthy are the many payments to troupes of parish performers, musical and otherwise, at both places. For a thorough discussion of local and amateur musicians, see the Households section. See also the records (insofar as they survive) of Suffolk parishes.

During the fifteenth century, the number of musical entertainers in Suffolk grows into the hundreds, turning up in the increasingly copious records of religious houses, private households, towns, and parishes. In Bury, for example, rent rolls of the sacrist of the abbey (the official responsible for the abbey’s many properties in the town) include the names of harpers and trumpeters who lived there in the early to mid-fifteenth century and early sixteenth century.BL: Harley 58, ff 8v, 14v, 36, and 81; and Bury, Suffolk Archives, A6/2/1, p 43. Payments to minstrels by religious houses during the fifteenth century included those by the Abbey at Bury in nearly every one of their account rolls that survives; in a play at Bungay Priory in 1443–4; and to a ‘citharedus’ (a lyrist accompanying himself with song) in 1497–8 by Felixstowe Priory at their Christmas feast. The greatest number of musical entertainers turn up in the unbroken registers of Mettingham College, which record payments to music makers in nearly every year between 1400 and 1500. During the fifteenth century professional entertainers increasingly turn up in the households of the nobility and the gentry. In 1402 Thomas de Mowbray, fourth earl of Norfolk, of Framlingham Castle, took into service the harper, Simon Huittebone. In 1408/9 a household account of Michael de la Pole, second earl of Suffolk, of Wingfield, includes a section called 'ffeoda ministrall{is},' that is, a section of regular fees being paid to de la Pole's own entertainers, which included a trumpeter, a player of the bumbard, and two shalmosers or players of shawms. Another section of the same account includes a payment to four minstrels of the earl of Somerset. In 1412–13 an account of Dame Alice de Bryene of Acton Hall near Long Melford contains fifteen payments to musicians between Christmas Day and 27 July in that accounting year (four of them to minstrels, ten to harpers, most of them between Christmas and Lent).

Richest in entertainers among the nobility are the household accounts of Sir John Howard, first duke of Norfolk, of Stoke-by-Nayland. Between 1462 and 1467 alone he made eleven payments to troupes of minstrels, all but two of them having three to six members and important patrons. The remaining three minstrels whom he rewarded, encountered during Howard's travels between 1462 and 1467, had no known patrons. He also paid singers, trumpeters, waits, harpers, and fiddlers, not to mention hockers, taborets, heralds, players, clerks of St Nicholas, and bearwards, for performances at Stoke-by-Nayland and a number of other places. The patrons included the king (twice); the lords of Oxford, St John, Suffolk, and Warwick; Howard himself; and the village of Polstead. Between 1481 and 1483 Howard paid the minstrels of the Lords Gloucester and Buckingham, and Lady Norfolk; the towns of Colchester, Hadleigh, and Harkstead; and a gentleman (Mr Woodes); other minstrels who had no patron; and his own household musicians. During those two years, he also paid waits, singers, harpers, children of the chapel, trumpeters, schalmers, piper, and taborers. One Thomas Stowe, 'the mynstrell of hadleyth [Hadleigh]' performed twice for the Howards at Stoke-by-Nayland, in 1483, as had the minstrels of Colchester, Essex, in 1482. Howard even made a covenant with a London harper to apprentice the son of a Colchester harper for a year to teach him to harp and to sing.

Finally, in fifteenth-century records local minstrelsy begins to emerge in the records of towns and villages. In 1470 the city of Ipswich ordered that players and pipers who performed at the council's dinners should be paid by a collection taken at the dinner. In 1496–7 the Jesus and Corpus Christi guild in the village of Creeting St Mary paid one Hert and a taborer, both of whom it called minstrels. Thereafter, in every year between 1500 and 1538 the guild paid an unnamed minstrel and a banner bearer for what must have been the guild's procession. The greater number of the minstrels in all these fifteenth-century records had identifiable patrons, but we have almost no evidence of their repertoires. The one exception is a fifteenth-century manuscript song book, originally the property of an unnamed Ipswich minstrel.Oxford, Bodl.: MS Eng. Poet.e.1. See also a microfilm copy (reference J479) of the original manuscript book at SRO, Ipswich. Written on paper in English and Latin, it has 64 leaves (including 10 preliminary pages) measuring 150mm x 110mm (text area average 115mm x 65mm). It bears the name of a later owner, William Roberts, 1574, on f 62v, and was purchased by the Bodleian Library in 1887. During the nineteenth century, it was repaired and bound in a hard cover. The book is a collection of song lyrics, some with parts, some in quatrains (aaaa, bbbb, and so on); several pages of musical notation; and one drawing or figure. Most of the songs are spiritual in nature. The great social, political, and religious tumult of the first half of the sixteenth century changed the musical landscape in Suffolk. With the dissolution of religious houses, musicians and other Suffolk performers abruptly lost major venues and income. At the same time, the word 'minstrel' was giving way to 'musician' in the records. While patrons and hosts most often referred to the entertainers as 'minstrels,' the entertainers increasingly referred to themselves as 'musicians’ (see below). Further, it is not always clear, especially in medieval records where the term was ubiquitous, that ‘minstrel’ was always referring to a musician. It might just as well refer to a troupe of professional players. However, in guild and parish records the term clearly referred to music-makers. In the village of Bardwell, for example, the guild of St Peter paid wages to three minstrels in 1511. In the village of Creeting St Mary the guild of Jesus and Mary did much the same. In 1468 (the year it was founded) the guild had made annual payments to 'the minstrel,' and it would do so until its record ceased in 1538. It listed two minstrels among its original members. In 1542 the maker of a will identified himself as 'Iohn Bannok otherwyse callid Barbour the mynstrell of Stradbrook.' William Guyblon, of Sudbury, referred to himself in his will as a minstrel in 1552, as did Daniel Wade, minstrel, of Westleton as late as 1607.

But elsewhere the word 'minstrel' began to disappear. Ipswich presents an interesting case in the evolution of the two terms. Early in the reign of Elizabeth I city accounts and minute books used the two terms alternatingly in referring to the town's waits. The master of the waits was 'the minstrel' in most years between 1557–8 and 1575–6, but he was 'the musician' in 1565 and 1571–2 and was paid for his music (not his minstrelsy) in 1576–7 and 1580–1. The records alternate terms in the same way when referring to the troupe of waits collectively. The records also refer to two other musical performers who had run afoul of the law as 'minstrels' (in 1555 and 1573).

After 1576 'minstrel' disappears almost entirely from the Ipswich records. The records do refer to the blind minstrel who received 16d in 1583–4, and to one 'Iohn Iohnson mynstrell for taking paines in the ma{r}ket by the direcc{i}on of Mr Bailiff{es},' who received 20s (though whether for music or something else is not clear), but the city thereafter refers to its musical performers as musicians or waits only. The term 'minstrel' also disappears concerning itinerant professionals. The impression arises that as a term of art, 'minstrel' eroded in Ipswich, being increasingly used to indicate a person of lower performative rank among musical entertainers.

The shift from 'minstrel' to 'musician' in the Suffolk records coincides with a complex historical moment, culturally speaking. Entertainers increasingly came to depend on towns, villages, the non-cloistered church, and private households for patronage. As the sixteenth century neared its end, only a few towns, the royal family, and a very few great noblemen continued to sponsor travelling performers, the effect, no doubt, of restrictions on patronage imposed by the Crown.Between 1580 and 1617 the Crown issued a great number of statutes, proclamations and orders exerting ever-tightening control over entertainments. For the range and nature of these actions during those years, see E.K. Chambers, ‘Appendix D: Documents of Control,’ Elizabethan Stage, vol 4 (Oxford, 1923), 278–345. Of particular note therein, see Minutes of the Privy Council on 25 July 1591 (prohibition of enterludes and plays on Sundays and Thursdays); 'An Act for the Punishment of Rogues, Vagabonds and Sturdy Beggars on 9 February 1598' (specifically defining performers of all kinds as rogues and vagabonds); 'An Act for Continuance of the Act Against Vagabonds of 1598,’ made on 7 July 1604; and 'An Act to Restrain Abuses (Prophanations) of Players on 27 May 1606.' While making it impossible for most players to perform, the Crown issued patents between 1604 and 1611, giving permission to royal troupes and a few select others to travel and perform as they would (Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, pp 307, 324-5, 336–7, 338-9, and 340–42). As the number of patrons was declining, musical performers, now identifying themselves as musicians, emerged from anonymity. In 1580–1 in Orford, for example, performer George Cowper of Ipswich, in bringing suit for disturbing the peace against one John Paynter, identified himself as a musician.Orford Civic Act Book, Ipswich, Suffolk Archives: EE 5/2/1. It appears that 'musician' bestowed independent entrepreneurial identity and a craftsman's level of skill, whereas 'minstrel' often came with anonymity and a degree of servitude to the patron. The amount of detail about musicians, their instruments, and their position in society grew exponentially in wills, family papers, and civic records. Composers appeared in the records. Whether or not this greater amount of evidence always reflects a general rise in the quality of musicianship is less than certain: in preparing the celebration of All Saints Day in 1638, the burgesses of Ipswich found it necessary to order the bailiffs to 'p{r}ovide the best Musicke they Canne gett to playe Afore them.'

The records certainly leave the impression that musicians were developing an independent identity as professionals who aspired to be (or were) gentlemen. For example, William Firmage, musician and musical tutor, of Rougham near Bury (d. 1622), was able to bequeath to his friends and associates a set of English and Italian madrigals in manuscript; a set of Latin motets and other sets of printed and manuscript singing books; a base viol with its case, with books of viol lessons both printed and manuscript; and sets of books of fancies and Latin motets. At the same time, he made considerable bequests to relatives. See also musician gentlemen John Roke, of Aldringham; and William Allgate, widower, of Bury (d. 1642). For three persons not identified as musicians but who left musical instruments to their children, see John Pettaugh, of Framsden; Barnabas Gibson, of Haughley; and Marian Lyster, widow, of Alpheton.

There is ample indication that musical entertainers in Suffolk contributed to drama, custom, and ceremony, although the precise nature of those contributions is often murky because of vagueness in the records.

The earliest possible evidence occurs in payments made at Ipswich on 1 January 1296/7 to three minstrels named 'Grisecote / Visage, & Magote Menestrall{i}s performing [before the Lady Elizabeth].' Their names sound like characters rather than given names, suggesting that their minstrelsy involved role-playing of some kind, pehaps farcical, before the royal bride-to-be. Also at this celebration, among a group of minstrels paid on the day of the nuptuals, was 'Thome le ffol,' suggesting the likelihood of a performance incorporating music and mimetic comic activity.

Performances combining minstrelsy and play occurred at religious houses as well. In 1404-5 Mettingham College paid a minstrel performing with a horse. It is hard to imagine this event as drama, but it certainly involved a dialogue of some sort between man and beast. On seven occasions between 1469–70 and 1522–3 the college paid minstrels and lusores (amateur local players) together. Visiting minstrels performed with entertainers other than players, including fools, bears, and jugglers six times between 1467–8 and 1523–4.

In Bury in 1608 the governors of King Edward School awarded John Greene the Musician 10s 'for his Musick at the Com{m}odye.' They paid him the same amount in 1619/20. Given the pattern of payments by villages and towns, minstrels made central contributions in customary processions—events that had mimetic elements.

Because of their institutional nature, the records tend to identify musicians who had patrons. However, a great many other musicians who had no apparent patron turn up as well. The records mention a few blind minstrels, exclusively in and under the care of towns. So do they mention boys, who are apprenticed to musicians, primarily waits. The records also reveal several instrument suppliers, instrument makers and repairers of instruments whom fathers bequeath musical instruments—often virginals; but in the wills of professional musicians, in Suffolk it is always the son(s) or other male relatives who receive the instruments and supplies. Most striking is the evolving role of patrons and sponsors, who changed with the times. In the medieval period the town of Ipswich, the religious houses of Bury and Mettingham College, and the powerful local religious guilds served as major hosts. But with the dissolution of the monasteries, the dismantling of local guilds and chantries, and the near disappearance of the nobility as patrons, the most reliable patrons and hosts became towns as the sixteenth century neared its end, until puritan residents impeded even that activity. Itinerancy and sustained, reliable, playing circuits eroded and decayed away. In Suffolk, the greatest enemy of the inherited musical culture became the increasingly vicious and inhibiting wars of ideology, religion, and politics.

div.head: Professional Performers
div.p: Performances by travelling professional troupes of actors and musicians, and individual performers of many kinds show up in the records of every period for which documents survive. Professional performers first appear in the Suffolk records at a singular event in 1296. On 27 December of that year in Ipswich, in the presence of Edward I, more than fifty professional entertainers performed at a celebration to honor the nuptials of the king's daughter, Elizabeth Plantagenet, and John I, Count of Holland. The couple would marry on 8 January 1296/7 in Ipswich.

All other references to professional troupes and individual performers occur between 1366 and 1642. During those years, 171 professional troupes visited Suffolk a recorded 508 times. Of these 171 troupes, 156 of their patrons were individual lords, nine were towns, one was the diocese of Lincoln, and five remain unidentified. These travelling professionals visited five towns, four households of the nobility, one castle, a village and two large religious houses—thirteen Suffolk places in all. The professional performers visited the towns of Aldeburgh, Bury, Dunwich, Ipswich, and Sudbury most often—a total of 294 times; 220 of that 294 were to Ipswich. The players visited the religious houses of Bury St Edmunds and Mettingham College a total of 165 times—the second greatest number of visits by professional toupes and individuals; but professionals also visited Ipswich Priory. For example, in 1360–1 Ipswich Priory awarded 8s to the minstrels of diverse lords.

Most of those visits (140) to religious households were to Mettingham College. Between 1396 and 1536 Mettingham made 211 payments to professional performers, whom it identified as minstrels. Since the payment might be to an individual minstrel or to a troupe of minstrels, the actual number of minstrels who performed is far greater than the 211 payments. Before the time of Henry VIII, the Mettingham registers always identify the performers with noble patrons as minstrels. Lacking other descriptive distinctions, it is impossible to know with certainty that those minstrels were always musicians. The college also paid a ‘citharedi,’ a luter, mimi (performers or waits), and symphoniste (a musician) (all one time each).

Of the 211 payments to minstrels, 184 mention patrons who were members of the nobility or the monarchy (twenty-eight were patrons whose performers visited often). The four noble patrons whose minstrels were paid most often all had local connections —Lord Willoughby (twenty times), Lord Morley (fifteen), the dukes of Norfolk (fourteen), and the duke of Suffolk (twelve); the king's minstrels visited more than those of any other patron (nineteen times). Eight of the remaining patrons of minstrels included six towns, one diocese, and one unidentifiable place. Of the 211 payments to minstrels in the Mettingham registers, the remaining nineteen mention no patron, either identifying the minstrel by name only or giving no indication of the minstrel's identity. Of the dated performances, twenty-seven occurred at Christmas, four on the college's community day, one at Shrovetide, and one at Pentecost. Nearly all dated payments went to players only, or to minstrels and players together, but only rarely to minstrels only. None of the many other payments bear a specific date of performance.

The number of minstrels sponsored by a noble patron varied from one to an indeterminate several. These minstrels never demonstrably received payments for performing with locals although minstrels lacking a noble patron did do so. Because the Mettingham College records so consistently distinguish minstrels from other performers, the impression arises that in those records minstrels likely (but not demonstrably) were musicians. Whether they were musicians or players, the word 'minstrel' appears in most cases to have conveyed a measure of professional identity and a level of musical skill that warranted a patron's protection and ensured his or its satisfaction with the performer. Identifying minstrels, both solo and troupes, by name in payments appears to be an acknowledgment of their status or their skill, or their familiarity, for example: Nicholas, minstrel of Lord Willoughby in 1419–20, or Nicholas Scarlet in 1463–4. Unless minstrels were players in minstrels' clothing (which is quite possible), no itinerant troupes of professional actors identified as such are confirmably recorded at Mettingham, though many troupes of local players are. But the fifteenth-century abbey at Bury differs utterly from Mettingham in that its surviving accounts include many professional performers but absolutely no payments to local festive performers or unsponsored entertainers of other kinds.

Professional troupes visited Acton Hall, Hengrave Hall, and Stoke-by-Nayland a total of forty-seven times, and visited Framlingham Castle and the village of Cratfield once each. Surprisingly perhaps, only this one Suffolk village records a payment to a professional troupe: in Lincolnshire, for example, large villages routinely paid travelling players.See Stokes, Lincolnshire, vol 1, pp 438–43. Finally, the players of the duke of Suffolk (Charles Brandon) and his wife, styled ‘The French Queen,’ who lived at Westhorpe, Suffolk, visited Thetford Priory, just across the border in Norfolk, five times.

From the records that survive it is possible to glimpse a few likely routes travelled by the professional troupes, mainly following ancient roadways. One (for which there is the most compelling evidence) is a north-south coastal route from Ipswich to Aldeburgh to Dunwich. Players using this route could have come into Suffolk from Essex by way of Colchester, Sudbury, or Stoke-by-Nayland (home of the dukes of Norfolk), and carried on after Dunwich into Norfolk via Yarmouth or Bungay. The records suggest a second north-south route, from Stoke-by-Nayland north to Sudbury, Bury St Edmunds, and Thetford. The records also suggest an east-west route from Cambridge (or the Midlands) to Newmarket, Bury, Framlingham Castle, and (veering southeast) Ipswich. The players who are recorded generally visited conveniently situated towns, powerful religious houses, or the residences of great lords. The east-west route Cambridge to Ipswich, and the south-north route (including its two branches) from Essex into Suffolk were all principal roads. While the route from Ipswich to Aldeburgh and Dunwich could not be called a principal road, it was the one preferred by travelling companies.For a thoroughly researched visual representation of the major roads in medieval and early modern Suffolk, see https://reed.library.utoronto.ca/maps.

Players representing a group of seventeen patrons made the greatest number of visits: those of various queens visited sixty-three times; those of kings fifty-one times; and those of the various dukes of Norfolk forty-nine times. Of the fourteen remaining patrons in this first group, five were from Essex; three from Suffolk; and two from Norfolk. Only four of this fourteen were from elsewhere in the kingdom. Royals aside, the pattern in the number of visits shows a strong regional bias: the patrons of those troupes that visited most often lived in East Anglia.

Sixteen other troupes in a second group each visited three times. Of that sixteen, the patrons of three were from Essex and three from Suffolk. The remaining ten patrons in that group of sixteen were from places far afield from East Anglia.

Twenty other troupes each visited twice. Ten of their patrons were from the four East Anglian counties. Ten others, from elsewhere in the kingdom, all had nationally important patrons (Beauchamp, Buckingham, Somerset, Strange, Warwick, Westmoreland, and so on).
Finally, of the 171 professional troupes that were paid during these years, fifty-four visited only once each. They came from just about everywhere, including East Anglia.

Several summary impressions arise from the records of visits by professional performers. First, in comparison with some other counties, an extraordinarily high number of professional performers received payments in Suffolk. Second, the greatest number of those paid troupes came from Suffolk and other parts of East Anglia. Third, the great number of those East Anglian patrons came into Suffolk from Essex, indicating very close bonds between those two neighbouring counties. Finally, a number of payments went to household professionals whose patrons were women. In addition to the various queens, those patrons included, for example, the duchess of York and the duchess of Suffolk, among other great ladies (see the section on Women as Patrons and Performers).

Children also apprenticed with professional troupes of adult actors, or performed in troupes comprising children only. The queen's players 'being the Childeren' received 20s for a performance in Ipswich in 1586–7. The Children of the Revels performed in Sudbury in 1618–19 (three of them, it appears), and again in 1632.

The Suffolk records use eleven terms (seven of them Latin) to identify performers. The earliest two of the terms are minstrel or ‘ministrallus’ (from 1389 to 1536–7, and ‘lusor’ (from 1445 to 1531–2). Both disappear from the records in the same decade. It is often difficult to know whether minstrel refers to a musician or an actor, but ‘lusor’ seems always to refer to an actor or puppet player. During the first three quarters of the fifteenth century, minstrel and ‘lusor’ never appear in the same year, making it possible that both refer to players during that period. But thereafter they do occasionally appear in the same year. Their joint appearances in these later decades suggest that 'minstrel' was now more likely to refer to a musical performer than to a player.

After the 1530s the term ‘player’ takes over. Many more of the documents are in English, but when they are in Latin, ‘ministrallus’ has given way to ‘iocator’ or ‘histrio.’ Players might also be called servants, men, women or youths—but never minstrel in these later records. When musicians are identified, the description is specialized (a player of a ‘citharedo,’ or a taborer). My conclusion is that throughout most of the fifteenth century, ‘lusor,’ player, and men (when the context clearly indicates that the men are performers, rather than a patron’s administrative officers or servants of his or her household, as for example, when the men were paid for performing at Christmas, which happened in 1405–6 at Mettingham College) all meant the same thing—an actor, and that ‘ministrallus’ increasingly came to mean musician.

Payments to a few keepers of animals occur in several household records. In November 1462 Sir John Howard of Stoke-by-Nayland, chamberlain to the duke of Norfolk, paid Lord Stanley's bearward 6s 8d, and in December of the same year he paid an unnamed bearward (perhaps in London). In 1464 he gave a gift of 40d to his own bearward that 'kepeth my ber.' The bearwards of Charles Brandon, duke of Suffolk, who lived at Westhorpe, Suffolk, received payments from Thetford Priory (on the Norfolk-Suffolk border) in 1514-5 and 1527-8. The Kitsons of Hengrave Hall paid the keeper of a bear from Leicestershire in 1541 (patron unidentifed). They also paid the keeper of the lions on 19 February 1575, and a man for bringing the apes in August 1575, both incidences in London.

div.head: Women and Performance
div.p: The records present contradictory glimpses of women and performance in Suffolk during the medieval and early modern periods, as they do elsewhere. Through the mid-sixteenth century, women in Suffolk demonstrably participated (as players, producers, and patrons) in every performative aspect of culture, ranging from public, customary, and civic performance by parishes and towns to quasi-public masques to private musical performances within the households of the nobility and the gentry, in a culture that had traditionally assumed and accepted the contributing presence of women in them all, however patriarchal other features of society might be. However, a sometimes violent backlash driven by religious ideology inhibited women's (and men's) unlicensed performance from the late sixteenth through the mid-seventeenth centuries. East Anglian legal records provide vivid, sometimes horrific, examples of social conflicts involving women and performance that reflect a moment of great cultural change in which efforts to suppress most festive and performative elements of traditional culture coincided with an end to the acceptance of women in performance. The result is a complex documentary picture of women and performance in Suffolk.

div.head: Women as Patrons
div.p: Minstrels and other performers sponsored by women of the nobility and the royal families turn up in Suffolk records from the fifteenth through the first thirty years of the seventeenth centuries. In the early fifteenth-century Alice de Bryene of Acton Hall made numerous payments to harpers and minstrels, stipulating that many of them had performed the entire day. Mettingham College paid the minstrels of the queen (Elizabeth Woodville, Queen Consort of Edward IV) in 1469 and 1488; of the duchess of Norfolk (Katherine Neville) in 1466, 1476, and 1481; and of the duchess of York (Cecily Neville) in 1478 and 1488. Thetford Priory in Norfolk paid (in 1521, 1527, and 1530) the entertainers (jocatores) of 'the French Queen,' (Mary Tudor, duchess of Suffolk), who lived at Westhorpe Hall, Suffolk. In 1542 the Kitsons of Hengrave Hall twice paid a reward to the fool of Lady Rich (Elizabeth Jenks), wife of Robert, the first Baron Rich.

By the mid-sixteenth century, noble and royal women were keeping players rather than minstrels. In 1562 and 1563 Ipswich twice paid the players of the duchess of Suffolk, Katherine Willoughby (who then lived at Grimsthorpe Castle, Lincolnshire). The players of Queen Mary performed at Ipswich in 1556 and 1558. The players of Queen Elizabeth performed thirty-three times at Ipswich, between 1562 and 1603. Queen Anne of Denmark's players received awards fifteen times between 1604–5 and 1622, as did those of the Princess Elizabeth, subsequently Queen of Bohemia, five times between 1610 and 1630.

div.head: Women and Private Performance
div.p: The royals had always come to Suffolk, in the process generating records of performance by women (both professional and amateur) spanning a wide temporal range. During the late thirteenth and early fourteenth centuries, the famous dancer and acrobat, Matilda Makejoy, twice perfomed in Suffolk: on 27 December 1296 before Lord Edward, son of King Edward I, in Ipswich, and in 1311 together with one William Pilke and his partner (or his wife) (both minstrels) before the princes Thomas and Edmund at Framlingham Castle.Two further items provide examples of possible performance by women and girls in royal settings. In 1347–8, as part of expenses by the Black Prince for tournaments, his wardrobe accounts include numerous payments for garments for the ladies of the court at hastiludi at numerous locations in the kingdom, which would seem to indicate that women of the royal family and the nobility played a part of an indeterminate kind in the tournament (TNA: E 36/278). See also Richard Barber, Edward III and the Triumph of England, (London, 2013), pp 70, 86-7, 94-5, 254-5. When Elizabeth I visited Hengrave Hall near Bury in 1578, the celebration mounted by the Kitsons included ‘A shew representing the Phayries’ (Churchyard, A discovrse, STC: 5226), There seems little reason to believe that women and girls did not perform in that show, since provincial performances before the Queen characteristically did so. In 1620 a group of Suffolk ladies invited the king and court at little Saxham 'to a maske of theyre owne inuention, (all those faire sisters being summoned for the purpose)' at Bury St Edmunds. Suffolk had numerous regionally and nationally important families whose household papers record a rich musical culture centered around women. In 1593, at Hengrave Hall, Lady Elizabeth Kitson 'danced all this last night as long as she was able to go.' Household accounts include payments for stringing Lady Kitson's lute; to a man for bringing her a lute; to one Maud for amending the virginals; and to a man for teaching the children (boys and girls) of the household to play the virginals. The accounts of the Adairs of Flixton paid one Charles' wife for exchanging a harp. Lady Anne Drury, daughter of Nicholas Bacon of Redgrave, included in her inventory a pair of virginals and a viol belonging to her. Yeoman families followed the same pattern. In 1620 John Pettaugh of Framsden, bequeathed his virginals to his daughter Katherine. In 1629 a widow named Marian Lyster, of Alpheton, willed to her youngest daughter, Iohanna, a pair of virginals that had belonged to her father.

div.head: Women and Local Performance
div.p: Women’s involvement in local drama and custom––as performers, organizers, and sponsors––was simply a universal part of parish life in Suffolk. Records indicate that it was a life to which the nobility and ecclesiastical institutions lent their support. The personal accounts of John Howard, duke of Norfolk show him giving rewards to the maidens of Colchester on 12 May 1482; to the maidens of Newgate on 14 May; and ‘to women on hoc Monday.’ In 1465 he had given a gift to the hoc pot, which appears to be the name given to the pot used for collections at Hocktide. In 1497–8 the prior of Felixstowe Priory gave a payment to the king and queen of the May. The prioress of Bungay Priory gave rewards to players from Bungay town in 1406-7, and to a town wait who had played before her in an interlude in 1443–4.

Local religious guilds in Suffolk enfranchised participation by women in the common culture. The charter of the Corpus Christi guild in Bury directs that the brothers and sisters of the guild convene together to honour the Body of Christ on Corpus Christi Day and other festivals each year and that they maintain a play. In the Ipswich civic minute books, innumerable orders confirm that the brothers and sisters of the guild merchant (also called the guild of Corpus Christi) bore joint responsibility for the city’s Corpus Christi procession and play. In 1475–6, in Creeting St Mary, one ‘Ioha{n}na Wildebeff hath gevin ou{er} to the behove of the Gylde holde in Creting A Torche.’ The parish accounts of Bardwell include a list of the brothers and sisters of the guild of St Peter. Involvement by women and girls in parish customs, as churchwardens’ accounts confirm, occurred whether a religious guild was involved or not, and most often in relation to May games. For typical examples concerning May games, see Mildenhall and Walberswick. Ales in both those places featured performances by women and maidens. In Bungay the parish recorded twenty-one shillings five pence ‘made by the wif{es} for the game,’ and in 1538–9 one of the two torch reeves of Bungay, named as reponsible for all gatherings in 1538–9, was a woman, the widow Stroger. In Aldeburgh the town paid six pence ‘to ye wemen yat went ye circuit of p{ro}cession’.

div.head: Attacks on Women as Performers
div.p: Ironically and unintentionally, attacks on women's performance in late sixteenth- and early seventeenth-century legal records confirm the central presence of women in local drama, custom, and ceremony up to that time. This demonization of women in performance became the central feature of a larger ideological attack on inherited English culture, abetted in its efforts by some opportunistic male performers, as a letter from Newmarket in 1620 testifies: ‘our pulpits ring continually of the insolence and impudence of women, and to helpe the matter forward the players haue likewise taken them to taske, and so the ballades and ballad-singers....’

The records vividly document suppressive attacks, both verbal and physical, on women, which intentionally invert the traditional performative world, turning punishment of women into a 'comic' performance. In traditional culture, customary performance characteristically elevated women to central roles – most notably as May or harvest queens, as leaders of long dances, as processional leaders (with their daughters) in Ascension Day activities, or as leaders of hocktide festive collections. Instead, these punishments (as in the case of some skimmingtons) parodied and mocked that elevation of women, making them chastened ‘stars’ of their own punishment in what became a theatre of cruelty. A case from the court of Star Chamber vividly illustrates the process.

In 1604 in Wetherden, some twenty disguised (costumed) persons led by a carpenter marched up and down the streets of Wetherden for three hours, laying seige to the house of a tanner named Nicholas Rosyer. The objective of the skimmington was to mock Rosyer for his alleged inability to 'control' his wife, who they said had beaten him for his drunkedness. Their goal was to admonish the woman by shaming her (and other women) 'for her misdemeano{u}r toward{es} her husband.' Wearing 'base and ragged ragg{es},' they dressed Rosyer's male neighbour as a woman and carried him through the streets on a cowl staff, assaulting Rosyer's wife when she confronted them.

On the surface this particular episode could be seen as a joke and parody that got out of hand. But it also illustrates an ancient custom (newly popular in the late sixteenth century) that used street theatre to admonish couples who failed to preserve patriarchal hierarchies; it did so mainly by threatening women. Its basic structure exemplifies the dark side of women and performance. This kind of domestic drama, as described in the court documents, was a form in which ‘the wife’ is the central character. She comes across as something approaching a wild woman with a supine and victimized husband. She becomes the cause of the problem in her harsh refusal to accept her drunken husband’s actions, thereby entering the county’s pantheon of shrews.

The newly repressive environment in English society from the late-sixteenth through the mid-seventeenth centuries, driven by evangelical reformists, appears to have signalled the end of the acceptance of women in performance. Female performers tend to disappear from most performance records (excepting private household and royal records).

div.head: Performance Venues
div.p: Unfortunately, most performance records do not name the venue, but those that do so mention halls of many kinds (civic, guild, monastic, private residence), churches and churchyards, streets, castles, inns and taverns, schools, greens, and dedicated game places (as at Walsham and Beccles).

Moot halls (the name given in East Anglia to the building used for a town's elections and other business) were the most frequently named venues. In Sudbury an order by the burgesses in 1607 forbade further use of the moot hall for interludes and other plays 'heretofore vsually suffred to be acted' there, 'because the hall had recently been repaired and 'bewtified.' Sudbury had two moot halls. The original or 'Old Moot Hall,' built in 1430, still stands. The 'New Moot Hall,' built in the sixteenth century but demolished in the nineteenth century, was the players' venue.

The Ipswich Moot Hall (also called 'the Guild Hall’ or 'the Hall') had originally been the Corpus Christi guild hall. It was located on the Cornhill and was 'converted from, or erected immediately to the north of, the redundant medieval church of St Mildred.'John Webb (ed), The Town Finances of Elizabethan Ipswich (Woodbridge, 1996), frontispiece. It is last mentioned unambiguously as a venue for players in 1571. However, a performance by the Queen's players before the master bailiff in 1572–3; by an Italian tumbler who likewise performed before the bailiff and his brethren in 1573–4; and by another tumbler performing 'at the hawll' in 1577–8 all likely occurred in the Moot Hall. The Hall probably continued as a playing venue because in 1614 the city found it necessary to issue an order newly forbidding any players of interludes resorting to the town to play in the Moot Hall, or indeed to play in the city at all. Shakespeare's company likely performed in the Moot Hall in 1594–5, 1603, and 1609, when they visited Ipswich.

Whatever the case with professional troupes, the Ipswich Moot Hall served as a venue for local performance throughout the sixteenth and early seventeenth centuries. The city had two major civic ceremonials each year. One was 'the Guild' (the name given the annual feast for burgesses and their wives); the other was the celebration of the Queen's Coronation Day. 'The Guild' included feasting, pageants (the records sometimes say a single ship pageant, sometimes several pageants) and orations. The Coronation Day celebration, increasingly militaristic after the defeat of the Spanish Armada (civic accounts include payments for gunpowder, paper, and thread), included triumphs, musters, and pageants. While the feast, with its dining and music, obviously occurred inside the hall, the other events would have required outdoor staging, most logically on the Cornhill near the hall. Records indicate that such ceremonials utilized both scaffold staging and pageants. It is a pattern typical of Suffolk. Additionally, in 1624–5 the city paid the players 'which did shew the sightes att the ffryers.' Ipswich had three friaries—the Caramelite, Dominican, and Franciscan, but at which of them these players performed is unclear.

Visiting troupes performed in one of Sudbury's two Moot Halls. The older of them, the so-called Old Moot Hall, still surviving on Cross Street, dates from the fifteenth century. The records (being from a later era) provide no evidence that it served as a performance venue. The second of the two, the New Moot Hall (also known as Town Hall), dates from the mid-sixteenth century. Visiting troupes performed there until at least 1606–7, at which point town officials forbade its further use for that purpose. This proper Moot Hall survived until 1841 when it was torn down and replaced with a new town hall.Hodson, 'Old Moot Hall,' p 266. It survives only in drawings and water colour paintings. A number of Suffolk's other urban halls served as entertainment venues. At Bury, people used the banquet room in the Guildhall for bride ales, weddings, guild elections and feasts (with music by the waits), and in 1608 a comedy by the scholars, with music and banqueting. The former Guildhall, which stands on Guildhall Street, four blocks from the abbey grounds, has a minstrel's gallery dating from the late fifteenth century or earlier, that overlooks the banquet room.See Margaret Statham, ‘The Guildhall, Bury St. Edmunds,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 31 (1970), 120–1, 130–3, 146. In Hadleigh in 1600 officials ordered that no plays or weddings could thereafter be held in the Guildhall without the consent of six of the chief inhabitants of the town. In 1607 officials in Sudbury forbade plays and interludes in the Moot Hall of that town. While out of period, in 1656 Beccles rented its Guildhall, receiving payment of 3s 6d ‘of the horse dauncers for the vse of the Guildhall and some damadge.’For a discussion of guild structure, properties, and practices in pre– and post–Reformation Beccles, see Evans, ‘Holy Ghost Gild,' pp 31–44. Evans wonders whether these dancers were hobby horse dancers and asks why, if they were, they would have been performing in Beccles during the Commonwealth (p 39). The entry could possibly refer to a real dancing horse (common during the period), but that seems unlikely since they were performing inside the Guildhall, and since there were several dancers.

Halls in religious houses also served as venues. The abbey at Bury had several halls (the Abbot's Hall over the cellar, New Hall, Old Hall, Great Hall, Hall of Pleas, King's Hall, Queen’s Hall, Abbot's Palace, Prior's House, and Bradfield Hall, among others).For excellent maps of the plan of the Abbey, including identification of all its structures, see Pevsner, Buildings of England: Suffolk, 2nd ed (London, 1974), pp 134–5. It is difficult to know which of them served as venues unless a surviving account specifies it as being one (for example, the Prior’s House and the Hall of the Convent). Players may have performed in the halls of two additional religious houses. The prioress of Bungay Priory watched a play in 1443–4, presumably in the hall of the Benedictine Nunnery of the Blessed Virgin Mary and the Holy Cross in Bungay.Bungay Priory was founded c 1160–95 and dissolved c 1536. At the time of its dissolution it had a prioress and eleven nuns. The Abbey (including its hall) was destroyed, but the Priory Church of the Blessed Virgin Mary and the Holy Cross became the Bungay Parish Church of St Mary (VCH: Suffolk, pp 81-3, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025]; Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 61-2.) A lyrist performed at the Benedictine Priory of Felixstowe after Christmas during the community's feast in 1497–8.The Benedictine priory of Felixstowe was founded c 1170–80. It was ‘suppressed in 1538 towards the founding of Cardinal’s [Wolsey’s] College, Ipswich.’ To that end, the priory was granted to Wolsey on 30 December 1528, but on the fall of the Cardinal, the Crown granted the priory and its appurtenances to the duke of Norfolk. A memorandum to Thomas Cromwell in 1528 makes reference to ‘the hall,’ but today nothing of the priory remains. (VCH: Suffolk, pp 80-1, BHO https://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/suff/vol2 [accessed 8 February 2025].

Churches and churchyards also sometimes served as playing spaces. Bungay held an interlude, with a scaffold stage, in the churchyard in 1565–6. Mildenhall collected profits and gifts from a play of St Thomas staged on St Thomas Day in the Hall Yard, which was 'part of the manorial complex which lay beyond the church.'Judith Middleton-Stewart (ed), Records of the Churchwardens of Mildenhall: Collections (1446 – 1454) and Accounts (1503 – 1553), Suffolk Record Society 54 (Woodbridge, 2011), 44, n 16. In 1556–7 Long Melford produced a game and paid to place thirteen seats in the churchyard (likely for the worthies). In 1597 Hadleigh planned to stage plays at Whitsuntide, thereby 'to draw a Concourse of people out of the Country,' but the privy council ordered them to desist and to 'pluck down' the stage that they had prepared. Given the content and the size of the intended audience, the venue was more likely the churchyard. In 1482 Sir John Howard, of Stoke-by-Nayland, gave 10s 'to the cherche on Whitson Monday at the pley.' The awkward phrasing makes it unclear whether the play was staged in the church or not.

Private houses were important staging venues in Suffolk for entertainers of every kind. Among the halls for which we have performance records are Brome Hall; Flixton Hall; Hengrave Hall; Little Saxham Hall; ‘the King’s House’ at Ipswich; Polstead Hall; Tendring Hall at Stoke-by-Nayland, and Wingfield Hall. Brome Hall, which had fallen into dereliction, was demolished in 1958. Flixton Hall was demolished in 1952. Of Hawstead Hall, situated four miles from the centre of Bury St Edmunds, only fragments remain. Originally a fortified manor house, it was abandoned c 1615. Hengrave Hall, three miles from Bury St Edmunds, survives as a privately owned house now used for wedding receptions and similar functions.One can request private viewing of the house. Its current owner, David Harris, is said to have plans to turn Hengrave Hall into private housing. The site of ‘the King’s House’ in Ipswich is unknown. Little Saxham Hall, a fortified hall with a gatehouse and drawbridge, was built in 1516 and pulled down in 1771–3. Nothing but foundations and moats remain. Long Melford Hall, built in the sixteenth century, is an excellent example of a turreted manor house. It incorporates part of an earlier manor house. The medieval Polstead Hall was replaced by a sixteenth century house that was itself modernized in the eighteenth century. The present Polstead Hall, located west of the parish church of St Mary, is a timber-framed structure dating from the sixteenth century. No evidence of a fourteenth-century hall is mentioned in available sources.Polstead Manor dates from the twelfth century. When the lord of the manor, Thomas de Lambourne, died in 1361, followed by the death of his son and heir William in the following year, the manor passed to Thomas's sister, the wife of William de Cheyne (or Chene) (1334–75). The lordship passed to his son, Roger de Cheyne (1362–1414), who would have been lord at the time of the summer game in 1381. The family held Polstead Manor for life on behalf of the king, however, the HPO observes that there is no evidence that Roger de Cheyne actually took possession of Polstead Manor ('Cheyne, Roger (1362–1414), of Drayton Beauchamp, Bucks,' http://www.historyofparliamentonline.org/volume/1386-1421/member/cheyne-roger-1362-1414), which may, in part, explain why Atteforth was so bold as to stage his uninvited summer game in its hall; the manor may have been uninhabited at the time. Polstead Hall survives as a Grade II Listed building in Polstead. Wingfield Hall was a manor house built within the walls of Wingfield Castle. The castle survives as a private dwelling, but the hall no longer exists, having been replaced with modern dwellings. Tendring Hall was demolished (apparently for no good reason) in 1955. See Christopher Dyer, ‘The Rising of 1381 in Suffolk: Its Origins and Participants,’ Publications of the Suffolk Institute for Archaeology 36.4 (1988), p 281; Pevsner, Suffolk, pp 395-6; and Birch, Ancient Sites, pp 300–1, and 355 (Tendring Hall). The medieval Tendring Hall in Stoke-by-Nayland was the residence of John, Lord Howard (c 1420-2–85), later named duke of Norfolk. All that remains of the original Tendring Hall is chimney stacks to the rear of stables.In 1522, Thomas Howard, Earl of Surrey was living at Tendring Hall, so it survived at that point. The date of its destruction is not given in the records, but eventually a new Tendring Hall was built in 1784, but demolished in 1955, See Birch, Ancient Sites, p 355. Of the original interior buildings of Wingfield Castle (including Wingfield Hall) nothing remains.

In 1567–8 the parish of Bungay staged a game in the castle yard of the twelfth-century Norman castle at Bungay, where the wives of the town collected 57s 8d among the booths and 'ells' at the game site.

Places of commercial hospitality must have been venues too because two towns felt it necessary to prohibit their use by performers. In 1607 the aldermen of Bury ordered that ‘noe Inholder Alehowskeep{er} [or] victualler’ permit stage plays, comedies, interludes, or sights involving horses, baboons, apes, bears, and puppets, or other shows in those three venues.

Streets were no less important for processions of all kinds. Corpus Christi pageants at Bungay, Bury, and Ipswich obviously moved through the streets. The musters, triumphs and public speeches on Coronation Day in Dunwich and Ipswich certainly happened in the streets. A strange and ancient fertility ceremony for women in Bury, called The Ceremony of the White Bull, involved a procession with the white bull, a supplicant woman (from the nobility), members of the clergy, and a crowd, made its way through Churchgate, Guildhall, and Abbeygate Streets to the Great West Gate of the Abbey, culminating in a religious service within the Abbey.Bury also used the bullring, in the street, as a place for the punishment of felons needing to be flogged. The tiny village of Weybread had a 'merriment' upon the town close in 1617.

Some evidence indicates that dedicated outdoor sites served as venues. At a corner of its camping close, Walsham le Willows had an outdoor playing space used to stage plays which local records called a game place. It was a ‘fayre round place of earth ... a half-acre in size,’ across the street, diagonally, from the parish church of St Mary. Walsham’s is one of two places in the county designated as game places (the other being Beccles).References to the Beccles Game Place occur in a number of documents in the Beccles collection now at Suffolk Archives in Ipswich. See Charity Trust Deed, 994/A/1/2 (reference to game place in deed, 1599); Statement of Bargain and Sale, 994/B/1/2 (John Mason’s sale of the property containing the game place to the Feoffees of the Beccles Town Lands Charity, 1631); Feoffees’ Account Book, 994/E/1, f 3v (payment to the Bailiff for the Game Place, 1635–6; Charity Trust Deed, 994/A/1/4 (sale of property containing game place, 1636). At least sixty other Suffolk communities had dedicated outdoor recreational sites, many with names similar to game place (for example, ‘Le Playing Place,’ or ‘The Little Playing Close’), but there is no record that plays were staged there.

div.head: Animal Entertainment
div.p: Bearbaiting is the only animal 'entertainment' that appears in the Suffolk records. Bearwards turn up in the records of private households, religious houses and towns. Several patterns emerge. Most (but not all) of the bearwards were itinerants with noble patrons. Keeping bears was expensive and labor-intensive; it was generally a patronage for the rich. Both single bearwards who had one or more bears, and bearwards performing together appear in town and household accounts. The many payments to bearwards in the Ipswich civic records show variety in the bearwards’ approach to travel and performance. Bearwards might mount spectacles alone or with other bearwards. Patron lords might have a single bearward or several in their employ. While payments by the town were almost always given to one individual bearward, he might, in fact, have had servants whom he, in turn, maintained. For examples of the variety in itinerant bearwarding as a form, see entries from the Ipswich civic records in 1577–8, 1584–5, 1592–3 and 1595–6.

The only payments to bearwards by a Suffolk religious house occur at Mettingham College between 1470 and 1479. The records of three private households include payments to bearwards: Howard in 1462 and 1464 (to his own bearward); the duke of Suffolk’s bearwards in 1514–15 and 1527–8 (payments by Thetford Priory near the Norfolk-Suffolk border); and the Kitsons in 1541.Cambridge, CUL: Add. MSS 6969, ff 119 and 205v.

Of Suffolk towns, bearwards received recorded payments in Aldeburgh and Ipswich. The Aldeburgh burgesses paid the bearward of the duke of Norfolk in 1566–7 and 1567–8. The fact that the duke's bearward also appeared in Ipswich during those years provides the only evidence in the Suffolk records of a possible itnerary. Ipswich has by far the greatest number of payments to bearwards. The first of them, in 1530–1, went to to the bearwards of the king and the 'French Queen' (Mary, duchess of Suffolk, daughter of Henry VIII and wife of Charles Brandon). The rest of the payments to bearwards in Ipswich—some twenty-six in all—occur between 1562–3 and 1619–20. The greatest number went to the queen's bearward (six times); the duke of Norfolk's and Lord Monteagle's (three each); the King's (two); and the Lords Berkeley, Cheney, Sheffield, and Vesey, and Sir Francis Hindes (one each). Four other bearwards had no named patron and appear to have been loners.

Some entries indicate that the bearward who was being paid had more than one bear. In 1568–9, for example, the duke of Norfolk's bearward was paid for baiting his bears uppon the Corn Hill in the centre of Ipswich. Other entries indicate that a lord had more than one bearward, as in payments to Lord Vesey's bearwards in 1578–9, Lord Berkeley's in 1581–2, and Lord Sheffield's in 1591–2. Whether such entries are referring to a bearward and his assistants or to several bearwards working together is unclear.
Such events must have been considerable spectacles. Payments to the bearwards range from 6s 8d to 10s, comparable to the amounts given important troupes of actors.

Bull baiting, while considered an entertaining diversion by spectators through the early nineteenth century, was apparently more of a tedious statutory regulation to many butchers (baiting was thought to tenderize the meat). In nearly every year Ipswich civic officials collected many fines from butchers who had failed to bait their bulls before slaughtering them. The city even hired a man to detect unbaited bulls and report the offending butcher.Ipswich, Suffolk Archives: Ipswich Audited Accounts, C/3/3/2/17, f [3]. Apparently butchers were content to pay fines rather than organize a baiting. Some baitings certainly did occur; civic account record payments to repair the rope and collar for the bulls but the accounts include no payments for the baitings themselves.

row.cell: Item sold sent Nycholas cote & woode greately eatyn wyth mothes
Item sold & toke of the sylver & stonys & sold them by the selffe
Item sold the bare myter vnto a paynter of sudbury hall

div.p: This garment and mitre had once been used by the boy bishop in Long Melford, in ceremonies abolished under the brief reign of Edward VI. This account was made by churchwardens William Dyke and William Marchall.

row.cell: Item of the profitt of a game kepptt at witsontyde
Item to Mr Rycherd Clopton for a seme of malt Ageynst þe gamyng
Item to Hammont for proclaymyng the games at BrantreBrantre: Braintree, Essex, & to peter for proclaymyng them at ypwyche
Item for borowyng of pottes at ye gamyng
Item to Bettes for settyng of xiij settes in ye Churche yerd
Item layd owt for that was owyng for ye games & for frynge

div.p: This folio of the account includes receipts of 41s 1d from a church ale, plus 22s 1d from a gathering made at the same ale by the the 'bachelors' (so identified in the subsequent entry), and a further 35s by the same bachelors. The bachelors routinely conducted gatherings on Plough Monday but the entry does not identify the ale in these entries as having occurred on Plough Monday, nor do the entries refer to mimetic activities (as would have occurred, for example, at a Whitsun Ale).
Folio 36v is headed 'Anno domini 1555' but no day/month range is specified. The sum at the foot of the previous folio is for 'one hole yere endyed at Ianuarye Anno Domini 1554.'
Folio 39 is headed 'Anno domini 1556,' and f 40v 'Anno domini 1557, both with no day/month range specified.

'[M]alet' (f 39) in this instance may mean 'malt' because on f 46, the miller of Hall Mill was paid for the grinding of two seams (sixteen bushels) of malt for the church ale. A seam equals two coombes. A coombe of grain equals four bushels. Therefore the parish bought two bushels. The purchase of malt against the gaming seemingly indicates that the play or game was mounted in conjunction with, or as part of, a church ale.
It was apparently the practice in Long Melford to send a single person to proclaim its game (and a different person for each place), rather than sending a troupe to cry the bans.

row.cell: Item paid to ffyrmin the glasier for mendinge the windowes that were broke at the scoole masters playe

div.p: The account is chronologically arranged, and the entry for the schoolmaster's play comes between midsummer and 2 October. An elementary school was present in Long Melford before 1484, and in 1548 a deed refers to Sir Edward Tyrell, a stipendiary priest of Long Melford as aiding the curate and teaching a grammar school at Long Melford (VCH: Suffolk, vol 2, p 340). The records do not indicate the venue at which the schoolmaster's play was performed.

The Long Melford churchwardens' accounts between 1573 and 1641 (FL 509/5/1) contain many payments to a widow known as 'waytes wyfe' or 'wedow wayte' (ff [1, 3v, 4, and ff]) and to another woman for keeping the deceased man's children (f [1v]). Whether he had been a musician is unclear from the records, but his family required poor relief from the parish. Typical is the entry 'payd to waites wyfe vj d.' (f [3v]).

div.head: single membrane
div.ab: The Scite of the Rectory with a hall and parlor at the west end thereof, and twoo butt ryes on the Est, being vnder one roofe, tyled throughout, with one stable & malting howse therevnto adioyning, and a barne with three bay=steds, all of them thacht togither with a yard , orchard=plot, & to est as they ly betwixt the Church=yard there in part, & the lands of Edmund Wittipot knight in part on the Est, and the lands of Akenham=hall in the tenure of Iohn Rose on. the west abutting vpon Maypole pyghtell south, and vpon the glebe-land of the said parsonage north, Containing togither by estimacion terce acres (more or les).

div.p: According to Birch, 'Rise Hall, near the church, is a late Georgian building on the site of an ancient manor house, formerly the residence of the Le Ruse or Rous family in the C13,' an apparent reference to Akenham Hall (Ancient Sites, p 16).

row.cell: Item paid to ye bearwarde of my Lordes beares

div.p: The closest dated entry before this payment occurred on 1 July 1567; the closest entry to follow is 24 September 1567. Thus this payment to the bearward occurred between those two dates.

Thomas Howard (p 34; 1537/8–72) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex, Kenninghall, Norfolk, and Duke's Palace, Norwich; he was executed for treason. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to Iohn browne ye mynstrell in parte of payment for ye clock
Item paid to ye Dukes bearwarde at ye balliffs comandement
Item paid for cartynge of Iohn Arnolde and alis smarte abowte þe towne & for þe pyper
Item paid to Iohn browne ye mynstrell more for ye dyall

div.p: The penultimate entry on f 12 (occuring two entries after the payment to the piper) refers to a meeting that was planned to occur on 15 August, indicating, as do several references to the payment of quarterly wages, that the payments on this folio were all made in August.
Browne the minstrel is one of several persons, including the priest, who were paid for contributing to the refurbishing of the clock.

A partial picture of John Browne can be pieced together from the several entries that mention him. In 1567–8 he is identified as a minstrel and in 1573–4 as a wait. He is paid in 1573–4 and 1574–5 for having a blind boy in his care, probably a poor boy taken as as an apprentice musician, since later records (see below) show that to have been the practice in Aldeburgh. These payments for wood at the church and for whiting the church, show him to have been employed, at least intermittently, by the parish. It is impossible to know whether the reference to stages indicates carpenter's scaffolding or stages for playing, but the Queen's Men did play in Aldeburgh that year. Someone named Brown, presumably this person, was dead in 1573–4 (f 78v) and a different person (John Batche) then took responsibility for the clock.

Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason.

row.cell: Item for wood for Iohn browne at ye Churche
Item to Iohn browne for whiting ye Church
Item to Iohn browne for ij bushelles of glovers shredes
Item for nayles to mak the stagis

div.p: The church referred to on f 49v is the Aldeburgh parish church of Saints Peter and Paul. It is built near the site of a Saxon church.
This payment to the Queen's players on f 52v occurs between entries dated 1 November and 1 December.
Elizabeth Tudor (f 52v; 1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

row.cell: To ye Blind boy being sent to mr brovnes
To Mr Bayly periman for Riding to ye Sessions with the blind boye
To thomas Smithes wiff for a ffourthnightes bourde of ye Blind boy

div.p: Mr Periman, who carried the blind boy to the sessions on f 67v, was one of the town's two bailiffs, the other being Mr Bence, in 1572-3. In 1574 Mr Periman reimbursed the town 6d for his seal of office (f 77). In that same year, his fellow bailiff, Mr Bence, received 24s for 2 cades (half-barrels) of full herrings, and 3 shillings for 2 cades of spratt (smelt) (f 80). Fishing was the town's principal commercial activity. In the same year the town paid Mr Periman for his dinner while travelling about the town's business (f 80). Of particular relevance to this collection, in 1584-5 Mr Periman paid unnamed players 10s. By 1595 Periman had disappeared from the records, replaced by a new bailiff, one Mr Nelson. Mr Bence continued.

row.cell: To Robert Hind for a Iyrken a paire of briches for making linyng & buttons for the same for ye blind Boye
To parsonne for a paire of shoes for ye blind boye
To thomas Smithes wiff for vj weekes keping of þe blinde boye at ij s. vj d. ye weke
To thomas smithes wiff for ye blind boyes bourd iij weekes & iij dayes at ij s. vj d. ye week
ffor a Shirt for ye blind boye
To ye earle of Lecesters menne when thei plaied in ye ChurchChurch: ie, of Saints Peter and Paul ye xxti of Ivne
To Robert LettesRobert Lettes: the town crier for his quater wages at mydsomer
more to him for writing of ye mvster book
more to him for going to mennes hovss to Bydd them to come to ffremans to ye play
More to him for him: John Foxe, one of the town's two bailiffs Mr caves man for ye blind boy
To thomas browne ye wait when he Receyved the Blind Boye

div.p: The Freman (or ffreman, who hosted the play on f 80v, was an innkeeper (Winn, Records, p 11).

The earl of Leicester whose men played in the church on f 80v was Robert Dudley (1532–3–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: To thomas Browne for ye blynde boy
for carieng of staging & Ropes for ye church
Item paid to peter Hont mvsicion for taking blind Harry to prentis
To thomas Lovenes his wiff for ye said harries bedd
To Brovne þe wait for blind harrie
To my Lord of Bathes players

div.p: The entries on ff 103v and 106, as well as the one for 1573–4, seem to indicate that Blind Harry lived in the care of the wait, Thomas Brown, but was apprenticed to another musician, Peter Hunt, or that for some other reason he was shuttled back and forth between the two musicians during these years.
In the general receipts section on f 121, the words 'Blind Harrie' are written large in the left margin, but the reason why is unclear.
The lord of Bath, whose players received a reward on f 114, was William Bourchier (1557–1623), fourth earl of Bath, with residence at Tawstock, Devon. See P&P.

Because of a payment six entries later that was made on Coronation Day (17 November), the payment to Bathes' players was likely made sometime in the first half of November, perhaps even on Coronation Day.
The patron lord Sheafildes mentioned on f 114v was Edmund Sheffield (1565–1646), third Baron Sheffield (of Butterwick) from 1568, with residence at Hammersmith, Middlesex. See P&P.

row.cell: Deliuered at þe commaundment of Mr bailiffes to ye Earle of Leicesters menne

div.p: On f 123v, a payment of wages made six items after this one occurred at Michaelmas 1578, thus the payment to Leicester's Men likely occurred sometime in that same September.

The earl of Leicester whose men were paid on f 123v was Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to my Lord Robertes menne & my Lord howardes menne when they played heere
paid to blynd harry at mr beuershins commandement
paid to Roberte hind for cloth for blinde harry
paid for a Coat for blind harry
more for a paire of bryches & ye making
more for a shirt & a paire of hose for him

div.p: There are no dated entries on f 136v, but the first entry on f 137 is a reckoning dated 3 September 1579, suggesting that the payment to Robert's men and Howard's men occurred in the later part of high summer.

The Lord Robert whose men were paid on 136v, was either Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex, or Robert Rich (c 1537–1580/1), second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex (though he was known as Lord Rich, not Lord Robert). See P&P pages for Robert Dudley and Robert Rich.
The Lord Howard on f 136v was Charles Howard (1536–1624), Lord Howard from 1573 and lord chamberlain 1574–7, tenth earl of Nottingham, with a residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P
An order for payment six entries later on f 138v identifies Mr Beuershin as one of the two bailiffs of the town.

row.cell: for a shalme for blind harry
more for a vyall for him
more for a Case for his vyall
more for a Case for his Shalme
To the mynstrelles at ye Lordes Court
To Iohn Bettes to bye blynd harry a Coat

div.p: The lord who held court on f 147 was Thomas Howard, duke of Norfolk, described as the lord of Aldeborough in letters patent granted on 21 October 1568 (see Great Britain, Historical Manuscripts Commission, Report on Manuscripts in Various Collections, W.D. Macray (ed), vol 4 (Dublin, 1907), 280).

Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.
Based on nearby entries in the account, the transaction on f 148 occurred in the Christmas season 1580.

row.cell: paid for the waites vittelles & gateslsgatesls: likely for gastels at christmes Court
paid to the Players ye iijd day of Avgust at mr bayliffes commandement
paid to Lionell manclarke for making of the devilles Coat
paid for paynting of ye devilles coat

div.p: Concerning the payments made to the Queen's players on f 180, payments made three entries before and six entries after it, the payment to the Queen's players occurred between 1 June and Midsummer.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

Entries for the devil's coat on f 182 occur between entries dated (respectively) 6 October and 20 October. Winn, Records, p 11, dates the entries related to the devil's coat as occurring in 1581, but they occurred in 1582-3. The bailiff's payment to 'the Players' on 3 August, and payments for gear related to the devil, suggest that these were local players likely performing a morality play.
The payment on f 183 is preceded, two entries earlier, by a payment made on the Sunday before Christmas 1583, thus this payment was likely made for a play on or near Christmas.

row.cell: paid for a coat for blynd harry
Item gyven to the Earle of Arundels players
paid to gryffyn for ye iiijor waites dynners

div.p: On f 194, based on a dated entry several entries earlier and one immediately after, this purchase for Harry was made between 13 and 26 April.

On f 195v, the entry immediately preceding this one, to the earl of Arundel's players, is dated 8 July 1584. The next dated entry, on the following leaf, is 15 August. Arundel's players likely visited c 7 July.
Philip Howard (1557–1595) was twenty-fifth earl of Arundel from 1579/80 to 14 January 1589, when he was attainted. He had residences at Arundel Castle, Sussex, and West Horsley, Surrey. See P&P.

row.cell: paid the xvijth of Ianuary for the waites
paid to mr periman for the players

div.p: The page containing this payment to the players has no dated entries. The nearest dated entry on the previous page is dated 20 September. Mr Periman was one of the town's two bailiffs at this time; the other was Mr Bence). In 1574 Mr Periman, for example, reimbursed the town 6d for his seal of office (f 77). In that same year, his fellow bailiff, Mr Bence, received 24s for 2 cades (half- barrels) of full herrings, and 3 shillings for 2 cades of spratt (smelt) (f 80). Fishing was the town's principal commercial activity. In the same year, the town paid Mr Periman for his dinner while traveling about the town's business(f 80). In 1581-2, Leicester's men received 20s at the command of the bailiffs (f 123v). By 1595, Periman had disappeared from the records, replaced by a new bailiff, one Mr Nelson. Mr Bence continued.

row.cell: paide to Blinde Harrie þe xxjth of maye 86
paid ye xxixth of September to Anthonie benedick for playeng of the drvmme

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I of England 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
