div.head: p 85 (8 May)
div.ab: At this court the bailiffs, townsmen, and the whole community granted that they shall pay for the maintenance of the Corpus Christi pagent just as they paid last year passed to be levied from the guilds of the same town, namely £3 11s etc.

From St George, 6s 8d; from St John, 5s; from St Thomas, 4s; from St Giles, 4s; from the carpenters, 5s; from the weavers, 3s; from the fullers, 5s; from the shoemakers, 6s; from the fishmongers, 3s; from the butchers, 5s; from the skinners, 3s; from the dyers, 3s 4d; from the mercers, 6s 8d; from the merchants, 8s; from the bakers, 3s 4d.
In total, £3 11s 6d

div.p: The hand specifying the sum total at the end of the first paragraph is the same as the one giving the detailed account of each guild's payment and the sum total in the second transcribed here. The two paragraphs are separated by two other paragraphs in the original hand which record other decisions taken at the session.

div.head: p 170 (29 September–29 September)
div.ab: ffower Guild wardens elected./
Corpus Christi pageant shall be provided at the charge of suche as have been used.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 170 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 23 December.

div.head: p 434 (24 April) (Ordinance)
div.ab: Ordinatum est quod decetero ludus siue le Pagent qui a multo tempore vsitabatur in die Corporis Christi & olim ad aliquod tempus non vsiebaturvsiebatur: for vsitabatur (?)quid per nobliyem modo concordatum est quod decetero inperpetuum tenebitur & custodiatur. Et ad supportandum illud quidam artifex ad illum convenient'convenient': for conveniens habebit annuatim pro termino certo .xl s. quod debet leuari ob formaforma: initially written foma; r written in afterwards so that it partially obscures o sequenti videlicet de quoque portmanno xvj d. & quoque xxiiijr xxiiijr: for xxiiijr s. viij d. que attingit ad xxxij s. & Residuum videlicet viij s. leuandi de residuis inhabitandisinhabitandis: for inhabitantibus sivibus xxiiijr

Insuper ordinatum quod nullus Balliuus pro suo tempore non impediet nec aliquid facietnullus … faciet: double negative to be disregarded in translation sic quod ludus siue le pagent auantdit non teneatur in dicto die Corporis Christi nisi sit per Curiam de portmanmote siue aliquod aliud speciale Sub pena utriusque Balliui x li. ad opus Gilde predicte
Thomas Baldry & William Ropkyn Balliui nominauerunt Robertum Godwyn & Ricardum Leneacre ad Colligendum pecunias pour le pagent in die Corporis Christi

div.head: p 434 (24 April) (Ordinance)
div.ab: ⸿ It has been determined that from henceforth the play or 'the pageant' which for a long time was performed on Corpus Christi day and sometimes was not performed at any time [anything by noble] now it has been agreed that from henceforth in perpetuity it will be observed and maintained. And to support that, a certain craftsman appropriate for that (purpose) will have 40s annually for a fixed term, which ought to be levied in the following manner, namely 16d from each councillor, and also 24s 8d which amounts to 32s, and the rest, that is 8s, is to be levied from [remaining inhabitants] twenty-four citizens.

Moreover, it was ordained that no baillif during his time (in office) shall impede or do anything so that the play or 'the aforesaid pageant' not be held on the said Corpus Christi day unless it be by portmanmoot court or some other special thing under penalty of £40 of each baillif for the use of the aforesaid guild.
Thomas Baldry and William Ropkyn, bailiffs, nominated Robert Godwyn and Richard Leneacre to collect money for the pagent on Corpus Christi day.

div.p: The first sentence of the first paragraph is poorly formed, having two governing clauses: 'Ordinatum est quod' and 'concordatum est quod'; rather than choose between the two, a literal translation has been given.

div.head: p 498 (8 April)
div.ab: Nominauerunt Thomam Cady & Henricum Stannard ColligendumColligendum: for ad Colligendum lx s. pro ludo in die Corporis Christi

div.head: p 548 (9 December)
div.ab: concesserunt quod Thomas Drayll & Edwardus Daundy habebunt pro Superoneracione sua circa ludum Corporis Christi Vnum Burgensem admittendum proxime. pro quod ffestum Willielmus Crowe assignatur eisdem

div.head: p 498 (8 April)
div.ab: They nominated Thomas Cady and Henry Stannard to collect 40s for the play on Corpus Christi day.

div.head: p 548 (9 December)
div.ab: They granted that Thomas Drayll and Edward Daundy, on account of their overburdening regarding the Corpus Christi play, shall have one burgess to be admitted next for that feast. William Crowe is assigned to the same.

div.head: p 570 (22 April)
div.ab:
mend' & etiam inveniet diuersos lusores
a tontz manges & boies pour tantz homez prendo quolibet anno pro eidem xxvj s.
omnia ornamenta pro eodem ludo es necessaries ‸pour le terme de xij anz& tontz Anz garda a le

div.head: p 570 (22 April)
div.ab: and also he shall find various players as many sleeves and armrings for as many men each year for the same, 26s
all ornaments for the same game (or play) necessary for the term of twelve years keep at the

div.p: More than half of the page, on the left side, is missing. The translation is therefore incomplete and very tentative. It is impossible to know if the 'lusores' of this fragmentary entry are connected with the Corpus Christi play of the order that follows. Nathaniel Bacon summarizes the order as saying 'Granted to John Stangilts, 20s 8d yerely for 12 yeres, to finde the stageing for Corp' Chr'i play. And to John Parnell, 33s 4d, to find the ornaments during suche time, and collectors named of assessments for the play'(Annalls of Ipswiche, p 177).

div.head: p 53 (25 September)
div.ab: Memorandum ad hanc Curiam Iohannes porteman soluit gardianos gillde corporis Christi xvj d.

div.head: p 53 (25 September)
div.ab: Memorandum: at this court John Porteman paid 16d for the wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi.

div.head: p 102 (26 March)
div.ab: EtEleccio eligerunt Ricardum Blodevell & Willellmum Deade ad officium Collectoris pro le pagent Corporis Christi

Precepti omnes inhabitantes & occupaciones ville. attendere & habeant tabernacula sua.pena ad festum corporis Christi proxime ffuturis sub pena cuiuslibet eorum vj s. viij d. &c. et quod conseruent ordinem processionis sicut continetur in libro constitucionum constitucionum: possibly for constitucioni with 4 minims for ni

div.head: p 102 (26 March)
div.ab: AndElection they choose Ricard Blodevell and William Deade for the office of the collector for the Corpus Christi pageant.

All the inhabitants and occupations of the city are ordered to attend and they shall have their tentspenalty at the feast of Corpus Christi next to come under penalty of 6s 8d for each of them, etc, and they shall preserve the order of the procession just as is found in the book of constitutions.

div.head: p 308 (7 November)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam ordinauerunt willelmum Rivet magistros de le pagent sancti Georgij Thomam Cuttinge & Iohannem Smythe & vequeveque: for vterque (?) eorum dabit predicto pageant ‸sancti Georgij vj s. viij d. Et Willelmus Rivet x s. Et Iohannes Catemayn x s. Et Iohannes Best x s. Et Thomas Melys x s. Et Iohannes Stannard x s. Et Christoferus lynner vj s. viij d. Et Thomas Bryan iij s. iiij d. Et Rogerus Smythe iij s. iiij d. Et Iohannes Southe xx d. Et Robertus Hardynge xij d. Et Iohannes Hardynge xij d. Et Nicholaus Cutynge iij s. iiij d. Et Radulfus Pegge xij d. Et Iohannes Bushe xij d. Et Robertus Bird xij d. Et Michaelis Wright vj s. viij d. Et Iohannes Barbour xx d. Et Willelmus Cuttynge xx d. Et Thomas Miles xx d. Et Ricardus Spynk xij d. Et Iohannes Peeck xij d. Et He Iohannes Hauk xij d. Et Robertus Byrde Tiler xx d. Et Petrus Lambe iij s. iiij d. Et Willelmus Nores xij d.

div.head: p 308 (7 November)
div.ab: At this court they appointed William Rivet Thomas Cuttinge and John Smythe masters of the pageant of St George and each will give the aforesaid pageant of St George 6s 8d, and William Rivet 10s, and John Catemayn 10s, and John Best 10s, and Thomas Melys 10s, and John Stannard 10s, and Christopher Lynner 6s 8d, and Thomas Bryan 3s 4d, and Roger Smythe 3s 4d, and John Southe 20d, and Robert Hardynge 12d, and John Hardynge 12d, and Nicholas Cutynge 3s 4d, and Ralf Pegge 12d, and John Bushe 12d, and Robert Bird 12d, and Michael Wright 6s 8d, and Jon Barbour 20d, and William Cuttynge 20d, and Thomas Miles 20d, and Richard Spynk 12d, and John Peeck 12d, and John Hauk 12d, and Robert Byrde, tiler, 20d, and Peter Lambe 3s 4d, and William Nores 12d.

div.head: p 330 (21 April)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam Concordatum est perper: corrected from pro burgensisburgensis: for burgenses predictos quod ludus vocatus Corpus Christi pley pro anno sequenti dimittitur et non luditurluditur: for ludetur(?) Et quod prandium vocatum xx: likely for deletion Corpus Christi Dyner pro anno sequenti similiter dimittitur et differratur et quod quilibet burgensis soluet pro predicto anno sequenti v s. Sufficiencia presbit' inventa erit pro eodem anno ad selebrandum missam pro . animabus fratrum et sororum burgensium predicte ville illius viij d. &c. vel aliter nichil

div.head: p 330 (21 April)
div.ab: At this court it was agreed by the aforesaid burgesses that the pastime called the Corpus Christi play is cancelled for the following year and will not be played and that the meal called the Corpus Christi dinner is likewise cancelled and will be put off and that each burgess shall pay for the aforesaid following year 5s. A sufficient amount for the priest/s will be found for that year for celebrating the mass for the souls of the brothers and sisters of the burgesses of that aforesaid town 8d etc, or otherwise nothing.

div.head: p 186 (24 January)
div.ab: Corpus Christi pageant and dinner againe laid aside.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 185 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 24 January.

div.head: p 188 (5 June)
div.ab: Corpus Christi play and dinner laide aside againe.
All the Utensiles belonging to Corpus Christi Guild shall be entred into a booke, to be kept safe by Iohn Butler to the use of the Guild

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 188 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 5 June.

A subsequent order, also on p 188, directs that the guild's many utensils (spoons, dishes, and so on) be kept safe. A connection between the play and the dinner (if there was any) is not clearly indicated in the records. Corpus Christi orders by the guild do often mention the play and dinner together in the same order, and the guild often pays for the building of scaffolds as part of guild feasts, which could indicate that the Corpus Christi play was indoors and was, therefore, intended for a small, privileged audience of burgesses and their wives as part of the feast (making the utensils a useful bit of evidence). But to take those considerations as fact would be to go beyond the evidence.

div.head: p 28 (13 March)
div.ab: ⸿ Ad hanc Curiam eligerunt in Gardianos Gilde Corporis Christi pro anno sequenti Robertum Cobat & Iohannem Petman

⸿ Ad hanc Curiam eligerunt Willelmum Nottyngham & Ricardum Humfrey Magistros de le Pagent de le Shippe pro anno sequenti & concordatum est quod hebebunthebebunt: for habebunt le Shippe paratum ad diem Corporis Christi sub pena forisfacture decem librarum
⸿ Ad hanc Curiam concordatum est quod ludus vocatus Corpus Christi Play pro hoc anno differratur & non luditurluditur: forludatur neque teneturtenetur: for teneatur

⸿ Ad hanc Curiam ordinatum est quod quilibet de le xxiiijor habebit togam cum Capam de Murrey ‸ingrayned citra festum Corporis Christi sub pena forisfacture s : likely written in another hand;
represents 64mm of erased text

div.head: p 28 (13 March)
div.ab: ⸿ At this court they selected Robert Cobat and John Petman as wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi for the following year.

⸿ At this court they selected William Nottingham and Richard Humfrey as masters of pageant of the ship for the following year and it was agreed that they shall have the ship prepared on pain of forfeiture of £10.
⸿ At this court, it was agreed that the play called the Corpus Christi play shall be deferred for this year and shall not be played nor held.
⸿ At this court it was decided that each of the twenty-four shall have a robe with a cape (or cap) from Murrey dyed before the feast of Corpus Christi on pain of forfeiture.

div.head: p 82 (3 April)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam eligerunt Thomam Bloise & Iohannem Petman Gardianos Corporis Christi pro anno proxime futuro & quod Prandium vocatum Corporis Christi dynner custoditur & tenetur Et quod v ludus vocatus Corporis Christi Play non luditur set deferratur

div.head: p 82 (3 April)
div.ab: At this court they elected Thomas Bloise and John Petman, wardens of Corpus Christi for the year next to come and (it was decided) that the repast called 'the Corpus Christ dinner' is kept and held and that the play called 'the Corpus Christi play' is not played but shall be deferred.

At this court it was agreed that the play called Corpus Christi is not played this year but is deferred.

div.head: p 204 (14 May)
div.ab: Corpus Christi play putt off, and the Court adjourned till ffriday next.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 204 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 14 May.

div.head: p 272 (12 March)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam omnes Burgenses aggreati & concordati ‸sunt quod ludus de Corpus Christi pro hoc anno sequenti non luditur

div.head: p 272 (12 March)
div.ab: At this court all the burghers were agreed and in accord that the Corpus Christi play is not played for the following year.

div.head: mb [8] (29 September–29 September)(Payments)
div.ab: To Master brandon the Kynges Iugler

row.cell: Item payd to Master brandond the Kynges Iugler for hys Reward

div.ab: Mynstrelles pleyers & berewardes

row.cell: Item to the erle of Darbys pleyers
Item to the dewke off Northfolkes mynstrelles
Item to the lorde of schrewsburys mynstrelles
Item to the Kynges mynstrelles At a nothyr tyme
Item to the frenche quenys berward

div.p: Thomas Brandon, an entertainer, was a servant to Henry VIII. Although the King referred to him as 'our pleyer,' Brandon was neither an actor nor a juggler but, as John Southworth puts it, a 'stage magician' (a 'tregatour' or 'prestigiator' in Latin usage). That he was much favoured is clear in that in 1522 Henry VIII requested the City of London to make him a freeman of the city, with the occupation of leather seller, a position that made it possible for Brandon to hire out his performing skills to the companies of London, bypassing the monopolistic control of the city's musicians and actors guild. Brandon traveled widely to perform throughout the kingdom, in venues as widely scattered as Shrewsbury, Thetford Priory in Norfolk, Exeter, and Barnstaple. He often performed at civic venues, including mayors' houses, on local celebration days. He was even cited with grudging admiration for his illusionist's skills by Reginald Scott Discoverie of Witchcraft indicating that his fame had survived his death (Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 94–9).
Henry Tudor (1491–1546/7) was king of England from 22 April 1509. See P&P.
Edward Stanley (1509–72) was twelfth earl of Derby from 1521, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Thomas Howard (1473–1554) was eighth duke of Norfolk from 1524 to 1546/7 and in 1553-4, with residence at Kenninghall, Norfolk. See P&P.
George Talbot (1468–1538) was seventh earl of Shrewsbury from 1473 until death, with residences at South Wingfield, Derbyshire, Shropshire, and Yorkshire. See P&P.
Mary Tudor (1494/5–1533), wife of Charles Brandon, fourth duke of Suffolk, had been crowned queen of France on 5 November 1514. See P&P.

div.head: p 336 (3 June)
div.ab: ⸿ Ad hanc Curiam concordatum est per prenominatos Balliuos portmannos & Burgenses quod ludus videlicet Corporis Christi pley pro hoc anno non luditur sed defertur

div.head: p 336 (3 June)
div.ab: ⸿ At this court it was agreed by by the aforesaid bailiffs, councillors, and burghers that the play, namely the Corpus Christi play is not played but deferred for this year.

div.head: p 205 (30 January)
div.ab: Corpus Christi play laide for ever aside by order.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 205 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 30 January.

div.head: p 212 (4 November)
div.ab: Granted to three waites, 13s 4d a peece yerely.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 211 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 4 November.

div.head: p 219 (2 June)
div.ab: Every householder, with their family, shall follow the pageants of Corpus Christi in due order, under penalty of 4d, if lawfull cause be not shewen, except the 12 portmen and theire wives, and the 24ty.

Every Warden and Master of the Trade shall offer to theire Pageants uppon the day of Corpus Christi, each of them 1d, the one halfe whereof shall goe to ye parish preist, the other halfe shall be divided between the Clerk and the Sexton, and every defalter shall loose 4d.
Every Burgess shall offer on the Guild Sunday one halfe penny to the preist, to be divided, the one halfe to the preist, the other to the Clerke and Sexton, and every defalter shall loose 4d.

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 219 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 2 June.

The Ipswich civic records indicate that the town annually sponsored several processions as part of its celebration of Corpus Christi. As this order indicates, a civic procession of pageants, accompanied by the entire population of the town, occurred on Corpus Christi Day itself (Thursday of Corpus Christi week). The entire population also took part in a purely liturgical procession spanning Corpus Christi Day and the day after, in which they accompanied the Sacrament of Corpus Christi from the Church of St Lawrence to the fishmarket on the Corn Hill to the St Mary Tower Church, thence to Margaret's Green and around the town, arriving again at St Mary Tower Church where they heard a mass. The following day, the population accompanied the Sacrament on a return journey (this time including Brook Street) to the Church of St Lawrence. The portmen of the town, the twenty-four burgesses, and the torchers, all bearing torches, accompanied the Holy Sacrament (pp 215, 220). The records give no indication that the liturgical processions included pageantry or involved performance.

row.cell: Item payde to the Quynes gestre for a rewarde the xvj day of Iune

div.p: The queen's jester was likely James Lockwood, jester to Queen Mary; see John Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 98-9.

row.cell: Item Received of Iohn Wapolle mynstrell for the ffyne of his indeightment

div.p: In 1559–60 Walpolle (f [2v]) was dwelling in the South Ward of Ipswich in that he is recorded in that year as giving 2s in 'the collection of the forreners of the sowthe warde'(C/3/4/1/2, p 9). See also Webb, Town Finances, p 25). Otherwise no biographical details have come to light.

James Lockwood (f [3]) was jester to Henry VIII, Mary, and Elizabeth I in turn. He appears in performance records between 1540/1 (at Nottingham) and 1570/1(at Leicester), as well as numerous other places. He is variously identified in performance records as 'the Kynges bourdar' and, almost always, as the king or queen's servant and/or jester. His travels to perform included an extraordinary number of cities and large towns throughout the kingdom (most often among them Leicester), and he is described by John Southworth as one among numerous 'semi-independent, peripatetic jesters' who performed in civic and private venues during the Tudor period, though he was never actually recorded at a performance before the Court (see Southworth, Fools and Jesters at the English Court (Stroud, 1998), 98–9).

Mary Tudor (f [6]; 1515/16–58) was crowned queen of England from 1 October 1553 until her death on 17 November, 1558. Her husband, Philip Habsburg (1527–98) was king of Spain from 16 July 1556 and styled king of England from 25 July 1554. See P&P.

John de Vere (c 1516–62) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 21 March 1539/40, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.

div.p: Mary Tudor (f [6]; 1515/16–58) was crowned queen of England from 1 October 1553 until her death on 17 November, 1558. Her husband, Philip Habsburg (1527–98) was king of Spain from 16 July 1556 and styled king of England from 25 July 1554. See P&P.

William Martin (f [6]) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v] and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

Thomas Howard (f [6v]; 1537/8–1572) was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.

Item to my lorde of Oxfordes plaiers

div.p: Peter Moone, a resident of Ipswich, was a tailor, actor, theatre-manager, gospeller, and radical reformist. According to John Webb, who has written a detailed article about him, he 'was a well-known character in the Tudor town' ('Peter Moone,' pp 35–55). He and his wife are recorded as having lived first in St Mary Tower parish, then in St Stevens parish, both in the North Ward. He sometimes drummed at musters for the town until giving way in that task in 1586–7 to John Minter, the town's newly appointed official drummer. In 1571–2 he was paid for drum heads and drum sticks (C/3/2/1/1, f 42v); he had repaired the town's ancient in 1578–9, and had repaired the town drum in 1586-7 (C/3/4/1/18, f 5v). Although Webb describes Moone as of 'low social status,' the many references to him in the records suggest a substantial person (though of limited financial means and always seeking ways to make money). Though originally a 'foreigner,' he was a burgess by 1560 (the year before his troupe performed) and he would serve as a burgess for the final twenty-eight years of his life. In 1581 he was fined for not wearing his gown at official ceremonies. In 1585, when town officials were particularly exercised about the proliferation of seditious rhymes, they hired (and paid the exorbitant amount of 30 li) to Moone to sleuth out the identity of two anonymous rhymers. He succeeded in identifying one of the two. He was a notable among his fellow burgesses, and was a trusted member of St Stephens parish in that he presented on behalf of the parish their contribution of 2d per in year's wages for the preacher (C/3/4/1/18, f 1; Webb, 'Peter Moone,' pp 35, 43–5).

Of particular resonance concerning this collection, Moone was one of the group of radical thinkers and writers present in Ipswich in the 1540's. In 1548 he published 'A short treatise of certayne things abused in the Popysh Church,' 'a rhyming tract of thirty-seven eight-line stanzas.' The tract is reprinted in Webb, 'Peter Moone,' pp 46-52. Moone's use of language shows him to have been a talented writer. While the tract is a sermon of sorts, in form it is a dramatic monologue. In the first stanza, he refers to 'this audience.' During the reign of Mary, he was fined and jailed in London for four months on suspicion of conspiracy and during the subsequent reign he acted as a source of contemporary witness by John Foxe in his Acts and Monuments. Some scholars have postulated that when Queen Elizabeth visited Ipswich on 5–11 August, 1561 – arriving by boat from Dunmow, Essex – the program of events staged in her honor included a performance by Moone's troupe of John Bale's King Johan. However, no evidence to confirm that suggestion has yet come to light (Webb, 'Peter Moone,' pp 37–8, 42).
Whether Moone's troupe comprised actors recruited for this one event or was a sustaining troupe whose patron was Moone is impossible to know.

William Martin (f [4v]) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors. Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market; see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).
John de Vere (c 1516–62) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 21 March 1539/40, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564 with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

Katherine Willoughby (1518/19–80) was likely twelfth Baroness Willoughby of Eresby, duchess of Suffolk, with seats at Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire from c 1536, with a residence at Westhorpe, Suffolk, from c 1528. See P&P.

Item there ys dewe vnto me Robart andrew . ij ll. xiiij s. x d. of moyemoye: for monye; abbreviation mark missing that I Layde not alowed owt att Mr. Gardeners Commandement then beynge Mr. Bayle for the Repayrenge of a pynnes at the quenes Maiesties Commynge to thys towne

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

Katherine Willoughby (1518/19–80) was likely twelfth Baroness Willoughby of Eresby, duchess of Suffolk, with seats at Grimsthorpe Castle and Tattershall Castle, Lincolnshire from c 1536, with a residence at Westhorpe, Suffolk, from c 1528. See P&P.

Romsey (f [3v]) was almost certainly John Ramsey, a carver or joiner, and the same Ramsey who was paid by the burgesses two years later for staging another play on 8 December (C/3/2/1/1, f 8). Ramsey was part of a group of radical reformists including Peter Moone and Richard Argentine alias Sexten who were active in Ipswich from the 1530's on. A talented group, they wrote and published their own anti-Catholic tracts as well as those of continental authors, and preached in the town, reciting their own tracts which combined poetry, dramatic monologue, politics, and evangelical arguments underpinned by scriptural quotations (Webb, 'Peter Moone,' p 36). Ramsey is thought to have authored the undated A Corosyfe to be layed hard unto the hartes of all faythfull Professours of Christes Gospel, Gathered out of the sciptures by Iohn Ramsey. Given the evangelical content of the work, its sermonly rhetorical approach, and the fact that Ramsey was nearly 60 years old in 1562-3, together with the fact that Ramsey was 'an uncommon Ipswich surname,' Webb concludes that 'he Ramsey may well have been described as "Father"'('Peter Moone,' p 42). Ramsey also served as bailiff of Ipswich Manor of Christchurch for Edmund Withipoll in the mid-1540's, suffered for his views during the reign of Mary, and, like Moone, later served as a contemporary witness for John Foxe in his writing of Acts and Monuments (Webb, pp 36, 38).
John de Vere (1516–62) was sixteenth earl of Oxford from 21 March 1539/40, with residence at Hedingham Castle, Essex. See P&P.

Robert Dudley (1532–1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. He was knighted but generally styled Lord Robert Dudley. See P&P.

row.cell: Item payde to younge braine for playinge on the drome at ther goinge forthe

div.p: This payment occurred in June. The 'goinge forthe' could refer either to a military exercise of some kind, as in a muster, or to a processional event that was typical of the civic guild in its activities.

div.p: Robert Dudley (f [4v]; 1532–1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. He was knighted but generally styled Lord Robert Dudley. See P&P.
William Willoughby (f [5v]; 1515–70) was first Baron Willoughby of Parham from 1546/7, with residence at Parham, Suffolk. See P&P.

William Smart (f [6]) was an important and trusted official of the town, who served as treasurer in 1560–1, and as bailiff in 1586–7 (ff 126, 149). In 1596 when the town was wanting in cash, he lent it £300 (f11). He appears many times in the accounts as a benefactor, collector, and witness of the accounts.
Sir Ralph Sadler (f [6v]; 1507–87) was knighted in 1540, with residence at Standon, Hertfordshire. See ODNB.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Francis Russell (f [7]; 1527–85) was fourth earl of Bedford from 14 March 1554/5, with residences at Amersham and Chenies, Buckinghamshire, and Woburn Abbey, Bedfordshire. See P&P.
Robert Rich (c 1537-81), was second Baron Rich from 1567, with residences at Leigh's Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.p: Ramsey (f 8) was almost certainly John Ramsey, a carver or joiner, who was part of a group of radical reformists including Peter Moone and Richard Argentine, alias Sexten, who were active in Ipswich from the 1530's on. A talented group, they wrote and published their own anti-Catholic tracts as well as those of continental authors, and preached in the town reciting their own tracts which combined poetry, dramatic monologue, politics, and evangelical arguments underpinned by scriptural quotations (Webb, 'Peter Moone,' p 36). Ramsey is thought to have authored the undated A Corosyfe to be layed hard unto the hartes of all faythfull Professours of Christes Gospel, Gathered out of the sciptures by Iohn Ramsey. Given the evangelical content of the work, its sermonly rhetorical approach, and the fact that Ramsey was nearly sixty years old in 1562–3, together with the fact that Ramsey was 'an uncommon Ipswich surname,' Webb concludes that 'he [Ramsey] may well have been described as "Father"' ('Peter Moone,' p 42). Ramsey also served as bailiff of the Ipswich manor of Christchurch for Edmund Withipoll in the mid-1540's, suffered for his views during the reign of Mary, and, like Moone, later served as a contemporary witness for John Foxe in his writing of Acts and Monuments ('Peter Moone,' pp 36, 38).
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (f 8v ; 1532 or 1533–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.
Sir John Byron (c 1488–1576), knight, was lord lieutenant of Sherwood Forest and sheriff of Nottinghamshire and Derbyshire, with residences at Colwick, Nottinghamshire and Newstead Abbey. See P&P.
William Somerset (c 1527–88/9), Lord Herbert, was eighth earl of Worcester from 26 November 1549, with a seat at Raglan, Monmouthshire and residence at Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. div.p: The heading of this treasurer's account (by the treasurer, Robert Sallowse) says that it was made on 8 December in 10 Elizabeth for the year before (that is, for 1567–8). But the heading does not specify the year, as most of the accounts in this series do. The account immediately follows the treasurer's account for 1577–8 (by Henry Hannam), and precedes Hannam's account for 1578–9, and has thus been placed out of sequence in the volume of accounts. Allen confirms that Robert Sallowse served as Treasurer at least four times: in 1562-3, 1564-5, 1565-6 and 1568-8 (Ipswich Borough Archives, pp 237-8

William Martin (f 166) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.p: The heading given by Bacon on his p 277 (presumably taken from a now-lost court book) says that this meeting of the court occurred on 24 September.

div.p: William Martin (f [9v]) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' ROMARD, pp 191–2).
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
William Stanley (f [10v]; c 1528–81) was third Baron Monteagle from 25 August 1560, with seat at Hornby Castle, Lancashire. See P&P.
Mr Denny (f [11v] was Edward Denny (1547-11 February 1599/1600), of Waltham Abbey, Essex. He was knighted 26 October 1589 by William Fitz Williams, lord deputy of Ireland.

div.p: While Becon (f 19v) has not been identified with certainty, John Wasson concludes that he is probably Sir John Becon, father of John Becon (d. 1587), LLD, of Suffolk, distinguished Cambridge scholar, canon of Norwich, 1574, and chancellor of the diocese of Norwich, 1576; and of Richard Becon, an 'official in Ireland under Queen Elizabeth' (Wasson, Plays and Players, p 214).
The entry following the payment to 'Becones men' is a payment made on 6 November.
Robert Rich (f 20v; c 1537–1580/1) was second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

'Mr Foskewes' (f 21) probably refers to Sir Henry Fortescue (by 1515–by 1576), succeeded on 8 August 1517, with his seat at Faulkbourne, Essex. He had extensive lands in Essex and his players were active in the period (several entries). See P&P.

The entry on f 21v following the bearward is dated 1 June. 'dewekes' likely refers to Thomas Howard (1537/8–1572), who was ninth duke of Norfolk and fifteenth earl of Surrey from 25 August 1554, with residences at Charterhouse, Middlesex and Kenninghall, Norfolk; he was executed for treason. See P&P.
George Tuke (1525-74) was sheriff of Essex in 1567, with residence at Layer Marney, situated between Colchester and Maldon, Essex.

row.cell: In primis paidIn primis paid: in display script the iiijth day of october vnto my lord montegewells barwood at commandement
Item paid the xix day of Maye to my Lord Riches men at comawndement of Mr balyffes

div.p: William Stanley (f 4v); c 1527–81) was third Baron Monteagle from 25 August 1560, with seat at Hornby Castle, Lancashire. See P&P.

The entry on f 6 does not confirm that 'my Lord Riches men' were players, but the wording of the entry and the fact that Rich's troupe often visited suggest that the men being paid may have been players. Robert Rich (c 1537–80/1) was second Lord Rich from 12 June 1567, with seats at Leighs Priory and Rochford Hall, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: paid ye .24. daye.24. daye: ie, of October for yat paid my Lord of Sussex playars

paid .11. Iuly to þe playars of Cambrydge

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (f [3v]; 1526/7-1583) was Lord Fitzwalter from 27 November 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 February 1556/7, with residences at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

'my Lord Robartes' (f [3v]) probably refers to Robert Dudley (c 1533–88) who was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

William Martin was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city, and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors. Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' Romard, pp 19–21).
Henry Neville (f [4]; 1527-86/7) was sixth Baron Abergavenny (Borgenys) from 1535 with seat at Comfort, near Birling, Kent See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to William Martyne for his seruice on the yield daie

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). div.head: f 6 (6 December)
div.ab:
Item it is agreed at this assembly that Iohn Mynter in respect of certen seruices and grante to
Iohn myntercharges he was at atat at: dittography ye quenes maiesties beinge here in the Towne & for other consideracions of dromynges by him Challenged at his humble sute & respectinge his pouertye shal have geven to hym by the treasurer xx s. So that he comme at the next audyt & shalbe him self or his wyef well contented to desyer the same and geve a generall acquittance for the promisser

div.p: William Martin (f 42) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). row.cell: Item paid to the Quenes maiesties plaiers At suche time As they plaied before mr Bailiffes & by ther comandiment
Item paid to the Quenes maiesties Berward by the Comaundiment of mr Bailiffes

div.p: Only three of the entries following the queen's players on ff [5v] are dated: 16 October and Christmas and 15 January (. Those dated entries must, respectively, be for 1572, 1572, and 1572/3. Therefore the payment to the queen's players must have occurred during a one-month period in The queen was Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3), crowned 15 January See P&P.

Henry Cheyne (1540–87), Lord Cheyne, knight from 1563, was first Baron Cheyne (of Toddington) from 1572, with residences at Toddington Manor, Bedfordshire and Shurland Hall, Kent, plus lands in Essex. See P&P.

The payment to Lord Talbot's players (f [6v]) happened after 30 June. Francis Talbot (1550–82), Baron Talbot, assumed Lord Talbot 1560; son of George Talbot, sixth earl of Shrewsbury. His father's residence was Sheffield Castle, Yorkshire. See P&P.

div.head: mbs 3-4 (16 May)
div.ab:
Et ultimo damus & concedemus pro nobis heredibus & successoribus nostris prefatis Balliuis Burgensibus & Communitati ville nostre predicte & sucessoribus suis imperpetuum quod bene liceat & licebit tam predictis Balliuis Burgensibis & Comunitati pro tempore existente quam eisdem & talibus gubernatoribus officiarijs vel ministris quos & quales predicti Balliui Burgenses & Communitat'Communitat': for Communitas appunctuabunt siue ordinabunt de tempore in tempus esse gubernatores officiarios vel ministros sub se euisdem domus vocate Christes hospitall aut illarum aliarum domorum eidem hospitali spectanti & tribus vel duobus eorum officiariorum omnino post hac de tempore in tempus tam infra Burgum & villam predictos & suburbijssuburbijs: for suburbia eiusdem quam alibi infra dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie inquirere & examinare diligenter omnibus vijs & modis quibus melius scire potuerint secundum eorum prudenciam & discrecionem omnes & omnimoda suspiciosas domos tabernas diuersaria alieatoria ludos saltatorios ac locos alios quoscumque suspiciosos & libertatem siue libertates & locos exemptos quoscumque suspiciosos infra dictum Burgum & villam & suburbia eiusdem & dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie quibuscumque nominibus seu titulis illa seu eorum alique sint aut erunt vocata nuncupata aut appelata acetiam scrutari inuestigare ac inquirere omnes & singulas domos aliquo modo suspectas siue locos quoscumque suspectos pro ociosis ruffianis ignauis ganionibus vagabundis & vallidis mendicis siue alijs quibuscumque personis suspectis & hominibus quibuscumque & mulieribus seu viris mali nominis & fame Et eosdem Ruffianos ganiones vagabundos & mendicos non solum apprehendere infra easdem domos suspectas seu locos libertatem vel libertates ‸& locos exemptos suspectos existentes infra dictam villam & suburbia eiusdem seu infra dictum Comitatum nostrum Suffolicie Sed etiam tenentes magistros Dominos siue Custodes talium domorum vel locorum suspectorum vbi aliquis talis vel tales inuenti
fuerint vnacum personis suspectis in domum occupacionum de Christes hospitall predicto per aduisamentum & superuisum dictorum quatuor gubernatorum committere aut aliquo alio modo eos omnes & singulos punire per aduisamentum & superuisum predictos prout bonum & legitimum tunc eisdem gubernatoribus expedire videbitur nisi honeste & iuste talium domorum & locorum tenentes magistri Dominj siue Custodes & suspecte persone predicte se excusare atque exonerare possint coram prefatis Balliuis seu quatuor gubernatoribus hospitalis predictis pro tempore existentibus quare tales ociosos Ruffianos & suspectas & vagabundas personas ita alant & nutriant seu permittant in suis domibus iacere conuersari & frequentare atque eciam nisi talis vel tales homines seu mulieres ita suspecti & vagabundi existentes sic capti sufficienter & plene monstrare seu palam facere possunt vel possit pro sua honestate & bona conuersacione & iustam racionem reddere quibus modis victitent vel victitet & quam ob causam ita vagantur vel vagatur & ingrediatur seu ingrediantur huiusmodi suspectos : line filler over erasure domos & absconditeabscondite: for absconditos seu prohibitos locos atque eciam sic apprehensi quod bene licebit dictis Balliuis capere de eisdem suspectibus sufficientem securitatem quod honeste se posthac gerent & quilibet eorum geret.

div.head: mb 3-4 (16 May)
div.ab:
And finally we give and grant on behalf of ourselves, our heirs, and successors to the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty of our aforesaid town and their successors in perpetuity that it be fully permitted and will be permitted both for the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty existing at the time and for the same and such governors, officers, or ministers whom and of what kind the aforesaid bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty will appoint or ordain from time to time to be governers, officers, or ministers under themselves of the same house called Christ's Hospital or of those other houses belonging to the same hospital, and to three or two of their officers in any circumstance after this from time to time both within the aforesaid borough and town and the suburbs of the same as well as elsewhere in our said county of Suffolk to inquire and examine diligently by all ways and means by which they might better know according to their wisdom and discretion, all and all manner of suspected houses, taverns, inns, gaming houses, dancing schools, and whatsoever other suspected places and liberty or liberties and whatsoever suspected exempt places, within the said borough and town and the suburbs of the same, and our said county of Suffolk, by whatever names or titles they or any of them is or will be called, named, or designated, and also to search, investigate, and seek out each and every house in any way suspected, or any places whatsoever, suspected for idle ruffians, lazy gluttons, vagabonds, and sturdy beggars or other suspected persons, whosoever they be, and any people, whosoever they be, both women and men, of evil name and repute, and not only to apprehend within the same suspected house or places, liberty or liberties, and suspected exempt places which are within the said town and suburbs of the same, or within our said county of Suffolk, the same ruffians, gluttons, vagabonds, and beggars, but also to commit the tenants, masters, lords, or keepers of such houses or suspected places where any such person or persons shall be found
together with suspected persons into the house of occupations of the aforesaid Christ's Hospital by deliberation and examination of the said four governors or in any other way to punish each and everyone of them, by the aforesaid deliberation and examination just as it seems (proportionate) at that time to the same governers to expedite the good and lawful, unless the tenants, the masters, lords, or keepers of those houses and places and the aforesaid suspected persons are able to excuse and exonerate themselves honestly and justly before the aforesaid bailiffs or four governors of the aforesaid hospital for the time being, and to show sufficiently and fully why they so feed and nourish such lazy ruffians and suspected persons and vagabonds or permit them to lodge in, dwell in, and frequent their houses, and also unless any such person or any such men or women so suspected and taken as living as vagabonds is able or are able to show sufficiently and fully or to make known with regard to their honesty and good way of life and give just account by what means they live or she or he lives and for what reason they so wander or she or he wanders, and she or he enters or they enter suspected houses of this kind or hidden or prohibited places, and also having been so apprehended that it be quite legal for the bailiffs to take from the same suspects sufficient surety that they will conduct themselves and each of them will conduct him or herself honestly hereafter.

row.cell: Item paid to Martyne & his companye for ther musick at ye yeld

div.p: William Martin (f 50v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (f 70v; 1526/7–83) was Lord Fitzwalter from 27 November 1542 and eight earl of Sussex from 17 February 1556/7, with residences at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.
Henry Wriothesley (f 71v; 1545–81), third earl of Southampton from 1550, with residences at Tichfield and Itchell, near Dogmersfield, Hampshire.
Robert Dudley (f 72v; 1532 or 1533–88), fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

William Martin (f 80) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: geven to my lorde Chamberleynes players at Master Bayliffes comaundement the xviijth of Maye
paid to the playeres of Norwich by Master Bayliffes comaundement the viijth of August
geven my lorde Staffordes players the xviijth of August at the comaundement of Master Bayliffes

div.p: The players of Norwich (f 98v) were likely the waits of Norwich, since there exists no evidence that the City of Norwich financially supported a dedicated company of actors. There is, however, evidence that, in addition to their music, the Norwich waits received the city's permission to act in comedies, interludes, and tragedies. David Galloway assumed that all those performances by the waits as actors occurred locally, and he found no evidence indicating that the company toured. If the troupe that was paid in Ipswich on 8 August 1575 was the waits, that would be the first record confirming that the waits did indeed tour. On the Norwich waits as actors, see Galloway, Norwich, pp xxxi, xxxix, lxxxvi n 3, and 57.
Charles Howard (1536–1624) was lord chamberlain from 1574, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Edward Stafford (f 99; 1535/6–1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1 January 1565/6, with his seat at Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item payd more to the sayd DabneDabne: Robert Dabne, a craftsman skilled in working with metal and wood for taken down of the bordes & the tresselles & mendyng of them for the geld & settyng them vpp for iij days work
Item payd to willyam marten for hys service at the gyld by a warant

div.p: Preparations for the annual guild feast (f [10]) often involved the building, and subsequently the taking down, of staging for the guild day (or guild feast commonly called 'the guild'). Because that feast always involved performance of one kind or another, it seems reasonable to conclude that the staging likely related to those performances, whether for music by the six waits (as happened this year at the annual guild feast, for staging drama, or for viewing pageants or another spectacle by the guild's worthies. Drama in Suffolk, as we have it in the records, often involved scaffold staging).

William Martin (f [11v]) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, the bailiffs' entries into the city, and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors. Martin further served as the Clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' 19–21).

Itemsecunda payd to wyllyam Marten Clark of the markett for his quarterli wages dew at owr lady day by a warant the 30 day of march
Item3a payd to wyllyam marten Clark of the markett the 24 day dayday day: dittographyof Ivne for his quarterli wages
Item payd to wyllyam Marten mor the xxv day of Ivne by a warant for mvsyk at the gyld dynner
Item4a payd to wyllyam marten clark of the markett for his quarterli wages dew at Myhellmes

div.p: William Martin was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568-9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.head: p 174 (29 September–29 September)
div.ab: In the 17th of Elizabeth, the Guild feast was ordered to be held henceforth upon the Sunday fortnight next after Midsummer day; and in the next year, the "occupacions" or trades of the town were newly drawn into companies. At that day they consisted of four only "Mercers, drapers, tailors, and shoemakers," into which all others merged. The Taylors' included, "cutlers, smyths, barbers, chandlers, pewterers, mynstrells, pedlers, plumbers, pynners, millers, millwrights, cowpers, shermen, glasiers, turners, tynkers, taylors, and two others."

div.p: This description by Wodderspoon is (presumably) taken from a now-lost court book). While his summary identifies the year of the order as being 17 Elizabeth (1575–6), he does not include the specific date of the court on which the order was made.

row.cell: paid to the Lorde chamberlynes players by master balyffes order Somme
paid to my Lorde Robertes players by master balyffesbalyffes: a written over y order

div.p: Dated entries on ff [5v] and [6] indicate that the payment to the lord chamberlain's players occurred between 30 January 1575/6 and 7 May 1576.

Thomas Radcliffe (f [5v]; 1526/7–83) was Lord FitzWalter from 27 November 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 February 1556/7, and lord chamberlain from 1572-8, with seats at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

Lord Robert (f [6]) is likely Robert Dudley (c 1532) who was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex; or, less likely, Robert Devereux (1565–1600/1) who was nineteenth earl of Essex from 22 September 1576 with seats at Chartley, Staffordshire and Lamphey Court, Pembrokeshire. See P&P.

row.cell: Item paid to william Marten Clarke of the Markett more the xxvtie daye of Iune by a warrant for Musike at ye gilde dinner

div.p: William Martin (f 102) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: Item paid to the players the 29 of maye
Item paid to my Lord Chamberlyns players þe 30 of may

of IohnRemytid
the 8 of
november
by the 12.
and 24/ Ionson mynstrell

div.p: Thomas Radcliffe (f [5]; 1526/7–83) was Lord FitzWalter from 27 November 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 February 1556/7, and lord chamberlain from 1572-8, with seats at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.

On f [8v], Johnson's is one of five remitted fines that are bracketed by the marginal note. The 12 and 24 are two bodies of burgesses. In later years, in the 1601–2 chamberlains' account, John Johnson would be described as clerk of the Market, for which he was paid 40s in wages and an additional 26s 8d 'for lokinge to the butchers' (C/3/3/2/34, ff 113–14 (see also Webb, Elizabethan Finances, pp 138–9). On f 114 of the same account Webb was twice listed among a group of persons no longer required, for various reasons, to pay a local subsidy tax charged to those who had achieved a certain level of wealth.

Having a minstrel serve as clerk of the Market was not without precedent. In 1575–6 and again in 1576–7 William Martin, master of the town's company of waits at that time, was paid both his quarterly wages as clerk of the Market and additional payments by warrant for his music at the annual guild dinner (C/3/2/1/1, f 102 and C/3/4/1/9, f [3v]). The records give no indication that Johnson was one of the town waits under the mastership of either William Martin or John Bettes, though he well may have been one of Martin's waits since the members of Martin's troupe are never named in the records.

row.cell: Paid to william Martyn the xjth of Iune for musicke at the guild last holden
Paid to Mr Smart to the vse of Iohn Mynter by warrant of the grete courte holden þe xviij of September

div.p: William Martin (f 120v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).
Mynter was the town drummer, who often performed with the waits.

row.cell: Itemin Iune payde to Iohn Pytman for making of ij formes for the halle agaynste the guylde
paid to Robert Dabeny for placyng of the tables at the guilde, and laying vp of the same
for certen nayles spente about the hanging and Trymmyng of the halle

for mendinge of the auncyant and for silke for the same

div.p: The words 'in Iune' are written in the left margin at the top of this folio, confirming that these payments occurred during that month.

row.cell: Item payd to my Lords howards players the 24 of october
payd vnto my Lord vassys Sarvantes being here with bears the 6 of Ianevary by Mr balyffes apoyntment
Item payd vnto the earll of Darbys players the 28 of maye by Mr Balyffes apoyntment

payd vnto my Lord of Leysetors players the 10 of September

div.p: 'Lord vassy' (f [4v]) is possibly William Vesey (d. 1577), lord of Cockerells Hall Manor, Buxhall, Suffolk, owner of the manor of Hintlesham Priory, Suffolk, and lord of Wix Manor and Abbey,in Essex.
Charles Howard (f [4]; 1536–1624) was second Baron Howard of Effingham from 1572/3, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Henry Stanley (f [5v] 1531–93) was thirteen earl of Derby from 1572, with seats at Lathom House and Knowsley Hall, Lancashire. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (f [6]; c1532–33–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: Paid to william Martyn for musicke at the guylde
Payed to Iohn Beckett for chardges of the pagent made by Mr Kynge the skryvener at the guilde daie
Payed to Iohn Kynge Skryvener for his paynes & chardges employed aboute preparacions A geinst the quenes Maiesties commyng

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

John Kynge (f 136) is identified in the records as a scrivener and schoolmaster, though there is no indication that he was the headmaster of Ipswich school. He was talented in making pageants and staging celebrations, shows and dramatizations, which the town paid him to do between 1578 and 1584, at which point he appears to have had a falling out with the town's officials and ceased to perfom those services thereafter.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

div.head: f 11v (26 June)
div.ab:
fforsomychpersons
Apoynted
to devise
agens the
quenes commyng As yt thought ‸is supposed the Quenes Maiesty is to comme to this Towne at this prog her progresse into Suffolk It is Agreed at this Assemblye that the persones herafter named videlicet ‸mr Augustine Parker & ‸ mr Edward Goodyng aldermen George Coppyng Thomas Blosse Thomas bennett william mydnall & Olyver Cowper shall haue Auctorytie dev to devise the order such orders & matters As shalbe mete & necessarye for ‸touchyng the recyuyng of her Maiestie into this Towne & to Also yt is Agred that the persones herafter shall haue Auctorytie to devise that what shall be necessarye to make demaund for of the quenes Maiesty touching the liberties ‸Incresing & Augmentacion of the such liberties ‸ & Iuresdicions of this Towne ‸ as they shall think proper vz Mr Clench Mr Smart Mr Scryven Iohn Hawys Henry Hannan & Edward Cage

div.head: f 14v (1 September)
div.ab:
Itemorder for
< . >tynge yt is Agreed where Iohn Kyng scryvener at the Assignes of Master bayliffes & others Apoynted / have disbursed in thinges touching the setting forthe of pagentes Ageinst the quenes maiestys commyng to þe somme xs ixd besydes for workemens labors & he toke yt by the treasurer & for his paynes taken about the same is referrd to þe next Assembly

div.head: f 15 (5 September)
div.ab: It is Agreed that forsomycheArrerages order for kyng / as Iohn Kynge Scryvener hath taken paynes for the Towne about the setting forthe of pagentes aswell at þe yeld as Ageinst the quenes Comynge/ the said Iohn Kynge shall haue geven to him of the Treasury of the Towne by the Towne treasurer xl s./

div.p: The town made these (f 11v) and numerous other elaborate preparations for the expected visit by Elizabeth I, but in spite of long-held local belief to the contrary, there is no evidence in the records that her visit ever actually happened. Her progress into Suffolk and Norfolk during August 1578 did take her, in turn, to Long Melford, Bury St Edmunds, Hawsted, Euston, and Hengrave. She then made her way through Norfolk, staying at Swaffam, Kenninghall (with a side trip to Redgrave, Suffolk), Bracon Ash, Norwich, Kimberley, Woodrising, Thetford, and again to Hengrave, Suffolk. She then progressed on into Cambridge. In each place she stayed in the palatial residences of important members of the gentry, whose entertainments staged on her behalf are richly detailed in numerous contemporary sources, including those by Thomas Churchyard. In no place were performances more lavishly staged or cleverly conceived than in Norwich between 15 and 22 August (see David Galloway (ed), Norwich 1540-1642 REED (Toronto, Buffalo, and London, 1984), pp 292–340). According to John Nichols, a year later, on 22–6 August 1579, the Queen spent four nights in Ipswich, having sailed up the Orwell from Essex. But once again local records offer no evidence confirming what Nichols, with some detail, claimed. Diarmaid MacCulloch (as reported by John Webb) offers factual reasons why the visit was not likely to have occurred, for example, the plague in Ipswich and the presence of the Queen's French suitor, the Duke of Anjou, at Greenwich during that time (Webb, Town Finances, p 46, n 4).

row.cell: Item paid by Mr Ballyffes commandement to the lord Stranges players in Reward
Item paid the Lord Vasses bearewardes in reward
Item paid the beareward yat bayted on the guyld day
Item paid the Lord charles howerdes players
Item paid the Lord bartletes players

Itemyt ys allowed for thys
tyme & vtterly forbydden
her afterpaid to Kinge scriviner ffor the pagent At the guild as appeare by warrant
ij li. iiij s. viij d.

div.p: The entry concerning Strange's players on f [5] is the third payment made in the account. Ferdinando Stanley (c 1559–94) was thirteen Baron Strange (of Knokyn) from 1572, with seat at Stanley House, Chester, Cheshire. See P&P.

'Lord Vasse,' patron of the bearward on f [5v], is possibly William Vesey (d. 1577), lord of Cockerells Hall Manor, Buxhall, Suffolk, owner of the Manor of Hintlesham Priory, Suffolk, and lord of Wix Manor and Abbey, in Essex.
Following the payment to Vassey's bearward on f [5v], the next dated entry twelve payments later is for 12 April.

Guild Day, identified as 'The Guild' on f [6], was the annual feast days of the Corpus Christi/Merchants Guild that was held during the summer on days that changed through the decades. The Guild Day (or the guild) included a dinner, ceremonies, music, and other kinds of performance. In 1574–5 the burgesses ordered the day to be permanently changed to the 'Sunday se'nnight next, after Midsummer-day,' though even that date proved subject to change, given the circumstances (Fitch, ' Corpus Christi Guild,' p 158).
Charles Howard (1536–1624) was second Baron Howard of Effingham from 1573, with a residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Henry Berkeley (1534–1613) was seventh Baron Berkeley, with residence at Caludon Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.

John Kinge (f [6v]), scrivener and schoolmaster, possessed the ability both to make pageants and to stage events that involved pageants. In 1578 the town paid him for both those tasks on Guild Day and in its preparations for an expected visit by the Queen. In 1579 he again supplied 'the pageant' for Guild Day and for the annual commemoration of the Queen's Coronation, and in 1579 he made a ship pageant 'with certen convenynt speches therein.' He appears in the records a final time in 1584. Between 1578 and 1584, Kinge clearly was the town's central figure in the mounting of civic shows. See Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 22–4).

row.cell: paid to William Marten for his musike at the Guylde

div.head: f 174v (December) (Treasurer's inventory of furniture and goods)
div.ab: a drome with the case and ij stickes
the auncient

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

row.cell: paid to the french tumbler at Master Bayliffes comaundemente
paid to therle of Leicesters players
Paid For caryinge a letter to Mr Kempe
paid to therle of essex plaiers

div.p: Robert Dudley (c 1532–3–88) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth Castle, Manor, and Lordship, Warwickshire, and Wanstead House, Essex. See P&P.

Mr Kempe was perhaps William Kempe, of Akenham, bailiff of a Mr Townesende, to whom the treasurer of Ipswich, Christopher Crane, had paid 3s in rent money owed by the town in 1571–2 (C/3/2/1/1, f 42v; see also Webb, Town Finances, p 44).
Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.

row.cell: paid to william Martyn for his musick at the guild

div.p: Edmund Sheffield (f [6v]; 1565–1646) was third Baron Sheffield (of Butterwick) from 1568 with residences at Hammersmith, Middlesex, and Yorkshire. See P&P.
Henry Berkeley (f [7v]; 1534–1613) was seventh Baron Berkeley, with residence at Caludon Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.
Ambrose Dudley (1528–89/90), knight, was twenty-first earl of Warwick from 26 December 1561 with residences at North Hall, Northaw, Hertfordshire, and Warwick Castle, Warwickshire. See P&P.

div.p: The entry following the payment to Lord Chandos' players on f 227 is dated 3 August.
William Somerset (a 1527–1588/9), Lord Herbert, was eighth earl of Worcester from 26 November 1549, with a seat at Raglan, Monmouthshire and residence at Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.
Edward Stafford (1535/6–1603) was twelfth Baron Stafford from 1 January 1565/6, with his seat at Stafford Castle, Staffordshire. See P&P.
Henry Stanley (1531–93) was thirteenth earl of Derby from 1572, with seats at Lathom and Knowsley, Lancashire. See P&P.
Giles Brydges (c 1548–1593/4) was third Baron Chandos from 11 March 1572/3, with seat at Sudley Castle, Gloucester. See P&P.

Thomas Radcliffe (1526/7–83) was Lord FitzWalter from 27 November 1542 and eighth earl of Sussex from 17 February 1556/7, and lord chamberlain from 1572–8, with residences at New Hall and Woodham Walther, Essex. See P&P.
Henry Berkeley (f 227v; 1534–1613) was seventh Baron Berkeley from 26 November 1534, with residence at Caludon Castle, Warwickshire.

The patron of 'lord Robertes players' was either Robert Dudley (1532 or 1533–88) who was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex, or Robert Devereux (1565-1600/1) who was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P pages for Robert Dudley or Robert Devereux.
Frederick Windsor (1559–85) was fourth Baron Windsor of Stanwell from 1575, with residence at Stanwell, Surrey.
Edward de Vere (1550–1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 3 August 1562, with residences at Hedingham Castle, Essex, and Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.

The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). div.head: f 74v (6 April)
div.ab:
Andorder for
waytes it is ordered & agreed that at the request of William Marten musitian the said William Marten & his Company being 6 in all shall have waighteswaightes: ie, pipes or wind instruments rather than the players of them (see entry on f 216v) bought at the Townes Chardge & that he & they shall therwith serue the Towne for one yere in suche order as by the bayliffes shalbe thought mete & requisit And the said William & his Company to stand to the consideracion of the Towne for ther Wages in that behalf, And it is furder agreed by the consent of the said William that if the Towne shall not lyke of ther seruice at the yeres ende that then he the said William shall repaye the somme of mony the Towne shall so disburse backe ageyne And for the better assurance of payment therof the said William promiseth to stonde bound With sufficient suerties accordyngly as by Mr Bayliffes for the tyme being shall thinke mete and allowe of/.

div.p: William Martin (f 135v) was master of a company of five musicians who served as the waits of Ipswich between 1561 and 1582. The troupe performed on Corpus Christi days, guild feasts, and the bailiffs' entries into the city and their official departures therefrom. The troupe also performed as actors, as evidenced by payments to them for 'plaing the ffoles in the halle' in 1568–9 (C/3/3/2/9, f [10v]) and for 'a play at the Mote hall' in 1571–2 (C/3/3/2/12, f [4]). Martin further served as the clerk of the Market (see Stokes, 'Waits,' pp 19–21).

div.head: f 83 (19 December)
div.ab:
Wheras Iohn Kynge scolemaster in the xvij ten daye of november last wherinxl s. geven
to Kyng the Quenes maiesties reigne newly beganne ageyne was at Charge about certen pageantes & other Shewes in this Towne in Ioye of that daye. Item agreed that he shall have geven to him out of the Towne Treasur in full satisfaccion of & for his said Charges & paynes taken in that behalf fourty shillinges to be payd by the Threasurer

div.p: There is no evidence that John Kyne was schoolmaster at Ipswich School and he is more often identified in the records as a scrivener, but he was most certainly talented in the making of pageants (including a ship carrying actors who spoke lines) and the production of shows (including the writing of the speeches for those actors) on behalf of the town.

div.p: John Kynge (f 237v) is identified in the records as a scrivener and schoolmaster, though there is no indication that he was the headmaster of Ipswich school. He was talented in the making of pageants and staging of celebrations, shows and dramatizations, which the town hired him to do between 1578 and 1584, at which point he appears to have had a falling out with the town's officials and ceased to perfom those services thereafter.

And yt is agred that the said weytes shall haue dew to them for ther seruice done the last yere of the Towne treasur fourtye shillinges & that ther shalbe a g

In 1579 he again supplied 'the pageant' for Guild Day and for the annual commemoration of the Queen's Coronation, and in 1579 he made a ship pageant 'with certen convenynt speches therein.' He appears in the records a final time in 1584. Between 1578 and 1584, Kinge clearly was the town's central figure in the mounting of civic shows. SeeStokes, 'Waits,' pp 22–4).

div.p: Edward de Vere (f [6v]; 1550–1604) was seventeenth earl of Oxford from 3 August 1562, with residences at Hedingham Castle, Essex, and Hackney, Middlesex. See P&P.
Robert Dudley (c1533–1588) was fourteenth earl of Leicester from 29 September 1564, with seats at Kenilworth, Warwickshire, and Wanstead, Essex. See P&P.

row.cell: paid william buckrome the 12th of december .84. for Sixe yardes of blewe cloth for 4 leueries for the waytes at 10 s. the yarde

div.p: On f 15, William Buckenham was presumably a tailor in that he routinely supplied blue cloth and made livery coats for the Ipswich waits between 1585 (when he was referred to as William Buckrome) and 1593–4. Mistress Buckenham, perhaps his wife, conducted the transaction in 1589–90. Between 1607–8 and 1619–20 Henry Buckenham, perhaps their son, made three similar payments.

row.cell: paid to Thomas Keele & his company for musicke at the Guylde, as bi warrant appereth
paid to my Lord Admyralles players the thethe the: dittography xxth of ffebruary bi commaundement
paid bi commaundement to my lorde of Essex players

div.p: Thomas Keele (f [4v]) was master of a company of musicians that briefly served, during a three-year period, as the town's waits. The records mention them in 1583–4, 1584–5, and here in 1585–6. The brevity of their tenure suggests that their hire was an interim measure at best. The company of William Martin that preceeded them served for twenty-one years, and John Bettes' company that followed them would serve for twenty years, from 1587 through 1607.
Charles Howard (f [5]; c 1536–1624) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.
Robert Devereux (f [5v]; 1565–1600/1) was nineteenth earl of Essex from 1576, with seat at Cassiobury House, near Watford, Hertfordshire. See P&P.
The next dated entry after the Essex payment is St Matthew's Day, 21 September, so the payment to Essex's players occurred sometime before that date.

row.cell: paide Iohn Minter the 9th of Marche by warrante
paide Richard Minter for his service for playinge vppon the drome in master Cutlers tyme
payde Richarde Mynter for playinge vppon the drome in master Mares tyme
paide Iohn Minter for Triminge the drome

div.p: In the audited accounts of Tooley's foundation (BL: Add MS 25343), John Mynter was paid 3s 4d for making four women's gowns (f 156v), and 3s 6d for making three pair of breeches and two pair of hose (f 156). John Minter was the town's drummer. Richard Minter succeeded him as the town's drummer.

div.head: f 84 7 January)
div.ab: wheras request is made by lettres from Sir ffrauncis walsingham knight Sir … knight: Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90) was secretary of state to Elizabeth I ‸aswell touching the Musitians wages of this Towne, dewe this yere by the Towne as also fos ‸for the colleccion of the benevelence of the Inhabitantes of this Towne, yt is Agred that they shall haue ther wages being iiij li. dewe by the Towne paid to them & for the rest commyng of the benevolence of the Towne Inhabitant of the Towne they shall collect that them selues/ And yt is furder agred that they shall not be chardged with x s. delyuerd to ballard nor with viij s. paid for his herse hyer to london, nor to v s. geven to the pursyvant which is for the said Musitcions

div.p: Francis Walsingham (c 1532–90) was secretary of state to Elizabeth I

div.head: ff 89v–90 (15 July)
div.ab:
wheras ther ben Appoynted vnder the chardge of Master Capten Carye twelue persons for the Towne to the seruice of the lowe Contries Contrye/ It is Agreed that those xij persons shall haue allowed to them seuerally ij s. vj d. of the Townes gyfte whiche is Agreed that the chamberlens shall paie presently & that Iohn Cressye
alias Mynster the yonger Apoynted for A dromme shall haue geven to him v s. towardes his Aparell & thes ben the names of the xij soldiers videlicet paule Grympston Robert Wollett William Wodes Edward Poughe Iohn Knagges Valentyne ffreman Lyonell Aylward Heue Goslyn Rychard Keye Iohn Robertson William Astyn & Rychard cake

div.p: The next entry in the Assembly book confirms that three of the soldiers (Grympston, Freman, and Wollett) had been prisoners in the jail before being impressed into service.

John Minter was John Cressey, alias Minter, the town drummer between 1587 and 1604–5 (the last time he appears in the records). The city routinely financed his annual wages, his livery, and his repairs to drums. In 1594–5 it also paid him for mending the civic ensigne using levant, white taffeta, and black silk. In 1608–9 the city paid one Richard Minter for two days' service with his drum.

row.cell: Item paid to quenes players xxv of october
Item paid to Richard woderam for the erle of oxfordes players
Item paid too my Lord admyralls players
Item paid to the quenes players
Item paid to the quenes players being the Childeren
Item paid to my Lord of Sussex men for playing

div.p: Elizabeth Tudor (f 2v; 1533-1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.
Charles Howard (c 1536-1624) (f 3v) was lord high admiral from 1585, with residence at Effingham, Surrey. See P&P.

The 'quenes players being the children' (f [4]) refers to the boys' troupe patronized by Elizabeth I (1533-1602/3). The Children of the Chapel was a company of boys first formed in its certain Tudor iteration in 1501, patronize successively by Tudor monarchs through Elizabeth I, and thereafter with a revised name by the Stuarts. The company performed both musically and in drama, mainly for the Court until c 1585. Thereafter through 1592 it performed both provincially and in the commercial theatres of London. Many of the boys had been impressed (because of their talent) from choral schools around the kingdom - a process not always appreciated by the schools, who saw it as the poaching of their best talent. The boys wore brightly coloured gowns, coats, and bonnets. Court records show that they enjoyed considerable financial support for their sustenance, educations, and the complexities of their travels to perform. See Chambers, Elizabethan Stage, vol 2, pp 23–61).
Edward de Vere (1550-1604), was seventeenth Earl of Oxford, with residence at Plaistow House, Essex. See P&P
Henry Radcliffe (1533-1593), suceeded as ninth earl of Sussex in 1583, with residence at New Hall, Essex. See P&P.

div.head: f 5v (29 September–29 September) (Treasurer's payments by warrant)

row.cell: To petter mone for Repayring of the tovne drome

div.head: f 121v (20 October)
div.ab:
Itorder for
musitions is furderIt is furder: in display script agreed that Iohn Bettes musitian with his companye to the nomber of ffoure persons shall Inioye the offyce of the weyghtes within this Towne to serue in that offyce ffrom the daye of the date herof vntyll assenscion daye next & that they shall procede ther aboutes nightlye from two of the Clock vntyll they have gone throughout the Towne And further that they shalbe at the commaundement of the Towne duryng the whole yere for furder seruice in ther musyck and therrbye it is agreed that they shall haue for ther salarye & wages this yere iiij li. & convenyent lyveryes of the Townes Chardge & besydes receyve the benevolence of the Inhabitantes of the Towne as Iohn Marten the late musitions hertofore have vsed to collect the same prouided it is agreed that the said waytes shall prouide them ther cognizances of ther owne charg.echarg.e: likely a misplaced
