div.p: The accounts of Lady Alice L'Estrange (NRO: P/7, ff 50, 60) always identify Randell as 'a travelling jester or fool' who performed at Hunstanton as late as 1639 (Wasson, Plays and Players, p 160).

div.head: mb 19 dorse (14 December)
div.ab: Etffinis ij d. quod Thomas Berne senior super lectum suum mortalem extra Curiam sursumreddidit in manus domini per manus Iohannis hawes de Cranmere nativi in presencia Edmundi page Iohannis page Iohannis pakynham et aliorum de homagio vnam rodam terre siue pasture de dominicis Manerij parcellam de le Conyngger cum pertinentibus in Walsham Ad opus laurencij Reyngberd Iohannis parker Stephani Rampoly Iohannis page Thome Rolff Roberti holme Iohannis Rampoly Iohannis hawes de Cranmere Iohannis Robhood Iunioris Willelmi parker & heredum suorum Quibus liberata est inde seisina Tenendam illis heredibus & assignatis suis ad proficium & commodum ecclesie de Walsham Ac promocionem et incrementum Gilde beate Marie Ac omnium Gildarum ville de Walsham predicte ad voluntatem domini per virgamffidelitas ad voluntatem domini faciendum seruicia & consuetudines &c. Saluo iure &c. Et dant de fine &c. Et fecerunt fidelitatem &c.

div.head: mb 19 dorse (14 December)
div.ab: AndFine, 2d (the jurors make presentment) that Thomas Berne, senior, on his death bed outside the court, surrendered into the hands of the lord by the hands of John Hawes, of Cranmere, a bondsman, in the presence of Edmund Page, John Page, John Pakynham, and others of the homage, one rood of land or of pasture of the demesne of the manor, a parcel from the cunnigar with appurtenances, in Walsham to the benefit of Lawrence Reyngberd, John Parker, Stephen Rampoly, John Page, Thomas Rolff, Robert Holme, John Rampoly, John Hawes of Cranmere, John Robhood Jr., William Parker and their heirs to whom seisin of it has been delivered, to be held by them, their heirs, and assigns for the profit and advantage of the church of Walsham and the advancement and increase of the guild of St Mary and of all the guilds of the town of the aforesaid town of Walsham according to the will of the lord by authority Fealtyto do service and custom, etc, and they granted regarding the fine, etc. With right reserved, etc. And they did fealty, etc.

div.head: mb 21 (19 May)
div.ab: Etffinis vj d. quod Iohannes Saye extra Curiam sursumreddidit in manus domini per manus Thome Miller nativi tenentis in presencia laurencij Reyngberd Thome Rolfe et aliorum de homagio dimidiam acram et xvj perticatas terre iacentes inter terram nuper Thome Berne ex parte australi et terram nuper Roberti Man ex parte Aquilonali vno capite abbuttante super hallegrene versus orientem Ad opus Iohannis Page et Roberti Holme Quibus liberata est inde seisina Tenendas illis ad vsum proficium et commodum Ecclesie de Walsham per virgam ad voluntatem domini per seruicia & consuetudines &c.

div.head: mb 21 (19 May)
div.ab: AndFine, 6d (the jurors make presentment) that John Saye, outside the court, surrendered into the hands of the lord by the hands of Thomas Miller, bondsman tenant, in the presence of Lawrence Reyngberd, Thomas Rolfe, and of others from the homage, half an acre and sixteen perches of land lying between the land of the late Thomas Berne on the south side and the land of the late Robert Man on the north side with one end abutting onto Hallegrene toward the east for the use of John Page and Robert Holme to whom seisin of it has been delivered, to be held by them for the use, profit, and advantage of the church of Walsham by authority according to the will of the lord by service and cunstom, etc.

div.p: As Dodd observes, this action by the manor court 'contains the earliest description of the Game Place as a recognizable separate tenement, although it was not then called by that name' ('Another English Theater,' p 129).

row.cell: Villata ibidem tenet de nouo redditu vnam percellam terre vocatam Campyngclosse percellam tenementi Thome berne per annum
The vill there holds by renewed rent one parcel of land called 'Campingclose,' a parcel of a tenement of Thomas Berne per annum

div.p: This entry is the final item in a group of properties listed under the heading 'Churchstreete' (f 173) as of 20 March 1509 (24 Henry VII). As this entry indicates, the tenure of the camping close (and therefore the site of the game place) reverted from the town to the son of Thomas Berne senior, and his wife, in 1509. According to a court roll of 1516, in that year Berne junior gave tenure of the site to his own son, Richard, and to his wife, Agnes, the court entry describing the site as:

quote.p: dimidiam acram terre percellam de conynger iacentem inter terras nuper Roberti Man ex parte Aquilonali et terras predicti Thome bernys ex parte australi vno capite abbuttante super hallegrene versus orientem alio vere capite abbuttante super terram predicti Thome bernys versus occidentem(Suffolk Archives, Bury: HA 504/1/18, mb 1).

half an acre of land, a parcel of the cunnigar, lying between the lands, lately of Robert Man, on the north side and the lands of the aforesaid Thomas Bernys on the south side with one extremity abutting on the hall green towards the east but the other extremity abutting on the land of the aforesaid Thomas Bernys towards the west

div.head: mb 8 (June)
div.ab: ItemItem: in display scriptObitus Iohannis Page presentant quod Iohannes Page de Cleystrete obijt solus seisitus de pictello terre natiue iacente iuxta le game place & quod Willelmus Page Iohannes Page et Ricardus Page filij predicti Iohannis Page sunt proximi heredes ipsius Iohannis secundum consuetudinem Manerij et plene etatis &c.

div.head: mb 8 (June)
div.ab: LikewiseDeath of John Page they present that John Page of Cleystreet has died solely seized by birth of the pightel of land which lies next to the game place, and that Willaim Page, John Page, and Richard Page are sons of the aforesaid John Page, the closest heirs of that John according to the custom of the manor, and are of full age, etc.

div.head: f 59v (Lands and tenements within Walsham)
div.ab: TheWalsham Towne sayd game place in the tenure ofLe Game place diuers men to the vse and behofe of the towne of walsham ‸aforesayd is customary ground holden of the sayd manor of walsham and a place compassed rownd with a fayer banke ‸cast vp on a good height & havinge sett v many great trees called populers growynge about the same banke, in the myddest a fayre round place of earth wythe a stone wall about the same to the height of the earth made of purpose for the vse of Stage playesdimidia acre x perticarum doth Lie betwene the ortyard of the Last sayd tenament on the northtenament on the north: the 1.5 acre tenement of Margery and the tenemente & ground in the tenure of Iohn vincent ff called barnes on the south thone hedd thereof abbutteth vppon the hall grene towardes the east the other on the sayd ground called barnes in parte and the ‸customary close of Ces cycelye margerye in parte on the west parte and conteyneth

Thevyncent I
Barnes Tenant sayd ‸customary tenemente called Barnes with one back yard thervnto adioyninge in the tenure of Iohn vincent lieth betwene the game place aforesayd towardes the north & the way to bury Saint Edmund towardes the south in parte and the customary cottage in the tenure of Iohn knyght in parte towardes the south parte

div.p: For a discussion of this playing space, and a conjectural reconstruction, see Dodd, 'Another Elizabethan Theater,' p 125–56. See also Richard Beadle, 'The East Anglian 'game-place': A Possibility for Further Research,' REED Newsletter (1978.1), 2-4.

div.head: ff 50v–1
div.ab:
7. Dicti InhabitantesDicti Inhabitantes: in display script ville de walsham tenent natiue vnam peciam pasture vocatam le game place quondam Thome Berne cum
percella vnius pecie pasture ad finem occidentalem eiusdem scituate et iacentis inter vltimam ex parte Australi et Tenementum ac croftum natiue in tenura Cicilie margery vidue ex parte altera Et Abuttat Similiter versus orientem et super peciam proximam sequentem versus occidentem Et continet dimidiam Acram/

div.head: ff 50v–1
div.ab:
7. The said inhabitants of the town of Walsham hold as bondsmen one piece of pasture called 'the game place' formerly of Thomas Berne with
a parcel of one piece of pasture situated on the west boundary of the same and lying between the last (mentioned, ie, the game place) on the south side and the tenement and croft in the villein tenure of Cecilia Margery, widow, on the other side, and abuts likewise on the east and onto the next following piece toward the west. And it contains half an acre.

div.head: mb 1 (2 October)
div.ab: Ad hanc CuriamAd … Curiam: in display script venerunt Thomas Page et Thomas Raynberd tenentes natiui huius Manerij in proprijs personis ffinisfinis: in display script xl s. suis, et in plena Curia sursumreddiderunt in manus domini per manus Senescalli vnum domum vocatum the towne howse continetem per estimacionem dimidiam acram. Ac vnam peciam terre native vocatam the game place nuper Thome Berne, iacentem inter terram modo Stephani vincente exteexte: likely for ex parte Australi, et Tenementum & Croftum modo Ricardi Margery exteexte: likely for ex parte aquilonali, et abbutat super le Hall greene versus orientem, et continet dimidiam acram sex decem perticatas & vnum pedem. Ac vnam peciam terre parcellam vnius acre & dimidie parcelle de le Connygree iacentem inter terram predicti Stephani vincente exteexte: likely for ex parte Australi abutantem super le game place predictum versus orientem, et super terram natiuam dicti Stephani versus occidentem et continet per estimacionem Rodam terre, Que ijdem Thomas & Thomas simulcum Thoma Page seniore Thoma Page Iuniore filio Iohannis Page & Iohannes Raynberd iam defuncti, nuper habuerunt illis & heredibus suis, ex concessione domini ad Curiam hic tentam die Lune videlicit vndecimo die decembris Anno regni domine Elizabethe nuper Regine Anglie &c vicesimo quartovndecimo … quarto: ie, 11 December 1581 prout in Rotulum Curie Manerij predicti plenius liquet Ad OpusAd Opus: in display script et vsum Thome Rampley generosi Iohannis Page filij Georgij Page defuncti Iohannis Page filij predicti Thome Page Ricardi Raynberd senioris Thome Seaman filij Thome Seaman willelmi Raynberd ‸filij willelmi Raynberd willelmi Complyn Iohannis vincent Ricardi Page filij Stephani Page & Ricardi Parker et heredum suorum Et quia constat Curia hic quod proficia terrarum & tenementorum predictorum pertinen'pertinen': likely for cum pertinentibus de tempore in tempus imperpetuum remanebunt ad vsum inhabitancium huius ville, qui in reperando domum predictum multum expenderunt Ideo dominus in recontinuacione antiquorum redituum & serviciorum per Senescallum suum liberauit eisdem Thome Rampley Iohanni Page Iohanni PageIohanni Page Iohanni Page: ie, one the son of George and the other of David Ricardo Raynberd seniori Thome Seaman willelmo Raynberd willelmo Complyn Iohanni vincent Ricardo Page & Ricardo Parker de premissis predictis cum pertinentibus seisinam, TenendumTenendum: in display script; for Tenendam illis & heredibus suis de domino per virgam ad voluntatem domini secundum consuetudines Manerij predicti per Redditus & seruiciam inde prius debitum & de iure consuetum Saluo iure &c. Et dant domino de fine Et admissi sunt inde Tenentes. et predictus Thomas Rampley fecit domino fidelitatem/

div.head: mb 1 (2 October)
div.ab: To this court Thomas Page and Thomas Raynberd villein tenants of the manor, came in personFine, 40s and in full court they surrendered into the hands of the lord by the hands of the steward one house called 'the town house' containing by estimation half an acre, and one piece of land held by villein tenure called 'the game place' lately of Thomas Berne, lying between the land now of Stephen Vincente on the south side, and the tenement and croft now of Richard Margery on the north side, and it abbuts on the hall green toward the east and contains half an acre, sixteen perches, and one foot, and one piece of land, a parcel of one acre and a half of a parcel of the cunnigar lying between the aforesaid land of Stephen Vincente on the south side, abbutting onto the aforesaid game place towards the east and onto the land held by villein tenure of the said Stephen towards the west and contains by estimation one rood of land which the same Thomas and Thomas together with Thomas Page, senior; Thomas Page, junior, son of John Page; and John Raynberd, now deceased, of late held for those and their heirs by concession of the lord at this court held on Monday, that is to say, 11 December in the twenty-fourth year of reign of the lady Elizabeth, late queen of England, etc, just as is completely clear in the roll of the court of the aforesaid manor, for the benefit and use of Thomas Rampley, gentleman; John Page, son of George Page, deceased; John Page, son of the aforesaid Thomas Page; Richard Raynberd, senior; Thomas Seaman, son of Thomas Seaman; William Raynberd, son of William Raynberd; William Complyn; John Vincent; Richard Page, son of Stephen Page; and Richard Parker; and their heirs. And because the court established here that the profits of the lands and aforesaid tenements with appurtenances from time to time inperpetuity will remain for the use of the inhabitants of this town, who in repairing the house have spent much, therefore the lord in continuation of ancient revenues [redituum] and services delivered by his steward to the same Thomas Rampley; John Page; John Page; Richard Raynberd, senior; Thomas Seaman; William Raynberd; William Complyn; John Vincent; Richard Page; and Richard Parker seisin regarding the aforesaid premises with appurtenances to be held by them and their heirs of the lord by authority (of the court) at the pleasure of the lord according to the customs of the manor aforesaid by rents and service of which formerly were owed and by right accustomed, with right reserved, etc. And they give to the lord of the fine. And were admitted therefore as tenants. And the aforesaid Thomas Rampley has done fealty to the lord.

row.cell: Item layd out to father wylbe when he went to the playe at Stanton

div.p: The account contains other payments to Father Wilby, who clearly represented the parish in ecclesiastical matters. The entry concerning the play follows references to Coronation Day, Christmas, and Whitsunday; it precedes a reference to the Sunday after St Bartholomew Day (28 August).

Wattisfield and Stanton are villages about ten miles apart, between Ixworth and Botesdale, approximately fifteen miles from Norfolk in a part of Suffolk that was rich in the production of local plays.

The accounts refer to provisions for Elizabeth's progress through the county in 1578 (ff 19, 34). Rogations in Wattisfield included references to bread and wine, cakes and beer (ff 1, 5, 60). The accounts also mention both the guildhall (f 26) and town house (f 1, sheet 2v).

div.head: Item [7] (Bill of complaint)(6 April)
div.ab: To the kinges most excellent Maiestie

Moste humbly Complayninge sheweth vnto your Excellent Maiestie Nicholas Rosyer of Hawlye in your highenes Countie of Suffolk Tanner, That whereas your said Subiecte and many his ancestors by the space of Twoe hundreth yeares last past have dwelt and inhabited in wetherden in your said Countye of Suffolk as there & well your said subiect as alsoe your subiectes said Auncestors had and enioyed certeyne ffrehold Landes and Tenementes lyinge within the said Towne of wetherden aforesaid and in other places within the said Cownty of Suffolk and dureinge all that tyme were rated and charged to pay subsidies and other Imposicions to your Maiestie & your Maiesties predecessors kinges and Queenes of this your highenes Realme of Englond which we alwayes payed & satisfied with a willinge & dutifull mynde And whereas alsoe your said subiecte together with his wief and familye loveingly and peaceable dwelled & Inhabited in wetherden aforesaid for diuerse yeares past without brablinge makeinge discorde or discention in the said Towne of wetherden or comittinge anye outrages or offence to your Maiesties lawes or statutes, yet notwithstandinge suche was the vyle and perverse disposicion of diuerse lewde persons dwellinge and abideinge in the said Towne of wetherden and other places neare therevnto adioyninge that they maliced and repyned at the good course and quyet lief and peaceable Condicion which your said subiecte his wief and familye lived in, And to thend and purpose not only to disgrace & drawe into scandall & reproche : line filler over erasure your said subiect his wief and kynred but alsoe to make a sedicion tumult & discention in the said Towne of wetherden and one Iames Quarrye of the said Towne of wetherden Carpenter Thomas Hamont yoman Iohn Horne husbondman & Suzan Hamont widdowe together with diuerse other persons to your subiecte vnknowne to the nomber of Twentye persons in or about the moneth of Ianuarye last past and synce your Maiesties most gracious generall pardon beinge all vnlawfullie assembled together at wetherden aforesaid and then & there they the said Iames Quarrye Iohn horne Thomas Hamont and Suzan Hamont with diuerse others aforesaid Ryotous persons to your subiect vnknowne beinge armed and weponed with long staves bills and great clubbes some of them beinge disguised in vile and base apparell to thentent that they should not be knowne did very vnlawfullie ryoteously & tumultuosly to the great disquyet & terror of your said subiect and diuerse other peaceable persons dwellinge in the said Towne goe vpp & downe in the said Towne : erasure with line filler there threatninge and revyleinge your said subiect and his said wief and then and there : word erased went vnto the then dwellinge Howse of your said subiecte in wetherden aforesaid in Ryotous manner to the entent by force and vyolence that they mighte have taken and gotten your said subiect out of his mansyon Howse and then to haue eyther murthered or otherwise wounded your said subiect and they the said Iohn Horne Iames Quarrye Thomas Hamont & Suzan Hamont then vnderstandinge : line filler over erasure of as many as 20 characters your said subiect to be then absent from his said dwellinge Howse did in most base vncivill & vnlawfull manner come neare vnto your subiectes said dwellinge Howse and there cryed out with loude voyces Rosyer Rosyer shall be beaten, and thus they the said ryotous and disordered persons contynewed in there ryotous course goinge vp and downe in the streetes of the said Towne from one end to the other by the space of three howers together lookinge for some other persons to assyst them in there vnlawfull & ryotous accions : line filler over erasure to countenance them in there lewde demeanours and they the said ryotous persons : line filler over erasure of as many as 12 characters haveinge comitted such ryottes and outrages in wetherden aforesaid Imediately after vppon the said daye in suche like vnlawfull ryotous & disorderly manner weaponed as aforesaid went from WetherdeWetherde: last letter lost at right edge of leaf aforesaid vnto Haughlie vnto the mansyon Howse of one (blank) Dawes in Haughlie aforesaid and there in most ryotous and vnlawfull manner entred into the said howse of the said Dawes against the will of the said Dawes and there teryfied diuerse persons being within the said Howse and spoyled & broke diuerse thinges within the said Howse to the great greivance and offence of your maiesties lovinge & faithfull subiectes & from thence all the said Ryotous persons went togeather throughe a streete called haughlie new streete in suche like ryotous manner as aforesaid and weaponed as aforesaid vnto the then mansion Howse of the said Suzan Hamont who had formerly put on diuerse base and ragged ragges vppon the said Quarrye and diuerse other persons vnknowne of the said ryotours and willed them to call the said Quarrye by the name of Rosyer in scoffinge and derisyon of your said subiect, and then & there the said Suzan Hamont did give vnto all or most parte of the aforesaid Ryotous persons meate and drinke and willed them to persevere in that there vnlawfull tumultuous and ryotous accions and therevppon the said Thomas Hamont beinge accompanyed as aforesaid in most vyolent & ryotous manner did assaulte & greivously beate the wief of your said subiect so as shee languished by the space of tenne daies and was in great daunger of death. In consideracion whereof and forasmuch as all the aforesaid offences & misdemeanours were comitted and done by the aforsaid Ryotours synce your Maiesties gracious generall pardon and contrary to your highenes lawes and statutes and would make a very dangerous & evillevill: i written over e president for other like ryotous and evill desposed persons to comitt and perpetrate the like if the said ryotous & disordered persons should escape vnpunished for there said offences and misdemeanours, may yt therefore please your excellent Maiestie of your accustomed and gracious favour to graunt your highenes writt of Subpena directed vnto the aforesaid Iames Quarrye Iohn Horne Thomas Hamont Suzan Hamont ‸ comandinge them at a certayne day & vnder a certeyn payne : line filler over erasure personally to be and appeare before your highnes Councell in your honorable Court of Starchamber then and there to answere the premisses and to abide such order and penalty as your highenes said honorable Councell shall award, And your said subiect as in duty he is bounde shall daily pray for your maiestie in all health & happines long to Reigne over vs./

div.head: Item [6] (4 June) (Answer by Susan Hamond and Thomas Hamond)
div.ab: The said defendantes by protestacion not confessinge or acknowledginge any thinge in the said Bill of Complaynt conteyned concerninge theis defendantes or eyther of them materiall to be answered vnto in this honourable Courte to be true in such maner and forme as the same ben therin sett forth & declared and savinge vnto themselfes at all tymes all advauntages of excepcion which they maye take to the said Bill touchinge the vncertentie & insufficiency therof ffor Answere theis defendantes sayen And first the said Susan Hamond sayeth That wheras the Complainant by his said Bill doth vainely sett forth a longe discourse of the contynuance of him the said Complainant & his Auncestoures in the Towne of Wetherden by the space of two hundred yeares last paste, with a vayne ostentacion of their good Condicions and peaceable demeanoures duringe that tyme, this defendant sayeth that she is not able to speake of tyme beyond memory but this defendant sayeth that within the tyme of her Remembrance the father of the Complainant in his lief tyme followed that corse of disorder as he was much offensyve to his neighboures & otheres, and the Complainant himself doth nothinge degenerate from his father in those Condicions ffor this defendant hathe credibly heard and doubteth not but she shall manifestly prove vnto this honourable Courte that before such tyme as the Complainant did come to dwell in the said Towne of wetherden he was detected of incontinency & lived in dronkennes & much discention with his wief & otheres and that there were many brawles & fallinges owt betwene him & his wife to the great disquiet of neighboures and the breache of the Common peace, And sithence the Complainant his Commynge to dwell in the said Towne of wetherden the complainant and his said wief have contynued in their vngodly and discentious lief and amongest other their brawles & misdemenoures it fell owt not longe before the tyme of the said supposed Ryott in the Bill mencioned as the common Report goeth in the said Towne of wetherden that the said Complainant was dronken at the howse of one william Devorous who kept an Alehouse within the said Towne of wetherden (which howse is sithence that tyme by some of his Maiesties Iustices of the Countie of Suffolk forbidden to be any more contynued for an Alehouse as this defendant hathe heard) and the said Complainant beinge overcome with drynke as the Comon report goeth he went home to his owne dwellinge howse and his wief fyndinge him to be dronken revyled him callinge him dronken dogg pispott & other vnseemely names and when the Complainant went into the bedd vnto his wief she still raged against him & badd him owt dronken dogg dronken pispott & gett him to his hoores againe from whence he came and withall his wief did strike at him twice or thrice & clawed him by the face & armes & spitted in his face & did beate him owt of bedd as was reported by a servaunt which did then dwell in the howse of the Complainant whervpon (as it was likewise credibly reported) the Complainant did pack vpp his Clothes & told his wief that he would goe from her & forsake her & he went into the Street about Nyne or Tenn of the Clock in the night tyme & there meetinge with one Thomas Quarry the said Complainant weept vnto him & told him that his wief had beatten him & shewed vnto the said Thomas Quarry where his said wief had scratched him by one of his Armes as it is said, And thervpon as it is reported the said Complainant & the said Quarry at that vnseasonable tyme of the night went againe into the said Alehowse and there the Complainant againe made his complaint that his wief had beatten him & did shewe his hurtes as aforesaid and then & there the Complainant did call for more drynke & for lynkes & salt meates which might encrease his desyre of drynkinge and in the ende did become so dronken as he did not knowe how to guide himself insomuch as he would have poured drinke into the mouthes of some which did lye sleepinge bedd there as the comon report goeth. vpon which misdemenour of the Complainant and vpon thaforesaid occasion happeninge that the Complainant his wief had beatten & misvsed him as aforesaid it fell owt as it is said that shortly after one Mathew Pettit alias Beckett & Bennett Rushbrooke meetinge with the said Thomas Quarry at the aforesaid alehowse & vnderstandinge by the said Thomas Quarry how the Complainant had complayned vnto him of his said beatinge, they agreed amongest themselfes that the said Thomas Quarry who dwelt at the next howse vnto the said Complainant towardes the Church should according to an Old Country Ceremony vsed in meriment vpon such Accidentes ryde abowt the towne vpon a cowlestaff wherby not onely the woman which had offended ‸might be shamed for her misdemenour towardes her husband but other women also by her shame might be admonished to offend in like sort And thervpon a sack & a Cowlestaff were borrowed at the said Alehowse and vpon that Sack & Cowlestaff the said Thomas Quarry was carryed to diveres places & as he rode did admonishe all wiefes to take heede how they did beate their husbandes as this defendant hathe heard, And this defendant sayeth that she dothe thinke that diveres yonge men & Children did accompany the said Thomas Quarry in mirthe and disport withowt any violence or force vsed to any to the knowledge of this defendant neyther was this defendant in the Company of any of them vntill they came into the howse of this defendant, And this defendant sayeth that when the said Thomas Quarry and the rest of that company came against the howse of this defendant in wetherden aforesaid they came into the howse of this defendant & desired to have somwhat to eate & drynke, but she willed them to goe awaye, nevertheles the daughter of this defendant by the entreatie of the said Thomas Hamond her sonne did bestowe some bread & cheese & drynke vpon them and sone after the said Quarry & the rest departed from the howse of this defendant in peace, this defendant tarryinge still in her howse, And as to any vnlawfull Assembly Ryott or any other misdemenour in the said Bill mencioned examynable in this honourable Courte this defendant sayethe that she is not of the same or any of them guiltie in such maner & forme as in the said Bill is declared And this defendant sayeth that she is verily perswaded that the said Bill is preferred into this honourable Courte rather to make a gayne to some private person then for any heynous offence committed by any of the said defendantes meet to be examyned in this honourable Courte, ffor the Complainant before thexhibitinge of the said Bill into this Courte did complayne vnto Edmund Poley esquier a Iustice of peaceEdmund Poley (1544-1613), of Badley, Suffolk for the said Countie of Suffolk of the said pretended Ryott & misdemenoures and the said Mr Poley hearinge and examyninge the matter did discharge all the parties and willed the Complainant & his wief to be quiet and shortly after that tyme the Complainant himself did discharge the said Thomas Quarry who was the cheif man in the action for two or three pottes of beere and hathe offered to discharge some other of the defendantes for very small recompence as this defendant hathe heard And the said Thomas Hamond the other defendant for himself sayeth that at the tyme of the said supposed Ryott & misdemenoures in the said Bill mencioned pretended to be committed this defendant was & yet is in his minoretie vnder the age of twentie & one yeares And most humbly prayeth the Iudgement of this honourable Courte if he shall be compelled to make any further or other Answere to the said Bill of Complaint. All which matteres & thinges as the same doe concerne theis defendantes then theis defendantes are seuerally redy to averr & prove as this honourable Courte shall award And prayen to be dismissed owt of the same with their reasonable costes & expenses by them in this behalf most wrongfully susteyned./

div.head: Item [1] mbs [1-1d] (1 October)(Examination of Thomas Hamond, yeoman, of Wetherden)
div.ab: To the 3 Interrogatory he saieth that he this defendant, ‸ & as he remembreth he Mathew Pettit Bennett Richbrook Rushbrooke, ‸ The har aforsaid Iames Quarrey & ‸diuers others dyd synce the first day of Ianuary last past ‸that is to say about Plowmonday goe up and downe in wetherden and hauley in the County of Suffolk, & that the said ‸IamesQuarrey and some other of the said company (but which of them he cannott certenly say) dyd terme them scafes by the name of Nicholas Rosyer & some by the name of Rosiers wief, and that the said Iames Quarrey had then all was ‸had ther as this defendant remembreth an Apron before him ‸& some other gowne or kirtle as if he had byn a woman & and more he remembreth not to this Interrogatory.

To the 4th Interrogatory he sayth that the said Hardy ‸alias a sheppard & A marryner had then as this defendant remembreth le< . > A staff. which staff this defendant carryed a lyttle waye for the said hardie And this ‸staffe staffe he sayth was to his remembraunce all the wepons that was then amongest them. And he sayth that this defendant and his said Company saving 2 cowle staves whereon the said Thomas Quarrey ‸then rode was then carried. And he sayth that the defendant and his said company before mencioned dyd vppon that day . eate and drincke at his said mothers ‸the howse of this defendants said mother

To the vth Interrogatory he sayth that on the same day ‸as he remembreth after the said Thomas Quarrey was carryed ‸vpp & downe vppon Cowlestaves as aforesaid the said Rosyers wyef came to his the howse of this defendants said mother & then & there exceedingly reviled at this defendant calling him ‸rascall bastard pezant & that he was like vnto her father & withall dyd then and there ‸ twice together spytt in this defendants face. Wheruppon he this defendant ‸did with his hande only shove or putt backe the said Rosyers wyef. But this defendant dyd not at any tyme in any sort beat or strycke the said Nicholas Rosier. neyther dyd he At at any tyme in any other sort then as he hath before shewed ‸beate or strycke the said Rosyers wyef.

div.p: In a separate answer given on 22 May 1604 (TNA: STAC 8/249/19, item 7, f [8]), defendant Robert Dawes declined (demurred in law) to respond to the charges made against him in Rosyer's bill of complaint, claiming that Rosyer's charges lacked sufficient legal merit as expressed in the bill.
The Interrogatory for deposition answer 4 (item 1) gives no further identification particulars about Hardy.

div.head: Item [2] (10 February) (Interrogatories for Thomas Hammond, Yeoman)
div.ab: Item3. whether did you and diuers other persons at eny tyme since the first daye of Ianuarye last goe vpp and downe in wetherden and Haulye in the countye of Suffolk And whether did eny person or persons in that Companie terme themselues by the name of Nicholas Rosyer or by the name of Rosyers wyffe And whether any of the sayd persons were disguised in womans apparrell or not And howe longe since was the same downe to your Remembrance
Item4. whether had you eny staffe or weapons in your Companye at that tyme And whether did you and they of your Companye vppon the same daye eate and drinke at your sayd mothers howse or not

Item5. whether did you since the first daye of December last beate or stryke the sayd Nicholas Rosyer or his sayd wyffe with any staffe or cudgell or with your hande or otherwyse And if you did vppon what occasion did you strike or beate them or eyther of them

row.cell: Item for a merriment uppon the towne close

div.head: f [1v]
div.ab: TheIune vth of Iune mr Powle did showe me an Infamous libel written in Ryming verses made as I suppose of P E.

div.p: Powle is mentioned on f 35 as having arrested someone, so he was likely a constable or similar official. For some partial transcriptions, see Winthrop, Life and Letters, pp 39-85.

div.head: single sheet v (12 May)
div.ab: memorandum that the kings maiestie sett forthe a proclamation giuen at Theobaldes the vjth of may against licenses granted by the late Queen to private persons of all monopolies/ & against prophaning of the Saboth by Enterludes Bulbaytinges & all other games/

div.p: The proclamation to which Winthrop is referring appears to be 'An Acte for the Continuance and Explanation of the Statute made in the 39 Yeere of the Raigne of our late Queene Elizabeth, intituled An Acte for Punishmente of Rogues Vagabondes and Sturdie Beggers,' made on 7 July 1603 (Statutes of the Realm, vol 4, pt 2 (London, 1819), 1024). The Elizabethan Act here being renewed was made on 9 February 1598 (Statutes of the Realm, vol 4, pt 2, p 899). The only substantial difference appears to be the addition of an emphasis on Sabbath-breaking, rather than unlicensed travel, in the statute of James I.
James Stuart (1566–1625) was crowned James I of England on 25 July 1603. See P&P.
Elizabeth Tudor (1533–1602/3) was crowned Elizabeth I on 15 January 1558/9. See P&P.

div.head: f 158 (28 February)
div.ab: The Lorde make you the Instrument of my helpe Lorde Cromewell, that I may have fre lyberty to preech the trewthe

I dedycat and offer to your lordeshype, A Reverent Receyvyng of the sacrament as A lenton matter, declaryd by vj Childern representyng, Chryst, the worde of god, pavle, Austyn, A chylde, a Nunn Nonne caulyd Ignoransy, as a secret thyng, that shall have his ende ons rehersyd a fore your Eye by ye sayd chyldern

The most part of the prystes of Suffolk wyll not reseyve me yn to ther Chyrchys to preche, but have dysdaynyd me euer synns I made a play agaynst the popys Covnselerrs, Error, Colle Clogger of Conseyens, and Incredulyte, That and the Act of Parlyament had not folowyd after, I had be Covntyd a gret lyar

I have made a playe caulyd a Rude Commynawlte / I am a making of a nother caulyd, The Woman on the Rokke, yn the fyer of faythe affynyng, & a purgyng yn the trewe purgatory, Never to be seen, but of your lordshyps Eye
Ayde me for Chrystys sake that I may preech chryst

div.head: mb 1d (29 August)
div.ab: AdGippewici eandem Curiam balliui domini Regis libertatis ville Gippewici & eiusdem tota Communitas concesserunt Thome Denys dimissioIohanni Caldewell Willelmo Rydout & Iohanni Causton totum proficuum illius tenementi vocatum Merssh cum domibus edificijs terris arrabilibus pratis pascuis pasturis marescis & omnibus alijs suis pertinentibus A festo Sancti Michaelis Archangeli vltimo preterito ante datam presencem vsque ad finem & terminum Trium Annorum proximorum sequentium plenarie complendorum ad Sustentacionem & reparacionem de lez pagentis Gilde Corporis Christi predicte ville Gippewici &c

div.head: mb 1d (29 August)
div.ab: AtIpswich the same court, the lord king's bailiffs of the liberty of the town of Ipswich and the whole commonalty of the same have granted to Thomas Denys,Demise John Caldewell, William Rydout, and John Causton all the profit of the tenement called 'Merssh' with the houses, buildings, arable lands, meadows, pastures, grazing lands, marshes, and all its other appurtenances from the last feast of Michaelmas before the present date until the end and term of the three years next following to be completed fully for the maintenance and repair of the pageants of the guild of Corpus Christi of the aforesaid town of Ipswich, etc.

div.head: mb 1d (8 April)
div.ab: Adfinis sub condicione eandem Curiam Iohannes Causton admissus est burgensie intrincece Et habet exitum videlicet Iohannem Henricum Thomam & Robertum Et Iuratus est sub ista condicione quod idem Iohannes Causton per vij Annos proxime sequentes post datam presentis Curie diligenter fideliter & assidue secundum suum posse attendet ministrabit & custodiet ornamenta quecumque de lez pagentis Gilde corporis Christi dicte ville Gippewici Ac preuidebit & ordinabit circa reparacionem de lez pagentis & pro factura de lez Stages pro lusoribus tam de villa quam extra vna cum Thoma Bysshop clerico Communi dicte ville Gippewici per superuisionem balliuorum eiusdem ville qui pro tempore fuerint capiendo omnes & singulas expensas tam pro reparacione de Lez pagentis quam pro conduccione araiamentorum vestimentorum & aliorum necessariorum que ad dicta Lez pagentis fuerint necessaria de firmarijs Communis Maresci & pratis portmannorum prout dictis balliuis necesse videatur & oportunum quam diu &c Et dictus Iohannes Causton obijt infra terminum Annorum predictorum

EtGippewici ad eandem Curiam ordinatum est & concordatum per predictos balliuos & burgenses dicte ville Gippewici quod firmarij Communis Marisci ac prati portmanorum eiusdem ville qui pro tempore erunt Annuatim soluent vel solui facient Iohanni Caldewell pro expensis factis circa predictos lez pagentis Gilde corporis christi xl s. quousque expense predicte prefato Iohanni Caldewell aut eius certo attornato plenarie fuerint solute &c

div.head: mb 1d (8 April)
div.ab: AtAgreement under condition the same court, John Causton was admitted to the civil burgessy, and he has issue, namely, John, Henry, Thomas, and Robert, and he was sworn under this condition that the same John Causton for the seven years next following after the date of the present court shall diligently, faithfully, and assiduously, according to his ability, attend, administer, and guard any and all of the accoutrements of the the pageants of the guild of Corpus Christi of the said town of Ipswich and will make provision and arrangements concerning the repair of the pageants and for the construction of the stages for the actors both from the town and outside, together with Thomas Bysshop, common clerk of the said town of Ipswich, by oversight of the bailiffs of the same town at the time, by receiving all and each of the expenses both for the repair of the pageants and for the hiring of the arrayment, clothing, and other necessaries which, for the said pageants, will be necessary from the farmers of the common marsh and the townsmen's (councillors') meadow as it seems necessary to the said bailiffs and opportune, as long as, etc. And the said John Causton died within the term of the aforesaid years.

AndIpswich at the same court it was ordered and agreed by the aforesaid bailiffs and burgesses of the said town of Ipswich that the farmers of the common marsh and the townsmen's meadow of the same town who exist at the time shall pay annually or shall cause to be paid to John Caldewell for the expenses incurred concerning the aforesaid pageants of the guild of Corpus Christi, £40, to the point that the aforesaid expenses will be fully paid to the aforesaid John Caldewell or his sure attorney, etc.

div.head: p 276 (25 April)
div.ab: Et eligerunt Willelmum Parnel Iohannem Balhed Willelmum Guykon Carpenter & Iacobum Cook ad gubernandum lez pagent & ad custodiendum omnia & singula eidem pertinencia

div.head: p 276 (25 April)
div.ab: And they elected William Parnell, John Balhed, William Guykon, carpenter, and James Cook to govern the pageant and to keep all and each of the things pertaining to it.

div.p: The court appointed a considerable number of burgesses annually to serve as wardens with responsibilities related to the celebration of Corpus Christi. Those with the most comprehensive responsibilities were the four wardens of the Guild of Corpus Christi. On this same page, the court names the wardens for five of the pageants in 1491, including those for St George, St John, St Eligius, St Thomas and the Tabernacle of the Carpenters. The list also includes an additional seven pairs of names following these five pairs. The seven pairs were apparently wardens as well, but the names of the pageants for which they were presumably responsible are not given.

div.head: p 289 (11 July)
div.ab: Et concesserunt Balliuis ‸qui nunc sunt fac' habebunt ffinum vnius Burgensis ad eorum eleccionem in recompensionem xlv s. j d. quos soluerunt pro expensis de le pagent iue Ita quod non sit alienus neque extraneaextranea: for extraneus ? aut carnifex

div.head: p 289 (11 July)
div.ab: And they granted to the current bailiffs that they shall have the fee of one burgess at their election in recompense for 45s 1d which they spent on the expenses for the pageant, provided that he is not an outsider, nor a stranger or butcher.

row.cell: Et Ordinauerunt quod Gilda Corporis Christi teneatur singulis annis dominice proxime post Octavas Corporis Christi
Et eligerunt Robertum Ioyne & Johannem Boteler Gardianos Gilde Corporis Christi pro anno future.
Et eligerunt Robertum Bobat mercer & Iohannem Barbour Taillor colligere illos denarios qui assessi erunt pro misis & costagijs de lez pagentes
And they have ordered that the Corpus Christi guild be held each year on the Sunday next after the octave of Corpus Christi
And they have elected Robert Joyne and John Boteler wardens of the Corpus Christi Guild for the year to come.
And they have elected Robert Bobat, mercer, and John Barbour, tailor, to collect those monies that were assessed for the expenses and costs of the pageants.

div.p: An additional entry - an order concerning the obligations of Corpus Christi Guild members related to vigils and obsequies for dead members - occurs on p 133.

div.head: f 12v (28 March)
div.ab: Ad⸿ hanc Curiam concordatum est & stabilitum est per balliuos burgenses & Communitatem quod ludus vocatus Corpus Christi pley pro hoc anno deferatur & non luditur Et quod prandium vocatum Corpus Christi dynner pro hoc anno deferatur & non custoditur

div.head: f 12v (28 March)
div.ab: At⸿ this court it was agreed and established by the bailiffs, burgesses, and commonalty that the pastime called 'the Corpus Christi play' shall be deferred this year and not played. And that the meal called 'the Corpus Christi dinner' shall be deferred this year, and not held.

div.head: f 33 (16 April)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam concordatum est & stabilitum quod ludus vocatus Corpus Cristi Pley & Prandium vocatum Corpus Cristi dynner pro anno futuro non luditur neque custoditur set deferrantur &c

div.head: f 33 (16 April)
div.ab: At this court it was agreed and established that the pastime called 'the Corpus Christi play' and the meal called 'the Corpus Christi dinner' for the coming year is not played nor held, but they shall be deferred, etc.

div.head: f 52 (26 September)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam eligerunt Robertum Ioyne & Robertum Bobat Gardianos Guilde Corporis Cristi pro anno sequente et quilibet Burgensis soluet pro Prandio suo prout ex antiquo consueuit Et ludus vocatus Corpus Cristi pley pro hoc anno non luditur &c

div.head: f 52 (26 September)
div.ab: At this court they elected Robert Joyne and Robert Bobat wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi for the following year and each burgess shall pay for their dinner as is the custom from ancient times. And the pastime called 'the Corpus Christi play' is not played this year, etc.

div.head: f 83v (24 April)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam similiter concordatum est per Balliuis & Burgensibus prescriptis quod ludus vocatus Corpus Cristi Pley & Prandium vocatum Corpus Cristi dynner pro hoc annaanna: for anno non luditur neque custoditur set deferantur &c

div.head: f 83v (24 April)
div.ab: At this court, it was likewise agreed by the aforementioned bailiffs and burgesses that the pastime called 'the Corpus Christi play' and the meal called 'the Corpus Christi dinner' for this year is not played nor held, but they shall be deferred, etc.

div.head: f 127 (14 March)
div.ab: Ad hanc Curiam concordatum est quod ludus vocatus Corpus Christi PaiePaie: for Plaie & Prandium vocatum Corpus Christi dynner pro hoc anno non luditur nec custoditur

div.head: f 127 (14 March)
div.ab: At this court, it was agreed that the pastime called 'the Corpus Christi play' and the dinner called 'the Corpus Christi dinner' for this year is not played nor held.

div.head: ff 153-3v (26 January)
div.ab: Et assignauerunt Robertum Ioyne & Ricardus lenaker Gardianos Gilde Corporis christi pro Anno sequenti Et quod Prandium vocatum Corpus christi Dynner hoc Anno tenetur & custoditur &c Et quod ludus vocatus Corpus christi Playe pro hoc anno ludeturludetur: likely for non ludetur nec tenetur
Et Assignauerunt Thomam Manser & Willelmum Gardener Magistros pro Anno sequenti Et quod haberent le Pagent paratum AA: for ad festum Corporis Christi sub pena forisfacture x li.

div.head: ff 153-3v (26 January)
div.ab: And they assigned Robert Joyne and Richard Lenaker to be wardens of the guild of Corpus Christi for the following year and the dinner called 'the Corpus Christi dinner' is held this year and kept And that the play called 'the Corpus Christi play' for this year shall not be played nor held.

And they assigned Thomas Manser and William Gardener to be masters for the following year, and they would have the pageant ready for the feast of Corpus Christi under penalty of the forfeiture of £10.

John Fordham (c 1340-1425) was bishop of Durham in 1381-2, and bishop of Ely from 3 April 1388.

Henry Beaufort (c 1375-1447) was bishop of Winchester from 1404, with residence at the Bishop's Palace, Winchester. He was the second son of the four legitimized children of John of Gaunt, and from 1426 was a cardinal of the Church of Rome. See P&P.

div.p: Richard Beadle identifies this Clyfton (f 35) as likely being Robert Clyfton (d. c 1482-3), of Topcroft, Norfolk, a place six miles northeast of Mettingham. If so, Clyfton was an associate of Sir Thomas Brews, of Topcroft ('Mettingham College,' p 130, nn 7,9).

div.head: f 41 (25 April-29 September 1451) (Gifts)
div.ab: Inprimis Thome menstrall' & socio suo iiij d.

div.ab: First to Thomas, a minstrel (or Thomas Menstrall), and his fellow, 4d.

div.p: A marginal entry on f 38v says that this entry on f 41, with those around it, was for payments made post-Easter 1451. Hereafter in the register, mini- headings and marginal entries similar to this one indicate whether the section of payments is Easter-Michaelmas or Michaelmas-Easter for a given accounting year.

div.p: Sir Thomas Brews of Topcroft, Norfolk, six miles northwest of Mettingham, appears again in the records in 1473-4. He was an associate of Robert Clyfton, also of Topcroft, and the father of Margery Brews, wife of John Paston III (Beadle, 'Mettingham College,' p 130).

div.head: mb [2d] (27 July)
div.ab: Iohannesffinem xl s. Attefforth dat domino de fine pro eo quod intrabat clausuram domini & simul cum alijs ludebat in aula domini vnum ludum vocatum Somergamen vt in capitulo

div.head: mb [2d] (27 July)
div.ab: JohnFine 40s Atteforth gives to the lord as regards a fine because he entered the lord's close and at the same time with others played a game called 'Summer-game' in the lord's hall, as in the (marginal) heading (ie, 40s).

div.p: Why the playing of the summer game in the lord's hall should generate a sizable fine is not clear, since in its traditional form the summer game was festive and non-controversial. One can only assume that Atte Forth either used this game for an unacceptable purpose, or entered the lord's close and hall without permission. Christopher Dyer argues that customs of this kind, because they involve processions and large gatherings of people, 'are directly relevant to the 1381 revolt because the first outbreaks in Essex and Kent took place in Whit week, 1-8 June, the normal time for summer games,' and for the holding of court leet sessions ('The rising of 1381 in Suffolk: Its Origins and Participants,' Proceedings of the Suffolk Institute of Archaeology 36.4 (1988), 281). Traditional festive forms certainly became political instruments much later during the sixteenth century but the immediate context of this particular incident in the late fourteenth century remains obscure.

div.head: single membrane
div.ab: Hec IndenturaHec Indentura: in display script testatur quod nos Iohannes permissione divina abbas Monasterij Sancti Edmundi de Bury ex assensu & voluntate prioris & ejusdem loci Conuentus Tradidimus & ad firmam dimisimus Roberto Wright Glaser & * Iohanni Anable Pewterer de Bury predicte Manerium nostrum de Haberdon cum pertinencijs pertinenspertinens: for pertinentibus (?) ad officium Sacriste dicti nostri Monasterij cum quatuor acris terre in le vynefeld quondam Margerie Howton Iacentes iuxta Nomannes medewe * cum omnibus alijs terris pratis pasturis & omnibus alijs pertinentijs Manerio predicto pertinentibus Exceptis Zabulo & lapidibus in Haberdon Clos predicta Habendum & TenendumHabendum & Tenendum: in display script predictum Manerium cum dictis quatuor acris terre & omnibus suis pertinentijs Exceptis preexceptis * prefatis Roberto Wryght & Iohanni Anable executoribus & assignatis suis a ffesto sancti Michaelis Archangeli proxime futuro post datum presencium vsque ad finem & terminum viginti annorum extunc proxime et immediate sequencium & plenarie Completorum ReddendoReddendo: for CL redentibus * inde annuatim dicto abbati & successoribus suis ad vsum Officij Sacriste dicti monasterij qui pro tempore fuerit durante termino predicto quinque libras & quatuor solidos legalis monete Anglie ad duos anni terminos videlicet ad ffesta pasche & sancti Michaelis * Archangeli equis porcionibus Et dicti Robertus Wryght & Iohannes Anable executores & assignati sui inuenient seu inueniri facient vnum album taurum omni anno eorum termini predicti tociens quociens Contigerit aliquam mulierem generosam * vel aliquas alias mulieres ex deuocione siue voto per ipsas facto venire ad feretrum gloriosi regis & Martiris Sancti Edmundi ad oblaciones dicti albi tauri faciendas

div.head: single membrane
div.ab: This indenture bears witness that we, John, by divine permission, abbot of the monastery of Bury St Edmunds, by the assent and will of the prior and of the community of the same place, have handed over and demised to farm to Robert Wright, glasier, and John Anable, pewterer, of Bury aforesaid our manor of Haberdon with appurtenances, belonging to the office of sacrist of our said monastery, with four acres of land in the vinefield formerly of Margery Howton, which lie next to No Man's Meadow with all the other lands, meadows, pastures, and all other appurtenances appertaining to the aforesaid manor, sand and stones being excepted, in the aforesaid Haberdon Close, the aforesaid manor to be had and held with the said four acres of land and all their appurtenances, with the pre-exceptions excepted, by the aforesaid Robert Wright and John Anable, their executors and assigns from the feast of St Michael the archangel next to come after the present date to the end and term of twenty years from that time next and immediately following and fully completed, who will pay thereafter annually to the said abbot and his successors to be used by the office of the sacrist of the said monastery who is for the time during the aforesaid term, five pounds and four shillings of legal money of England twice a year, namely at the feast of Easter and of St Michael the archangel, in equal portions. And the said Robert Wryght and John Anable, their executors and assigns will find or will cause to be found one white bull every year of their term aforesaid as often as it should happen that any gentle woman, or any other women by devotion or vows made by themselves, come to the shrine of the glorious king and martyr, St Edmund, to make the offerings of the said white bull there

div.head: ff 24-4v (7 January)
div.ab:
Item I geve and bequethe to the Gylde of seynt Iohn Baptist in Bury and also for the Revell on Seynt Edmundes E nyght my
longe gown of blak demaske and my short gowne of damakse and I will that Iohn Basse haue the kepyng of the seid ij gownes duryng his lyff and after the discease of the seid Iohn Basse to remayn to thuse aboueseid

div.p: John Basse (d. 1506) was 'a prominent draper' of Bury, who would 'request burial in the north porch of St Mary's church in his will' written in 1506 (Gibson, Theatre of Devotion, pp 115, and 206, n 37). Given the content concerning Basse and the St Edmund's Night revel, in John Benale's will, Basse was a fellow member of the guild of St John Baptist and a participant, along with Benale, in that revel.

div.head: f 330 (19 November)
div.ab: Item he dyd giue vnto his brother Robert Critofte his best dublet his Cote his best cloke his tabret with the pypes and stik flewed with syluer all his maskinge geare with visers and the drome, all his new dauncinge crestes with all his foyle assydew and glew all his gylt workes lyeng vppon the chambre in a chist a table paynted of the passion of christe. Item he dyd gyve to Robert Boyton his seruaunt all his paynters patrones.

div.p: Dymond says that in Sexten's original will, Critofte is identified as Sexten's cousin rather than his brother (Suffolk Archives, Bury: IC 500/1/20, f 249). Dymond has used the registered version of Sexten's will because, as he says, 'the original is damaged and incomplete' (Three Entertainers , p 5, n 11).

Citing J.O. Halliwell-Phillips, Dictionary of Archaic and Provincial Words, vol 1 (London, 1846), p 97, Dymond says that 'assidue' was much used by participants at Christmas and on Plough Monday, in referring to their decorations.

By policy, REED does not systematically search royal records or include extracts from royal records in the main Records text. However, in the course of researching for the Suffolk collection, there have turned up several entries in royal records that provide significant information about performances in Suffolk, or elsewhere by Suffolk performers. Those records have been selected for inclusion in this appendix because they show Suffolk aristocracy involved in dramatic entertainment at an early date. These include performances by numerous entertainers before and at the nuptuals of Margaret, daughter of Edward I, at Ipswich in 1296-7; guardrobe accounts of the custodian of the two princes, Thomas of Brotherton and Edmund of Woodstock, in 1311-12; a mimetically and musically informed hastiludium sponsored by the Black Prince at Bury St Edmunds in 1348; a reward at Bury St Edmunds to a minstrel in an inventory of the Black Prince in 1348; and a reward to a troupe of Suffolk players performing at court in 1512.

row.cell: Item to iiij players that came oute of Suffolke that playd afore the lorde Stewardelorde Stewarde: George Talbot, earl of Shrewsbury in the kinges hall Monday nyght in Rewarde

div.p: Henry VIII had many residences, several of which had a king's hall, but section headings within this account indicate that the king was at Greenwich in December 1511 and January 1512, so it seems likely that the players fom Suffolk performed at Greenwich Palace, or at another royal venue in Greenwich. The payment to the Suffolk players ocurs within a cluster of payments, mostly to members of the king's household, at Greenwich.

div.ab: One charger called Morel de Burghersh given by the lord (prince), to a minstrel at the tournament at Bury St Edmunds, in the twenty-second year (of the reign of Edward III).

row.cell: Roberto de fframelyngham Citheratori & Iohanni socio suo & Ricardo Dassa menestrallis domine Comitisse marescalle venientibus in comitiam eiusdem Comitisse facientibus menestralciam in presencia dominorum de dono eorundem apud fframelyngham .xv. die Iunij
Matillde Makeioie Saltatrici facienti menestralciam suam in presencia dominorum de dono eorundem precepto domini Thome ibidem. xxiiijto. die Iunij

Willelmo Pilk Waffrario Regis & Elene consorti sue menestralle seruientibus de Waffris suis ad mensas dominorum & familie sue & facientibus menestralciam suam in presencia ipsorum dominorum & capientibus licenciam suam eundo ad dominum Regem in partibus borialibus existem de dono eorundem nunciante domino Ade Weston apud fframelyngham xxiiij die Iunij

To Robert de Framlingham, harper, and John, his fellow, and Richard Dassa, minstrels of the lady countess, the marshaless, who came into the county of the same countess, and who made their minstrelsy in the presence of lords from a gift of the same at Framlingham, 15 June.
To Matilda Makejoy, dancer, who made her minstrelsy in the presence of the lords from a gift of same by order of Lord Thomas there, 24 June

To William Pilk, waferer of the king, and his partner (or wife), Ellen, minstrels, who served with respect to their wafers at the table of the lords, and to their family, and who made their minstralsy in the presence of the same lords and took their leave in going to the lord king while he dwells in northern parts, from a gift of the same (lords), with Lord Adam Weston announcing (it) at Framlingham, 24 June

div.p: According to Constance Bullock-Davies, Matilda Makejoy, who appears in the household accounts of both Edward I and Edward II, was a saltatrix or 'acrobatic dancer' She is listed among the minstrels receiving payments for their performances at this feast and on other occasions. Makejoy was not a 'royal domestic minstrel,' that is, a member of the household entertainers, though she was 'attached to the royal household for at least 14 years' (Menstrellorum Multitudo: Minstrels at a Royal Feast (Cardiff, 1978), 26, 55). As Bullock-Davies explains it, Matilda Makejoy's profession of 'acrobatic dancing girl' had ancient roots, dating at least to the time of Homer and Zenophon, and is traceable through the Middle Ages both in England and in Europe. While the assorted payments to Makejoy are unique in the records, a number of medieval manuscripts contain illustrations of female acrobatic dancers, including the biblical Salome, and other unidentified dancing girls (for some of the British examples, see BL: MS Harley 1527, f 29; BL: MS Cotton Domitian A2, f 7; BL: Royal MS E iv, f 58; and Bodl.: MS 264 (Bullock-Davies, Menstrellorum Multitudo, pp 55-7)). The royal payroll edited and analyzed by Bullock-Davies in her book also identifies nine performers (male) and their patrons, who were women, including discussion of the specific skills and musical instruments favored in their household performers by these women patrons (Bullock-Davies, Menstrellorum Multitudo, pp 11, 67-173).

row.cell: Giloto cithariste domini hugonis de Cressingham redeunti ad eundem dominum suum in Scotia de dono Regis per manus proprias apud Sanctum Edmundum xx. die Nouembris

Menstrallis die Nuptiarum Comitisse Hollandie filie Regis

Girsecote/ Visage, & Magote Menestrallis facientibus eodem modo menstralcias suas coram dicta domina Elizabetha die predicto per manus dicti domini Iohannis ibidem eodem die cuilibet eorum xx s. de dono Regis

Diuersis Menestrallis facientibus Menestralcias suas coram Comite Hollandie & Comitissa filia Regis die nuptiarum suarum predicto de dono eiusdem Comitis per preceptum Regis videlicet Ricardino vidulatori Morello Regi. Guilloto de Ros Ianino le leutor Thome le ffol cuilibet eorum L s. xij li. x.s. Duobus Citharistis/ duobus Trumpatoribus Regis Iohanni Drake Wafrario, Duneme, Bandetto Thomelino vidulatori Duobus Citharistis Episcopi Dunolmi duobus menestrallis Comitis Marescalli Hamoni Lestinour, Lambyn Clay, Iohanni de Cressin cuilibet istorum xv. xx s. xv. li. Cithariste domini Iohannis Comyn. I marcam, Druetto Monthant & Iaketto de Scocie RegibusScocie Regibus: Robert the Bruce succeeded John Balliol on 25 March 1296, which perhaps accounts for the plural Regibus cuilibet eorum xl. s vj li. Waffrario filii Regis quatuor vigilibus Regis & filii Regis duobus Citharistis Comitis Oxonie & domini Thome de Multon Henrico le Harpour/ Laurencio le Harpour, Martinetto le taburer cuilibet istorum x s. C s. et quibusdam aliis Menestrallis in comuni per manus domini Christiani Raphurst xlvj. s. viij. d.

To a harper of lord Hugh
of Cressingham
To Giloto, harper of Lord Hugh of Cressingham, returning to the same, his lord, in Scotland from a gift of the king by his own hands at (Bury) St Edmunds, 20 November

To Nicholas and Adam, harpers of the king, from a gift of the same king, for a piece of wood to be bought by them (or him?) for their portable bed (? lit. bed to be carried), Lord Peter chaumpnent announcing (it) on behalf of the king himself by the hands of the said Nicholas at Bures, 9 December

To Matilda Makejoy , a dancer who did her dances before Lord Edward, son of the king, in the hall of the same king from a gift of the same Lord Edward by the hands of Nicholas Arcard at Ipswich, 27 December
To minstrels on the wedding day of the Countess of Holland, daughter of the king

To John, page of the king, fiddler and his companion, Simon, (his) son, a minstrel making (their) minstralcy on the wedding day of Elizabeth, daughter of the king, Countess of Holland, to each of them, 50s from a gift of the king by the hands of Lord John of Boutetourte there, 8 January

To Girsecote, Visage, and Magote, minstrels, who, in the same way, made their minstrelcy before the said lady Elizabeth on the aforesaid day by the hands of the said Lord John there on the same day, to each of them, 20s from a gift of the king

To various minstrels who made their minstrelcy before the count of Holland and the countess, the daughter of the king, on their wedding day aforesaid from a gift of the same count by order of the king, that is to say, to Richardino, fiddler, Morello Regi, Guilloto of Ros, Janino the Luter, Thomas the Fool, to each of them, 50s: £7 10s. To two harpers; two trumpeters of the king; to John Drake; (to a) waferer, to Duneme Bandetto; to Thomelino, a fiddler; to two harpers of the bishop of Durham; to two minstrels of earl marshall; to Ham Lestinoni, Lambyn Clay, John de Cressin; to each of those fifteen, 20s: £15. To a harper of Lord John Cumin, 1 mark. To Druetto, Monthant (or Mouthaut, etc), and Jaketto of the kings of Scotland, to each of them 40s: £6. To a waferer of the son of the king, to four watchmen of the king and of the son of the king, to two harpers of the earl of Oxford and of Lord Thomas of Multon , to Henry the harper, to Lawrence the harper, to Martinetto the tabourer, to each of them, 10s: 100s. And to each of the other minstrels in common by the hands of Lord Christian Raphurst, 46s 8s.

div.p: The lavish wedding celebration of Elizabeth Planagenet in Ipswich between late December 1296 and early January 1296/7 occurred between two military campaigns in Edward's war against the Scots. The first of the two campaigns had begun on 27 April 1296 and ended in late July of that year. The second campaign would begin in September 1297. Edward's itineraries to and from the conflicts took him the eastern length of England, from London to the expanses of Scotland, including considerable preparation time spent in Essex, Suffolk and Norfolk. Nearly all of the non-royal patrons named in this document lived in the eastern-most parts of England. The English exception was Sir Hugh de Cressingham (1264-11 September 1297), lord high treasurer of Scotland (for Edward I) from 1296, with a residence at Gressingham, Lancashire, plus at curacies in Norfolk and elsewhere. The one Scot, John Comyn (c 1260-1308), was seventh earl of Buchan from 1289, with residence at Buchan, Scotland. A defeated opponent of Robert the Bruce, he was now under the protection of Edward I. The patrons with East Anglian connections included Simon Fitz Richard, lord of Threxton, Norfolk, Dunmow, Essex, and Letheringham, Suffolk, with residence in Dunmow, Essex; William Marshal (1277-1314), lord of Hingham, Norfolk, first lord marshal from 1313, with residence at Denham, Suffolk; and Robert de Vere (1257-1331); sixth earl of Oxford from 16 February 1295/6, with seat at Hedingham Castle, Essex. Those patrons who lived farther north in the eastern reaches included Anthony Bek (c 1245-1310/11), bishop of Durham from 9 July 1283, with residence at Durham Castle (also serving as the Durham Bishop's Palace); and Thomas de Moulton (1275/6-1313), first Baron Multon of Gilsand from 1307, with residence in Gilsland, Northumberland. Also present were Edward Plantagenet (Edward of Caernarfon) (1284-1327), fourth son of Edward I, prince of Wales from 1301, and King Edward II of England from 1307), and, of course, Elizabeth Plantagenet (Elizabeth of Bohun, Elizabeth of Rhuddlan and countess of Hertford) (1282-1316). While this document includes no explicit references to the Scottish conflicts, the patrons there present, would seem, in their geographical distribution, to reflect the concerns of a monarch who was in the midst of not only the wedding celebration of his daughter, but of domestic wars past and looming.

div.head: The Ceremony of the White Bull

div.p: The medieval abbey at Bury had a curious custom called the Ceremony of the White Bull, in which a wealthy married woman (or any other married woman who could afford it), who was unable to conceive a child, went in a large procession through the town, preceeded by a white bull. The procession traveled from and returned to the Abbey where there occurred a religious ceremony at the Shrine of St Edmund involving prayers that, with the intercession of St Edmund, gave the lady the ability to conceive. Descriptions of the custom show that it traveled west from the Great Churchyard onto Churchgate Street, then right (some six blocks later) onto Guildhall Street, then right (several blocks later) onto Abbeygate Street (once called Cook Row), which ends at the main gate of the abbey. The route took the procession through the two great market squares of the town combining spectacle and loud engagement by townspeople, and ending with a pious ceremony in the Abbey. The fame of the event attracted women (or their surrogates) from other European countries as well.

The earliest surviving description of the event, by schoolmaster William Hawkins, dates from the seventeenth century. Hawkins served as curate of Hadleigh and schoolmaster of Hadleigh Grammar School from 1626 until 1637, when he died of the plague. In his Corolla Varia (a Latin compendium), the entirety of its chapter 26 involves discussion of ‘The Ceremony of the White Bull.’ Hawkins says therein that he is describing an undated court case in which witnesses brought forth three leases, respectively dated 1487, 1519, and 1533, as precedents for the practice of leasing the manor of Haberdon with the attendant responsibility of the leasee to keep or to find a white bull for use in the ceremony. Hawkins’ description includes partial transcriptions of the leases from 1487 and 1519, and a complete transcription of the one from 1533. Of the three leases, only the one from 1533 is known to survive.

According to Hawkins, the earliest of these three leases, the one made on 4 June 1487 at the order of the Sacrist John Swaffham, was written into a register of his that apparently no longer survives. Hawkins’ summary confirms only that the lease of Haberdon Manor to one Simon Lolepke was made on this date, and that in return Lolepeke was to provide a while bull for the ceremony.

The second of the leases, also now lost, was made on 12 September 1519. Hawkins’ summary says little more than that the Sacrist John Eye had leased Haberdon, with responsibility for the white bull, to one Richard Mancrium of Haberdon, using language mirroring the lease of 1487.

The third of the leases, made on 28 April 1533, fortunately survives (TNA: PRO E 327/252). It was made not by a sacrist but by Abbot John Reeve of Melford, the thirty-third and final abbot of Bury St Edmunds (served 1514-38; ejected from the abbey in 1540) whose seal is affixed to the document. The lease was presented to the court by John Hill, an attorney of the King’s Bench (Martin Taylor, '10 Abbots of the Abbey of St Edmund,' Bury St Edmunds and Beyond, accessed 14 November 2024). It offers more detail about the ceremony than do the extracts in Hawkins from the two lost leases of 1487 and 1519. The purpose of this court case appears to concern a dispute over who, at the time of the case, had the right to lease or own the Manor of Haberdon. The case had to have been brought sometime after 1533, at a time when the abbot, not a sacrist, awarded the lease. The parties appear to agree that the ceremony of the white bull had traditionally been a significant part of the land agreement, though the ceremony itself likely was no longer an operative customary event.

div.ab: Orgia Iuridicæ spectate Boalia Musæ Proxima pars pompæ mulier devota Iuvencum Sedula nunc sequitur, nunc blandula passibus æquis It comes. Ille simul (ceu Iuppiter esset in illo) Lacteolum latus & palearia pendula præbet Fœmineâ palpanda manu. Quos tramite longo subsequitur sacris induti sacra canentes Tota cohors Monachorum.
