div.head: pp 60-2 (Legal Instruments Related to the Ceremony of the White Bull)
div.ab: Ex pacto Domini Sacristæ] Prodeant testes in caussa Taurina. Testis primus comparuit vir probus ac lepidus, Iacobus Copinus Notarius publicus, in Ecclesiasticis circumvicinæ Iurisdictionis Curiis Procurator. Profert ille Registrum autenticum Monasterii S. Edmundi, olim Sacristæ custodiæ destinatum. Legit distinctè Dominus Copinus: Hæc indentura testatur quòd Dompnus Iohannes Swaffham Sacrista Monasterii Sancti Edmundi de Bury, ex assensu & voluntate Prioris & Conventûs ejusdem loci, tradidit & ad firmam dimisit Simoni Lolepeke de Bury prædicti yeoman Manerium vocatum Habyrdon in Bury prædicta &c. Habendum &c. ad termum septem annorum &c. Reddendum indè annuatim &c. Et dictus Simon executores & assignati sui invenient seu inveniri facient unum album Taurum omni anno termini sui totiens quotiens contingat aliquam mulierem generosam, vel aliquas alias mulieres ex devotione sive vota per ipsas facta venire ad feretrum gloriosi Regis & Martyris Sancti Edmundi ad oblationes dicti albi Tauri faciendas, &c. In cujus rei testimonium uni parti sigillum Sacristae est appensum &c. Data quarto die Iunii, anno regni Regis Henrici septimi post Conquestum Angliæ secundo.quarto die … secundo: ie, 4 June 1487

Testis secundus, Iohannes Mallosius, Attornatus ad Placita Communia, Burgi ejusdem incorporati Actuarius, sive Scriba publicus. Comparuit. Profert aliud prædicti Monasterii Registrum, ac clarè legit: Hæc indentura facta 12. die Septembris anno regni Regis Henrici VIII. undecimo,12. die … undecimo: ie, 12 September 1519 inter Dompnum Iohannem Eye Sacristam Monasterii Sancti Edmundi de Bury, & Richardum Skinner de Bury prædicta husbandman, testatur, quod praedictus Iohannes Eye ex assensu &c. tradidit & ad firmam dimisit praedicto Richardo Mancrium de Habrydon &c, ad terminum decem annorum &c. Et dictus Richardus inveniet unum album Taurum totiens quotiens contingat, &c. ut priús.

Prodit denique alter Attornatus de Banco Regio, Iohannes Montanu (Anglicè Hill) fide optimâ & canitie priori Attornato haud absimilis. Hic tertiùs testis, isque locuples, tum quia postnominati Hannibalis ex filia nepos, & hæres, cum etiam quia obsignatis tabulis agit. Profert enim instrumentum originale Capituli Monastici sigillo munitum: Hæc Indentura testatur quòd nos Iohannes permissione divinà Abbas Monasterii Sancti Edmundi de Bury, ex assensu & voluntate Prioris & ejusdem loci Conventûs, tradidimus & ad firmam dimisimus Roberto Wright GlasierGlasier: in gothic type & Iohanni Anable PewtererPewterer: in gothic type de Bury praedicta Manerium nostrum de Habyrdon cum pertinentibus pertinens ad officium Sacristæ dicti nostri Monasterii &c. Habendum à festo Sancti Michaëlis Archangeli proxime futuro post datum presentem usque ad finem virgintì annorum, &c. Reddendo inde annuatim dicto Abbati & Successoribus suis ad usum oficii Sacristæ quinque libras & quatuor solidos, &c. Et dicti Robertus & Iohannes invenient unum album Taurum omni anno Termini sui prædicti totiens quotiens contigerit aliquam mulierem generosam, vel aliquas alias mulieres ex devotione sive vota per ipsas facta venire ad feretrum gloriosi Regis & Martyris Sancti Edmundi ad oblationes dictas albi Tauri faciendas &c. In cujus rei Testimonium uni parti istius indenturæ penes præfatos Abbatem, Priorem, & Conventem remanenti prædicti Robertus & Iohannes sigilla sua apposuerunt, alteri vero parti ejusdem pènes præfatos Robertum & Iohannem remanenti
prædicti Abbas, Prior, & Conventus sigillum commune nostri capitalì ad causas fecimus apponi. Datum in domo nostra capitulari xxviii die Aprilis, Anno Regis Henrici Octavi xxv. Et anno Domini 1533.

div.head: p 55
div.ab: In the fields of Haberdon near the walls of the town,
the pastor, the hhThe keeper of the bull, more suited for the fields than the keeper of the north star is to the sky keeper of the bull, by agreement with the lord sacrist, nourished him,
who was accustomed not to turn the earth with the ploughshare,
nor to serve a heavy wagon, nor, in chains,
to be vexed by the bite of a dog as a spectacle for the people.

div.head: p 56
div.ab: Barren wives entreated the holy shrine
of the martyr, Edmund, and placing gifts. Still,
vows and prayers were worth nothing, gifts nothing, nor gold
to prevent them returning barren, unless there was also
an offering to the white bull

div.head: pp 57-9
div.ab: Muses of justice, observe the bovine rites,
the next part of the display. A woman devoted to the young bull
follows, now attentive, now flattering, with equal steps
as a companion she goes. He at same the time - as if Jupiter were in him -
offers (his) milk-white flank and hanging dewlaps
to be caressed by a feminine hand. A whole company
of monks follows them on the long path, singing sacred (songs), dressed
in sacred (vestments). And so, that which is accustomed to be called
a sacred procession, serving the choragus, rejoices in a beast.
And, lest the pomp be too little seen

they go around the larger meeting-places of the town,indeed, by the much frequented streets: Church Street, Guildhall Street, Cook Row, the last of which leads back to the main door of the monastery by a left turn.
When the bull has been led back to his usual stall,
she immediately enters the temple. Edmund's supplicant prostrates herself before the altars.
'O help (your) servant, most holy martyr', she exclaims 'Succour me, being childless; succour (my) husband,
for you are able.' At the same time she presses kisses on the cold stones.
Tears wash the stones; faithful hope calms the tears.
Lately done and returning to the mind - she was herself a great part of it - the splendid nuptial semblance strengthens hope.
Accordingly he (St Edmund?) adds a gift in the name of the life- giving bull.
The more the gentle lady has faith in the signs, And the more plentifully and the more passionately, so much the more quickly he offers the gift.
Joyful, she returns home. She becomes a mother.
The monks rejoice in the votive reward; the husband in the votive heir;
you also, muses of justices, in this votive song.

div.head: pp 60-2 (Legal Instruments Related to the Ceremony of the White Bull)
div.ab: From the lord sacrist's agreement] Let witnesses come forth in the case of the bull. The first witness has appeared, an honourable and agreeable man, James Copinus, notary public, proctor in the ecclesiastical courts of the neighbouring jurisdictions. He produces an authentic register of the monastery of St Edmund, which at one time was assigned to the guardianship of the sacrist. Master Copinus reads clearly: 'This indenture bears witness that John Swaffham, sacrist of the monastery of Bury St Edmunds, by the assent and will of the prior and the community of the same place, has handed over and leased to farm to Simon Lolepeke of the aforesaid Bury, yeoman, the manor called Haberdon in the aforesaid Bury, etc. to have, etc. for a term of seven years and revisited yearly after that. And the said Simon, his executors and assigns will find or will cause to be found one white bull every year of their term as often as it should happen that any gentle woman or any other women by devotion or vow made by themselves come to the shrine of the glorious king and martyr, St Edmund, to make offerings of the said white bull, &c. In witness of which, the sacrist's seal is appended to one part, &c. Given 4 June, in the second year of the reign of King Henry the seventh after the conquest of England.'

The second witness, John Mallosius, attorney of the Common Pleas, actuary of the same incorporated town, or notary public, has appeared. He produces another register of the aforesaid monastery, and clearly reads: 'This indenture made 12 September in the eleventh year of the reign of King Henry VIII, between Master John Eye, sacrist of the monastery of Bury St Edmunds and Richard Skinner, husbandman of Bury aforesaid, bears witness that the aforesaid John Eye by assent, etc, has handed over and leased to farm to the aforesaid Richard Mancrium of Haberdon, etc, for a term of ten years, etc, and the said Richard will find one white bull as often as it should happen, etc, as before.'

Lastly, another attorney of the King's Bench, John Montanus, in English 'Hill,' not at all unlike the earlier attorney in great trustworthiness and maturity. This is the third witness, and he is a valuable one, both because he is a descendant and heir of the later renowned Hannibal from his daughter, and because he works with sealed tablets. For he produced an original instrument of the monastic chapter fortified with a seal: 'This indenture bears witness that we, John, by divine permission abbot of the monastery of Bury St Edmunds, by the assent and will of the prior and of the religious community of the same place, have handed over and leased to farm to Robert Wright, glasier, and John Anable, pewterer, of the aforesaid Bury, our manor of Haberdon with appurtenances belonging to the office of sacrist of our said monastery, etc, to be held from the feast of St Michael the archangel next to come after the present date for the period of twenty years, and revisiting annually after that, etc, five pounds and four shillings to be paid thereafter annually to the said abbot and his successors for the use of the office of the sacrist, etc. And the said Robert and John will find one white bull every year of their aforesaid term as often as it should happen that any gentle woman or any other women by devotion or vows made by themselves come to the shrine of the the glorious king and martyr, St Edmund, to make the said offerings
of the white bull, etc. In testimony of which matter the aforesaid Robert and John have placed their seals to one part of this indenture which remains in the possession of the abbot, prior, and community, but to the other part of this same which remains in the possession of the aforesaid Robert and John,
we, the aforesaid abbot, prior and community, have caused to be placed the seal common to our capital for cases. Given in our chapter house, 28 April, in the twenty-fifth year of King Henry VIII, and the year of the lord, 1533.

div.p: An article in Gentleman's Magazine, by one D. H. describes the event in these terms: 'Whenever a married woman wished to be pregnant, this white bull, who enjoyed full ease and plenty in the fields of Habyrdon, never meanly yoked to the plough, no ever cruelly baited at the stake, was led in procession through the principal streets of the town, viz., Church Street, Guildhall Street, and Cook Row, of which the last led to the principal gate of the monastery, attended by all the monks singing, and a shouting crowd, the woman walking by him, and stroking his milk-white side and pendant dewlaps. The bull then being dismissed, the woman entered the church, and paid her vows at the altar of St. Edmund, kissing the stone, and entreating with tears the blessing of a child. This reminds one of the luperci among the Romans, who ran naked about the streets, and with thongs of goatskins struck women with child in order to give easy labour (Virg., "Æn," viii, 633),' reprinted from 1783, pt 2, pp 900-01, in George Laurence Gomme (ed), The Gentleman's Magazine Library: Being a Classified Collection of the Chief Contents of the Gentleman's Magazine from 1731 to 1868, vol 24 (London, 1883-1905), 209). A nineteenth-century civic guide from Bury claims that quotes from a deed say that 'on the 2nd of June, 1474, three religious persons of the city of Ghent, came and offered, as had been accustomed of old time, at the shrine of the blessed King, Virgin, and Martyr, St. Edmund, in the presence of several reputable people, and of the said martyr, one white bull, for the accomplishment of the longing of a certain noble lady (in relevamen desiderii cujusdam nobilis dominae)' (Anonymous, Guide to the Town, Abbey, and Antiquities of Bury St. Edmunds With a List of the Numerous Benefactions and Other General and Useful Information, 2nd ed (Bury, 1836), 55-6.

The originals of the first two leases extracted by Hawkins have not yet come to light. The third is from TNA: PRO E 327/252. For a transcription of this third lease, see 1533 below. Thomson, Archives, p 58, says that Haberdon is a manor in Essex, but it is in fact a manor farm in Bury (with thanks to Bury Archivist Jane Ingle for this information).

div.head: Remembrances of pre-Reformation Drama, Custom and Ceremony in Long Melford

div.p: Before the Reformation, Long Melford (near Bury) had a flourishing tradition of local drama, customs, and religious ceremonials, many of those activities making use of Melford’s cathedral-like parish church and churchyard. When the Reformation brought the destruction of those traditional customs and ceremonials, Roger Martin, one of Melford’s most influential (and anti-Reformation) parishioners wrote a unique contempory description of them, hoping thereby to preserve them in the community’s historical memory.

Sixteenth-century Long Melford was a small but significant market town in Babergh Hundred, lying along the principal Sudbury to Bury road three miles from Sudbury and twelve miles from Bury. Paradoxically, being an important manor of the Abbey of Bury St Edmunds furthered both Long Melford's industrial development and its pre-Reformation parish culture. As Mark Bailey has observed, like other successful textile towns in Suffolk, Long Melford flourished 'on the large manor of a major landlord' (increasing the tax base fattened the coffers of the landlord, and Long Melford ranked sixth in Suffolk in taxable wealth). The abbot's manor was an '800-acre desmene together with 600 acres of villein land' Bailey, Medieval Suffolk pp 33, 282, 300.) The abbot was granted a weekly market and fair on Thursdays at Long Melford in 1235 and the town had a nine-day annual fair from 1330 that ran from the vigil and day of Pentecost through the next seven days (Gibson, ‘Bury St Edmunds,’ p 79, n 132). Its population grew from sixty-three (in 1086), to sixty-two taxpayers (1327), to 1,000 persons (1524), to 1,150 persons (1603). It had a school by 1350, in which the chantry priest served as schoolmaster. In the 1460s Long Melford ranked fifth among Suffolk towns as a centre of cloth manufacturing, and by the 1520s it had more fullers than any other Suffolk town (Dymond Northeast, History of Suffolk, pp 52–3; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, pp 249, 272–4; Goult, West Suffolk, np; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, p 5).

Long Melford's early parish identity was equally substantial. Its grand fifteenth century parish church of the Holy Trinity has been variously described as 'one of the finest parish churches in England,' 'a village cathedral,' and one of the two most famous churches in Suffolk; the 'enormous' glebe of the parish covered 251 acres of arable, meadow, pasture, and wood lands. The town had six guilds , including Corpus Christi, St Thomas, Blessed Virgin Mary, St Peter, Jesus, and Bachelors, four of whom left streamers or banner cloths in an inventory of 1541. A guildhall of Corpus Christi stood at what Goult says was Little St Mary's in Hall Street (Dymond and Northeast, History of Suffolk, p 55; Blackwood, Tudor and Stuart Suffolk, pp 62, 63-4; Bailey, Medieval Suffolk, p 15).

Roger Martin or Martyn, esquire (1526-1615), who wrote this document, was a member of an ancient and influential family of clothiers in Long Melford. He deeply opposed the spoliation of his parish church and the abolition of its traditional religious customs, ceremonies, and entertainments during the sixteenth-century protestant reform movement. For his efforts, he was several times fined, jailed, and otherwise punished as a recusant by the new ruling order. Eventually he wrote a unique recollection of pre-Reformation customs and services, as he had known them, used at Long Melford before they were destroyed. In the late sixteenth century, one of Martin’s descendents showed the description to then Long Melford Rector, Dr. Nathaniel Bisbie, who ordered it transcribed by Melford schoolmaster Jonathan Moor. In 1825, the then owner of Moor’s transcription permitted it to be published by J. P. Neale. Since then, both Martyn’s original and Moor’s transcription have disappeared, making Neale’s published transcription the earliest surviving version. Neale’s transcription has since been republished, by at least five others.

The Neale version of Martyn’s description is also published, with varying degrees of fidelity, in The Gentlemen’s Magazine 100 (1830), 206-7; Sir William Parker, History of Long Melford (London, 1873), 72-3.; E. L. Conder, Church of the Holy Trinity, Long Melford (np, 1887); and David Dymond and Clive Paine, The Spoil of Melford Church: The Reformation in a Suffolk Parish (Ipswich, 1989), 1–9).

div.head: pp 13-14
div.ab: Upon Palm Sunday, the Blessed Sacrament was carryed in Procession about the Church-yard, under a fair Canopy, borne by four Yeomen; the Procession coming to the Church Gate, went westward, and they with the Blessed Sacrament, went eastward: and when the procession came against the door of Mr. Clopton's Ile, they, with the Blessed Sacrament, and with a little bell and singing, approached at the east end of our Ladie's Chappel, at which time a Boy, with a thing in his hand, pointed to it, signifying a Prophet, as I think, sang, standing upon the Tyrret that is on the said Mr. Clopton's Ile doore, Ecce Rex tuus, venit, &c.; and then all did kneel down, and then, rising up, went and met the Sacrament, and so then, went singing together, into the Church, and coming near the Porch, a Boy, or one of the Clerks, did cast over among the Boys flowers, and singing cakes, &c.

On Corpus Christi day, they went likewise with the blessed Sacra
ment, in Procession about the Church green, in copes; and I think also, they went in Procession, on St. Mark's day, about the said green, with handbells ringing before them, as they did about the bounds of the Town, in Rogation Week, on the Monday, one way, on the Tuesday, another way, and on the Wednesday, another, praying for rain or fair weather, as the time required, having a drinking and a dinner there, upon Munday, being fast day; and Tuesday, being a fish day, they had a breakfast with butter and cheese, &c. at the Parsonage, and a drinking at Mr. Clopton's by Kentwell, at his Manor of Lutons, near the pond in the Park, where there was a little Chappel, I think of St. Anne, for that was their longest perambulacion. Upon Wednesday, being fasting day, they had a drinking at Melford Hall. All the Quire dined there, three times in the year at the least, viz. St. Stephen's Day, Midlent Sunday, and I think, upon Easter Munday.

On Saint James's Day, Mass being sung then by note, and the Organs going in St. James's Chappel, which were brought into my House, with the Clock and Bell, that stood there, and the Organs which stood upon the Rood Loft, that was then a little from the Rood, which Chappel hath been maintained by my ancestors, and therefore I Will, that my heires, when time serve, shall repair, place there, and maintain, all these things again. There were also fair stooles, on either side, such as are in the Church, which were had away, by John King's means, who was Sir William Cordell's Baylif, about which Chappel, there was paled in, round about a convenient piece of the Green, for one to walk in.

Memorandum On Saint James's Even, there was a bonefire, and a tub of ale, and bread then given to the poor, and before my doore, there were made, three other bonefires, viz. on Midsummer Even, on the Even of St. Peter and Paul, when they had the like drinkings, and on St. Thomas's Even, on which, if it fell not on the fish day, they had some long pyes of mutton, and peasecods, set out upon boards, with the aforesaid quantity of bread, and ale; and in all these bonefires, some of the friends and more civil poor neighbours were called in, and sat at the board, with my Grandfather, who had, at the lighting of the bonefires, wax tapers, with balls of wax, yellow and green, set up, all the breadth of the Hall, lighted then, and burning there, before the image of St. John the Baptist; and after they were put out, a watch candle was lighted, and set in the midst of the said Hall, upon the pavement, burning all night.

This was transcribed by Mr. Jonathan Moor, by my order, out of certain papers written by, and belonging to Mr. Roger Martin, of Melford, who died circ. ann. 23d Eliz. 1580. These papers were showed to me, by Mr. Valentine Martin, and were part of the large MS. book, lately wasted. N. B. 12th April, 1692.

div.p: It is thought that the author of this reminiscence of pre-Reformation religious practices in Long Melford was Roger Martin, esq. (c 1526-1615), a member of a prominent family of clothiers in Long Melford, and an ardent opponent of the Reformation (Neale, Views, p 70). If Neale is right, Martin would have been seventeen years old at the onset of the Reformation, and served as a Long Melford churchwarden during the reign of Mary (1554-8), during the brief restoration of Catholic practices. His reminiscence would, therefore, likely have been written by Martin between 1554 and his death in 1615.

Neale's book is a compendium of descriptions of architecturally interesting churches and church furniture. Each description of a church is paged separately. The page numbers here (13-14) are those within the description of Long Melford's church of the Holy Trinity. On the Martins (or Martyns) and other important clothier families in Long Melford, see Gail McMurry Gibson, in 'Long Melford Church, Suffolk: Some Suggestions for the Study of Visual Artifacts and Medieval Drama,' Research Opportunities in Renaissance Drama 21 (1978), 103-15.
